{"influenza a/h5n1num_articles": "496", "influenza a/h5n1": [{"archive_id": "8232248", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (41): Sweden (SN), Niger (NI) poultry, HPAI H5N5, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8232248", "date": "2021-01-15 10:04:41", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (10): CAMBODIA (BATTAMBANG) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Jan 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2021; 34(02) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37605\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 14 Jan 2021 from Mr. Phannara Tan, Director General, General Directorate of Animal Health and Production, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 5 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 11 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 26 Apr 2019\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Preak Tachraeng, Preak Norean, Aek Phnom, Battambang [Batdambang]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 5 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: resolved (13 Jan 2021)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1990 / 1827 / 1827 / 163 / 0\nAffected population: Avian influenza affected poultry in backyard farms.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 91.81 / 91.81 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: On [9 Jan 2021], a provincial veterinarian received information about sick-dead poultry from a farmer in the village. He then went there to check and collect samples from the affected poultry and sent them to the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute, which confirmed positive to H5N1 on 11 Jan [2021].\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\nInstitute Pasteur, Cambodia (regional reference laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cambodia has been experiencing HPAI H5N1 since 2005. This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI associated with serotype H5N1 since 2018 (see https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=27724). No cases in humans have been recorded in Cambodia since 2014. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nBattambang Province, Cambodia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12508]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nAvian POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Jan 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2021; 34(02) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37605\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 14 Jan 2021 from Mr. Phannara Tan, Director General, General Directorate of Animal Health and Production, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 5 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 11 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 26 Apr 2019\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Preak Tachraeng, Preak Norean, Aek Phnom, Battambang [Batdambang]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 5 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: resolved (13 Jan 2021)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1990 / 1827 / 1827 / 163 / 0\nAffected population: Avian influenza affected poultry in backyard farms.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 91.81 / 91.81 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: On [9 Jan 2021], a provincial veterinarian received information about sick-dead poultry from a farmer in the village. He then went there to check and collect samples from the affected poultry and sent them to the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute, which confirmed positive to H5N1 on 11 Jan [2021].\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\nInstitute Pasteur, Cambodia (regional reference laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cambodia has been experiencing HPAI H5N1 since 2005. This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI associated with serotype H5N1 since 2018 (see https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=27724). No cases in humans have been recorded in Cambodia since 2014. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nBattambang Province, Cambodia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12508]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nAvian (BATTAMBANG) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Jan 2021\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2021; 34(02) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37605\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 14 Jan 2021 from Mr. Phannara Tan, Director General, General Directorate of Animal Health and Production, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 5 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 11 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 26 Apr 2019\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Preak Tachraeng, Preak Norean, Aek Phnom, Battambang [Batdambang]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 5 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: resolved (13 Jan 2021)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1990 / 1827 / 1827 / 163 / 0\nAffected population: Avian influenza affected poultry in backyard farms.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 91.81 / 91.81 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: On [9 Jan 2021], a provincial veterinarian received information about sick-dead poultry from a farmer in the village. He then went there to check and collect samples from the affected poultry and sent them to the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute, which confirmed positive to H5N1 on 11 Jan [2021].\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\nInstitute Pasteur, Cambodia (regional reference laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cambodia has been experiencing HPAI H5N1 since 2005. This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI associated with serotype H5N1 since 2018 (see https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=27724). No cases in humans have been recorded in Cambodia since 2014. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nBattambang Province, Cambodia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12508]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nAvian 20200810.7663163\nAvian influenza (43): Viet Nam (CN, DT, VL) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20200511.7323954\nAvian influenza (26): Viet Nam (TV) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20200219.7005518\n2019\n----\nAvian influenza (31): Cambodia (TA) poultry, HPAI H5N6, OIE 20190419.6430282\n2018\n----\nAvian influenza (94): Cambodia (KC) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE H5N1, OIE 20170131.4806507\nAvian influenza (34): Cambodia (Thom) poultry, LPAI H7N3, 1st report, OIE 20170127.4797820\n2016\n----\nAvian influenza (44): Cambodia (KP) poultry, HPAI H5N1 Cambodia (BA, SI) H5N1, poultry, OIE 20151116.3796387\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza, human (85): Cambodia (KP, KN, KG), H5N1 20140317.2338293\nAvian influenza, human (82): Cambodia, H5N1 20140308.2320936\nAvian influenza (32): Cambodia (KS, KN) H5N1, spread, poultry, OIE 20140228.2306401\nAvian influenza, human (76): Cambodia, H5N1 20140219.2287700\nAvian influenza (20): Cambodia (KC) Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, Cambodia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 5 Jan 2021\nDate of confirmation of the event: 11 Jan 2021\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 26 Apr 2019\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Preak Tachraeng, Preak Norean, Aek Phnom, Battambang [Batdambang]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 5 Jan 2021\nOutbreak status: resolved (13 Jan 2021)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 1990 / 1827 / 1827 / 163 / 0\nAffected population: Avian influenza affected poultry in backyard farms.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 91.81 / 91.81 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: On [9 Jan 2021], a provincial veterinarian received information about sick-dead poultry from a farmer in the village. He then went there to check and collect samples from the affected poultry and sent them to the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute, which confirmed positive to H5N1 on 11 Jan [2021].\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\nInstitute Pasteur, Cambodia (regional reference laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cambodia has been experiencing HPAI H5N1 since 2005. This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI associated with serotype H5N1 since 2018 (see https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=27724). No cases in humans have been recorded in Cambodia since 2014. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nBattambang Province, Cambodia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12508]\nSee Also\n2020\n----\nAvian (TH) poultry, HPAI H5N1, 1st rep, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8085504", "date": "2020-12-02 19:58:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, SPREAD, OVERVIEW\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Dec 2020\nSource: Animal & Plant Health Agency (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]\nhttps://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdf\n\n\nSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.\n\nThis situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).\n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.\n\nIraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. Detections in poultry followed with initial H5N8 cases in the Netherlands and the UK submitted to national reference laboratories on 28 Oct and 2 Nov 2020, respectively. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020].\n\nNearly all detections of HPAI H5 in wild birds have been found close to coastlines with significant clusters of cases in the Jutland peninsula and within the extensive Wadden Sea -- a continuous intertidal wetland stretching from Denmark to the Netherlands and where many of the Danish, German and Dutch cases occurred. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEurope: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (100): Europe, wild bird, H5N8, H5N5, spread, OIE 20201201.7983360\nAvian influenza (99): "2020-01-02 00:00:00", "2020-06-04 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-05-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1991-03-15 "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (114): UK, Germany, poultry, wild bird, HPAI H5N1, H5N3, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8039475", "date": "2020-12-02 19:58:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, SPREAD, OVERVIEW\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Dec 2020\nSource: Animal & Plant Health Agency (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]\nhttps://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdf\n\n\nSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.\n\nThis situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).\n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.\n\nIraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. Detections in poultry followed with initial H5N8 cases in the Netherlands and the UK submitted to national reference laboratories on 28 Oct and 2 Nov 2020, respectively. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020].\n\nNearly all detections of HPAI H5 in wild birds have been found close to coastlines with significant clusters of cases in the Jutland peninsula and within the extensive Wadden Sea -- a continuous intertidal wetland stretching from Denmark to the Netherlands and where many of the Danish, German and Dutch cases occurred. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEurope: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (100): Europe, wild bird, H5N8, H5N5, spread, OIE 20201201.7983360\nAvian influenza (99): Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (102): Europe, wild bird, poultry, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7988670", "date": "2020-12-02 19:58:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, SPREAD, OVERVIEW\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Dec 2020\nSource: Animal & Plant Health Agency (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]\nhttps://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdf\n\n\nSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.\n\nThis situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).\n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.\n\nIraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. Detections in poultry followed with initial H5N8 cases in the Netherlands and the UK submitted to national reference laboratories on 28 Oct and 2 Nov 2020, respectively. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020].\n\nNearly all detections of HPAI H5 in wild birds have been found close to coastlines with significant clusters of cases in the Jutland peninsula and within the extensive Wadden Sea -- a continuous intertidal wetland stretching from Denmark to the Netherlands and where many of the Danish, German and Dutch cases occurred. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEurope: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (100): Europe, wild bird, H5N8, H5N5, spread, OIE 20201201.7983360\nAvian influenza (99): We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (06): Laos (SL) H5N1, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7939962", "date": "2020-12-02 19:58:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, SPREAD, OVERVIEW\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Dec 2020\nSource: Animal & Plant Health Agency (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]\nhttps://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdf\n\n\nSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.\n\nThis situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).\n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.\n\nIraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. Detections in poultry followed with initial H5N8 cases in the Netherlands and the UK submitted to national reference laboratories on 28 Oct and 2 Nov 2020, respectively. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020].\n\nNearly all detections of HPAI H5 in wild birds have been found close to coastlines with significant clusters of cases in the Jutland peninsula and within the extensive Wadden Sea -- a continuous intertidal wetland stretching from Denmark to the Netherlands and where many of the Danish, German and Dutch cases occurred. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEurope: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (100): Europe, wild bird, H5N8, H5N5, spread, OIE 20201201.7983360\nAvian influenza (99): 20201006.7840560\nAvian influenza (64): Russia, H5N8, Kazakhstan, H5, poultry, spread, OIE 20201006.7838872\nAvian influenza (52): Russia (CL) HPAI H5N8, poultry, OIE 20200806.7652834\nAvian influenza (46): Bulgaria (PD) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE 20200621.7489706\nAvian influenza (42): Hungary (BE) poultry, HPAI H5N8, spread, OIE 20200501.7289038\nAvian influenza (41): Hungary (BK, CS) poultry, HPAI H5N8, spread 20200428.7277841\nAvian influenza (38): Hungary (CS) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE 20200403.7176779\nAvian influenza (37): Germany (ST) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE 20200401.7168460\nAvian influenza (36): Hungary (BK) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE 20200327.7147622\nAvian influenza (35): Europe, poultry, wild, HPAI H5N8, LPAI H6N1 20200325.7139260\nAvian influenza (34): Germany (NI) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE 20200323.7130557\nAvian influenza (31): Germany (SN) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE 20200317.7102102\nAvian influenza (23): Germany (BW) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE 20200211.6978876\nAvian (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]\nhttps://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdf\n\n\nSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.\n\nThis situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).\n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.\n\nIraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (53): Viet Nam (TV) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7663163", "date": "2020-12-02 19:58:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, SPREAD, OVERVIEW\n*************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Dec 2020\nSource: Animal & Plant Health Agency (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]\nhttps://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdf\n\n\nSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.\n\nThis situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.\n\nThe 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAdam Brouwer\nAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza\nAPHA-Weybridge, UK\n<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>\n\n[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.\n\nThe following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:\n\nH5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).\n\nThere were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.\n\nIraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. Detections in poultry followed with initial H5N8 cases in the Netherlands and the UK submitted to national reference laboratories on 28 Oct and 2 Nov 2020, respectively. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020].\n\nNearly all detections of HPAI H5 in wild birds have been found close to coastlines with significant clusters of cases in the Jutland peninsula and within the extensive Wadden Sea -- a continuous intertidal wetland stretching from Denmark to the Netherlands and where many of the Danish, German and Dutch cases occurred. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.\n\n---\nThe report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEurope: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (100): Europe, wild bird, H5N8, H5N5, spread, OIE 20201201.7983360\nAvian influenza (99): INFLUENZA (18): DENMARK (NORTH JUTLAND) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Jan 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=33109\n\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 30 Jan 2020 from Dr Hanne Larsen, chief veterinary officer, Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, Ministry of Environment and Food, Glostrup, Denmark\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jan 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 29 Jan 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Jul 2019\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: low pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Saederup, Aalborg, West [North Jutland]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jan 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 48 000 / - / 0 / - / 0\n\nAffected population: On [29 Jan 2020], low pathogenic avian influenza H5 has been confirmed in a commercial poultry holding with organic laying hens. The layers were tested in accordance with the Danish surveillance programme for avian influenza in poultry. The holding consists of approximately 48 000 organic egg layers. The egg layers at the infected holding will be culled, and the carcasses will be disposed of by rendering.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / ** / 0 / ** / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established a restricted zone of 1 km [0.62 mi] around the holding and are implementing the necessary measures in accordance with Council Directive 2005/94/EC. There are no other commercial poultry holdings within the established restricted zone 1 km [0.62 mi] around the infected holding. There has been no trade of poultry from the holding to other EU countries or 3rd countries within the last 30 days.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoning, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: traceability; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institut (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\nBirds / virus sequencing / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"The outbreak is located in the town of Saederup in the municipality of Aalborg in the Northern part of Jutland.\" The latest news about avian influenza in Denmark can be found on the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration (DVFA) website at https://www.foedevarestyrelsen.dk/english/Animal/AnimalHealth/Avian_influenza/Pages/default.aspx (last update 30 Jan 2020). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNorth Jutland, Denmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16381]\nSee Also\n2019\n----\nAvian influenza (39): Denmark (SD) poultry, LPAI H5, OIE There has been no trade of poultry from the holding to other EU countries or 3rd countries within the last 30 days.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoning, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: traceability; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institut (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\nBirds / virus sequencing / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"The outbreak is located in the town of Saederup in the municipality of Aalborg in the Northern part of Jutland.\" The latest news about avian influenza "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7017760", "date": "2020-01-30 20:30:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): DENMARK (NORTH JUTLAND) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Jan 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=33109\n\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 30 Jan 2020 from Dr Hanne Larsen, chief veterinary officer, Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, Ministry of Environment and Food, Glostrup, Denmark\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jan 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 29 Jan 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Jul 2019\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: low pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Saederup, Aalborg, West [North Jutland]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jan 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 48 000 / - / 0 / - / 0\n\nAffected population: On [29 Jan 2020], low pathogenic avian influenza H5 has been confirmed in a commercial poultry holding with organic laying hens. The layers were tested in accordance with the Danish surveillance programme for avian influenza in poultry. The holding consists of approximately 48 000 organic egg layers. The egg layers at the infected holding will be culled, and the carcasses will be disposed of by rendering.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / ** / 0 / ** / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established a restricted zone of 1 km [0.62 mi] around the holding and are implementing the necessary measures in accordance with Council Directive 2005/94/EC. There are no other commercial poultry holdings within the established restricted zone 1 km [0.62 mi] around the infected holding. There has been no trade of poultry from the holding to other EU countries or 3rd countries within the last 30 days.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoning, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: traceability; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institut (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\nBirds / virus sequencing / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"The outbreak is located in the town of Saederup in the municipality of Aalborg in the Northern part of Jutland.\" The latest news about avian influenza in Denmark can be found on the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration (DVFA) website at https://www.foedevarestyrelsen.dk/english/Animal/AnimalHealth/Avian_influenza/Pages/default.aspx (last update 30 Jan 2020). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNorth Jutland, Denmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16381]\nSee Also\n2019\n----\nAvian influenza (39): Denmark (SD) poultry, LPAI H5, OIE "France"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6936337", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (18): Denmark (ND) poultry, LPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6936337", "date": "2020-01-30 20:30:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): DENMARK (NORTH JUTLAND) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Jan 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=33109\n\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 30 Jan 2020 from Dr Hanne Larsen, chief veterinary officer, Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, Ministry of Environment and Food, Glostrup, Denmark\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jan 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 29 Jan 2020\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Jul 2019\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: low pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Saederup, Aalborg, West [North Jutland]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jan 2020\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 48 000 / - / 0 / - / 0\n\nAffected population: On [29 Jan 2020], low pathogenic avian influenza H5 has been confirmed in a commercial poultry holding with organic laying hens. The layers were tested in accordance with the Danish surveillance programme for avian influenza in poultry. The holding consists of approximately 48 000 organic egg layers. The egg layers at the infected holding will be culled, and the carcasses will be disposed of by rendering.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / ** / 0 / ** / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established a restricted zone of 1 km [0.62 mi] around the holding and are implementing the necessary measures in accordance with Council Directive 2005/94/EC. There are no other commercial poultry holdings within the established restricted zone 1 km [0.62 mi] around the infected holding. There has been no trade of poultry from the holding to other EU countries or 3rd countries within the last 30 days.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoning, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: traceability; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; disinfection\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institut (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\nBirds / virus sequencing / 29 Jan 2020 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"The outbreak is located in the town of Saederup in the municipality of Aalborg in the Northern part of Jutland.\" The latest news about avian influenza in Denmark can be found on the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration (DVFA) website at https://www.foedevarestyrelsen.dk/english/Animal/AnimalHealth/Avian_influenza/Pages/default.aspx (last update 30 Jan 2020). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nNorth Jutland, Denmark: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16381]\nSee Also\n2019\n----\nAvian influenza (39): Denmark (SD) poultry, LPAI H5, OIE "France"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6927574", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (17): India (OR) poultry, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6927574", "date": "2019-05-14 11:46:07", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR) H5N1, UPDATE\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 May 2019\nSource: The Kathmandu Post[edited]\nhttp://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2019-05-11/authorities-to-send-more-specimens-abroad-to-test-for-bird-flu-virus.html\n\n\nThe Epidemiology and Disease Control Division says it is preparing to send specimens collected from the people who came in close contact with the person who died after contracting the H5N1 (bird flu) virus on [29 Mar 2019].\n\nThe division, under the Department of Health Services, had formed a team of medical doctors and lab technicians to carry out an epidemiological investigation after the death of a 21-year-old from Kavrepalanchok district [Province Three] from the bird flu virus.\n\n\"We have collected specimens from doctors, nurses, close family members, relatives, and hospitals -- and also from homes,\" Dr Bibek Kumar Lal, director at the division, told the Post.\n\nThe name of the deceased has not been disclosed yet, but he was said to be residing in Bhaktapur [district, Province Three] in a rented room and worked as a driver.\n\nThe Health Ministry, however, announced only on [30 Apr 2019] that the man had died from H5N1. Throat swabs of the deceased had been sent to the World Health Organisation's Collaborating Centre for Influenza in Japan, which confirmed that he had contracted influenza A(H5N1), which caused his death.\n\nFollowing the confirmation of deadly virus responsible for the death, health experts from the WHO's headquarters and its regional office in New Delhi, India arrived in Kathmandu to assist Nepali health officials to carry out an epidemiological investigation.\n\nAccording to Lal, his office would send samples to the country recommended by the UN health agency. Earlier, WHO officials suggested that specimens be sent to the Collaborating Center for Influenza in Japan that confirmed the virus. Such labs are in several countries and the UN health body may recommend any one of them. \"We are working closely with them and will decide our next step accordingly,\" said Lal.\n\nThe division has secured all collected samples in the biosafety level-3 laboratory of the National Public Health Laboratory.\n\nHealth officials say it takes time to send samples to laboratories abroad, as manpower trained to handle the biohazard are required for that.\n\nAirlines do not easily carry such specimens and for that, protocols of international health regulations need to be followed, according to officials at the Health Ministry.\n\nMeanwhile, the ministry said it was still tracking some people, who came in contact with the deceased but are out of home for personal business.\n\nThe death of the 21-year-old from H5N1 virus, the 1st bird flu casualty in Nepal and 1st in the world since February 2017, has been a cause for concern. H5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic.\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to WHO guidance on regulations for the Transport of Infectious Substances 2015-2016. Annex 2 (https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/149288/WHO_HSE_GCR_2015.2_eng.pdf); and the available list for classification of infectious substances prior to shipment, highly pathogenic avian influenza 'Cultures only' are classified as category A shipments. These have more stringent shipping regulations and require certified shippers to package them and complete the relevant documentation.\n\nThe same classification does not apply to suspected samples/sample materials from patients that require testing for confirmation.\n\nThe report above highlights one of the key areas in outbreak response and preparedness, that is, availability of trained and/or certified shippers to prepare the shipments for international transport. Having mentioned that, use of national/WHO guidelines for safe transport of infectious materials must also be ensured during domestic or in-country transportation. -Mod.UBA\n\nMaps of Nepal: https://setopati.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/mapofnepal.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10454]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (07): Nepal (BK) H5N1, fatal 20190505.6453747\nAvian influenza, human (02): Nepal (KT) poultry 20190117.6261121\nAvian influenza, human (01): Nepal (KT), poultry susp, RFI 20190108.6245559\n2018\n----\nAvian influenza, human (24): China (GD, GX) H9N2 Such labs are in several countries and the UN health body may recommend any one of them. \"We are working closely with them and will decide our next step accordingly,\" said Lal.\n\nThe division has secured all collected samples in the biosafety level-3 laboratory of the National Public Health Laboratory.\n\nHealth officials say it takes time to send samples to laboratories abroad, as manpower trained to handle the biohazard are required for that.\n\nAirlines do not easily carry such specimens and for that, protocols of international health regulations need to be followed, according to officials at the Health Ministry.\n\nMeanwhile, the ministry said it was still tracking some people, who came in contact with the deceased but are out of home for personal business.\n\nThe death of the 21-year-old from H5N1 virus, the 1st bird flu casualty in Nepal and 1st in the world since February 2017, has been a cause for concern. H5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic.\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to WHO guidance on regulations for the Transport of Infectious Substances 2015-2016. Annex 2 (https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/149288/WHO_HSE_GCR_2015.2_eng.pdf); and the available list for classification of infectious substances prior to shipment, highly pathogenic avian influenza 'Cultures only' are classified as category A shipments. "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "6512992", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (37): Bangladesh, poultry, HPAI H5N1, new variant", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6512992", "date": "2019-05-14 11:46:07", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR) H5N1, UPDATE\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 May 2019\nSource: The Kathmandu Post[edited]\nhttp://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2019-05-11/authorities-to-send-more-specimens-abroad-to-test-for-bird-flu-virus.html\n\n\nThe Epidemiology and Disease Control Division says it is preparing to send specimens collected from the people who came in close contact with the person who died after contracting the H5N1 (bird flu) virus on [29 Mar 2019].\n\nThe division, under the Department of Health Services, had formed a team of medical doctors and lab technicians to carry out an epidemiological investigation after the death of a 21-year-old from Kavrepalanchok district [Province Three] from the bird flu virus.\n\n\"We have collected specimens from doctors, nurses, close family members, relatives, and hospitals -- and also from homes,\" Dr Bibek Kumar Lal, director at the division, told the Post.\n\nThe name of the deceased has not been disclosed yet, but he was said to be residing in Bhaktapur [district, Province Three] in a rented room and worked as a driver.\n\nThe Health Ministry, however, announced only on [30 Apr 2019] that the man had died from H5N1. Throat swabs of the deceased had been sent to the World Health Organisation's Collaborating Centre for Influenza in Japan, which confirmed that he had contracted influenza A(H5N1), which caused his death.\n\nFollowing the confirmation of deadly virus responsible for the death, health experts from the WHO's headquarters and its regional office in New Delhi, India arrived in Kathmandu to assist Nepali health officials to carry out an epidemiological investigation.\n\nAccording to Lal, his office would send samples to the country recommended by the UN health agency. Earlier, WHO officials suggested that specimens be sent to the Collaborating Center for Influenza in Japan that confirmed the virus. Such labs are in several countries and the UN health body may recommend any one of them. \"We are working closely with them and will decide our next step accordingly,\" said Lal.\n\nThe division has secured all collected samples in the biosafety level-3 laboratory of the National Public Health Laboratory.\n\nHealth officials say it takes time to send samples to laboratories abroad, as manpower trained to handle the biohazard are required for that.\n\nAirlines do not easily carry such specimens and for that, protocols of international health regulations need to be followed, according to officials at the Health Ministry.\n\nMeanwhile, the ministry said it was still tracking some people, who came in contact with the deceased but are out of home for personal business.\n\nThe death of the 21-year-old from H5N1 virus, the 1st bird flu casualty in Nepal and 1st in the world since February 2017, has been a cause for concern. H5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic.\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to WHO guidance on regulations for the Transport of Infectious Substances 2015-2016. Annex 2 (https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/149288/WHO_HSE_GCR_2015.2_eng.pdf); and the available list for classification of infectious substances prior to shipment, highly pathogenic avian influenza 'Cultures only' are classified as category A shipments. These have more stringent shipping regulations and require certified shippers to package them and complete the relevant documentation.\n\nThe same classification does not apply to suspected samples/sample materials from patients that require testing for confirmation.\n\nThe report above highlights one of the key areas in outbreak response and preparedness, that is, availability of trained and/or certified shippers to prepare the shipments for international transport. Having mentioned that, use of national/WHO guidelines for safe transport of infectious materials must also be ensured during domestic or in-country transportation. -Mod.UBA\n\nMaps of Nepal: https://setopati.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/mapofnepal.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10454]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (07): Nepal (BK) H5N1, fatal 20190505.6453747\nAvian influenza, human (02): Nepal (KT) poultry 20190117.6261121\nAvian influenza, human (01): Nepal (KT), poultry susp, RFI 20190108.6245559\n2018\n----\nAvian influenza, human (24): China (GD, GX) H9N2 20181226.6223398\nAvian influenza, human (13): China (GD) H9N2 20180801.5940642\nAvian influenza (118): India (BR) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20181228.6226636\nAvian influenza (77): Nepal (TH) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20180530.5828169\nAvian influenza (75): Nepal (Narayani) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20180519.5805891.\n2017\n----\nAvian influenza, human (66): Philippines, H5 20170818.5254521\nAvian influenza, human (33): Indonesia (JR) H5 susp, RFI 20170315.4898106\nAvian influenza, human (11): Uganda, H5 susp, NOT 20170124.4787380\nAvian influenza, human (09): Uganda, H5 susp, RFI 20170122.4779120\n2015\n----\nAvian influenza, human (118): CDC H5 virus risk assessment 20150731.3548675\nAvian influenza, human (27): WHO update H5 & H7N9, China (GD) H7N9 "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR) H5N1, UPDATE\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 May 2019\nSource: The Kathmandu Post[edited]\nhttp://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2019-05-11/authorities-to-send-more-specimens-abroad-to-test-for-bird-flu-virus.html\n\n\nThe Epidemiology and Disease Control Division says it is preparing to send specimens collected from the people who came in close contact with the person who died after contracting the H5N1 (bird flu) virus on [29 Mar 2019].\n\nThe division, under the Department of Health Services, had formed a team of medical doctors and lab technicians to carry out an epidemiological investigation after the death of a 21-year-old from Kavrepalanchok district [Province Three] from the bird flu virus.\n\n\"We have collected specimens from doctors, nurses, close family members, relatives, and hospitals -- and also from homes,\" Dr Bibek Kumar Lal, director at the division, told the Post.\n\nThe name of the deceased has not been disclosed yet, but he was said to be residing in Bhaktapur [district, Province Three] in a rented room and worked as a driver.\n\nThe Health Ministry, however, announced only on [30 Apr 2019] that the man had died from H5N1. Throat swabs of the deceased had been sent to the World Health Organisation's Collaborating Centre for Influenza in Japan, which confirmed that he had contracted influenza A(H5N1), which caused his death.\n\nFollowing the confirmation of deadly virus responsible for the death, health experts from the WHO's headquarters and its regional office in New Delhi, India arrived in Kathmandu to assist Nepali health officials to carry out an epidemiological investigation.\n\nAccording to Lal, his office would send samples to the country recommended by the UN health agency. Earlier, WHO officials suggested that specimens be sent to the Collaborating Center for Influenza in Japan that confirmed the virus. Such labs are in several countries and the UN health body may recommend any one of them. \"We are working closely with them and will decide our next step accordingly,\" said Lal.\n\nThe division has secured all collected samples in the biosafety level-3 laboratory of the National Public Health Laboratory.\n\nHealth officials say it takes time to send samples to laboratories abroad, as manpower trained to handle the biohazard are required for that.\n\nAirlines do not easily carry such specimens and for that, protocols of international health regulations need to be followed, according to officials at the Health Ministry.\n\nMeanwhile, the ministry said it was still tracking some people, who came in contact with the deceased but are out of home for personal business.\n\nThe death of the 21-year-old from H5N1 virus, the 1st bird flu casualty in Nepal and 1st in the world since February 2017, has been a cause for concern. H5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic.\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to WHO guidance on regulations for the Transport of Infectious Substances 2015-2016. Annex 2 (https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/149288/WHO_HSE_GCR_2015.2_eng.pdf); and the available list for classification of infectious substances prior to shipment, highly pathogenic avian influenza 'Cultures only' are classified as category A shipments. These have more stringent shipping regulations and require certified shippers to package them and complete the relevant documentation.\n\nThe same classification does not apply to suspected samples/sample materials from patients that require testing for confirmation.\n\nThe report above highlights one of the key areas in outbreak response and preparedness, that is, availability of trained and/or certified shippers to prepare the shipments for international transport. Having mentioned that, use of national/WHO guidelines for safe transport of infectious materials must also be ensured during domestic or in-country transportation. -Mod.UBA\n\nMaps of Nepal:
