Annex 2 (https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/149288/WHO_HSE_GCR_2015.2_eng.pdf); and the available list for classification of infectious substances prior to shipment, highly pathogenic avian influenza 'Cultures only' are classified as category A shipments. These have more stringent shipping regulations and require certified shippers to package them and complete the relevant documentation.\n\nThe same classification does not apply to suspected samples/sample materials from patients that require testing for confirmation.\n\nThe report above highlights one of the key areas in outbreak response and preparedness, that is, availability of trained and/or certified shippers to prepare the shipments for international transport. Having mentioned that, use of national/WHO guidelines for safe transport of infectious materials must also be ensured during domestic or in-country transportation. -Mod.UBA\n\nMaps of Nepal: https://setopati.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/mapofnepal.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10454]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (07): Nepal (BK) H5N1, fatal 20190505.6453747\nAvian "6420700", "headline": "PRO> Avian influenza (29): Bhutan (CK) poultry, HPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6420700", "date": "2019-05-14 11:46:07", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR) H5N1, UPDATE\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 May 2019\nSource: The Kathmandu Post[edited]\nhttp://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2019-05-11/authorities-to-send-more-specimens-abroad-to-test-for-bird-flu-virus.html\n\n\nThe Epidemiology and Disease Control Division says it is preparing to send specimens collected from the people who came in close contact with the person who died after contracting the H5N1 (bird flu) virus on [29 Mar 2019].\n\nThe division, under the Department of Health Services, had formed a team of medical doctors and lab technicians to carry out an epidemiological investigation after the death of a 21-year-old from Kavrepalanchok district [Province Three] from the bird flu virus.\n\n\"We have collected specimens from doctors, nurses, close family members, relatives, and hospitals -- and also from homes,\" Dr Bibek Kumar Lal, director at the division, told the Post.\n\nThe name of the deceased has not been disclosed yet, but he was said to be residing in Bhaktapur [district, Province Three] in a rented room and worked as a driver.\n\nThe Health Ministry, however, announced only on [30 Apr 2019] that the man had died from H5N1. Throat swabs of the deceased had been sent to the World Health Organisation's Collaborating Centre for Influenza in Japan, which confirmed that he had contracted influenza A(H5N1), which caused his death.\n\nFollowing the confirmation of deadly virus responsible for the death, health experts from the WHO's headquarters and its regional office in New Delhi, India arrived in Kathmandu to assist Nepali health officials to carry out an epidemiological investigation.\n\nAccording to Lal, his office would send samples to the country recommended by the UN health agency. Earlier, WHO officials suggested that specimens be sent to the Collaborating Center for Influenza in Japan that confirmed the virus. Such labs are in several countries and the UN health body may recommend any one of them. \"We are working closely with them and will decide our next step accordingly,\" said Lal.\n\nThe division has secured all collected samples in the biosafety level-3 laboratory of the National Public Health Laboratory.\n\nHealth officials say it takes time to send samples to laboratories abroad, as manpower trained to handle the biohazard are required for that.\n\nAirlines do not easily carry such specimens and for that, protocols of international health regulations need to be followed, according to officials at the Health Ministry.\n\nMeanwhile, the ministry said it was still tracking some people, who came in contact with the deceased but are out of home for personal business.\n\nThe death of the 21-year-old from H5N1 virus, the 1st bird flu casualty in Nepal and 1st in the world since February 2017, has been a cause for concern. H5N1 is a lethal bird flu virus strain that is highly pathogenic.\n\n[Byline: Arjun Poudel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[According to WHO guidance on regulations for the Transport of Infectious Substances 2015-2016. Annex 2 (https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/149288/WHO_HSE_GCR_2015.2_eng.pdf); and the available list for classification of infectious substances prior to shipment, highly pathogenic avian influenza 'Cultures only' are classified as category A shipments. These have more stringent shipping regulations and require certified shippers to package them and complete the relevant documentation.\n\nThe same classification does not apply to suspected samples/sample materials from patients that require testing for confirmation.\n\nThe report above highlights one of the key areas in outbreak response and preparedness, that is, availability of trained and/or certified shippers to prepare the shipments for international transport. Having mentioned that, use of national/WHO guidelines for safe transport of infectious materials must also be ensured during domestic or in-country transportation. -Mod.UBA\n\nMaps of Nepal: https://setopati.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/mapofnepal.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10454]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (07): Nepal (BK) H5N1, fatal 20190505.6453747\nAvian notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Dec 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 21 Dec 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 5 Jun 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: Mubarakchak, Jamalpur, Munger, Bihar\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Nov 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 15 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 3 / 3 / - / -\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 4\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced HPAI outbreaks due to H5N1 virus infection in domestic poultry almost every year since the 1st report in 2006. So far, around 150 outbreaks in poultry have been reported, and 4 genetic clades of the virus have been identified. In 2016 and 2017, several cases of HPAI H5N1 were reported in poultry farms, crows and Guinea fowl. Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 outbreaks were reported in India. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nOdisha, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56741\nBihar, India: Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced HPAI outbreaks due to H5N1 virus infection in domestic poultry almost every year since the 1st report in 2006. So far, around 150 outbreaks in poultry have been reported, and 4 genetic clades of the virus have been identified. In 2016 and 2017, several cases of HPAI H5N1 were reported in poultry farms, crows and Guinea fowl. Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 outbreaks were reported in India. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nOdisha, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56741\nBihar, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46246]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nAvian influenza (118): India (BR) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20181228.6226636\nAvian influenza (116): India (OR) poultry, wild bird, HPAI wild birds), India\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 7 Jan 2019 from Mr. Tarun Shridhar, secretary, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Dec 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 21 Dec 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 5 Jun 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: Mubarakchak, Jamalpur, Munger, Bihar\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Nov 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 15 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 40 / 40 / - / -\n\nOutbreak 2: Patna (Sanjay Gandhi Zoological Park), Patna, Patna, Bihar\nDate of start of the outbreak: 16 Dec 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 16 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: zoo\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nIndian Peafowl: _Pavo cristatus_ (Phasianidae)/ - / 6 / 6 / - / -\n\nOutbreak 3: Muthagadia, Nayagarh, Nayagarh, Orissa\nDate of start of the outbreak: 16 Dec 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 16 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 3 / 3 / - / applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 3 / 3 / - / -\n\nSummary of Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\nIndian Peafowl: _Pavo cristatus_ (Phasianidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / House crow / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 21 Dec 2018 / positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / House crow / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Dec 2018 / positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / Indian Peafowl / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Dec 2018 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced HPAI outbreaks due to H5N1 virus infection in domestic poultry almost every year since the 1st report in 2006. So far, around 150 outbreaks in poultry have been reported, and 4 genetic clades of the virus have been identified. In 2016 and 2017, several cases of HPAI H5N1 were reported in poultry farms, crows and Guinea fowl. Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 outbreaks were reported in India. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nOdisha, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56741\nBihar, India: wild birds), India\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 7 Jan 2019 from Mr. Tarun Shridhar, secretary, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Dec 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 21 Dec 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 5 Jun 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: Mubarakchak, Jamalpur, Munger, Bihar\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Nov 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 15 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 40 / 40 / - / -\n\nOutbreak 2: Patna (Sanjay Gandhi Zoological Park), Patna, Patna, Bihar\nDate of start of the outbreak: 16 Dec 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 16 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: zoo\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nIndian Peafowl: _Pavo cristatus_ (Phasianidae)/ - / 6 / 6 / - / -\n\nOutbreak 3: Muthagadia, Nayagarh, Nayagarh, Orissa\nDate of start of the outbreak: 16 Dec 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 16 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 3 / 3 / - / -\n\nOutbreak 4: Cuttack municipality, Ward no. 44, Cuttack, Cuttack, Orissa\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Dec 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 18 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 3 / 3 / - / -\n\nSummary of -\nIndian Peafowl: _Pavo cristatus_ (Phasianidae)/ - / 6 / 6 / - / -\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\nIndian Peafowl: _Pavo cristatus_ (Phasianidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / House crow / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 21 Dec 2018 / positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / House crow / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Dec 2018 / positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / Indian Peafowl / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Dec 2018 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced HPAI outbreaks due to H5N1 virus infection in domestic poultry almost every year since the 1st report in 2006. So far, around 150 outbreaks in poultry have been reported, and 4 genetic clades of the virus have been identified. In 2016 and 2017, several cases of HPAI H5N1 were reported in poultry farms, crows and Guinea fowl. Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 outbreaks were reported in India. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nOdisha, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56741\nBihar, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46246]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nAvian influenza (118): India (BR) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20181228.6226636\nAvian influenza (116): India (OR) poultry, wild bird, HPAI wild birds), India\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nInformation received on [and dated] 7 Jan 2019 from Mr. Tarun Shridhar, secretary, Department of Animal Husbandry, Dairying and Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Dec 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 21 Dec 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 5 Jun 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: Mubarakchak, Jamalpur, Munger, Bihar\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Nov 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 15 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 40 / 40 / - / -\n\nOutbreak 2: Patna (Sanjay Gandhi Zoological Park), Patna, Patna, Bihar\nDate of start of the outbreak: 16 Dec 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 16 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: zoo\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nIndian Peafowl: _Pavo cristatus_ (Phasianidae)/ - / 6 / 6 / - / -\n\nOutbreak 3: Muthagadia, Nayagarh, Nayagarh, Orissa\nDate of start of the outbreak: 16 Dec 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved 16 Dec 2018\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 3 / 3 / - / applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 3 / 3 / - / -\n\nSummary of Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nHouse Crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\nIndian Peafowl: _Pavo cristatus_ (Phasianidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / House crow / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Dec 2018 / positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases, Bhopal (OIE reference laboratory) / Indian Peafowl / real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 24 Dec 2018 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[India has experienced HPAI outbreaks due to H5N1 virus infection in domestic poultry almost every year since the 1st report in 2006. So far, around 150 outbreaks in poultry have been reported, and 4 genetic clades of the virus have been identified. In 2016 and 2017, several cases of HPAI H5N1 were reported in poultry farms, crows and Guinea fowl. Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 outbreaks were reported in India. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nOdisha, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56741\nBihar, India: backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6226636", "date": "2018-08-07 17:09:58", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (89): MALAYSIA (SABAH) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(32) [edited] http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=27462\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Malaysia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 6 Aug 2018 from Dr Quaza Nizamuddin Bin Hassan Nizam, deputy director general (veterinary health), Department of Veterinary Services, Division of Livestock Resources & Technology Development, Putrajaya, Malaysia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Jul 2018\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (Sabah_HPAI_2018/01): Kampung Kauluan, Tamparuli, Tuaran, Sabah\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 28 000 / 3000 / 3000 / 25 000 / 0\nAffected population: the affected population is flocks of layer chickens in one farm.\n\nOutbreak statistics [apparent rates, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 10.7 / 10.7 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: the report of high mortality of layer chickens was received by Sabah Department of Veterinary Services on [27 Jul 2018]. Investigation and sampling were carried out on the same day. Movement of animals and animal products was banned on the same day. Upon confirmation of the laboratory of the samples positive for HPAI (H5N1), stamping out of the flock was carried out and the carcasses were officially disposed of. This is the 1st occurrence of HPAI in Sabah state. Sabah is a state of Malaysia located at East Malaysia, on the island of Borneo. Sabah and Peninsular Malaysia are separated by the South China Sea.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nSabah Veterinary Laboratory (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Jul 2018 / Positive\nVeterinary Research Institute Ipoh Perak (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / inoculation test / 5 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2017, Malaysia reported 36 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in the state of Kelantan (Peninsular Malaysia). The event was resolved on 1 Apr 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=23159.\n\n\"The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa, and following ongoing evolution is now grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n\"In late 2005, the Asian lineage H5N1 was introduced to Europe and several European countries experienced outbreaks in poultry and wild birds in the subsequent years. The last outbreak of H5N1 occurred in France in 2015, but that virus was not related to the H5N1 viruses circulating in other parts of the world and appears to have evolved from a low pathogenic avian influenza virus circulating in Europe.\n\n\"In 2015, America and Canada reported novel reassortant H5N1 outbreaks with Eurasian and North American origin in poultry. This virus was also different from the H5N1 strain circulating in Asia.\n\n\"As of June 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.\" (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/OIE_SituationReport_AI_June2018.pdf). - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Malaysia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Malaysian.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64429.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (82): China (QH) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6226196", "date": "2018-08-07 17:09:58", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (89): MALAYSIA (SABAH) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(32) [edited] http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=27462\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Malaysia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 6 Aug 2018 from Dr Quaza Nizamuddin Bin Hassan Nizam, deputy director general (veterinary health), Department of Veterinary Services, Division of Livestock Resources & Technology Development, Putrajaya, Malaysia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Jul 2018\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (Sabah_HPAI_2018/01): Kampung Kauluan, Tamparuli, Tuaran, Sabah\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 28 000 / 3000 / 3000 / 25 000 / 0\nAffected population: the affected population is flocks of layer chickens in one farm.\n\nOutbreak statistics [apparent rates, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 10.7 / 10.7 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: the report of high mortality of layer chickens was received by Sabah Department of Veterinary Services on [27 Jul 2018]. Investigation and sampling were carried out on the same day. Movement of animals and animal products was banned on the same day. Upon confirmation of the laboratory of the samples positive for HPAI (H5N1), stamping out of the flock was carried out and the carcasses were officially disposed of. This is the 1st occurrence of HPAI in Sabah state. Sabah is a state of Malaysia located at East Malaysia, on the island of Borneo. Sabah and Peninsular Malaysia are separated by the South China Sea.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nSabah Veterinary Laboratory (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Jul 2018 / Positive\nVeterinary Research Institute Ipoh Perak (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / inoculation test / 5 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2017, Malaysia reported 36 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in the state of Kelantan (Peninsular Malaysia). The event was resolved on 1 Apr 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=23159.\n\n\"The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa, and following ongoing evolution is now grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n\"In late 2005, the Asian lineage H5N1 was introduced to Europe and several European countries experienced outbreaks in poultry and wild birds in the subsequent years. The last outbreak of H5N1 occurred in France in 2015, but that virus was not related to the H5N1 viruses circulating in other parts of the world and appears to have evolved from a low pathogenic avian influenza virus circulating in Europe.\n\n\"In 2015, America and Canada reported novel reassortant H5N1 outbreaks with Eurasian and North American origin in poultry. This virus was also different from the H5N1 strain circulating in Asia.\n\n\"As of June 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.\" Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2017, Malaysia reported 36 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in the state of Kelantan (Peninsular Malaysia). The event was resolved on 1 Apr 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=23159.\n\n\"The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa, and following ongoing evolution is now grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n\"In late 2005, the Asian lineage H5N1 was introduced to Europe and several European countries experienced outbreaks in poultry and wild birds in the subsequent years. The last outbreak of H5N1 occurred in France in 2015, but that virus was not related to the H5N1 viruses circulating in other parts of the world and appears to have evolved from a low pathogenic avian influenza virus circulating in Europe.\n\n\"In 2015, America and Canada reported novel reassortant H5N1 outbreaks with Eurasian and North American origin in poultry. This virus was also different from the H5N1 strain circulating in Asia.\n\n\"As of June 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.\" (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/OIE_SituationReport_AI_June2018.pdf). - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Malaysia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Malaysian.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64429.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (82): China (QH) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6210437", "date": "2018-08-07 17:09:58", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (89): MALAYSIA (SABAH) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(32) [edited] http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=27462\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Malaysia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 6 Aug 2018 from Dr Quaza Nizamuddin Bin Hassan Nizam, deputy director general (veterinary health), Department of Veterinary Services, Division of Livestock Resources & Technology Development, Putrajaya, Malaysia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Jul 2018\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (Sabah_HPAI_2018/01): Kampung Kauluan, Tamparuli, Tuaran, Sabah\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 28 000 / 3000 / 3000 / 25 000 / 0\nAffected population: the affected population is flocks of layer chickens in one farm.\n\nOutbreak statistics [apparent rates, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 10.7 / 10.7 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: the report of high mortality of layer chickens was received by Sabah Department of Veterinary Services on [27 Jul 2018]. Investigation and sampling were carried out on the same day. Movement of animals and animal products was banned on the same day. Upon confirmation of the laboratory of the samples positive for HPAI (H5N1), stamping out of the flock was carried out and the carcasses were officially disposed of. This is the 1st occurrence of HPAI in Sabah state. Sabah is a state of Malaysia located at East Malaysia, on the island of Borneo. Sabah and Peninsular Malaysia are separated by the South China Sea.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nSabah Veterinary Laboratory (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Jul 2018 / Positive\nVeterinary Research Institute Ipoh Perak (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / inoculation test / 5 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2017, Malaysia reported 36 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in the state of Kelantan (Peninsular Malaysia). The event was resolved on 1 Apr 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=23159.\n\n\"The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa, and following ongoing evolution is now grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n\"In late 2005, the Asian lineage H5N1 was introduced to Europe and several European countries experienced outbreaks in poultry and wild birds in the subsequent years. The last outbreak of H5N1 occurred in France in 2015, but that virus was not related to the H5N1 viruses circulating in other parts of the world and appears to have evolved from a low pathogenic avian influenza virus circulating in Europe.\n\n\"In 2015, America and Canada reported novel reassortant H5N1 outbreaks with Eurasian and North American origin in poultry. This virus was also different from the H5N1 strain circulating in Asia.\n\n\"As of June 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.\" All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.\" (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/OIE_SituationReport_AI_June2018.pdf). - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Malaysia: ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1989-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-08-06 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-08-05 00:00:00", "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6001626", "date": "2018-08-07 17:09:58", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (89): MALAYSIA (SABAH) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(32) [edited] http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=27462\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Malaysia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 6 Aug 2018 from Dr Quaza Nizamuddin Bin Hassan Nizam, deputy director general (veterinary health), Department of Veterinary Services, Division of Livestock Resources & Technology Development, Putrajaya, Malaysia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Jul 2018\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (Sabah_HPAI_2018/01): Kampung Kauluan, Tamparuli, Tuaran, Sabah\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 28 000 / 3000 / 3000 / 25 000 / 0\nAffected population: the affected population is flocks of layer chickens in one farm.\n\nOutbreak statistics [apparent rates, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 10.7 / 10.7 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: the report of high mortality of layer chickens was received by Sabah Department of Veterinary Services on [27 Jul 2018]. Investigation and sampling were carried out on the same day. Movement of animals and animal products was banned on the same day. Upon confirmation of the laboratory of the samples positive for HPAI (H5N1), stamping out of the flock was carried out and the carcasses were officially disposed of. This is the 1st occurrence of HPAI in Sabah state. Sabah is a state of Malaysia located at East Malaysia, on the island of Borneo. Sabah and Peninsular Malaysia are separated by the South China Sea.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nSabah Veterinary Laboratory (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Jul 2018 / Positive\nVeterinary Research Institute Ipoh Perak (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / inoculation test / 5 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2017, Malaysia reported 36 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in the state of Kelantan (Peninsular Malaysia). The event was resolved on 1 Apr 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=23159.\n\n\"The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa, and following ongoing evolution is now grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n\"In late 2005, the Asian lineage H5N1 was introduced to Europe and several European countries experienced outbreaks in poultry and wild birds in the subsequent years. The last outbreak of H5N1 occurred in France in 2015, but that virus was not related to the H5N1 viruses circulating in other parts of the world and appears to have evolved from a low pathogenic avian influenza virus circulating in Europe.\n\n\"In 2015, America and Canada reported novel reassortant H5N1 outbreaks with Eurasian and North American origin in poultry. This virus was also different from the H5N1 strain circulating in Asia.\n\n\"As of June 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.\" (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/OIE_SituationReport_AI_June2018.pdf). - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Malaysia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Malaysian.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64429.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (82): China (QH) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5951109", "date": "2018-08-07 17:09:58", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (89): MALAYSIA (SABAH) H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(32) [edited] http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=27462\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Malaysia\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 6 Aug 2018 from Dr Quaza Nizamuddin Bin Hassan Nizam, deputy director general (veterinary health), Department of Veterinary Services, Division of Livestock Resources & Technology Development, Putrajaya, Malaysia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Jul 2018\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1 Apr 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (Sabah_HPAI_2018/01): Kampung Kauluan, Tamparuli, Tuaran, Sabah\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBirds / 28 000 / 3000 / 3000 / 25 000 / 0\nAffected population: the affected population is flocks of layer chickens in one farm.\n\nOutbreak statistics [apparent rates, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 10.7 / 10.7 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: the report of high mortality of layer chickens was received by Sabah Department of Veterinary Services on [27 Jul 2018]. Investigation and sampling were carried out on the same day. Movement of animals and animal products was banned on the same day. Upon confirmation of the laboratory of the samples positive for HPAI (H5N1), stamping out of the flock was carried out and the carcasses were officially disposed of. This is the 1st occurrence of HPAI in Sabah state. Sabah is a state of Malaysia located at East Malaysia, on the island of Borneo. Sabah and Peninsular Malaysia are separated by the South China Sea.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, screening, quarantine, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nSabah Veterinary Laboratory (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Jul 2018 / Positive\nVeterinary Research Institute Ipoh Perak (regional reference laboratory) / Birds / inoculation test / 5 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In February 2017, Malaysia reported 36 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in the state of Kelantan (Peninsular Malaysia). The event was resolved on 1 Apr 2018. See event summary and updated map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=23159.\n\n\"The Asian lineage HPAI H5N1 virus first emerged in China in 1996 and spread to Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa, and following ongoing evolution is now grouped under different genetic clades. Currently the virus continues to be reported in Asia and Africa in both poultry and wild birds. The virus has become enzootic in Asia and Africa and continues to cause outbreaks in poultry and sporadic human infections.\n\n\"In late 2005, the Asian lineage H5N1 was introduced to Europe and several European countries experienced outbreaks in poultry and wild birds in the subsequent years. The last outbreak of H5N1 occurred in France in 2015, but that virus was not related to the H5N1 viruses circulating in other parts of the world and appears to have evolved from a low pathogenic avian influenza virus circulating in Europe.\n\n\"In 2015, America and Canada reported novel reassortant H5N1 outbreaks with Eurasian and North American origin in poultry. This virus was also different from the H5N1 strain circulating in Asia.\n\n\"As of June 2018, 860 human infections have been reported to WHO from 16 countries and territories. All cases of H5N1 infection in humans have been associated with close contact with infected live or dead birds, or H5N1-contaminated environments. Countries affected should focus on strengthening biosecurity measures to prevent introduction of disease into flocks and avoid contact between wild birds and poultry.\" (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/OIE_SituationReport_AI_June2018.pdf). - Mod.CRD\n\nMaps of Malaysia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Malaysian.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64429.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (82): China (QH) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE confirmation of the event: 12 Feb 2018\nReport date: 1 Mar 2018\nDate submitted to OIE: 1 Mar 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Paradeep [Paradip], Kujanga, Jagatsinghpur, Orissa [Odisha]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Feb 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _ Corvus splendens_(Corvidae) / - / 173 / 173 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / morbidity rate / mortality rate / case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nHouse Crow: _ Corvus splendens_(Corvidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Disease, Bhopal (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nHouse Crow / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 12 Feb 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Paradeep [Paradip], Kujanga, Jagatsinghpur, Orissa [Odisha]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Feb 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Disease, Bhopal (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nHouse Crow / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 12 Feb 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. including wild birds), India\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 1 Mar 2018 from Mr Devendra Chaudhry, secretary, Animal Husbandry, Dairying & Fisheries, Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare, New Delhi, India\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 11 Feb 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 12 Feb 2018\nReport date: 1 Mar 2018\nDate submitted to OIE: 1 Mar 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Paradeep [Paradip], Kujanga, Jagatsinghpur, Orissa [Odisha]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Feb 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse Crow: _ Corvus splendens_(Corvidae) / - / 173 / 173 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / morbidity rate / mortality rate / case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nHouse Crow: _ Corvus splendens_(Corvidae) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Institute of High Security Animal Disease, Bhopal (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nHouse Crow / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 12 Feb 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Currently there are 2 known HPAI subtypes circulating in India -- H5N1 and H5N8. Bali Province Health Office heightened influenza surveillance'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 20 Sep 2017\nSource: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\n'One confirmed case has been reported in Banjar Minggir, Nusa Penida, Bali. It was the 1st confirmed case of avian influenza in humans in Bali [in 2017]. An epidemiological investigation and response has been conducted by District Health Office of Nusa Penida, Provincial Health Office of Bali, Animal Health Office and also Ministry of Health of Indonesia'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks the EpiCore Global Surveillance Project members who submitted responses to our request for further information. - Avian influenza (134): Viet Nam (BL) backyard, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5284351", "date": "2017-04-02 14:20:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (40): EGYPT (FAYOUM), H5N1, COMMENTS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nThe following comments were received in response to the RFI on ProMED post; Avian influenza, human (27): Egypt (Fayoum) H5N1, RFI 20170227.4866795\n\n******\n[1] Age discrepancy between age cited for Fayoum case by EMRO (45 years) and WHO and media sources (48 years)\nDate: Thu 16 Mar 2017\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nInfluenza at the human-animal interface Summary and assessment, 14 Feb [2017] to 16 Mar 2017\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nA 4-year-old male resident of Menia Governorate, Egypt, had onset of illness on Thu 2 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Fri 10 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient recovered and was discharged on Mon 20 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with domestic birds in his household.\n\nIn addition, a 48-year-old man from Fayoum Governorate had onset of illness on Fri 10 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Wed 15 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient developed severe disease and passed away on Fri 24 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with sick and dead backyard poultry.\n\nInvestigation and follow up of contacts of the 2 cases took place for 14 days with no further cases reported. Avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses are enzootic in poultry in Egypt.\n\nSince 2003, a total of 858 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, including 453 deaths, have been reported to WHO from 16 countries .\n\n----------------------------------\nDate: Tue 7 Mar 2017\nSource: EMRO Influenza update [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/influenza-update-february-2017.html\n\n\nIn the WHO Eastern Mediterranean Region, influenza activity remained low in February, based on data received. All seasonal influenza sub-types were detected in the Region. In Qatar, moderate activity was reported for the predominant sub-type influenza A(H1N1)pdm09\n\nInfluenza activity by sub-type\n------------------------------\nEgypt reported 2 human cases caused by avian influenza A(H5N1) a 45-year-old man (dead) and a 4-year-old child from 2 governorates.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[WHO has corrected the age of the 2nd patient through a corrected version available on;http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1. - Mod.UBA]\n\n******\n[2] FAO reports\nDate: Mon 27 Feb 2017\nSource: FAO [edited]\n\n\nFAO posted reports of confirmations on 2 fatal cases on Mon 27 Feb 2017, but both cases have observation dates from 1st week of February.\n\n5 "date": "2017-04-02 14:20:15", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (40): EGYPT (FAYOUM), H5N1, COMMENTS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nThe following comments were received in response to the RFI on ProMED post; Avian influenza, human (27): Egypt (Fayoum) H5N1, RFI 20170227.4866795\n\n******\n[1] Age discrepancy between age cited for Fayoum case by EMRO (45 years) and WHO and media sources (48 years)\nDate: Thu 16 Mar 2017\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nInfluenza at the human-animal interface Summary and assessment, 14 Feb [2017] to 16 Mar 2017\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nA 4-year-old male resident of Menia Governorate, Egypt, had onset of illness on Thu 2 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Fri 10 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient recovered and was discharged on Mon 20 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with domestic birds in his household.\n\nIn addition, a 48-year-old man from Fayoum Governorate had onset of illness on Fri 10 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Wed 15 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient developed severe disease and passed away on Fri 24 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with sick and dead backyard poultry.\n\nInvestigation and follow up of contacts of the 2 cases took place for 14 days with no further cases reported. Avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses are enzootic in poultry in Egypt.\n\nSince 2003, a total of 858 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, including 453 deaths, have been reported to WHO from 16 countries .\n\n----------------------------------\nDate: Tue 7 Mar 2017\nSource: EMRO Influenza update [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/influenza-update-february-2017.html\n\n\nIn the WHO Eastern Mediterranean Region, influenza activity remained low in February, based on data received. All seasonal influenza sub-types were detected in the Region. In Qatar, moderate activity was reported for the predominant sub-type influenza A(H1N1)pdm09\n\nInfluenza activity by sub-type\n------------------------------\nEgypt reported 2 human cases caused by avian influenza A(H5N1) a 45-year-old man (dead) and a 4-year-old child from 2 governorates.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[WHO has corrected the age of the 2nd patient through a corrected version available on;http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1. - Mod.UBA]\n\n******\n[2] FAO ProMED post; Avian influenza, human (27): Egypt (Fayoum) H5N1, RFI 20170227.4866795\n\n******\n[1] Age discrepancy between age cited for Fayoum case by EMRO (45 years) and WHO and media sources (48 years)\nDate: Thu 16 Mar 2017\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nInfluenza at the human-animal interface Summary and assessment, 14 Feb [2017] to 16 Mar 2017\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nA 4-year-old male resident of Menia Governorate, Egypt, had onset of illness on Thu 2 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Fri 10 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient recovered and was discharged on Mon 20 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with domestic birds in his household.\n\nIn addition, a 48-year-old man from Fayoum Governorate had onset of illness on Fri 10 Feb 2017, was hospitalized on Wed 15 Feb [2017] and treated with antivirals for pneumonia. A sample collected on admission tested positive for influenza A(H5N1). The patient developed severe disease and passed away on Fri 24 Feb [2017]. Prior to his illness, the case had contact with sick and dead backyard poultry.\n\nInvestigation and follow up of contacts of the 2 cases took place for 14 days with no further cases reported. Avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses are enzootic in poultry in Egypt.\n\nSince 2003, a total of 858 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, including 453 deaths, have been reported to WHO from 16 countries .\n\n----------------------------------\nDate: Tue 7 Mar 2017\nSource: EMRO Influenza update [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/influenza-update-february-2017.html\n\n\nIn the WHO Eastern Mediterranean Region, influenza activity remained low in February, based on data received. All seasonal influenza sub-types were detected in the Region. In Qatar, moderate activity was reported for the predominant sub-type influenza A(H1N1)pdm09\n\nInfluenza activity by sub-type\n------------------------------\nEgypt reported 2 human cases caused by avian influenza A(H5N1) a 45-year-old man (dead) and a 4-year-old child from 2 governorates.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[WHO has corrected the age of the 2nd patient through a corrected version available on;http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_03_16_2017.pdf?ua=1. - Mod.UBA]\n\n******\n[2] FAO reports\nDate: Mon 27 Feb 2017\nSource: FAO [edited]\n\n\nFAO posted reports of confirmations on 2 fatal cases on Mon 27 Feb 2017, but both cases have observation dates from 1st week of February.\n\n5 Feb 17\n--------\nhttp://empres-i.fao.org/empres-i/2/obd?idOutbreak=224262&rss=tFAYOUM\n\n1 Feb 17\n--------\nhttp://empres-i.fao.org/empres-i/2/obd?idOutbreak=224264&rss=t\n\n--\nCommunicated OIE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\n\n******\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22498\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rajshashi Medical College Campus, Sadar, Rajshahi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The event started on 15 Jan 2017 and is still continuing as of 21 Jan 2017. One outbreak with HPAI was already detected in house crows last year (February 2016).\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The surveillance is continuing in the affected premises and adjacent poultry farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22467\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak cluster 1: SS Agro Complex, Burokoi, Kulla, Dhamrai, Dhaka, (1 outbreak)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 16 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). The affected species was also crows. The event was declared resolved on 4 Feb 2016. The source of infection was said to be \"eating of city waste.\" The event summary and map are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19727\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date (23 Jan 2017) can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/husgawz (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nThe Sonali breed is a cross-breed of Rhode Island Red cocks and Fayoumi hens and has a similar phenotypic appearance to that of local chickens; it was introduced in 1996-2000 in northern parts of Bangladesh http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/3523/can-the-sonali-chicken-crossbreed-improve-the-poultry-industry-in-bangladesh/.\n\nMaps of Bangladesh can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Bangladesh.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14503.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza
