provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The event started on 15 Jan 2017 and is still continuing as of 21 Jan 2017. One outbreak with HPAI was already detected in house crows last year (February 2016).\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The surveillance is continuing in the affected premises and adjacent poultry farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22467\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak cluster 1: SS Agro Complex, Burokoi, Kulla, Dhamrai, Dhaka, (1 outbreak)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 16 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). The affected species was also crows. The event was declared resolved on 4 Feb 2016. The source of infection was said to be \"eating of city waste.\" The event summary and map are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19727\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date (23 Jan 2017) can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/husgawz (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nThe Sonali breed is a cross-breed of Rhode Island Red cocks and Fayoumi hens and has a similar phenotypic appearance to that of local chickens; it was introduced in 1996-2000 in northern parts of Bangladesh http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/3523/can-the-sonali-chicken-crossbreed-improve-the-poultry-industry-in-bangladesh/.\n\nMaps of Bangladesh can be seen at HPAI H5N1, OIE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\n\n******\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22498\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rajshashi Medical College Campus, Sadar, Rajshahi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The event started on 15 Jan 2017 and is still continuing as of 21 Jan 2017. One outbreak with HPAI was already detected in house crows last year (February 2016).\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The surveillance is continuing in the affected premises and adjacent poultry farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22467\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak cluster 1: SS Agro Complex, Burokoi, Kulla, Dhamrai, Dhaka, (1 outbreak)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 16 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). The affected species was also crows. The event was declared resolved on 4 Feb 2016. The source of infection was said to be \"eating of city waste.\" The event summary and map are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19727\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date (23 Jan 2017) can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/husgawz (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nThe Sonali breed is a cross-breed of Rhode Island Red cocks and Fayoumi hens and has a similar phenotypic appearance to that of local chickens; it was introduced in 1996-2000 in northern parts of Bangladesh http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/3523/can-the-sonali-chicken-crossbreed-improve-the-poultry-industry-in-bangladesh/.\n\nMaps of Bangladesh can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Bangladesh.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14503.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza One outbreak with HPAI was already detected in house crows last year (February 2016).\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The surveillance is continuing in the affected premises and adjacent poultry farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak cluster 1: SS Agro Complex, Burokoi, Kulla, Dhamrai, Dhaka, (1 outbreak)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 16 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). BANGLADESH, CROW, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\n\n******\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22498\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rajshashi Medical College Campus, Sadar, Rajshahi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The event started on 15 Jan 2017 and is still continuing as of 21 Jan 2017. One outbreak with HPAI was already detected in house crows last year (February 2016).\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The surveillance is continuing in the affected premises and adjacent poultry farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22467\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak cluster 1: SS Agro Complex, Burokoi, Kulla, Dhamrai, Dhaka, (1 outbreak)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 16 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). The affected species was also crows. The event was declared resolved on 4 Feb 2016. The source of infection was said to be \"eating of city waste.\" The event summary and map are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19727\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date (23 Jan 2017) can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/husgawz (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nThe Sonali breed is a cross-breed of Rhode Island Red cocks and Fayoumi hens and has a similar phenotypic appearance to that of local chickens; it was introduced in 1996-2000 in northern parts of Bangladesh http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/3523/can-the-sonali-chicken-crossbreed-improve-the-poultry-industry-in-bangladesh/.\n\nMaps of Bangladesh can be seen at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Bangladesh.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14503.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak cluster 1: SS Agro Complex, Burokoi, Kulla, Dhamrai, Dhaka, (1 outbreak)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 16 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). The affected species was also crows. The event was declared resolved on 4 Feb 2016. The source of infection was said to be \"eating of city waste.\" The event summary and map are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19727\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date (23 Jan 2017) can be seen on the interactive map at http://tinyurl.com/husgawz (click on the section of interest on the map, and zoom in).\n\nThe Sonali breed is a cross-breed of Rhode Island Red cocks and Fayoumi hens and has a similar phenotypic appearance to that of local chickens; it was introduced in 1996-2000 in northern parts of Bangladesh http://www.thepoultrysite.com/articles/3523/can-the-sonali-chicken-crossbreed-improve-the-poultry-industry-in-bangladesh/.\n\nMaps of Bangladesh can be seen at CROW, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\n\n******\n[1] HPAI H5N1, crow (Rajshahi)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22498\n\n\nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rajshashi Medical College Campus, Sadar, Rajshahi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nHouse crow: _Corvus splendens_ (Corvidae) / - / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: The event started on 15 Jan 2017 and is still continuing as of 21 Jan 2017. One outbreak with HPAI was already detected in house crows last year (February 2016).\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: The surveillance is continuing in the affected premises and adjacent poultry farms.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, poultry (Dhaka)\nDate: Sat 21 Jan 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(03) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=22467\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bangladesh\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2017 from Dr H.B.M Golam Mahmud, Doctor of Veterinary Medicine (DVM), Director, Livestock Research Institute, Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock, Dhaka, Bangladesh\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 15 Jan 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 16 Jan 2017\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 4 Apr 2016\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak cluster 1: SS Agro Complex, Burokoi, Kulla, Dhamrai, Dhaka, (1 outbreak)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jan 2017\nOutbreak status: resolved on 16 Jan 2017\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 732 / 2268 / 0\nAffected population: On 16 Jan 2017, a poultry farm (Sonali type poultry, Age: 15 weeks) infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was reported by the livestock authority, and the birds were culled on the same day by burial method with proper disinfection.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 24.40 / 24.40 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Surveillance and monitoring in the infected farm is continuing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: disinfection/disinfestation; dipping/spraying; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 16 Jan 2017 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 1 Feb 2016, Bangladesh also reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 in the same division (Rajshahi). The affected species was also crows. The event was declared resolved on 4 Feb 2016. The source of infection was said to be \"eating of city waste.\" The event summary and map are available at\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=19727\n\nAll outbreaks of HPAI (highly pathogenic avian influenza) reported from 1 Jan 2016 to date (23 Jan influenza (26): India (GJ) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4778689", "date": "2016-10-20 13:53:28", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (81): H5N1, INDIA, DELHI ZOO\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Oct 2012\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-37701028\n\n\nThe zoo in the Indian capital Delhi has been temporarily closed after at least 9 birds died of suspected bird flu. Zoo officials have said tests on 2 of the carcasses had confirmed H5N1 avian influenza. The other bodies have also been sent for testing.\n\nThe zoo curator said that the zoo was only shut as a precautionary measure and would reopen in a few days. Curator, Riaz Khan, told reporters that the casualties included ducks, pelicans and painted storks.\n\nDelhi's zoo is one of the biggest in India, and has an estimated 2.2 million visitors every year.\n\nThis incident marks the 2nd time the Delhi zoo has been shut over a health scare this year [2016]. In May [2016], it was closed for a few days after 46 of its spotted deer died of rabies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several H5N1 outbreaks were reported in India earlier this year and in 2015, involving mainly poultry. However, there are not recent reports of outbreaks in the Delhi area. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/330.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (42): post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Oct 2012\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-37701028\n\n\nThe zoo in the Indian capital Delhi has been temporarily closed after at least 9 birds died of suspected bird flu. Zoo officials have said tests on 2 of the carcasses had confirmed H5N1 avian influenza. The other bodies have also been sent for testing.\n\nThe zoo curator said that the zoo was only shut as a precautionary measure and would reopen in a few days. Curator, Riaz Khan, told reporters that the casualties included ducks, pelicans and painted storks.\n\nDelhi's zoo is one of the biggest in India, and has an estimated 2.2 million visitors every year.\n\nThis incident marks the 2nd time the Delhi zoo has been shut over a health scare this year [2016]. In May [2016], it was closed for a few days after 46 of its spotted deer died of rabies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several H5N1 outbreaks were reported in India earlier this year and in 2015, involving mainly poultry. However, there are not recent reports of outbreaks in the Delhi area. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/330.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (42): post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Oct 2012\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-37701028\n\n\nThe zoo in the Indian capital Delhi has been temporarily closed after at least 9 birds died of suspected bird flu. Zoo officials have said tests on 2 of the carcasses had confirmed H5N1 avian influenza. The other bodies have also been sent for testing.\n\nThe zoo curator said that the zoo was only shut as a precautionary measure and would reopen in a few days. Curator, Riaz Khan, told reporters that the casualties included ducks, pelicans and painted storks.\n\nDelhi's zoo is one of the biggest in India, and has an estimated 2.2 million visitors every year.\n\nThis incident marks the 2nd time the Delhi zoo has been shut over a health scare this year [2016]. In May [2016], it was closed for a few days after 46 of its spotted deer died of rabies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several H5N1 outbreaks were reported in India earlier this year and in 2015, involving mainly poultry. However, there are not recent reports of outbreaks in the Delhi area. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/330.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (42): [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-37701028\n\n\nThe zoo in the Indian capital Delhi has been temporarily closed after at least 9 birds died of suspected bird flu. Zoo officials have said tests on 2 of the carcasses had confirmed H5N1 avian influenza. The other bodies have also been sent for testing.\n\nThe zoo curator said that the zoo was only shut as a precautionary measure and would reopen in a few days. Curator, Riaz Khan, told reporters that the casualties included ducks, pelicans and painted storks.\n\nDelhi's zoo is one of the biggest in India, and has an estimated 2.2 million visitors every year.\n\nThis incident marks the 2nd time the Delhi zoo has been shut over a health scare this year [2016]. In May [2016], it was closed for a few days after 46 of its spotted deer died of rabies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several H5N1 outbreaks were reported in India earlier this year and in 2015, involving mainly poultry. "India"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4561296", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (80): Laos (LP) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4561296", "date": "2016-07-31 22:39:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (69): INDONESIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 31 Jul 2016\nSource: The Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/31/bird-flu-rates-rise-again-in-indonesia.html\n\n\nIndonesia has detected a sharp rise in bird flu cases in July [2016] since the country's last report of an unexpected climb earlier this year, bringing the total number of the cases so far in 2016 to 188.\n\n\"The number of bird flu cases has risen in 7 consecutive months since January 2016, with the highest number of cases recorded in April 2016, which is quite alarming. It subsequently fell from May to June 2016, only to rise again this month [July 2016],\" Agriculture Ministry official Muhammad Azhar said on Friday [29 Jul 2016].\n\nHe made the comments when explaining the results of the government's monitoring of bird flu trends in 2016 to the audience at a poultry health and production seminar in Jakarta.\n\nAzhar said as many as 92 014 poultry had died as a result of the bird flu virus in the last 7 months. Most of them were ducks and layer poultry, which made up almost 60 percent of the total number. The remainder were quails, free-range village chickens and broilers, he added.\n\nData show that the 3 provinces with the highest number of [outbreaks] are West Java with 65 in total, Lampung with 28 and South Sulawesi with 23 [outbreaks].\n\nAzhar said the highest number of poultry deaths nationwide was recorded in March 2016 with 48 066 deaths, followed by 15 581 in February 2016.\n\nThe following months saw vast improvements, with the number of poultry deaths declining to 9860 in April and to 558 in June 2016. However, the rates rose by more than tenfold in July 2016, with 6550 cases recorded, Azhar said.\n\nAzhar noted that the rainy season, which occurred throughout the 1st few months of the year, might have contributed to the deaths of the birds, which might have been vulnerable given poor farm conditions and sanitation.\n\nHe further said that monitoring by the ministry's officials had revealed that many farms failed to implement biosecurity measures, a framework in quality maintenance of farm and poultry products developed in collaboration with the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) more than a decade ago, after the virus was 1st detected in Indonesia.\n\n[Byline: Liza Yosephine]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indonesia is available at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif.\n\nThe numbers of dead birds reported by the ministry are not excessive in relative terms and compared to other countries. This may be indicative of the rather small size of the affected holdings, which are, most probably, not commercial farms.\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in 2003, and as of 28 Jul 2016, human cases have been reported from 16 countries with 854 cases, of which 450 reportedly died. The countries most affected are Egypt (354 cases, 117 deaths), Indonesia (199, 167), Viet Nam (127, 64), Cambodia (56, 37), and mainland China (53, 31). Its incidence in poultry, and subsequently in humans, demonstrates a seasonal pattern. The countries which have reported human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) during the past 6 months are Egypt and mainland China.\n\nDetailed quantitative information on HPAI H5N1 in poultry by state and month was last reported by Indonesia for the year 2014 (see at http://tinyurl.com/hyxly65, scroll down). According to the report, Indonesia applies vaccination of poultry against the disease. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (30): Indonesia (SE) poultry, HPAI H5N1 20160404.4136698\nAvian influenza (26): Indonesia, poultry, RFI 20160325.4118905\n2015\n----\nAvian influenza, human (79): Egypt FAO update, Indonesia "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4554039", "date": "2016-07-31 22:39:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (69): INDONESIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 31 Jul 2016\nSource: The Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/31/bird-flu-rates-rise-again-in-indonesia.html\n\n\nIndonesia has detected a sharp rise in bird flu cases in July [2016] since the country's last report of an unexpected climb earlier this year, bringing the total number of the cases so far in 2016 to 188.\n\n\"The number of bird flu cases has risen in 7 consecutive months since January 2016, with the highest number of cases recorded in April 2016, which is quite alarming. It subsequently fell from May to June 2016, only to rise again this month [July 2016],\" Agriculture Ministry official Muhammad Azhar said on Friday [29 Jul 2016].\n\nHe made the comments when explaining the results of the government's monitoring of bird flu trends in 2016 to the audience at a poultry health and production seminar in Jakarta.\n\nAzhar said as many as 92 014 poultry had died as a result of the bird flu virus in the last 7 months. Most of them were ducks and layer poultry, which made up almost 60 percent of the total number. The remainder were quails, free-range village chickens and broilers, he added.\n\nData show that the 3 provinces with the highest number of [outbreaks] are West Java with 65 in total, Lampung with 28 and South Sulawesi with 23 [outbreaks].\n\nAzhar said the highest number of poultry deaths nationwide was recorded in March 2016 with 48 066 deaths, followed by 15 581 in February 2016.\n\nThe following months saw vast improvements, with the number of poultry deaths declining to 9860 in April and to 558 in June 2016. However, the rates rose by more than tenfold in July 2016, with 6550 cases recorded, Azhar said.\n\nAzhar noted that the rainy season, which occurred throughout the 1st few months of the year, might have contributed to the deaths of the birds, which might have been vulnerable given poor farm conditions and sanitation.\n\nHe further said that monitoring by the ministry's officials had revealed that many farms failed to implement biosecurity measures, a framework in quality maintenance of farm and poultry products developed in collaboration with the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) more than a decade ago, after the virus was 1st detected in Indonesia.\n\n[Byline: Liza Yosephine]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indonesia is available at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif.\n\nThe numbers of dead birds reported by the ministry are not excessive in relative terms and compared to other countries. This may be indicative of the rather small size of the affected holdings, which are, most probably, not commercial farms.\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in 2003, and as of 28 Jul 2016, human cases have been reported from 16 countries with 854 cases, of which 450 reportedly died. The countries most affected are Egypt (354 cases, 117 deaths), Indonesia (199, 167), Viet Nam (127, 64), Cambodia (56, 37), and mainland China (53, 31). Its incidence in poultry, and subsequently in humans, demonstrates a seasonal pattern. The countries which have reported human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) during the past 6 months are Egypt and mainland China.\n\nDetailed quantitative information on HPAI H5N1 in poultry by state and month was last reported by Indonesia for the year 2014 (see at http://tinyurl.com/hyxly65, scroll down). influenza, human (35): Indonesia, Viet Nam, WHO 20120313.1069571\n.................................................sb/arn/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00", "2016-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-16 00:00:00", "9860-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-06-16 00:00:00", "2016-07-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "2056-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "1979-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "2063-03-16 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2053-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2050-03-16 "Vietnam"}, {"location": "BT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4547262", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (62): Indonesia, H5N1 sero-prevalence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4547262", "date": "2016-07-31 22:39:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (69): INDONESIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 31 Jul 2016\nSource: The Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/31/bird-flu-rates-rise-again-in-indonesia.html\n\n\nIndonesia has detected a sharp rise in bird flu cases in July [2016] since the country's last report of an unexpected climb earlier this year, bringing the total number of the cases so far in 2016 to 188.\n\n\"The number of bird flu cases has risen in 7 consecutive months since January 2016, with the highest number of cases recorded in April 2016, which is quite alarming. It subsequently fell from May to June 2016, only to rise again this month [July 2016],\" Agriculture Ministry official Muhammad Azhar said on Friday [29 Jul 2016].\n\nHe made the comments when explaining the results of the government's monitoring of bird flu trends in 2016 to the audience at a poultry health and production seminar in Jakarta.\n\nAzhar said as many as 92 014 poultry had died as a result of the bird flu virus in the last 7 months. Most of them were ducks and layer poultry, which made up almost 60 percent of the total number. The remainder were quails, free-range village chickens and broilers, he added.\n\nData show that the 3 provinces with the highest number of [outbreaks] are West Java with 65 in total, Lampung with 28 and South Sulawesi with 23 [outbreaks].\n\nAzhar said the highest number of poultry deaths nationwide was recorded in March 2016 with 48 066 deaths, followed by 15 581 in February 2016.\n\nThe following months saw vast improvements, with the number of poultry deaths declining to 9860 in April and to 558 in June 2016. However, the rates rose by more than tenfold in July 2016, with 6550 cases recorded, Azhar said.\n\nAzhar noted that the rainy season, which occurred throughout the 1st few months of the year, might have contributed to the deaths of the birds, which might have been vulnerable given poor farm conditions and sanitation.\n\nHe further said that monitoring by the ministry's officials had revealed that many farms failed to implement biosecurity measures, a framework in quality maintenance of farm and poultry products developed in collaboration with the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) more than a decade ago, after the virus was 1st detected in Indonesia.\n\n[Byline: Liza Yosephine]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indonesia is available at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif.\n\nThe numbers of dead birds reported by the ministry are not excessive in relative terms and compared to other countries. This may be indicative of the rather small size of the affected holdings, which are, most probably, not commercial farms.\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in 2003, and as of 28 Jul 2016, human cases have been reported from 16 countries with 854 cases, of which 450 reportedly died. The countries most affected are Egypt (354 cases, 117 deaths), Indonesia (199, 167), Viet Nam (127, 64), Cambodia (56, 37), and mainland China (53, 31). Its incidence in poultry, and subsequently in humans, demonstrates a seasonal pattern. The countries which have reported human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) during the past 6 months are Egypt and mainland China.\n\nDetailed quantitative information on HPAI H5N1 in poultry by state and month was last reported by Indonesia for the year 2014 (see at http://tinyurl.com/hyxly65, scroll down). According to the report, Indonesia applies vaccination of poultry against the disease. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (30): Indonesia (SE) poultry, HPAI H5N1 20160404.4136698\nAvian influenza (26): Indonesia, poultry, RFI 20160325.4118905\n2015\n----\nAvian influenza, human (79): Egypt FAO update, Indonesia The countries most affected are Egypt (354 cases, 117 deaths), Indonesia (199, 167), Viet Nam (127, 64), Cambodia (56, 37), and mainland China (53, 31). Its incidence in poultry, and subsequently in humans, demonstrates a seasonal pattern. The countries which have reported human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) during the past 6 months are Egypt and mainland China.\n\nDetailed quantitative information on HPAI H5N1 in poultry by state and month was last reported by Indonesia for the year 2014 (see at http://tinyurl.com/hyxly65, scroll down). According to the report, Indonesia applies vaccination of poultry against the disease. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (35): Indonesia, Viet Nam, WHO 20120313.1069571\n.................................................sb/arn/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00", "2016-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-07-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-02-16 00:00:00", "9860-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-16 00:00:00", "2016-06-16 00:00:00", "2016-07-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2064-03-16 00:00:00", "Vietnam"}, {"location": "BT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4442617", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (71): Togo (MA) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4442617", "date": "2016-07-31 22:39:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (69): INDONESIA, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 31 Jul 2016\nSource: The Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/31/bird-flu-rates-rise-again-in-indonesia.html\n\n\nIndonesia has detected a sharp rise in bird flu cases in July [2016] since the country's last report of an unexpected climb earlier this year, bringing the total number of the cases so far in 2016 to 188.\n\n\"The number of bird flu cases has risen in 7 consecutive months since January 2016, with the highest number of cases recorded in April 2016, which is quite alarming. It subsequently fell from May to June 2016, only to rise again this month [July 2016],\" Agriculture Ministry official Muhammad Azhar said on Friday [29 Jul 2016].\n\nHe made the comments when explaining the results of the government's monitoring of bird flu trends in 2016 to the audience at a poultry health and production seminar in Jakarta.\n\nAzhar said as many as 92 014 poultry had died as a result of the bird flu virus in the last 7 months. Most of them were ducks and layer poultry, which made up almost 60 percent of the total number. The remainder were quails, free-range village chickens and broilers, he added.\n\nData show that the 3 provinces with the highest number of [outbreaks] are West Java with 65 in total, Lampung with 28 and South Sulawesi with 23 [outbreaks].\n\nAzhar said the highest number of poultry deaths nationwide was recorded in March 2016 with 48 066 deaths, followed by 15 581 in February 2016.\n\nThe following months saw vast improvements, with the number of poultry deaths declining to 9860 in April and to 558 in June 2016. However, the rates rose by more than tenfold in July 2016, with 6550 cases recorded, Azhar said.\n\nAzhar noted that the rainy season, which occurred throughout the 1st few months of the year, might have contributed to the deaths of the birds, which might have been vulnerable given poor farm conditions and sanitation.\n\nHe further said that monitoring by the ministry's officials had revealed that many farms failed to implement biosecurity measures, a framework in quality maintenance of farm and poultry products developed in collaboration with the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) more than a decade ago, after the virus was 1st detected in Indonesia.\n\n[Byline: Liza Yosephine]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Indonesia is available at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif.\n\nThe numbers of dead birds reported by the ministry are not excessive in relative terms and compared to other countries. This may be indicative of the rather small size of the affected holdings, which are, most probably, not commercial farms.\n\nSince the start of the HPAI H5N1 event in 2003, and as of 28 Jul 2016, human cases have been reported from 16 countries with 854 cases, of which 450 reportedly died. The countries most affected are Egypt (354 cases, 117 deaths), Indonesia (199, 167), Viet Nam (127, 64), Cambodia (56, 37), and mainland China (53, 31). Its incidence in poultry, and subsequently in humans, demonstrates a seasonal pattern. The countries which have reported human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) during the past 6 months are Egypt and mainland China.\n\nDetailed quantitative information on HPAI H5N1 in poultry by state and month was last reported by Indonesia for the year 2014 (see at http://tinyurl.com/hyxly65, scroll down). According to the report, Indonesia applies vaccination of poultry against the disease. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184.]\nSee Also\nAvian "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4370398", "date": "2016-05-18 12:16:36", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (44): CAMBODIA (KAMPOT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 17 May 2016\nSource: The Phnom Penh Post [edited]\nhttp://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/avian-flu-outbreak-kampot-confirmed\n\n\nThe 1st outbreak of H5N1 this year [2016] was confirmed in Kampot province on [10 May 20106], health officials said yesterday [Mon 16 May 2016].\n\nA total of 349 chickens, one duck, and 37 chicken eggs, belonging to 7 families in Chhouk district's Koh Russei village, were culled and burned by health officials to prevent the virus from spreading further, said Chan Rith, provincial agriculture department director.\n\nA total of 4 human cases were also suspected, but blood samples confirmed there was no infection, Rith said.\n\n\"We advised the people not to eat the sick or dead animals, and they need to cage the sick animals in a separate place,\" he said.\n\n\"We will assign experts to monitor [the situation] to make sure that there is no transportation of animals from the nearby areas until we reach 30 days after the outbreak.\"\n\nMinistry of Health spokesman Ly Sovann said the ministry will monitor the health of the villagers who were tested for the next 2 weeks.\n\nHe appealed to the public to practice proper hygiene, and not eat or touch sick animals. If a person who has handled an animal comes down with flu symptoms, the person is advised to seek medical attention.\n\n\"Bird flu keeps happening rampantly in our country, so precaution is the most important [step],\" Sovann said.\n\nA bird flu outbreak last November [2015] in Siem Reap and Battambang provinces saw more than 4000 ducks killed by the virus or culled to prevent further spread.\n\n[Byline: Pech Sotheary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nJohn T Cathey\n<jt.cathey@gmail.com>\n\n[As a recurrent event after absence of HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in Cambodia since November 2015, Cambodia submitted an immediate notification to the OIE on 17 May 2016. For the said notification and commentary by Mod.CRD, addressing earlier published data which might be of relevance to this event, please refer to archive no. 20160517.4227842. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Cambodia can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Cambodia,_administrative_divisions_-_de_-_colored.svg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1262. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee "unknown"}, {"location": "Chhouk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4343176", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (62): West & Central Africa, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread, FAO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4343176", "date": "2016-05-18 12:16:36", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (44): CAMBODIA (KAMPOT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 17 May 2016\nSource: The Phnom Penh Post [edited]\nhttp://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/avian-flu-outbreak-kampot-confirmed\n\n\nThe 1st outbreak of H5N1 this year [2016] was confirmed in Kampot province on [10 May 20106], health officials said yesterday [Mon 16 May 2016].\n\nA total of 349 chickens, one duck, and 37 chicken eggs, belonging to 7 families in Chhouk district's Koh Russei village, were culled and burned by health officials to prevent the virus from spreading further, said Chan Rith, provincial agriculture department director.\n\nA total of 4 human cases were also suspected, but blood samples confirmed there was no infection, Rith said.\n\n\"We advised the people not to eat the sick or dead animals, and they need to cage the sick animals in a separate place,\" he said.\n\n\"We will assign experts to monitor [the situation] to make sure that there is no transportation of animals from the nearby areas until we reach 30 days after the outbreak.\"\n\nMinistry of Health spokesman Ly Sovann said the ministry will monitor the health of the villagers who were tested for the next 2 weeks.\n\nHe appealed to the public to practice proper hygiene, and not eat or touch sick animals. If a person who has handled an animal comes down with flu symptoms, the person is advised to seek medical attention.\n\n\"Bird flu keeps happening rampantly in our country, so precaution is the most important [step],\" Sovann said.\n\nA bird flu outbreak last November [2015] in Siem Reap and Battambang provinces saw more than 4000 ducks killed by the virus or culled to prevent further spread.\n\n[Byline: Pech Sotheary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nJohn T Cathey\n<jt.cathey@gmail.com>\n\n[As a recurrent event after absence of HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in Cambodia since November 2015, Cambodia submitted an immediate notification to the OIE on 17 May 2016. For the said notification and commentary by Mod.CRD, addressing earlier published data which might be of relevance to this event, please refer to archive no. 20160517.4227842. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of If a person who has handled an animal comes down with flu symptoms, the person is advised to seek medical attention.\n\n\"Bird flu keeps happening rampantly in our country, so precaution is the most important [step],\" Sovann said.\n\nA bird flu outbreak last November [2015] in Siem Reap and Battambang provinces saw more than 4000 ducks killed by the virus or culled to prevent further spread.\n\n[Byline: Pech Sotheary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nJohn T Cathey\n<jt.cathey@gmail.com>\n\n[As a recurrent event after absence of HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in Cambodia since November 2015, Cambodia submitted an immediate notification to the OIE on 17 May 2016. Cambodia can be seen at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Cambodia,_administrative_divisions_-_de_-_colored.svg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1262. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4249967", "date": "2016-05-18 12:16:36", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (44): CAMBODIA (KAMPOT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 17 May 2016\nSource: The Phnom Penh Post [edited]\nhttp://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/avian-flu-outbreak-kampot-confirmed\n\n\nThe 1st outbreak of H5N1 this year [2016] was confirmed in Kampot province on [10 May 20106], health officials said yesterday [Mon 16 May 2016].\n\nA total of 349 chickens, one duck, and 37 chicken eggs, belonging to 7 families in Chhouk district's Koh Russei village, were culled and burned by health officials to prevent the virus from spreading further, said Chan Rith, provincial agriculture department director.\n\nA total of 4 human cases were also suspected, but blood samples confirmed there was no infection, Rith said.\n\n\"We advised the people not to eat the sick or dead animals, and they need to cage the sick animals in a separate place,\" he said.\n\n\"We will assign experts to monitor [the situation] to make sure that there is no transportation of animals from the nearby areas until we reach 30 days after the outbreak.\"\n\nMinistry of Health spokesman Ly Sovann said the ministry will monitor the health of the villagers who were tested for the next 2 weeks.\n\nHe appealed to the public to practice proper hygiene, and not eat or touch sick animals. If a person who has handled an animal comes down with flu symptoms, the person is advised to seek medical attention.\n\n\"Bird flu keeps happening rampantly in our country, so precaution is the most important [step],\" Sovann said.\n\nA bird flu outbreak last November [2015] in Siem Reap and Battambang provinces saw more than 4000 ducks killed by the virus or culled to prevent further spread.\n\n[Byline: Pech Sotheary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Surveillance Project member\nJohn T Cathey\n<jt.cathey@gmail.com>\n\n[As a recurrent event after absence of HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in Cambodia since November 2015, Cambodia submitted an immediate notification to the OIE on 17 May 2016. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4227842", "date": "2016-04-15 16:42:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (37): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2016\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\n\nIn a monthly update on zoonotic flu strains, the World Health Organization (WHO) recently noted reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.\n\nThe WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.\n\nThe 4 Egyptian cases were previously reported but with very few epidemiologic details by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization. Health officials have been closely watching developments in Egypt, because the country had an unprecedented surge of cases at about this time last year [2015].\n\nTwo of the H5N1 patients are from Giza governorate, a 70-year-old woman who is in critical condition and a 5-year-old girl who recovered. A 1-year-old girl in Sohag governorate and a 7-year-old girl in Cairo have also recovered. The 3 girls were exposed to live or dead poultry, while the investigation into the virus source is still under investigation for the older woman, the WHO said.\n\nSince 2003 the agency has recorded 850 H5N1 infections, 449 of them fatal, in 16 countries.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most A(H5) influenza human cases have history of exposure through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments, including live poultry markets. Since the viruses continue to be detected in animals and environments, further human cases can be expected. Even though small clusters of A(H5N1) virus infections have been reported previously, including those involving healthcare workers, current epidemiological and virological evidence suggests that the A(H5) viruses are still essentially avian and have not acquired the ability of sustained transmission among humans. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (33): Egypt (JZ) H5N1 20160323.4114052\nAvian influenza, human (30): Egypt (Cairo) H5N1, China (GD) H5N6 20160315.4095095\nAvian "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4218976", "date": "2016-04-15 16:42:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (37): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2016\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\n\nIn a monthly update on zoonotic flu strains, the World Health Organization (WHO) recently noted reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.\n\nThe WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.\n\nThe 4 Egyptian cases were previously reported but with very few epidemiologic details by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization. Health officials have been closely watching developments in Egypt, because the country had an unprecedented surge of cases at about this time last year [2015].\n\nTwo of the H5N1 patients are from Giza governorate, a 70-year-old woman who is in critical condition and a 5-year-old girl who recovered. A 1-year-old girl in Sohag governorate and a 7-year-old girl in Cairo have also recovered. The 3 girls were exposed to live or dead poultry, while the investigation into the virus source is still under investigation for the older woman, the WHO said.\n\nSince 2003 the agency has recorded 850 H5N1 infections, 449 of them fatal, in 16 countries.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most A(H5) influenza human cases have history of exposure through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments, including live poultry markets. Since the viruses continue to be detected in animals and environments, further human cases can be expected. Even though small clusters of A(H5N1) virus infections have been reported previously, including those involving healthcare workers, current epidemiological and virological evidence suggests that the A(H5) viruses are still essentially avian and have not acquired the ability of sustained transmission among humans. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (33): Egypt (JZ) H5N1 20160323.4114052\nAvian influenza, human (30): Egypt (Cairo) H5N1, China (GD) H5N6 20160315.4095095\nAvian "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4210295", "date": "2016-04-15 16:42:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (37): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2016\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\n\nIn a monthly update on zoonotic flu strains, the World Health Organization (WHO) recently noted reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.\n\nThe WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.\n\nThe 4 Egyptian cases were previously reported but with very few epidemiologic details by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization. Health officials have been closely watching developments in Egypt, because the country had an unprecedented surge of cases at about this time last year [2015].\n\nTwo of the H5N1 patients are from Giza governorate, a 70-year-old woman who is in critical condition and a 5-year-old girl who recovered. A 1-year-old girl in Sohag governorate and a 7-year-old girl in Cairo have also recovered. The 3 girls were exposed to live or dead poultry, while the investigation into the virus source is still under investigation for the older woman, the WHO said.\n\nSince 2003 the agency has recorded 850 H5N1 infections, 449 of them fatal, in 16 countries.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most A(H5) influenza human cases have history of exposure through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments, including live poultry markets. Since the viruses continue to be detected in animals and environments, further human cases can be expected. Even though small clusters of A(H5N1) virus infections have been reported previously, including those involving healthcare workers, current epidemiological and virological evidence suggests that the A(H5) viruses are still essentially avian and have not acquired the ability of sustained transmission among humans. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (33): Egypt (JZ) H5N1 20160323.4114052\nAvian influenza, human (30): Egypt (Cairo) H5N1, China (GD) H5N6 20160315.4095095\nAvian reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.\n\nThe WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.\n\nThe 4 Egyptian cases were previously The 3 girls were exposed to live or dead poultry, while the investigation into the virus source is still under investigation for the older woman, the WHO said.\n\nSince 2003 the agency has recorded 850 H5N1 infections, 449 of them fatal, in 16 countries.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most A(H5) influenza human cases have history of exposure through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments, including live poultry markets. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4184541", "date": "2016-04-15 16:42:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (37): EGYPT, H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2016\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\n\nIn a monthly update on zoonotic flu strains, the World Health Organization (WHO) recently noted reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.\n\nThe WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.\n\nThe 4 Egyptian cases were previously reported but with very few epidemiologic details by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization. Health officials have been closely watching developments in Egypt, because the country had an unprecedented surge of cases at about this time last year [2015].\n\nTwo of the H5N1 patients are from Giza governorate, a 70-year-old woman who is in critical condition and a 5-year-old girl who recovered. A 1-year-old girl in Sohag governorate and a 7-year-old girl in Cairo have also recovered. The 3 girls were exposed to live or dead poultry, while the investigation into the virus source is still under investigation for the older woman, the WHO said.\n\nSince 2003 the agency has recorded 850 H5N1 infections, 449 of them fatal, in 16 countries.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most A(H5) influenza human cases have history of exposure through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments, including live poultry markets. Since the viruses continue to be detected in animals and environments, further human cases can be expected. Even though small clusters of A(H5N1) virus infections have been reported previously, including those involving healthcare workers, current epidemiological and virological evidence suggests that the A(H5) viruses are still essentially avian and have not acquired the ability of sustained transmission among humans. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Apr 2016\nSource: WHO Monthly Risk Assessment Summary [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/\n\n\nIn a monthly update on zoonotic flu strains, the World Health Organization (WHO) recently noted reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.\n\nThe WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.\n\nThe 4 Egyptian cases were previously reported but with very few epidemiologic details by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization. Health officials have been closely watching developments in Egypt, because the country had an unprecedented surge of cases at about this time last year [2015].\n\nTwo of the H5N1 patients are from Giza governorate, a 70-year-old woman who is in critical condition and a 5-year-old girl who recovered. A 1-year-old girl in Sohag governorate and a 7-year-old girl in Cairo have also recovered. The 3 girls were exposed to live or dead poultry, while the investigation into the virus source is still under investigation for the older woman, the WHO said.\n\nSince 2003 the agency has recorded 850 H5N1 infections, 449 of them fatal, in 16 countries.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most A(H5) influenza human cases have history of exposure through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments, including live poultry markets. Since the viruses continue to be detected in animals and environments, further human cases can be expected. Even though small clusters of A(H5N1) virus infections have been reported previously, including those involving healthcare workers, current epidemiological and virological evidence suggests that the A(H5) viruses are still essentially avian and have not acquired the ability of sustained transmission among humans. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: 00:00:00", "2055-03-16 00:00:00", "2052-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2045-03-16 00:00:00", "2039-03-16 00:00:00", "2035-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00",
