ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this post:\n[1] HPAI H5N6, OIE\n[2] HPAI H5N1, OIE\n\n******\n[1] HPAI H5N6, OIE\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(31) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18215\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Viet Nam\n-----------------------------\nInformation received on 24 Jul 2015 from Dr Dong Pham Van, director general, chief veterinary officer, Department of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 12 Jul 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 18 Jul 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 24 Jun 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N6\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Neighbourhood 5, Quynh Tan, Quynh Luu, Nghe An\nDate of start of the outbreak: 12 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 605 / - / 256 / 349 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / ** / 42.31 / ** / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; disinfection/disinfestations; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nRegional Animal Health Office (RAHO3) (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 18 Jul 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] HPAI H5N1, OIE\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(31) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18221\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Viet Nam\n----------------------------\nInformation received on 24 Jul 2015 from Dr Dong Pham Van, director general, chief veterinary officer, Department of Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Hanoi, Viet Nam.\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 18 Jul 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 22 Jul 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 24 Jun 2015\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Phu Quoi, Phu Quoi, Long Ho, Vinh Long\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 300 / 300 / 117 / 183 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 100 / 39 / 39 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; disinfection/disinfestations; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nRegional Animal Health Office (RAHO7) (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 22 Jul 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 and H5N6 in Vietnam have taken place earlier this year as follows:\n\n1. HPAI H5N6\nstarted 12 Mar 2015\nTotal outbreaks: 3\nResolved: 25 May 2015\nInteractive map & reports available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17385\n\n2. HPAI H5N1\nStarted 27 May 2015\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nResolved: 24 Jun 2015\nInteractive map & reports available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17835.\n\nViet Nam's HPAI control policy is based upon stamping out.\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has suffered a total of 127 HPAI H5N1 cases in humans, of which 64 deaths.\nDuring 2014, 2 human cases were reported, both died. No human cases so far in 2015. - Mods.CRD/AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (148): Viet Nam (DO) poultry, HPAI H5N6, post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Jun 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2015; 28(25) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17926\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Iran\n----------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Jun 2015 from Dr Mehdi Khalaj, Head, Iran Veterinary Organization (IVO), Ministry of Jihad-e-Agriculture, Tehran, Iran\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 12 Jun 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 14 Jun 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Jan 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Nogardan, Amol, Amol, Mazandaran\nDate of start of the outbreak: 12 Jun 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 25 / 19/ 17 / 8/ 0\nAffected population: Free-range chicken (backyard) in a village named Nogardan in Mazandaran province.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 76 / 68 / 89.47 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments:\n1. The event was reported according to Iran passive surveillance in place.\n2. A post-outbreak investigation is ongoing to trace the source of infection, and to detect a probable spread and circulation of the virus. 3. Active surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoir, stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 14 Jun 2015 / Positive\nRazi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 15 Jun 2015 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Amol is located on the banks of the Haraz River 26 25'N 52 21'E, at an altitude of 76 m (250 ft) above sea level, about 18 km (11.2 mi) from the Caspian sea and about 10 km (6.2 mi) from the northern Alborz mountains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amol).\n\nDuring April and May 2015, Russia and Kazakhstan reported HPAI in wild birds (see report below). These findings were located in areas around the Caspian Sea. Given the proximity of this recent outbreak in Iran to these previous findings, and the occurrence of HPAI H5N1 in wild birds in this area, there is a likely link between these events.\n\nA previous outbreak in Iran was also located in the Mazandaran province. The event was resolved on 18 Jan 2012. See final report and map at, http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000011517_20120118_123834.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21167.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (150): Turkey (BU) poultry, HPAI H5N1 conf 20150606.3413987\nAvian influenza (147): Turkey (BU) poultry, susp, RFI, human (AD) NOT 20150605.3410097\nAvian influenza (133): Kazakhstan (Guryev) HPAI H5, wild bird, OIE 20150523.3381278\nAvian influenza (121): Turkey (BK) poultry, susp, RFI 20150510.3353695\nAvian influenza (110): Turkey (KS) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20150504.3340995\nAvian influenza (109): Turkey (BK) poultry, HPAI H5N1, susp. A post-outbreak investigation is ongoing to trace the source of infection, and to detect a probable spread and circulation of the virus. 3. Active surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoir, stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 14 Jun 2015 / Positive\nRazi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 15 Jun 2015 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. These findings were located in areas around the Caspian Sea. Given the proximity of this recent outbreak in Iran to these previous findings, and the occurrence of HPAI H5N1 in wild birds in this area, there is a likely link between these events.\n\nA previous outbreak in Iran was also located in the Mazandaran province. The event was resolved on 18 Jan 2012. 28(25) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17926\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Iran\n----------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Jun 2015 from Dr Mehdi Khalaj, Head, Iran Veterinary Organization (IVO), Ministry of Jihad-e-Agriculture, Tehran, Iran\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 12 Jun 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 14 Jun 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Jan 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Nogardan, Amol, Amol, Mazandaran\nDate of start of the outbreak: 12 Jun 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 25 / 19/ 17 / 8/ 0\nAffected population: Free-range chicken (backyard) in a village named Nogardan in Mazandaran province.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 76 / 68 / 89.47 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments:\n1. The event was reported according to Iran passive surveillance in place.\n2. A post-outbreak investigation is ongoing to trace the source of infection, and to detect a probable spread and circulation of the virus. 3. Active surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoir, stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 14 Jun 2015 / Positive\nRazi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 15 Jun 2015 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Amol is located on the banks of the Haraz River 26 25'N 52 21'E, at an altitude of 76 m (250 ft) above sea level, about 18 km (11.2 mi) from the Caspian sea and about 10 km (6.2 mi) from the northern Alborz mountains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amol).\n\nDuring April and May 2015, Russia and Kazakhstan reported HPAI in wild birds (see report below). These findings were located in areas around the Caspian Sea. Given the proximity of this recent outbreak in Iran to these previous findings, and the occurrence of HPAI H5N1 in wild birds in this area, there is a likely link between these events.\n\nA previous outbreak in Iran was also located in the Mazandaran province. The event was resolved on 18 Jan 2012. See final report and map at, http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000011517_20120118_123834.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21167.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (150): Turkey (BU) poultry, HPAI H5N1 conf 20150606.3413987\nAvian influenza (147): Turkey (BU) poultry, susp, RFI, human (AD) NOT 20150605.3410097\nAvian influenza (133): Kazakhstan (Guryev) HPAI H5, wild bird, OIE 20150523.3381278\nAvian influenza (121): Turkey (BK) poultry, susp, RFI 20150510.3353695\nAvian influenza (110): Turkey (KS) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20150504.3340995\nAvian influenza (109): Turkey (BK) poultry, HPAI H5N1, susp. 28(25) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17926\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Iran\n----------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Jun 2015 from Dr Mehdi Khalaj, Head, Iran Veterinary Organization (IVO), Ministry of Jihad-e-Agriculture, Tehran, Iran\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 12 Jun 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 14 Jun 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 18 Jan 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Nogardan, Amol, Amol, Mazandaran\nDate of start of the outbreak: 12 Jun 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 25 / 19/ 17 / 8/ 0\nAffected population: Free-range chicken (backyard) in a village named Nogardan in Mazandaran province.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 76 / 68 / 89.47 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments:\n1. The event was reported according to Iran passive surveillance in place.\n2. A post-outbreak investigation is ongoing to trace the source of infection, and to detect a probable spread and circulation of the virus. 3. Active surveillance is ongoing.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoir, stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, screening, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 14 Jun 2015 / Positive\nRazi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 15 Jun 2015 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Amol is located on the banks of the Haraz River 26 25'N 52 21'E, at an altitude of 76 m (250 ft) above sea level, about 18 km (11.2 mi) from the Caspian sea and about 10 km (6.2 mi) from the northern Alborz mountains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amol).\n\nDuring April and May 2015, Russia and Kazakhstan reported HPAI in wild birds (see report below). These findings were located in areas around the Caspian Sea. Given the proximity of this recent outbreak in Iran to these previous findings, and the occurrence of HPAI H5N1 in wild birds in this area, there is a likely link between these events.\n\nA previous outbreak in Iran was also located in the Mazandaran province. The event was resolved on 18 Jan 2012. RFI 20110410.1138\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (17): Iran (Mazandaran), India (West Bengal) - OIE 20080119.023\n.................................................crd/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-06-15 00:00:00", "2015-06-14 00:00:00", "2012-01-18 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-06-14 00:00:00", "2015-06-15 00:00:00", "2012-01-18 00:00:00", "2062-03-16 00:00:00", "2061-03-16 00:00:00", "2049-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Amol", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tehran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mazandaran province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alborz", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3436984", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (158): Ghana (AA) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3436984", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee {"archive_id": "3430111", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (155): Russia (TU) HPAI H5N1, wild bird, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3430111", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee "2014-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-04-30 00:00:00", "2014-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-02-28 00:00:00", "2014-02-28 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 {"archive_id": "3413987", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (150): Turkey (BU) poultry, HPAI H5N1 conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3413987", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SQ", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "GD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "JS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Mainland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "H5N8", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": {"archive_id": "3397148", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (140): Egypt, poultry, HPAI H5N1, control, revision", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3397148", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee {"archive_id": "3392836", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (138): Cote d'Ivoire (VB) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3392836", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee
