{"archive_id": "3373783", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (105): Egypt H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3373783", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee {"archive_id": "3373064", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (130): Viet Nam, HPAI H5N1, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3373064", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee {"archive_id": "3366602", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (104): Egypt H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3366602", "date": "2015-05-16 13:29:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (104): EGYPT H5N1\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 May 2015\nSource: WHO/FAO/OIE/US-CDC/US-NAMRU-3/UNICEF [edited]\nhttp://www.emro.who.int/images/stories/Executive_Summary_14_May_2015.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nJoint high-level mission on the current H5N1 situation in Egypt\n-----\nEgypt, 8-12 Mar 2015\n\nExecutive summary\n\nIntroduction\n----\nBetween November 2014 and February 2015, Egypt saw a major rise in the number of human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1). In fact, the number of cases occurring in this period exceeded the number of cases ever found in any country since the disease's reemergence in 2004. In view of the serious risk of a pandemic, which is enhanced by the enzootic state of H5N1 in Egypt, the Ministry for Health and Population requested a joint assessment to better understand the recent upsurge, and to provide concrete measures to curb the trend of increasing infection. From 8-12 Mar [2015], a team representing the World Health Organization (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US-CDC), the United States Naval Medical Research Unit 3 (US-NAMRU-3) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) met with key stakeholders and analysed the current situation.\n\nSummary of findings\n----\n\nAnimal health (Please see in commentary below)\n\nHuman health\n----\nConcomitant with the dramatic increase in the number of poultry outbreaks, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of human cases detected each month, particularly from December 2014 through February 2015. According to the Ministry of Health and Population, the numbers of H5N1 cases reported for these months greatly exceeded the expected numbers based on historical data.\n\nThis upsurge most likely results from increased exposure of people to infected poultry. Most recent human cases (approximately 70 percent) had exposure to backyard poultry. Children under 5 make up a significantly higher portion of all confirmed H5N1 cases in Egypt (33 percent) compared with the rest of the world (15 percent). Young children and women often are engaged in rearing backyard poultry, which puts them at high risk during poultry outbreaks.\n\nLikewise, the number of human samples being tested for H5N1 has increased compared with [during] earlier poultry outbreaks. Testing has also increased as a result of rapid response by the preventive sector and increased awareness among clinicians.\n\nDespite the unprecedented surge in human cases in Egypt, it does not appear that the risk of an H5N1 pandemic has changed appreciably. This conclusion is based on the following:\n1) although human-to-human transmission cannot be excluded, there has been no change in the size or number of clusters of human cases during the surge compared with previous years;\n2) there is no evidence of transmission from patients to healthcare workers during the surge;\n3) most recent human cases had direct or indirect poultry contact;\n4) genetic sequence data have not identified changes that would make human-to-human transmission efficient.\n\nNevertheless, the presence of H5N1 viruses in Egypt with the ability to jump more readily from birds to humans than viruses in other enzootic countries is of concern and requires a high level of vigilance from the Ministries of Health and Agriculture.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has strengthened multiple disease surveillance [for] influenza-like illness (ILI), severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and avian influenza [which has] generated valuable epidemiological information for this and other important influenza outbreaks. The Central Public Health Laboratory functions well and has provided training for regional and local laboratories.\n\nGenetic and antigenic data from human and poultry samples are being jointly analysed by staff in Egypt along with international counterparts. However, increased real-time sharing and analysis should be encouraged. The 4-way linking platform could be used to accomplish this; it should also meet fortnightly during a surge of cases and every 2 months when there are no outbreaks.\n\nThe Ministry of Health and Population has purchased antiviral drugs (neuraminidase inhibitors) [which] have been made available to clinicians for patients with suspected and laboratory-confirmed infections. This is particularly important to reduce mortality\n\nCoordination and collaboration\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nKey recommendations\n----\nCoordination and strategic planning\nMinistry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation\nMinistry of Health and Population\nCommunication for behavior change\n\nThe way forward\n----\nA successful approach to addressing H5N1 requires long-term, sustainable investments in agriculture, health and communities. In particular, close collaboration between sectors is required in communications, policy development, surveillance and response, and the production and sharing of information. Accurate, regular assessment of the impact of control measures is required to evaluate progress.\n\nThe government should undertake 1 or more pilot projects at the district level to determine which changes in policies and practices are most effective in reducing spread of infection among poultry and to humans and sustainable on a medium- to long-term basis. Addressing H5N1 nationally will require long-term changes in policies, practices, culture, awareness and community engagement.\n\nWithin 3 months, a 2-year action plan that encompasses these recommendations and includes clear outcomes and indicators for monitoring will be developed by the ministries of health, agriculture and local development. FAO, WHO and OIE will support development of the plan, which will be presented to the NSC.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Executive summary is the result of an invitation Egypt extended 2 months ago to the WHO, FAO, NAMRU-3, CDC and UNICEF for a joint investigation of H5N1 in the country, and to make recommendations on containing that outbreak.\n\nThe updated H5N1 case count from WHO, which covers reported cases since November 2014 to 30 April 2015,, is 165 cases and 48 deaths. This represents an increase in human cases over what has been observed in previous years in Egypt. Case fatality appears to be lower in Egypt compared with other countries, likely because children are more commonly infected in Egypt. The task of controlling spread of the virus represents a serious challenge to Egypt. While there is no evidence for other than occasional spread from human to human, the risk exists and must be closely monitored.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be found at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\n\n[The executive summary of the mission includes a section on the animal health aspects of HPAI H5N1 in Egypt. The following extracts deserve attention:\n\n\"A preponderance of the evidence examined by the team suggests that there has been a real and measurable increase in the incidence of H5N1 [in poultry] since June 2014. Between 1 Dec 2014 and 28 Feb 2015, 333 outbreaks in poultry were observed in Egypt, while between 1 Dec 2013 and 28 Feb 2014 there were only 44 reported outbreaks. Reports indicate that H5N1 is circulating in all sectors of poultry production and geographically in all parts of Egypt. The reasons for this increase are clearly complex and multi-factorial; however, certain factors associated with poultry production and disease control provide possible means of strengthening prevention and response. Changes in the economy and poultry industry since 2011 have had a negative impact on food safety and the capacity of the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation (MOALR) to prevent or respond to outbreaks of disease. With the reduction in control of poultry production nationally, many small farmers have turned to raising poultry for food and income in an unmonitored and uncontrolled farming sector. Evidence suggests that H5N1 virus is deeply entrenched on such farms and in household flocks. Further, implementation of a proper control strategy is currently impeded by weak response capacity, weak public-private partnerships, sub-optimal vaccination strategies and low levels of biosecurity in some poultry production sectors. [There are] 2 excellent national laboratories that contribute significantly to the diagnosis and control of avian influenza -- the National Laboratory for Quality Control of Poultry Production and Central Laboratory for Evaluation of Veterinary Biologics; both could be used more effectively by linking diagnosis with rapid response and monitoring of disease control and vaccine use.\"\n\n\"The national HPAI Integrated National Plan for Avian and Human Influenza that was developed with support from FAO after the 2009 joint-UN evaluation mission addresses many of the current challenges, but has not been implemented. This strategy should be brought up to date and put into force. Since 2007, through USAID-funded FAO projects, considerable investment has been made to improve the animal health surveillance system in Egypt, including the establishment of 230 epidemiological units covering almost all districts and governorate; 4 animal disease surveillance systems (passive reporting, community animal health outreach, targeted live bird market reporting, and active surveillance) are maintained by the Veterinary Services. Surveillance data are regularly shared between national stakeholders and with other relevant partners (OFFLU, EMPRES-i, etc.), including through publication in peer-reviewed journals\". - Mod.AS]\nSee {"archive_id": "3364585", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (129): Palestinian Auth (WE, GZ) HPAI H5N1, resolved, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3364585", "date": "2015-05-02 10:36:34", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (106): BURKINA FASO, HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 May 2015\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/34962/seven-new-outbreaks-of-bird-flu-in-burkina-faso/\n\n\nThere have been 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza in the country.\n\nAccording to follow-up report no 2 to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), dated 29 Apr 2015, the veterinary authority in Burkina Faso reports 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 [highly pathogenic avian influenza] on poultry farms, all starting on 19 Apr 2015.\n\nMost of the affected farms were in the provinces of Kadiogo (5) and Poni (1), which have reported previous outbreaks, but Bazega in central Burkina Faso now has its 1st cases.\n\nOf the 18 264 bird affected, 16 009 died and 2255 were slaughtered.\nThe presence of the H5N1 subtype of the virus has been confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Burkina Faso, in early February 2015 (initially reported to the OIE 1 Apr 2015), a total of 18 outbreaks, in 6 provinces, have been reported to the OIE. This includes the 7 new outbreaks covered in follow-up report no. 2, submitted on 30 Apr 2015, and available (with an interactive map) at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17625.\n\nThe epizootic continues it spread in Nigeria and has spread to Niger as well. The virus spreading in the 3 countries is considered to be caused by a novel clade of the A(H5N1) virus, specifically clade 2.3.2.1c, which, according to a recent 'ahead of print' paper (see reference below), most likely entered Nigeria in December 2014. The authors further indicate that the identification of genetic clustering between the strains from Nigeria and the HPAI A(H5N1) viruses originally identified in Asia, suggests an unknown epidemiologic link between these regions, probably associated with human activities, migratory bird movements, or both. They further state that this virus is an intersubtype reassortant which has already caused infection in humans, underlining the urgent need for its complete characterization in terms of virulence and host range.\n\nA map showing all 18 outbreaks in Burkina Faso is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825.\n\nReference\n---------\nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; (21)7; http://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2107.150421. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (88): Burkina Faso, HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread 20150418.3306005\nAvian influenza (65): Burkina Faso (CO, CT) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE 20150402.3272825\nAvian influenza (41): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20150220.3181009\nAvian influenza (40): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20150216.3170856\nAvian influenza (24): poultry, Taiwan, Nigeria, HPAI H5, India, RFI 20150126.3121257\nAvian influenza (14): Nigeria (KN) poultry, HPAI H5, spread, RFI 20150118.3101333\nAvian influenza (10): Nigeria (LA) poultry, HPAI H5, OIE, RFI 20150117.3097743\nAvian influenza (06): global, H5 evolution, new clade 2.3.4.4, WHO/OIE/FAO 20150114.3090250\nAvian influenza (03): Nigeria (KN) poultry, HPAI H5, OIE 20150110.3083730\n2006\n----\nAvian influenza (121) - Burkina Faso 20060521.1442\nAvian "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (124): Israel (HZ) turkey, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3357484", "date": "2015-05-02 10:36:34", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (106): BURKINA FASO, HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 May 2015\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/34962/seven-new-outbreaks-of-bird-flu-in-burkina-faso/\n\n\nThere have been 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza in the country.\n\nAccording to follow-up report no 2 to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), dated 29 Apr 2015, the veterinary authority in Burkina Faso reports 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 [highly pathogenic avian influenza] on poultry farms, all starting on 19 Apr 2015.\n\nMost of the affected farms were in the provinces of Kadiogo (5) and Poni (1), which have reported previous outbreaks, but Bazega in central Burkina Faso now has its 1st cases.\n\nOf the 18 264 bird affected, 16 009 died and 2255 were slaughtered.\nThe presence of the H5N1 subtype of the virus has been confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Burkina Faso, in early February 2015 (initially reported to the OIE 1 Apr 2015), a total of 18 outbreaks, in 6 provinces, have been reported to the OIE. This includes the 7 new outbreaks covered in follow-up report no. 2, submitted on 30 Apr 2015, and available (with an interactive map) at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17625.\n\nThe epizootic continues it spread in Nigeria and has spread to Niger as well. The virus spreading in the 3 countries is considered to be caused by a novel clade of the A(H5N1) virus, specifically clade 2.3.2.1c, which, according to a recent 'ahead of print' paper (see reference below), most likely entered Nigeria in December 2014. The authors further indicate that the identification of genetic clustering between the strains from Nigeria and the HPAI A(H5N1) viruses originally identified in Asia, suggests an unknown epidemiologic link between these regions, probably associated with human activities, migratory bird movements, or both. They further state that this virus is an intersubtype reassortant which has already caused infection in humans, underlining the urgent need for its complete characterization in terms of virulence and host range.\n\nA map showing all 18 outbreaks in Burkina Faso is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825.\n\nReference\n---------\nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; (21)7; http://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2107.150421. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (88): spread 20150220.3181009\nAvian influenza (40): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20150216.3170856\nAvian influenza (24): poultry, Taiwan, Nigeria, HPAI H5, India, RFI 20150126.3121257\nAvian influenza (14): Nigeria (KN) poultry, HPAI H5, spread, RFI 20150118.3101333\nAvian influenza (10): Nigeria (LA) poultry, HPAI H5, OIE, RFI 20150117.3097743\nAvian influenza (06): global, H5 evolution, The authors further indicate that the identification of genetic clustering between the strains from Nigeria and the HPAI A(H5N1) viruses originally identified in Asia, suggests an unknown epidemiologic link between these regions, probably associated with human activities, migratory bird movements, or both. They further state that this virus is an intersubtype reassortant which has already caused infection in humans, underlining the urgent need for its complete characterization in terms of virulence and host range.\n\nA map showing all 18 outbreaks in Burkina Faso is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825.\n\nReference\n---------\nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. This includes the 7 new outbreaks covered in follow-up report no. 2, submitted on 30 Apr 2015, and available (with an interactive map) at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17625.\n\nThe epizootic continues it spread in Nigeria and has spread to Niger as well. The virus spreading in the 3 countries is considered to be caused by a novel clade of the A(H5N1) virus, specifically clade 2.3.2.1c, which, according to a recent 'ahead of print' paper (see reference below), most likely entered Nigeria in December 2014. The authors further indicate that the identification of genetic clustering between the strains from Nigeria and the HPAI A(H5N1) viruses originally identified in Asia, suggests an unknown epidemiologic link between these regions, probably associated with human activities, migratory bird movements, or both. They further state that this virus is an intersubtype reassortant which has already caused infection in humans, underlining the urgent need for its complete characterization in terms of virulence and host range.\n\nA map showing all 18 outbreaks in Burkina Faso is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825.\n\nReference\n---------\nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; (21)7; http://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2107.150421. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (88): Burkina Faso, HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread 20150418.3306005\nAvian influenza (65): Burkina Faso (CO, CT) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE 20150402.3272825\nAvian influenza (41): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20150220.3181009\nAvian influenza (40): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20150216.3170856\nAvian influenza (24): poultry, Taiwan, Nigeria, HPAI H5, India, RFI 20150126.3121257\nAvian influenza (14): Nigeria (KN) poultry, HPAI H5, spread, RFI 20150118.3101333\nAvian influenza (10): Nigeria (LA) poultry, HPAI H5, OIE, RFI 20150117.3097743\nAvian influenza (06): global, H5 evolution, new clade 2.3.4.4, WHO/OIE/FAO 20150114.3090250\nAvian influenza (03): Nigeria (KN) poultry, HPAI H5, OIE 20150110.3083730\n2006\n----\nAvian influenza (121) - Burkina Faso 20060521.1442\nAvian "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (107): India (MN) HPAI H5N1, poultry, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3337773", "date": "2015-05-02 10:36:34", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (106): BURKINA FASO, HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, SPREAD\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 May 2015\nSource: The Poultry Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thepoultrysite.com/poultrynews/34962/seven-new-outbreaks-of-bird-flu-in-burkina-faso/\n\n\nThere have been 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza in the country.\n\nAccording to follow-up report no 2 to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), dated 29 Apr 2015, the veterinary authority in Burkina Faso reports 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 [highly pathogenic avian influenza] on poultry farms, all starting on 19 Apr 2015.\n\nMost of the affected farms were in the provinces of Kadiogo (5) and Poni (1), which have reported previous outbreaks, but Bazega in central Burkina Faso now has its 1st cases.\n\nOf the 18 264 bird affected, 16 009 died and 2255 were slaughtered.\nThe presence of the H5N1 subtype of the virus has been confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Burkina Faso, in early February 2015 (initially reported to the OIE 1 Apr 2015), a total of 18 outbreaks, in 6 provinces, have been reported to the OIE. This includes the 7 new outbreaks covered in follow-up report no. 2, submitted on 30 Apr 2015, and available (with an interactive map) at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17625.\n\nThe epizootic continues it spread in Nigeria and has spread to Niger as well. The virus spreading in the 3 countries is considered to be caused by a novel clade of the A(H5N1) virus, specifically clade 2.3.2.1c, which, according to a recent 'ahead of print' paper (see reference below), most likely entered Nigeria in December 2014. The authors further indicate that the identification of genetic clustering between the strains from Nigeria and the HPAI A(H5N1) viruses originally identified in Asia, suggests an unknown epidemiologic link between these regions, probably associated with human activities, migratory bird movements, or both. They further state that this virus is an intersubtype reassortant which has already caused infection in humans, underlining the urgent need for its complete characterization in terms of virulence and host range.\n\nA map showing all 18 outbreaks in Burkina Faso is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825.\n\nReference\n---------\nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; (21)7; http://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2107.150421. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/49.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (88): spread 20150220.3181009\nAvian influenza (40): Nigeria, poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread 20150216.3170856\nAvian influenza (24): poultry, Taiwan, Nigeria, HPAI H5, India, RFI 20150126.3121257\nAvian influenza (14): Nigeria (KN) poultry, HPAI H5, spread, RFI 20150118.3101333\nAvian influenza (10): Nigeria (LA) poultry, HPAI H5, OIE, RFI 20150117.3097743\nAvian influenza (06): global, H5 evolution, country.\n\nAccording to follow-up report no 2 to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), dated 29 Apr 2015, the veterinary authority in Burkina Faso reports 7 new outbreaks of H5N1 [highly confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the start of the current HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Burkina Faso, in early February 2015 (initially reported to the OIE 1 Apr 2015), a total of 18 outbreaks, in 6 provinces, have been reported to the OIE. This includes the 7 new outbreaks covered in follow-up report no. 2, submitted on 30 Apr 2015, and available (with an interactive map) at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=17625.\n\nThe epizootic continues it spread in Nigeria and has spread to Niger as well. The virus spreading in the 3 countries is considered to be caused by a novel clade of the A(H5N1) virus, specifically clade 2.3.2.1c, which, according to a recent 'ahead of print' paper (see reference below), most likely entered Nigeria in December 2014. The authors further indicate that the identification of genetic clustering between the strains from Nigeria and the HPAI A(H5N1) viruses originally identified in Asia, suggests an unknown epidemiologic link between these regions, probably associated with human activities, migratory bird movements, or both. They further state that this virus is an intersubtype reassortant which has already caused infection in humans, underlining the urgent need for its complete characterization in terms of virulence and host range.\n\nA map showing all 18 outbreaks in Burkina Faso is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=17455.\n\nFor further background, please refer to the commentary by Mod.CRD in ProMED-mail posting 20150402.3272825.\n\nReference\n---------\nMonne I, Meseko C, Joannis T, et al: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in poultry, Nigeria, 2015 [letter]. "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (97): Egypt, H5N1, poultry", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3334280", "date": "2015-04-16 21:30:21", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (84): BHUTAN (THIMPHU) BACKYARD POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2015; 28 (16) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17533\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bhutan\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Apr 2015 from Dr Tashi Samdup, Director, Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture and Forests, Thimphu, Bhutan\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 17 Apr 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Motithang City Camp, Thimphu Thromde, Thimphu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 37 / 16 / 16 / 21 / 0\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 43.24 / 43.24 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: The outbreak has occurred in a backyard, free-ranging poultry population. While interviewing the owners of the birds, none of the mentioned source of infection could be ascertained. Further investigation on the source of infection will be followed-up. A host-pathogen interaction particularly in this case would be potential research topic. Only a small number of birds in an isolated pocket were affected. No further infection in flocks in close proximity was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Centre for Animal Health, Serbithang, Thimphu (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 6 Apr 2015 / Positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 14 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2012, Bhutan reported 14 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1. The event was resolved 17 Apr 2013. The event summary and map are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=11465.\n\nFor this current outbreak, the source of infection has not been determined. According to comments made in the epidemiologic section of the report, \"none of the mentioned sources of infection could be ascertained.\" However, one should note that for the event reported in 2012, the introduction of new animals and the illegal movement of animals were identified as the source of infection. For this outbreak reported in Thimphu, these sources as well as the role of wildlife should not be completely discounted, especially given the occurrence of HPAI in the area.\n\nBhutan, officially the Kingdom of Bhutan, is a landlocked country in South Asia at the eastern end of the Himalayas. It is bordered to the north by China and to the south, east and west by India. To the west, it is separated from Nepal by the Indian state of Sikkim, while farther south it is separated from Bangladesh by the Indian states of Assam and West Bengal (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutan).\n\nSee a map of Bhutan at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/Bhutan_CIA_WFB_2010_map.png. - Mod.CRD]\n\n[Backyard poultry in Thrimshing, Bhutan:\nhttp://rocky.ess.washington.edu/areas/Bhutan/slm_photos/thrimshing/poultry%20farming.jpg - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1517.]\nSee HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread 20150306.3211783\nAvian influenza (46): Myanmar (SA) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE, RFI 20150302.3202068\nAvian influenza (43): China (GX) tiger, HPAI H5N1, OIE "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3314939", "date": "2015-04-16 21:30:21", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (84): BHUTAN (THIMPHU) BACKYARD POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2015; 28 (16) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17533\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bhutan\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Apr 2015 from Dr Tashi Samdup, Director, Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture and Forests, Thimphu, Bhutan\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 17 Apr 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Motithang City Camp, Thimphu Thromde, Thimphu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 37 / 16 / 16 / 21 / 0\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 43.24 / 43.24 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: The outbreak has occurred in a backyard, free-ranging poultry population. While interviewing the owners of the birds, none of the mentioned source of infection could be ascertained. Further investigation on the source of infection will be followed-up. A host-pathogen interaction particularly in this case would be potential research topic. Only a small number of birds in an isolated pocket were affected. No further infection in flocks in close proximity was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Centre for Animal Health, Serbithang, Thimphu (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 6 Apr 2015 / Positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 14 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2012, Bhutan reported 14 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1. The event was resolved 17 Apr 2013. The event summary and map are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=11465.\n\nFor this current outbreak, the source of infection has not been determined. According to comments made in the epidemiologic section of the report, \"none of the mentioned sources of infection could be ascertained.\" However, one should note that for the event reported in 2012, the introduction of new animals and the illegal movement of animals were identified as the source of infection. For this outbreak reported in Thimphu, these sources as well as the role of wildlife should not be completely discounted, especially given the occurrence of HPAI in the area.\n\nBhutan, officially the Kingdom of Bhutan, is a landlocked country in South Asia at the eastern end of the Himalayas. It is bordered to the north by China and to the south, east and west by India. To the west, it is separated from Nepal by the Indian state of Sikkim, while farther south it is separated from Bangladesh by the Indian states of Assam and West Bengal (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutan).\n\nSee a map of Bhutan at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/Bhutan_CIA_WFB_2010_map.png. - Mod.CRD]\n\n[Backyard poultry in Thrimshing, Bhutan:\nhttp://rocky.ess.washington.edu/areas/Bhutan/slm_photos/thrimshing/poultry%20farming.jpg - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1517.]\nSee HPAI H5N1, poultry, spread 20150306.3211783\nAvian influenza (46): Myanmar (SA) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE, RFI 20150302.3202068\nAvian influenza (43): China (GX) tiger, HPAI H5N1, OIE 20150226.3194224\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza, human (128): India (CH,UP) H5N1, susp 20141223.3051376\nAvian influenza (113): India (CH) H5N1, ducks, OIE, RFI 20141219.3043523\nAvian influenza (96): Bhutan\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Apr 2015 from Dr Tashi Samdup, Director, Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture and Forests, Thimphu, Bhutan\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 17 Apr 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Motithang City Camp, Thimphu Thromde, Thimphu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 37 / 16 / 16 / 21 / 0\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 43.24 / 43.24 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: The outbreak has occurred in a backyard, free-ranging poultry population. While interviewing the owners of the birds, none of the mentioned source of infection could be ascertained. Further investigation on the source of infection will be followed-up. A host-pathogen interaction particularly in this case would be potential research topic. Only a small number of birds in an isolated pocket were affected. No further infection in flocks in close proximity was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Centre for Animal Health, Serbithang, Thimphu (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 6 Apr 2015 / Positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 14 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2012, Bhutan reported 14 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1. According to comments made in the epidemiologic section of the report, \"none of the mentioned sources of infection could be ascertained.\" However, one should note that for the event reported in 2012, the introduction of new animals and the illegal movement of animals were identified as the source of infection. For this outbreak reported in Thimphu, these sources as well as the role of wildlife should not be completely discounted, especially given the occurrence of HPAI in the area.\n\nBhutan, officially the Kingdom of Bhutan, is a landlocked country in South Asia at the eastern end of the Himalayas. Thimphu, Bhutan\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 17 Apr 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Motithang City Camp, Thimphu Thromde, Thimphu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 37 / 16 / 16 / 21 / 0\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 43.24 / 43.24 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: The outbreak has occurred in a backyard, free-ranging poultry population. While interviewing the owners of the birds, none of the mentioned source of infection could be ascertained. Further investigation on the source of infection will be followed-up. A host-pathogen interaction particularly in this case would be potential research topic. Only a small number of birds in an isolated pocket were affected. No further infection in flocks in close proximity was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Centre for Animal Health, Serbithang, Thimphu (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 6 Apr 2015 / Positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 14 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2012, Bhutan reported 14 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1. The event was resolved 17 Apr 2013. The event summary and map are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=11465.\n\nFor this current outbreak, the source of infection has not been determined. According to comments made in the epidemiologic section of the report, \"none of the mentioned sources of infection could be ascertained.\" However, one should note that for the event reported in 2012, the introduction of new animals and the illegal movement of animals were identified as the source of infection. For this outbreak reported in Thimphu, these sources as well as the role of wildlife should not be completely discounted, especially given the occurrence of HPAI in the area.\n\nBhutan, officially the Kingdom of Bhutan, is a landlocked country in South Asia at the eastern end of the Himalayas. It is bordered to the north by China and to the south, east and west by India. To the west, it is separated from Nepal by the Indian state of Sikkim, while farther south it is separated from Bangladesh by the Indian states of Assam and West Bengal (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutan).\n\nSee a map of Bhutan at http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/Bhutan_CIA_WFB_2010_map.png. - Mod.CRD]\n\n[Backyard poultry in Thrimshing, Bhutan\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 16 Apr 2015 from Dr Tashi Samdup, Director, Department of Livestock, Ministry of Agriculture and Forests, Thimphu, Bhutan\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 3 Apr 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 17 Apr 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Motithang City Camp, Thimphu Thromde, Thimphu\nDate of start of the outbreak: 3 Apr 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 37 / 16 / 16 / 21 / 0\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 43.24 / 43.24 / 100 / 100\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comment: The outbreak has occurred in a backyard, free-ranging poultry population. While interviewing the owners of the birds, none of the mentioned source of infection could be ascertained. Further investigation on the source of infection will be followed-up. A host-pathogen interaction particularly in this case would be potential research topic. Only a small number of birds in an isolated pocket were affected. No further infection in flocks in close proximity was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Centre for Animal Health, Serbithang, Thimphu (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 6 Apr 2015 / Positive\nNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE's Reference Laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 14 Apr 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2012, Bhutan reported 14 outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1. The event summary and map are available at: http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=11465.\n\nFor this current outbreak, the source of infection has not been determined. According to comments made in the epidemiologic section of the report, \"none of the mentioned sources of infection could be ascertained.\" However, one should note that for the event reported in 2012, the introduction of new animals and the illegal movement of animals were identified as the source of infection. For this outbreak reported in Thimphu, these sources as well as the role of wildlife should not be completely discounted, especially given the occurrence of HPAI in the area.\n\nBhutan, officially the Kingdom of Bhutan, is a landlocked country in South Asia at the eastern end of the Himalayas. "locations": [{"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Bhutan", "country": "Bhutan"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Motithang City Camp", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "TG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, "Thrimshing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3301012", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (93): WHO update H5N1 and H7N9, China H7N9", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3301012", "date": "2015-04-02 20:51:16", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (81): GENETIC CHANGES H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Apr 2015\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\n\nEmergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nA distinct cluster of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype A(H5N1) has been found to emerge within clade 2.2.1.2 in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and appears to have quickly become predominant. Viruses of this cluster may be associated with increased incidence of human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt over the last months.\n\nIn Egypt, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) influenza A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.2.1 and their descendants have been circulating in poultry populations since 2006, causing sporadic human infections [1]. Human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt have been reported since the introduction of the virus in 2006 with \u2009204 cases occurring until end of 2014 and a fatality rate of 35.8 percent in laboratory-confirmed cases reported to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, since January 2015, the incidence of human H5N1 cases in Egypt has increased dramatically: as of 21 March 2015, 116 human cases including 36 deaths have been reported to WHO [2]. This study was initiated to analyse molecular properties of H5N1 viruses that have caused outbreaks in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and to compare them with published sequences from H5N1 viruses obtained from recent human cases. ... [more]\n\nTable 1. Influenza A(H5N1) viruses included in this study and collected from poultry, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\nTable 2. Antigenic characterisation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from Egypt and elsewhere, based on haemagglutination inhibition assays\nTable 3. Amino acid residues distinguishing recently emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from virus lineages circulating before November 2014, Egypt, March 2015\nFigure 1. Temporal (graph) and geographic (map) distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry, Egypt, October 2014-February 2015 (n=435)\nFigure 2. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA (A) and NA (B) genes (coding regions) and maximum clade credibility tree (C) based on the HA open reading frame of selected highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n\n1. Abdelwhab EM, Hafez HM. An overview of the epidemic of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus in Egypt: epidemiology and control challenges. Epidemiol Infect. 2011;139(5):647-57. http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S0950268810003122 PMID:21281550\n2. World Health Organization (WHO). Avian influenza A (H5N1) in Egypt update, 21 March 2015. Geneva: WHO. [Accessed: 2 Apr 2015]. Available from: http://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/avian-influenza-a-h5n1-in-egypt-update-21-march-2015.html\n... [more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015;20(13):pii=21085. Available online: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\nReaders are referred to the full text and figures available at the above URL.\n\nAccording to FluTrackers, the current tally of human H5N1 cases in Egypt is 128 (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links), a number greater than the 116 quoted above by WHO. In addition, there have been heavy losses in poultry due to high infection rates. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza,
