(79): Palestinian Auth (GZ) HPAI H5N1, spread, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3297762", "date": "2015-04-02 20:51:16", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (81): GENETIC CHANGES H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Apr 2015\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\n\nEmergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nA distinct cluster of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype A(H5N1) has been found to emerge within clade 2.2.1.2 in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and appears to have quickly become predominant. Viruses of this cluster may be associated with increased incidence of human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt over the last months.\n\nIn Egypt, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) influenza A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.2.1 and their descendants have been circulating in poultry populations since 2006, causing sporadic human infections [1]. Human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt have been reported since the introduction of the virus in 2006 with \u2009204 cases occurring until end of 2014 and a fatality rate of 35.8 percent in laboratory-confirmed cases reported to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, since January 2015, the incidence of human H5N1 cases in Egypt has increased dramatically: as of 21 March 2015, 116 human cases including 36 deaths have been reported to WHO [2]. This study was initiated to analyse molecular properties of H5N1 viruses that have caused outbreaks in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and to compare them with published sequences from H5N1 viruses obtained from recent human cases. ... [more]\n\nTable 1. Influenza A(H5N1) viruses included in this study and collected from poultry, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\nTable 2. Antigenic characterisation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from Egypt and elsewhere, based on haemagglutination inhibition assays\nTable 3. Amino acid residues distinguishing recently emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from virus lineages circulating before November 2014, Egypt, March 2015\nFigure 1. Temporal (graph) and geographic (map) distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry, Egypt, October 2014-February 2015 (n=435)\nFigure 2. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA (A) and NA (B) genes (coding regions) and maximum clade credibility tree (C) based on the HA open reading frame of selected highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n\n1. Abdelwhab EM, Hafez HM. An overview of the epidemic of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus in Egypt: epidemiology and control challenges. Epidemiol Infect. 2011;139(5):647-57. http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S0950268810003122 PMID:21281550\n2. World Health Organization (WHO). Avian influenza A (H5N1) in Egypt update, 21 March 2015. Geneva: WHO. [Accessed: 2 Apr 2015]. Available from: http://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/avian-influenza-a-h5n1-in-egypt-update-21-march-2015.html\n... [more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015;20(13):pii=21085. Available online: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\nReaders are referred to the full text and figures available at the above URL.\n\nAccording to FluTrackers, the current tally of human H5N1 cases in Egypt is 128 (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links), a number greater than the 116 quoted above by WHO. In addition, there have been heavy losses in poultry due to high infection rates. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "JX", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3295430", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (92): ECDC update, H5N1 genetics", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3295430", "date": "2015-04-02 20:51:16", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (81): GENETIC CHANGES H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Apr 2015\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\n\nEmergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nA distinct cluster of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype A(H5N1) has been found to emerge within clade 2.2.1.2 in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and appears to have quickly become predominant. Viruses of this cluster may be associated with increased incidence of human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt over the last months.\n\nIn Egypt, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) influenza A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.2.1 and their descendants have been circulating in poultry populations since 2006, causing sporadic human infections [1]. Human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt have been reported since the introduction of the virus in 2006 with \u2009204 cases occurring until end of 2014 and a fatality rate of 35.8 percent in laboratory-confirmed cases reported to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, since January 2015, the incidence of human H5N1 cases in Egypt has increased dramatically: as of 21 March 2015, 116 human cases including 36 deaths have been reported to WHO [2]. This study was initiated to analyse molecular properties of H5N1 viruses that have caused outbreaks in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and to compare them with published sequences from H5N1 viruses obtained from recent human cases. ... [more]\n\nTable 1. Influenza A(H5N1) viruses included in this study and collected from poultry, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\nTable 2. Antigenic characterisation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from Egypt and elsewhere, based on haemagglutination inhibition assays\nTable 3. Amino acid residues distinguishing recently emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from virus lineages circulating before November 2014, Egypt, March 2015\nFigure 1. Temporal (graph) and geographic (map) distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry, Egypt, October 2014-February 2015 (n=435)\nFigure 2. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA (A) and NA (B) genes (coding regions) and maximum clade credibility tree (C) based on the HA open reading frame of selected highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n\n1. Abdelwhab EM, Hafez HM. An overview of the epidemic of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus in Egypt: epidemiology and control challenges. Epidemiol Infect. 2011;139(5):647-57. http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S0950268810003122 PMID:21281550\n2. World Health Organization (WHO). Avian influenza A (H5N1) in Egypt update, 21 March 2015. Geneva: WHO. [Accessed: 2 Apr 2015]. Available from: http://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/avian-influenza-a-h5n1-in-egypt-update-21-march-2015.html\n... [more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015;20(13):pii=21085. Available online: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\nReaders are referred to the full text and figures available at the above URL.\n\nAccording to FluTrackers, the current tally of human H5N1 cases in Egypt is 128 (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links), a number greater than the 116 quoted above by WHO. In addition, there have been heavy losses in poultry due to high infection rates. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, In addition, there have been heavy losses in poultry due to high infection rates. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "JX", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3285745", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (88): Egypt H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3285745", "date": "2015-04-02 20:51:16", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (81): GENETIC CHANGES H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Apr 2015\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\n\nEmergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nA distinct cluster of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype A(H5N1) has been found to emerge within clade 2.2.1.2 in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and appears to have quickly become predominant. Viruses of this cluster may be associated with increased incidence of human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt over the last months.\n\nIn Egypt, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) influenza A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.2.1 and their descendants have been circulating in poultry populations since 2006, causing sporadic human infections [1]. Human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt have been reported since the introduction of the virus in 2006 with \u2009204 cases occurring until end of 2014 and a fatality rate of 35.8 percent in laboratory-confirmed cases reported to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, since January 2015, the incidence of human H5N1 cases in Egypt has increased dramatically: as of 21 March 2015, 116 human cases including 36 deaths have been reported to WHO [2]. This study was initiated to analyse molecular properties of H5N1 viruses that have caused outbreaks in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and to compare them with published sequences from H5N1 viruses obtained from recent human cases. ... [more]\n\nTable 1. Influenza A(H5N1) viruses included in this study and collected from poultry, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\nTable 2. Antigenic characterisation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from Egypt and elsewhere, based on haemagglutination inhibition assays\nTable 3. Amino acid residues distinguishing recently emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from virus lineages circulating before November 2014, Egypt, March 2015\nFigure 1. Temporal (graph) and geographic (map) distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry, Egypt, October 2014-February 2015 (n=435)\nFigure 2. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA (A) and NA (B) genes (coding regions) and maximum clade credibility tree (C) based on the HA open reading frame of selected highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n\n1. Abdelwhab EM, Hafez HM. An overview of the epidemic of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus in Egypt: epidemiology and control challenges. Epidemiol Infect. 2011;139(5):647-57. http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S0950268810003122 PMID:21281550\n2. World Health Organization (WHO). Avian influenza A (H5N1) in Egypt update, 21 March 2015. Geneva: WHO. [Accessed: 2 Apr 2015]. Available from: http://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/avian-influenza-a-h5n1-in-egypt-update-21-march-2015.html\n... [more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015;20(13):pii=21085. Available online: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\nReaders are referred to the full text and figures available at the above URL.\n\nAccording to FluTrackers, the current tally of human H5N1 cases in Egypt is 128 (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links), a number greater than the 116 quoted above by WHO. In addition, there have been heavy losses in poultry due to high infection rates. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "JX", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3274191", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (81): genetic changes H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3274191", "date": "2015-04-02 20:51:16", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (81): GENETIC CHANGES H5N1\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Apr 2015\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\n\nEmergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nA distinct cluster of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of subtype A(H5N1) has been found to emerge within clade 2.2.1.2 in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and appears to have quickly become predominant. Viruses of this cluster may be associated with increased incidence of human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt over the last months.\n\nIn Egypt, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) influenza A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.2.1 and their descendants have been circulating in poultry populations since 2006, causing sporadic human infections [1]. Human influenza A(H5N1) infections in Egypt have been reported since the introduction of the virus in 2006 with \u2009204 cases occurring until end of 2014 and a fatality rate of 35.8 percent in laboratory-confirmed cases reported to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, since January 2015, the incidence of human H5N1 cases in Egypt has increased dramatically: as of 21 March 2015, 116 human cases including 36 deaths have been reported to WHO [2]. This study was initiated to analyse molecular properties of H5N1 viruses that have caused outbreaks in poultry in Egypt since summer 2014 and to compare them with published sequences from H5N1 viruses obtained from recent human cases. ... [more]\n\nTable 1. Influenza A(H5N1) viruses included in this study and collected from poultry, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\nTable 2. Antigenic characterisation of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from Egypt and elsewhere, based on haemagglutination inhibition assays\nTable 3. Amino acid residues distinguishing recently emerging highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses from virus lineages circulating before November 2014, Egypt, March 2015\nFigure 1. Temporal (graph) and geographic (map) distribution of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry, Egypt, October 2014-February 2015 (n=435)\nFigure 2. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA (A) and NA (B) genes (coding regions) and maximum clade credibility tree (C) based on the HA open reading frame of selected highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Egypt, June 2014-January 2015 (n=29)\n\n1. Abdelwhab EM, Hafez HM. An overview of the epidemic of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus in Egypt: epidemiology and control challenges. Epidemiol Infect. 2011;139(5):647-57. http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S0950268810003122 PMID:21281550\n2. World Health Organization (WHO). Avian influenza A (H5N1) in Egypt update, 21 March 2015. Geneva: WHO. [Accessed: 2 Apr 2015]. Available from: http://www.emro.who.int/surveillance-forecasting-response/surveillance-news/avian-influenza-a-h5n1-in-egypt-update-21-march-2015.html\n... [more]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arafa AS, Naguib MM, Luttermann C, Selim AA, Kilany WH, Hagag N, Samy A, Abdelhalim A, Hassan MK, Abdelwhab EM, Makonnen Y, Dauphin G, Lubroth J, Mettenleiter TC, Beer M, Grund C, Harder TC. Emergence of a novel cluster of influenza A(H5N1) virus clade 2.2.1.2 with putative human health impact in Egypt, 2014/15. Euro Surveill. 2015;20(13):pii=21085. Available online: http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21085\n\nReaders are referred to the full text and figures available at the above URL.\n\nAccording to FluTrackers, the current tally of human H5N1 cases in Egypt is 128 (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links), a number greater than the 116 quoted above by WHO. In addition, there have been heavy losses in poultry due to high infection rates. 435 outbreaks of H5N1 infections in poultry in Egypt are noted in this paper between October 2014 and February 2015, as reported to the National Laboratory for Quality Control on Poultry Production (NLQP) by Egyptian veterinary authorities. Therefore, it cannot be ruled out that this increased level of transmission in the birds in Egypt (which includes chickens, ducks, turkeys and quail) has led to increased exposure of bird handlers and buyers and backyard bird owners, and consequently increased numbers of cases. However, another possibility proposed by this paper is that the genetic changes observed in the 2015 viruses have led to greater transmissibility of the virus. The investigators found that strains analyzed since November 2014 contain distinct fixed mutations in several genome segments PB2, PB1-F2, HA, NA, M1. The emerging cluster identified in this study seems to be predominant across all poultry production sectors and has already caused 1/3rd of all human H5N1 infections reported in Egypt since 2006, in only 3 months of 2015.\n\nBut questions remain -- what are the molecular determinants that increase fitness of these viruses? What are the selective pressures acting on the virus? Are the observed genetic changes random, or is natural selection acting to favor mutations that make the virus more transmissible? Studies of the pathogenicity and transmissibility of these viruses, most likely using the ferret model, need to be conducted to answer the question of whether the genetic changes are affecting the current outbreak.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, testing. He thought there may be lower numbers suspected of having bird flu as a result of high temperatures, which facilitate the disappearance of the virus.\n\nThere will be regular meetings held with officials of preventive medicine in various departments to raise awareness of the dangers of dealing directly with the birds, emphasizing the full safety of the citizens. edited]\nhttps://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/727803-egypt-8-people-hospitalized-suspected-h5n1-bird-flu-in-menoufia-tests-pending-march-24-2015\n\n\nDr. Reza, Director of the Preventive Medicine Department of the Directorate of Health, province of Menoufia, announced he was detaining 8 suspected cases of bird flu, with samples to be sent to labs in central Cairo for testing. He thought there may be lower numbers suspected of having bird flu as a result of high temperatures, which facilitate the disappearance of the virus.\n\nThere will be regular meetings held with officials of preventive medicine in various departments to raise awareness of the dangers of dealing directly with the birds, emphasizing the full safety of the citizens. He admonished all citizens to be aware of dealing with any birds suspected of being infected with the virus, stressing the need for immediate reporting in case of any suspicion of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at edited]\nhttps://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/egypt/h5n1-tracking-egypt/727803-egypt-8-people-hospitalized-suspected-h5n1-bird-flu-in-menoufia-tests-pending-march-24-2015\n\n\nDr. Reza, Director of the Preventive Medicine Department of the Directorate of Health, province of Menoufia, announced he was detaining 8 suspected cases of bird flu, with samples to be sent to labs in central Cairo for testing. He thought there may be lower numbers suspected of having bird flu as a result of high temperatures, which facilitate the disappearance of the virus.\n\nThere will be regular meetings held with officials of preventive medicine in various departments to raise awareness of the dangers of dealing directly with the birds, emphasizing the full safety of the citizens. He admonished all citizens to be aware of dealing with any birds suspected of being infected with the virus, stressing the need for immediate reporting in case of any suspicion of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Egypt can be seen at H5N1\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 7 Mar 2015\nSource: Avian Flu diary via Aswat Asriya [in Arabic, trans. edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com/\n\n\nEgypt's ministry of health reported on Sat [7 Mar 2015] the deaths of 2 women infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus, the state news agency MENA reported. The women are from the governorates of Menufia and Sharqiya the Health Ministry said in a statement reported by MENA.\n\nThe virus has killed over a dozen this year [2015] alone, according to Health Ministry figures.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the FAO/WHO, as of more than 2 weeks ago, there has been a net increase of 108 cases and 39 deaths since 1 Nov 2014. The Flutrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links) tally of cases is currently 82 (without evidence of these 2 latest cases) since the start of 2015.\n\nIt has been extremely difficult to find accurate numbers of H5N1 cases in Egypt in 2015, even with searches of multiple sites. There are discrepant case numbers reported by WHO, the Egyptian Ministry of Health, and FluTrackers.\n\nA map of Egypt may be found at http://www.mapsofworld.com/egypt/google-map.html.\n\nA Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 7 Mar 2015\nSource: Avian Flu diary via Aswat Asriya [in Arabic, trans. edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com/\n\n\nEgypt's ministry of health reported on Sat [7 Mar 2015] the deaths of 2 women infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus, the state news agency MENA reported. The women are from the governorates of Menufia and Sharqiya the Health Ministry said in a statement reported by MENA.\n\nThe virus has killed over a dozen this year [2015] alone, according to Health Ministry figures.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the FAO/WHO, as of more than 2 weeks ago, there has been a net increase of 108 cases and 39 deaths since 1 Nov 2014. The Flutrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links) tally of cases is currently 82 (without evidence of these 2 latest cases) since the start of 2015.\n\nIt has been extremely difficult to find accurate numbers of H5N1 cases in Egypt in 2015, even with searches of multiple sites. There are discrepant case numbers reported by WHO, the Egyptian Ministry of Health, and FluTrackers.\n\nA map of Egypt may be found at http://www.mapsofworld.com/egypt/google-map.html.\n\nA Sat [7 Mar 2015] the deaths of 2 women infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus, the state news agency MENA reported. The Flutrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links) tally of cases is currently 82 (without evidence of these 2 latest cases) since the start of 2015.\n\nIt has been extremely difficult to find accurate numbers of H5N1 cases in Egypt in 2015, even with searches of multiple sites. There are discrepant case numbers reported by WHO, the Egyptian Ministry of Health, and FluTrackers.\n\nA map of Egypt may be found at http://www.mapsofworld.com/egypt/google-map.html.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (64): China (GD) H7N9 2150307.3214917\nAvian influenza, human (63): China H5N1\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 7 Mar 2015\nSource: Avian Flu diary via Aswat Asriya [in Arabic, trans. edited]\nhttp://afludiary.blogspot.com/\n\n\nEgypt's ministry of health reported on Sat [7 Mar 2015] the deaths of 2 women infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus, the state news agency MENA reported. The women are from the governorates of Menufia and Sharqiya the Health Ministry said in a statement reported by MENA.\n\nThe virus has killed over a dozen this year [2015] alone, according to Health Ministry figures.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the FAO/WHO, as of more than 2 weeks ago, there has been a net increase of 108 cases and 39 deaths since 1 Nov 2014. The Flutrackers (https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h7n9-outbreak-tracking/143874-flutrackers-2013-15-human-case-list-of-provincial-ministry-of-health-government-confirmed-influenza-a-h7n9-cases-with-links) tally of cases is currently 82 (without evidence of these 2 latest cases) since the start of 2015.\n\nIt has been extremely difficult to find accurate numbers of H5N1 cases in Egypt in 2015, even with searches of multiple sites. There are discrepant case numbers reported by WHO, the Egyptian Ministry of Health, and FluTrackers.\n\nA map of Egypt may be found at http://www.mapsofworld.com/egypt/google-map.html.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (64): China (GD) H7N9 2150307.3214917\nAvian influenza, human (63): China "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3211783", "date": "2015-01-29 17:31:16", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (27): BULGARIA (BURGAS) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Jan 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2015; 28(05) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17083\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bulgaria\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 28 Jan 2015 from Pr Nikola T Belev, OIE Delegate, OIE Regional Representation for Eastern Europe, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Jan 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 26 Jan 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2010\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Burgas, Burgas\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nDalmatian pelican: _Pelecanus crispus_ (Pelecanidae) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\nEpidemiological comment: Dalmatian pelican (_Pelecanus crispus_) real-time PCR positive for HPAI subtype H5N1 was found dead on [22 Jan 2015] in Poda Protected Area [located on the southeastern Bulgarian Black Sea Coast]. The samples will be tested for confirmation by inoculation of chicken embryos. The pelican was found dead together with a black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_) in the framework of the passive surveillance under the national avian influenza surveillance and control program approved by European Commission. The black-headed gull was tested with negative result for avian influenza.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; screening; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for avian influenza and Newcastle disease (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / real-time (PCR) / 26 Jan 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The spatial spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 and its long-term persistence in Asia since 1996 have resulted in avian influenza outbreaks across Eurasia and Africa and enormous economic losses in the poultry sector.\n\nIn Eastern Europe, there have been several wild bird incidents of HPAI H5N1. There are migratory linkages between breeding and moulting areas in northern Kazakhstan and southern Siberia, with nonbreeding areas in the Caspian, Black, and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins. There are frequent movements of wild waterfowl between Kazakhstan and the Caspian Sea, Black Sea and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins during the autumn migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18239. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (21): Palestinian Auth. (WE), Israel (HA), poultry, H5N1, RFI 20150124.3116798\nAvian influenza (17): Palestinian Auth. (WE), turkey, HPAI H5, OIE 20150121.3108879\nAvian influenza (15): Israel (HA) turkey, HPAI H5N1, conf, OIE 20150119.3102962\nAvian influenza (12): Israel (HA) turkey, HPAI H5N1, RFI 20150117.3099260\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza (117): Europe, HPAI H5N8 & H5N1, routes of spread 20141227.3056665\n2010\n----\nAvian influenza (23): Bulgaria, wild bird, conf. OIE 20100404.1083\nAvian influenza, poultry vs migratory birds (02) 20100402.1063\nAvian influenza, poultry vs migratory birds - Bulgaria 20100331.1022\nAvian influenza (21): Bulgaria, wild bird, susp. 28(05) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17083\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bulgaria\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 28 Jan 2015 from Pr Nikola T Belev, OIE Delegate, OIE Regional Representation for Eastern Europe, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Jan 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 26 Jan 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2010\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Burgas, Burgas\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nDalmatian pelican: _Pelecanus crispus_ (Pelecanidae) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\nEpidemiological comment: Dalmatian pelican (_Pelecanus crispus_) real-time PCR positive for HPAI subtype H5N1 was found dead on [22 Jan 2015] in Poda Protected Area [located on the southeastern Bulgarian Black Sea Coast]. The samples will be tested for confirmation by inoculation of chicken embryos. The pelican was found dead together with a black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_) in the framework of the passive surveillance under the national avian influenza surveillance and control program approved by European Commission. The black-headed gull was tested with negative result for avian influenza.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; screening; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for avian influenza and Newcastle disease (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / real-time (PCR) / 26 Jan 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The spatial spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 and its long-term persistence in Asia since 1996 have resulted in avian influenza outbreaks across Eurasia and Africa and enormous economic losses in the poultry sector.\n\nIn Eastern Europe, there have been several wild bird incidents of HPAI H5N1. There are migratory linkages between breeding and moulting areas in northern Kazakhstan and southern Siberia, with nonbreeding areas in the Caspian, Black, and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins. There are frequent movements of wild waterfowl between Kazakhstan and the Caspian Sea, Black Sea and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins during the autumn migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18239. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (21): Palestinian Auth. 28(05) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=17083\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Bulgaria\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 28 Jan 2015 from Pr Nikola T Belev, OIE Delegate, OIE Regional Representation for Eastern Europe, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Jan 2015\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 26 Jan 2015\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2010\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Burgas, Burgas\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Jan 2015\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nDalmatian pelican: _Pelecanus crispus_ (Pelecanidae) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\nEpidemiological comment: Dalmatian pelican (_Pelecanus crispus_) real-time PCR positive for HPAI subtype H5N1 was found dead on [22 Jan 2015] in Poda Protected Area [located on the southeastern Bulgarian Black Sea Coast]. The samples will be tested for confirmation by inoculation of chicken embryos. The pelican was found dead together with a black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_) in the framework of the passive surveillance under the national avian influenza surveillance and control program approved by European Commission. The black-headed gull was tested with negative result for avian influenza.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; screening; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for avian influenza and Newcastle disease (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / real-time (PCR) / 26 Jan 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The spatial spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 and its long-term persistence in Asia since 1996 have resulted in avian influenza outbreaks across Eurasia and Africa and enormous economic losses in the poultry sector.\n\nIn Eastern Europe, there have been several wild bird incidents of HPAI H5N1. There are migratory linkages between breeding and moulting areas in northern Kazakhstan and southern Siberia, with nonbreeding areas in the Caspian, Black, and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins. There are frequent movements of wild waterfowl between Kazakhstan and the Caspian Sea, Black Sea and eastern Mediterranean Sea basins during the autumn migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18239. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (21): Palestinian Auth. The samples will be tested for confirmation by inoculation of chicken embryos. The pelican was found dead together with a black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_) in the framework of the passive surveillance under the national avian influenza surveillance and control program approved by European Commission. The black-headed gull was tested with negative result for avian influenza.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; screening; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory for avian influenza and Newcastle disease (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Dalmatian pelican / real-time (PCR) / 26 Jan 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. [The death of the 47 year old woman was reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp. 20150119.3103703. This report adds the child's death. - Mod.LK]\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. Both Assiut and Minya provinces are rural areas that have seen a number of bird flu cases in the past year. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. This includes 5 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 9 cases still under treatment, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. At least 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. The WHO said last week that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015 there were 18 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country.\n\nThe WHO says that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers tend to raise and slaughter poultry themselves.\n\n[Byline: Shadi Bushra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Thus far, there have been no credible reports suggesting community spread of the virus, and nearly all appear to have had direct contact with infected poultry.\n\nThe Egyptian Government has announced the creation of a high-level \"Supreme National Committee On Bird Flu\", ordered by the Chairman of the Council of Ministers, to be chaired the 1st year by the Minister of Agriculture (http://afludiary.blogspot.ch/2015/01/egypt-government-statements-on-h5n1.html).\n\nMaps of Egypt an be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (15): WHO update, China (GD) H7N9 EGYPT (MINYA, ASSIUT) H5N1 FATALITIES\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/19/health-birdflu-egypt-idUSL6N0UY3GZ20150119\n\n\nAn [The death of the 47 year old woman was reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp. 20150119.3103703. This report adds the child's death. - Mod.LK]\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. This includes 5 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 9 cases still under treatment, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. At least 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. The WHO said last week that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015 there were 18 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country.\n\nThe WHO says that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers tend to raise and slaughter poultry themselves.\n\n[Byline: Shadi Bushra]\n\n--\nCommunicated "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (21): Palestinian Auth. (WE), Israel (HA), poultry, H5N1, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3116798", "date": "2015-01-21 16:33:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (16): EGYPT (MINYA, ASSIUT) H5N1 FATALITIES\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/19/health-birdflu-egypt-idUSL6N0UY3GZ20150119\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman and child died of H5N1 [avian influenza], the health ministry said on [Mon 19 Jan 2015], the 4th and 5th persons to die of the illness in the country this year. [The death of the 47 year old woman was reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp. 20150119.3103703. This report adds the child's death. - Mod.LK]\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. Both Assiut and Minya provinces are rural areas that have seen a number of bird flu cases in the past year. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. This includes 5 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 9 cases still under treatment, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. At least 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. The WHO said last week that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015 there were 18 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country.\n\nThe WHO says that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers tend to raise and slaughter poultry themselves.\n\n[Byline: Shadi Bushra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Thus far, there have been no credible reports suggesting community spread of the virus, and nearly all appear to have had direct contact with infected poultry.\n\nThe Egyptian Government has announced the creation of a high-level \"Supreme National Committee On Bird Flu\", ordered by the Chairman of the Council of Ministers, to be chaired the 1st year by the Minister of Agriculture (http://afludiary.blogspot.ch/2015/01/egypt-government-statements-on-h5n1.html).\n\nMaps of Egypt an be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (15): WHO update, China (GD) H7N9 Egypt, H5N1, mutations, comment 20150110.3084116\nAvian influenza, human (08): Egypt, H5N1, mutations 20150109.3082553\nAvian influenza, human (07): China (GD) H7N9 20150109.3080184\nAvian influenza, Egyptian woman and child died of H5N1 [avian influenza], the health ministry said on [Mon 19 Jan 2015], the 4th and 5th persons to die of the illness in the country this year. [The death of the 47 year old woman was reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp. 20150119.3103703. This report adds the child's death. - Mod.LK]\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. This includes 5 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 9 cases still under treatment, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. human cases in the country.\n\nThe WHO says that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (18): USA (WA) wild duck, HPAI H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3109001", "date": "2015-01-21 16:33:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (16): EGYPT (MINYA, ASSIUT) H5N1 FATALITIES\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/19/health-birdflu-egypt-idUSL6N0UY3GZ20150119\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman and child died of H5N1 [avian influenza], the health ministry said on [Mon 19 Jan 2015], the 4th and 5th persons to die of the illness in the country this year. [The death of the 47 year old woman was reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp. 20150119.3103703. This report adds the child's death. - Mod.LK]\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. Both Assiut and Minya provinces are rural areas that have seen a number of bird flu cases in the past year. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. This includes 5 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 9 cases still under treatment, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. At least 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. The WHO said last week that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015 there were 18 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country.\n\nThe WHO says that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers tend to raise and slaughter poultry themselves.\n\n[Byline: Shadi Bushra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Thus far, there have been no credible reports suggesting community spread of the virus, and nearly all appear to have had direct contact with infected poultry.\n\nThe Egyptian Government has announced the creation of a high-level \"Supreme National Committee On Bird Flu\", ordered by the Chairman of the Council of Ministers, to be chaired the 1st year by the Minister of Agriculture (http://afludiary.blogspot.ch/2015/01/egypt-government-statements-on-h5n1.html).\n\nMaps of Egypt an be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/egypt/eg3r92t/egypt_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55. - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (15): WHO update, China (GD) H7N9 "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (16): Egypt (MN,AT) H5N1 fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3108144", "date": "2015-01-21 16:33:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (16): EGYPT (MINYA, ASSIUT) H5N1 FATALITIES\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/19/health-birdflu-egypt-idUSL6N0UY3GZ20150119\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman and child died of H5N1 [avian influenza], the health ministry said on [Mon 19 Jan 2015], the 4th and 5th persons to die of the illness in the country this year. [The death of the 47 year old woman was reported in ProMED-mail post Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp. 20150119.3103703. This report adds the child's death. - Mod.LK]\n\nThe 6-year-old child died in Minya province on Monday evening [12 Jan 2015], after a 47-year-old woman succumbed to the disease in Assiut province earlier in the day, ministry spokesman Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said. Both Assiut and Minya provinces are rural areas that have seen a number of bird flu cases in the past year. The ministry announced one other case in treatment, bringing the total number of cases in Egypt to 20 this year [2015] so far. This includes 5 deaths as well as 6 recoveries and 9 cases still under treatment, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nThe World Health Organization says there has been a jump in the number of H5N1 infections in people in Egypt, but that there does not appear to have been any major genetic change in the flu strain to explain the rise in human cases. At least 10 people died from the disease in Egypt in 2014. The WHO said last week that between 4 Dec 2014 and 6 Jan 2015 there were 18 new laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection in Egypt, including 4 deaths, the highest ever monthly number of human cases in the country.\n\nThe WHO says that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers tend to raise and slaughter poultry themselves.\n\n[Byline: Shadi Bushra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Thus far, there have been no credible reports suggesting community spread of the virus, and nearly all appear to have had direct contact with infected poultry.\n\nThe Egyptian Government has announced the creation of a high-level \"Supreme National Committee On Bird Flu\", ordered by the Chairman of the Council of Ministers, to be chaired the 1st year by the Minister of Agriculture (http://afludiary.blogspot.ch/2015/01/egypt-government-statements-on-h5n1.html).\n\nMaps of Egypt an be seen at ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-19 00:00:00", "2015-01-19 00:00:00", "2015-01-12 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (14): Egypt, H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3103703", "date": "2015-01-07 19:33:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): EGYPT H5N1, CHINA (GUANGDONG) H7N9\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\n\n******\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\nDate: Mon 5 Jan 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/01/avian-flu-scan-jan-05-2015\n\n\n4 more H5N1 cases reported in Egypt\n-----------------------------------\nA recent flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt continued with at least 4 more over the past 5 days, along with 2 deaths, according to media and government reports.\n\nTwo cases involved a 6-year-old girl from Giza governorate who was in critical condition and a 45-year-old man from Menoufiya governorate who was on a respirator, according to a machine-translated Egyptian Ministry of Health (MOH) statement that was posted 1 Jan [2015] on the infectious-disease blog Avian Flu Diary (AFD).\n\nThe 2 cases raised Egypt's H5N1 count for 2014 to 29 cases, with 11 deaths, the MOH said.\n\nThe 45-year-old man apparently died of his illness, as a 3 Jan [2015] English-language report from Ahram Online noted the death of a 45-year-old Menoufiya man that day. It said he had had pneumonia and had been on a ventilator.\n\nTwo additional cases, both in Minya governorate, were revealed today [5 Jan 2015] in a machine-translated AhramOnline report posted on AFD (with a note that a subsequent MOH statement matched it). They involve a 30-year-old man in \"medium\" condition and an 11-year-old boy in critical condition.\n\nThe other death involved a 3-year-old child from Giza governorate, according to a story today [5 Jan 2015] in the Jerusalem Post, citing the MOH. The description matched that of a case-patient reported by the MOH on 31 Dec [2014]. It was not clear today whether the 3-year-old Giza child had any connection with the 6-year-old Giza girl whose case was reported 1 Jan [2015].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/37773.html\n\n\nCHP notified of human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing [Guangdong province]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [7 Jan 2015] closely monitoring an additional human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing notified by the Health and Family Planning Commission of Guangdong Province (GDHFPC), and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.\n\nAccording to the GDHFPC, the male patient, aged 56 with underlying illnesses, was hospitalised for management in critical condition.\n\nTo date, 458 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (141 cases), Guangdong (115 cases), Jiangsu (59 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Fujian (23 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case).\n\nAll boundary control points have implemented health surveillance measures. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Here we report the isolation of a novel human HA-stem-reactive monoclonal antibody, mAb 1.12, with exceptionally broad neutralizing activity encompassing viruses from 15 distinct HA subtypes. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.\" - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (SZ, GD) H7N9 20150106.3075021\nAvian influenza, human (04): Egypt (MF, GZ) fatal, China (HK) 20150105.3072586\nAvian influenza, human (03): Egypt (AN, Cairo, MF) fatal, H5N1 20150103.3069160\nAvian influenza, human (02): China (HK,GD) LPAI H7N9, poultry, control, OIE 20150102.3067796\nAvian influenza, human (01): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp, RFI 20150101.3061029\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza, human (133): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp 20141228.3058834\nAvian influenza, human (132): Egypt (AN) H5N1, fatal 20141225.3055022\nAvian influenza, human (129): Egypt (SJ) fatal case 20141224.3051603\nAvian influenza, human (127): Egypt (AT) H5N1, fatal 20141219.3042397\nAvian influenza, human (126): Egypt (SJ) H5N1, 8th death 20141212.3030546\nAvian influenza, human (123): Egypt (SJ) H5N1, child 20141207.3017616\nAvian influenza, human (122): Egypt (MN,BN) H5N1, fatalities 20141202.3006388\nAvian influenza, human (117): Egypt (MN) H5N1, 8th case in 2014 20141119.2969552\nAvian influenza, human (116): Egypt (AT) H5N1, new fatality 20141118.2965663\nAvian influenza, human (115): Egypt (AT,MN) H5N1, new cases 20141116.2960328\nAvian influenza, human (112): Egypt, H5N1 seroprevalence 20141101.2921788\nAvian influenza, human (107): Egypt (JZ) H5N1, infant 20141001.2822498\nAvian influenza, human (103): Egypt, H5N1 20140628.2571119\nAvian influenza, human (91): Egypt, H5N1 20140406.2385849\nAvian influenza, human (88): Egypt, H5N1, RFI 20140324.2353435\nAvian influenza, human (25): Egypt (DK) H5N1, Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.\" - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (SZ, GD) H7N9 20150106.3075021\nAvian influenza, human (04): Egypt (MF, GZ) fatal, China (HK) 20150105.3072586\nAvian Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp, RFI 20150101.3061029\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza, human (133): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp 20141228.3058834\nAvian influenza, human (132): Egypt (AN) H5N1, fatal
