RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3099260", "date": "2015-01-07 19:33:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): EGYPT H5N1, CHINA (GUANGDONG) H7N9\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\n\n******\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\nDate: Mon 5 Jan 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/01/avian-flu-scan-jan-05-2015\n\n\n4 more H5N1 cases reported in Egypt\n-----------------------------------\nA recent flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt continued with at least 4 more over the past 5 days, along with 2 deaths, according to media and government reports.\n\nTwo cases involved a 6-year-old girl from Giza governorate who was in critical condition and a 45-year-old man from Menoufiya governorate who was on a respirator, according to a machine-translated Egyptian Ministry of Health (MOH) statement that was posted 1 Jan [2015] on the infectious-disease blog Avian Flu Diary (AFD).\n\nThe 2 cases raised Egypt's H5N1 count for 2014 to 29 cases, with 11 deaths, the MOH said.\n\nThe 45-year-old man apparently died of his illness, as a 3 Jan [2015] English-language report from Ahram Online noted the death of a 45-year-old Menoufiya man that day. It said he had had pneumonia and had been on a ventilator.\n\nTwo additional cases, both in Minya governorate, were revealed today [5 Jan 2015] in a machine-translated AhramOnline report posted on AFD (with a note that a subsequent MOH statement matched it). They involve a 30-year-old man in \"medium\" condition and an 11-year-old boy in critical condition.\n\nThe other death involved a 3-year-old child from Giza governorate, according to a story today [5 Jan 2015] in the Jerusalem Post, citing the MOH. The description matched that of a case-patient reported by the MOH on 31 Dec [2014]. It was not clear today whether the 3-year-old Giza child had any connection with the 6-year-old Giza girl whose case was reported 1 Jan [2015].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/37773.html\n\n\nCHP notified of human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing [Guangdong province]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [7 Jan 2015] closely monitoring an additional human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing notified by the Health and Family Planning Commission of Guangdong Province (GDHFPC), and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.\n\nAccording to the GDHFPC, the male patient, aged 56 with underlying illnesses, was hospitalised for management in critical condition.\n\nTo date, 458 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (141 cases), Guangdong (115 cases), Jiangsu (59 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Fujian (23 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case).\n\nAll boundary control points have implemented health surveillance measures. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Here we report the isolation of a novel human HA-stem-reactive monoclonal antibody, mAb 1.12, with exceptionally broad neutralizing activity encompassing viruses from 15 distinct HA subtypes. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.\" - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (SZ, GD) H7N9 20150106.3075021\nAvian influenza, human (04): Egypt (MF, GZ) fatal, China (HK) 20150105.3072586\nAvian Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp, RFI 20150101.3061029\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza, human (133): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp 20141228.3058834\nAvian influenza, human (132): Egypt (AN) H5N1, fatal [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3093018", "date": "2015-01-07 19:33:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): EGYPT H5N1, CHINA (GUANGDONG) H7N9\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\n\n******\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\nDate: Mon 5 Jan 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/01/avian-flu-scan-jan-05-2015\n\n\n4 more H5N1 cases reported in Egypt\n-----------------------------------\nA recent flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt continued with at least 4 more over the past 5 days, along with 2 deaths, according to media and government reports.\n\nTwo cases involved a 6-year-old girl from Giza governorate who was in critical condition and a 45-year-old man from Menoufiya governorate who was on a respirator, according to a machine-translated Egyptian Ministry of Health (MOH) statement that was posted 1 Jan [2015] on the infectious-disease blog Avian Flu Diary (AFD).\n\nThe 2 cases raised Egypt's H5N1 count for 2014 to 29 cases, with 11 deaths, the MOH said.\n\nThe 45-year-old man apparently died of his illness, as a 3 Jan [2015] English-language report from Ahram Online noted the death of a 45-year-old Menoufiya man that day. It said he had had pneumonia and had been on a ventilator.\n\nTwo additional cases, both in Minya governorate, were revealed today [5 Jan 2015] in a machine-translated AhramOnline report posted on AFD (with a note that a subsequent MOH statement matched it). They involve a 30-year-old man in \"medium\" condition and an 11-year-old boy in critical condition.\n\nThe other death involved a 3-year-old child from Giza governorate, according to a story today [5 Jan 2015] in the Jerusalem Post, citing the MOH. The description matched that of a case-patient reported by the MOH on 31 Dec [2014]. It was not clear today whether the 3-year-old Giza child had any connection with the 6-year-old Giza girl whose case was reported 1 Jan [2015].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/37773.html\n\n\nCHP notified of human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing [Guangdong province]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [7 Jan 2015] closely monitoring an additional human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing notified by the Health and Family Planning Commission of Guangdong Province (GDHFPC), and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.\n\nAccording to the GDHFPC, the male patient, aged 56 with underlying illnesses, was hospitalised for management in critical condition.\n\nTo date, 458 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (141 cases), Guangdong (115 cases), Jiangsu (59 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Fujian (23 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case).\n\nAll boundary control points have implemented health surveillance measures. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Here we report the isolation of a novel human HA-stem-reactive monoclonal antibody, mAb 1.12, with exceptionally broad neutralizing activity encompassing viruses from 15 distinct HA subtypes. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.\" - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (SZ, GD) H7N9 20150106.3075021\nAvian influenza, human (04): Egypt (MF, GZ) fatal, China (HK) 20150105.3072586\nAvian influenza, human (03): Egypt (AN, Cairo, MF) fatal, H5N1 20150103.3069160\nAvian influenza, human (02): China (HK,GD) LPAI H7N9, poultry, control, OIE 20150102.3067796\nAvian influenza, human (01): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp, RFI 20150101.3061029\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza, human (133): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp 20141228.3058834\nAvian influenza, human (132): Egypt (AN) H5N1, fatal 20141225.3055022\nAvian influenza, human (129): Egypt (SJ) fatal case 20141224.3051603\nAvian influenza, human (127): Egypt (AT) H5N1, fatal 20141219.3042397\nAvian influenza, human (126): Egypt (SJ) H5N1, 8th death 20141212.3030546\nAvian influenza, human (123): Egypt (SJ) H5N1, child 20141207.3017616\nAvian influenza, human (122): Egypt (MN,BN) H5N1, fatalities 20141202.3006388\nAvian influenza, human (117): Egypt (MN) H5N1, 8th case in 2014 20141119.2969552\nAvian influenza, human (116): Egypt (AT) H5N1, new fatality 20141118.2965663\nAvian influenza, human (115): Egypt (AT,MN) H5N1, new cases 20141116.2960328\nAvian influenza, human (112): Egypt, H5N1 seroprevalence 20141101.2921788\nAvian influenza, human (107): Egypt (JZ) H5N1, infant 20141001.2822498\nAvian influenza, human (103): Egypt, H5N1 20140628.2571119\nAvian influenza, human (91): Egypt, H5N1 20140406.2385849\nAvian influenza, human (88): Egypt, H5N1, RFI 20140324.2353435\nAvian influenza, human (25): Egypt (DK) H5N1, Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Here we report the isolation of a novel human HA-stem-reactive monoclonal antibody, mAb 1.12, with exceptionally broad neutralizing activity encompassing viruses from 15 distinct HA subtypes. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.\" - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (SZ, GD) H7N9 20150106.3075021\nAvian influenza, human (04): Egypt (MF, GZ) fatal, China (HK) 20150105.3072586\nAvian "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2015-01-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-05 00:00:00", "2015-01-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-01-07 00:00:00", "2015-01-07 00:00:00", "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Zhejiang", "country": "China"}, {"location": "hmabs", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3082553", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (08): Egypt, H5N1, mutations", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3082553", "date": "2015-01-07 19:33:44", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): EGYPT H5N1, CHINA (GUANGDONG) H7N9\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\n\n******\n[1] Egypt: H5N1\nDate: Mon 5 Jan 2015\nSource: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2015/01/avian-flu-scan-jan-05-2015\n\n\n4 more H5N1 cases reported in Egypt\n-----------------------------------\nA recent flurry of human H5N1 influenza cases in Egypt continued with at least 4 more over the past 5 days, along with 2 deaths, according to media and government reports.\n\nTwo cases involved a 6-year-old girl from Giza governorate who was in critical condition and a 45-year-old man from Menoufiya governorate who was on a respirator, according to a machine-translated Egyptian Ministry of Health (MOH) statement that was posted 1 Jan [2015] on the infectious-disease blog Avian Flu Diary (AFD).\n\nThe 2 cases raised Egypt's H5N1 count for 2014 to 29 cases, with 11 deaths, the MOH said.\n\nThe 45-year-old man apparently died of his illness, as a 3 Jan [2015] English-language report from Ahram Online noted the death of a 45-year-old Menoufiya man that day. It said he had had pneumonia and had been on a ventilator.\n\nTwo additional cases, both in Minya governorate, were revealed today [5 Jan 2015] in a machine-translated AhramOnline report posted on AFD (with a note that a subsequent MOH statement matched it). They involve a 30-year-old man in \"medium\" condition and an 11-year-old boy in critical condition.\n\nThe other death involved a 3-year-old child from Giza governorate, according to a story today [5 Jan 2015] in the Jerusalem Post, citing the MOH. The description matched that of a case-patient reported by the MOH on 31 Dec [2014]. It was not clear today whether the 3-year-old Giza child had any connection with the 6-year-old Giza girl whose case was reported 1 Jan [2015].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China (Guangdong): H7N9\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection [edited]\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/37773.html\n\n\nCHP notified of human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing [Guangdong province]\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [7 Jan 2015] closely monitoring an additional human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) in Zhaoqing notified by the Health and Family Planning Commission of Guangdong Province (GDHFPC), and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.\n\nAccording to the GDHFPC, the male patient, aged 56 with underlying illnesses, was hospitalised for management in critical condition.\n\nTo date, 458 human cases of avian influenza A(H7N9) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities, respectively in Zhejiang (141 cases), Guangdong (115 cases), Jiangsu (59 cases), Shanghai (42 cases), Hunan (24 cases), Fujian (23 cases), Anhui (17 cases), Jiangxi (8 cases), Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (8 cases), Beijing (5 cases), Shandong (5 cases), Henan (4 cases), Guangxi (3 cases), Jilin (2 cases), Guizhou (1 case) and Hebei (1 case).\n\nAll boundary control points have implemented health surveillance measures. Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Here we report the isolation of a novel human HA-stem-reactive monoclonal antibody, mAb 1.12, with exceptionally broad neutralizing activity encompassing viruses from 15 distinct HA subtypes. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.\" - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (SZ, GD) H7N9 20150106.3075021\nAvian influenza, human (04): Egypt (MF, GZ) fatal, China (HK) 20150105.3072586\nAvian influenza, human (03): Egypt (AN, Cairo, MF) fatal, H5N1 20150103.3069160\nAvian influenza, human (02): China (HK,GD) LPAI H7N9, poultry, control, OIE 20150102.3067796\nAvian influenza, human (01): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp, RFI 20150101.3061029\n2014\n----\nAvian influenza, human (133): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp 20141228.3058834\nAvian influenza, human (132): Egypt (AN) H5N1, fatal H5N1, 8th death 20141212.3030546\nAvian influenza, human (123): Egypt (SJ) H5N1, child 20141207.3017616\nAvian influenza, human (122): Egypt (MN,BN) H5N1, fatalities 20141202.3006388\nAvian influenza, human (117): Egypt (MN) H5N1, 8th case in 2014 20141119.2969552\nAvian influenza, human (116): Egypt (AT) H5N1, new fatality 20141118.2965663\nAvian influenza, human (115): Egypt (AT,MN) H5N1, new cases 20141116.2960328\nAvian influenza, human (112): Egypt, H5N1 seroprevalence 20141101.2921788\nAvian influenza, human (107): Egypt (JZ) H5N1, infant 20141001.2822498\nAvian influenza, human (103): Thermal imaging systems are in place for body temperature checks on inbound travellers. Suspected cases will be immediately referred to public hospitals for follow-up. The DH's Port Health Office has enhanced body temperature checks by handheld devices. ... -- more\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[How is China going to distinguish a flu fever from an Ebola fever? - Mod.JW]\n\n[Maps of China can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/China and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34106.\n\nMaps of Egypt can be accessed at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Egypt and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/55.\n\nSuggested reading:\nWyrzucki A, Bianchi M, Kohler I, et al. Heterosubtypic antibodies to influenza A virus have limited activity against cell-bound virus but are not impaired by strain-specific serum antibodies. J Virol. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JVI.03069-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552718/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nThe majority of influenza virus-specific antibodies elicited by vaccination or natural infection is only effective against the eliciting or closely related viruses. Rare stem-specific heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (hmAbs) can neutralize multiple strains and subtypes by preventing hemagglutinin (HA)-mediated fusion of the viral with the endosomal membrane. The epitopes recognized by these hmAbs are therefore considered promising targets for the development of pan-influenza vaccines. Here we report the isolation of a novel human HA-stem-reactive monoclonal antibody, mAb 1.12, with exceptionally broad neutralizing activity encompassing viruses from 15 distinct HA subtypes. Using mAb 1.12 and 2 other monoclonal antibodies, we could demonstrate that neutralization by hmAbs is virtually irreversible but becomes severely impaired following virus attachment to cells. In contrast, no interference by human anti-influenza serum antibodies was found, indicating that apically binding antibodies do not impair access to the membrane-proximal heterosubtypic epitopes. Our findings therefore encourage development of new vaccine concepts aiming at the induction of stem-specific heterosubtypic antibodies, as we provide support for their effectiveness in individuals previously exposed to influenza virus.\"\n\nOdagiri T, Matsuzaki Y, Okamoto et al. Isolation and characterization of influenza C viruses in the Philippines and Japan. J Clin Microbiol_. 2014 Dec 31. pii: JCM.02628-14. [Epub ahead of print] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25552361/\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\nFrom November 2009 to December 2013, 15 influenza C viruses were isolated, using MDCK cells, from specimens obtained from children with severe pneumonia and influenza-like illness (ILI), in the Philippines. This is the 1st report of influenza C virus isolation in the Philippines. In addition, from January 2008 to December 2013, 7 influenza C viruses were isolated from specimens that were obtained from children with acute respiratory illness (ARI) in Sendai city, Japan. Antigenic analysis with monoclonal antibodies to the hemaggultinin-esterase (HE) glycoprotein showed that 19 strains (12 from Philippines and 7 from Japan) were similar to the reference strain C/Sao Paulo/378/82(SP82). Phylogenetic analysis of the HE gene showed that strains from the Philippines and Japan formed distinct clusters within an SP82-related lineage. The clusters including the Philippine and Japanese strains were shown to have diverged from a common ancestor around 1993. In addition, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that all strains isolated in the Philippines and Japan had emerged through reassortment events. The composition of the internal genes of the Philippine strains was different from that of the Japanese strains, although all strains were classified into an SP82-related lineage by HE gene sequence analysis. These observations suggest that the influenza C viruses analyzed here had emerged through different reassortment events; however, the time and place at which the reassortment events occurred could not be determined.\" - Mod.LK]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (SZ, GD) H7N9 20150106.3075021\nAvian influenza, human (04): Egypt (MF, GZ) fatal, China (HK) 20150105.3072586\nAvian "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3069160", "date": "2014-12-25 17:43:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (132): EGYPT (ASWAN) H5N1, FATAL\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Dec 2014\nSource: Daily Mail, Reuters report [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-2886569/Tenth-Egyptian-dies-H5N1-bird-flu--Health-Ministry.html\n\n\nA 5 year old Egyptian child died from bird flu on Wednesday [24 Dec 2014], the 10th death from the virus in the country out of 22 identified cases this year, the Health Ministry said.\n\nMinistry spokesman Dr Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said the boy came to a hospital in the southern province of Aswan on Monday [22 Dec 2014] with \"fever, sore throat and respiratory distress\". He was transferred to another hospital, and later put on a ventilator in a 3rd hospital where he died. His mother said he had had contact with sick birds, the spokesman added.\n\nOut of the 12 other surviving infected patients, 8 have been discharged and 4 others are still sick in hospital, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), from 2003 to 2 Oct 2014, 668 laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection have been officially reported by 16 countries. Of these cases, 393 have died.\n\nWHO has warned that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases, especially in people exposed to infected birds or contaminated environments.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers, particularly women, tend to keep and slaughter poultry in the home.\n\n[byline: Mahmoud Mourad and Ahmed Tolba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Indonesia and Egypt remain the only countries where human cases of H5N1 avian influenza is continuing to occur in the human population. In Egypt, H5N1 avian influenza virus occurs sporadically throughout the country and is associated with the breeding of poultry domestically. Transmission from human to human is rare. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12468.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (129): Egypt (SJ) fatal case 20141224.3051603\nAvian influenza, human (127): Egypt (AT) H5N1, fatal 20141219.3042397\nAvian influenza, human (126): Egypt (SJ) H5N1, 8th death 20141212.3030546\nAvian influenza, human (123): "Indonesia"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Aswan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3061029", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (01): Libya, fatal, H5N1 susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3061029", "date": "2014-12-25 17:43:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (132): EGYPT (ASWAN) H5N1, FATAL\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Dec 2014\nSource: Daily Mail, Reuters report [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-2886569/Tenth-Egyptian-dies-H5N1-bird-flu--Health-Ministry.html\n\n\nA 5 year old Egyptian child died from bird flu on Wednesday [24 Dec 2014], the 10th death from the virus in the country out of 22 identified cases this year, the Health Ministry said.\n\nMinistry spokesman Dr Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said the boy came to a hospital in the southern province of Aswan on Monday [22 Dec 2014] with \"fever, sore throat and respiratory distress\". He was transferred to another hospital, and later put on a ventilator in a 3rd hospital where he died. His mother said he had had contact with sick birds, the spokesman added.\n\nOut of the 12 other surviving infected patients, 8 have been discharged and 4 others are still sick in hospital, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), from 2003 to 2 Oct 2014, 668 laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection have been officially reported by 16 countries. Of these cases, 393 have died.\n\nWHO has warned that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases, especially in people exposed to infected birds or contaminated environments.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers, particularly women, tend to keep and slaughter poultry in the home.\n\n[byline: Mahmoud Mourad and Ahmed Tolba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Indonesia and Egypt remain the only countries where human cases of H5N1 avian influenza is continuing to occur in the human population. In Egypt, H5N1 avian influenza virus occurs sporadically throughout the country and is associated with the breeding of poultry domestically. Transmission from human to human is rare. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12468.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (129): Egypt (SJ) fatal His mother said he had had contact with sick birds, the spokesman added.\n\nOut of the 12 other surviving infected patients, 8 have been discharged and 4 others are still sick in hospital, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), from 2003 to 2 Oct 2014, 668 laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection have been officially reported by 16 countries. southern province of Aswan on Monday [22 Dec 2014] with \"fever, sore throat and respiratory distress\". He was transferred to another hospital, and later put on a ventilator in a 3rd hospital where he died. His mother said he had had contact with sick birds, the spokesman added.\n\nOut of the 12 other surviving infected patients, 8 have been discharged and 4 others are still sick in hospital, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), from 2003 to 2 Oct 2014, 668 laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection have been officially reported by 16 countries. Of these cases, 393 have died.\n\nWHO has warned that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases, especially in people exposed to infected birds or contaminated environments.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers, particularly women, tend to keep and slaughter poultry in the home.\n\n[byline: Mahmoud Mourad and Ahmed Tolba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Indonesia and Egypt remain the only countries where human cases of H5N1 avian influenza is continuing to occur in the human population. In Egypt, H5N1 avian influenza virus occurs sporadically throughout the country and is associated with the breeding of poultry domestically. Transmission from human to human is rare. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12468.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (129): Egypt (SJ) fatal Avian influenza (113): India (CH) H5N1, ducks, OIE, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3043523", "date": "2014-12-25 17:43:20", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (132): EGYPT (ASWAN) H5N1, FATAL\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Dec 2014\nSource: Daily Mail, Reuters report [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-2886569/Tenth-Egyptian-dies-H5N1-bird-flu--Health-Ministry.html\n\n\nA 5 year old Egyptian child died from bird flu on Wednesday [24 Dec 2014], the 10th death from the virus in the country out of 22 identified cases this year, the Health Ministry said.\n\nMinistry spokesman Dr Hossam Abdel Ghaffar said the boy came to a hospital in the southern province of Aswan on Monday [22 Dec 2014] with \"fever, sore throat and respiratory distress\". He was transferred to another hospital, and later put on a ventilator in a 3rd hospital where he died. His mother said he had had contact with sick birds, the spokesman added.\n\nOut of the 12 other surviving infected patients, 8 have been discharged and 4 others are still sick in hospital, Abdel Ghaffar said.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), from 2003 to 2 Oct 2014, 668 laboratory-confirmed human cases of H5N1 infection have been officially reported by 16 countries. Of these cases, 393 have died.\n\nWHO has warned that whenever bird flu viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infections or small clusters of human cases, especially in people exposed to infected birds or contaminated environments.\n\nEgypt's H5N1 cases have largely been in poor rural areas in the south, where villagers, particularly women, tend to keep and slaughter poultry in the home.\n\n[byline: Mahmoud Mourad and Ahmed Tolba]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Indonesia and Egypt remain the only countries where human cases of H5N1 avian influenza is continuing to occur in the human population. In Egypt, H5N1 avian influenza virus occurs sporadically throughout the country and is associated with the breeding of poultry domestically. Transmission from human to human is rare. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12468.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (129): Egypt (SJ) fatal Avian influenza, human (127): Egypt (AT) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3042397", "date": "2014-11-18 12:53:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (116): EGYPT (ASSIUT) H5N1, NEW FATALITY\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Nov 2014\nSource: BBC News, Middle East [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30086364\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman has died after coming into contact with birds infected with the H5N1 avian influenza virus. The 19-year-old woman died in hospital in the region of Assiut in the south of the country. It was the 2nd death in Egypt this year [2014] out of a total of 7 confirmed cases, said Egyptian health officials.\n\nIt comes after several cases of birds infected with a different type of the virus were discovered in commercial farms in England, Germany, and the Netherlands. [H5N8 avian influenza virus in Germany and the Netherlands, and probably in England]. There have been 667 human cases of H5N1 worldwide since 2003, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). Egypt's health ministry said 2 other people were infected, according to Reuters news agency. One of them was a 3-year-old child who was recovering well in hospital and the other was a 30-year-old woman, the news agency added. Health ministry official Amr Kandil said the 1st death from H5N1 in Egypt this year [2014] had happened in June.\n\nH5N1 was first seen in a human patient in Hong Kong in 1993 but has since spread worldwide. It has a death rate of about 60 percent in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The current outbreaks of H5 high pathogenicity avian influenza virus infection affecting commercial poultry flocks in Germany and the Netherlands, (and now probably England) have been characterised as a strain of H5N8 avian influenza virus, probably originating in the Far East and transmitted by migratory birds.\n\nThe H5N1 virus responsible for current illness and death in Egypt, on the other hand, has been associated with sporadic human illness and deaths over a wide area particularly where domestic fowl are reared at home.\n\nAccording to the WHO (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf), Egypt ranks 2nd (after Indonesia) among the 15 countries where H5N1 avian influenza virus has been responsible for human cases (and deaths from) of avian H5N1 avian influenza virus infection. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/37853.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (115): Egypt (AT,MN) H5N1, new cases 20141116.2960328\nAvian influenza, human affecting commercial poultry flocks in Germany and the Netherlands, (and now probably England) have been characterised as a strain of H5N8 avian influenza virus, probably originating in the Far East "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2045-03-16 00:00:00", "2043-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "2049-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 "United States"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3017616", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (123): Egypt (SJ) H5N1, child", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3017616", "date": "2014-11-18 12:53:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (116): EGYPT (ASSIUT) H5N1, NEW FATALITY\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Nov 2014\nSource: BBC News, Middle East [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30086364\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman has died after coming into contact with birds infected with the H5N1 avian influenza virus. The 19-year-old woman died in hospital in the region of Assiut in the south of the country. It was the 2nd death in Egypt this year [2014] out of a total of 7 confirmed cases, said Egyptian health officials.\n\nIt comes after several cases of birds infected with a different type of the virus were discovered in commercial farms in England, Germany, and the Netherlands. [H5N8 avian influenza virus in Germany and the Netherlands, and probably in England]. There have been 667 human cases of H5N1 worldwide since 2003, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). Egypt's health ministry said 2 other people were infected, according to Reuters news agency. One of them was a 3-year-old child who was recovering well in hospital and the other was a 30-year-old woman, the news agency added. Health ministry official Amr Kandil said the 1st death from H5N1 in Egypt this year [2014] had happened in June.\n\nH5N1 was first seen in a human patient in Hong Kong in 1993 but has since spread worldwide. It has a death rate of about 60 percent in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The current outbreaks of H5 high pathogenicity avian influenza virus infection affecting commercial poultry flocks in Germany and the Netherlands, (and now probably England) have been characterised as a strain of H5N8 avian influenza virus, probably originating in the Far East and transmitted by migratory birds.\n\nThe H5N1 virus responsible for current illness and death in Egypt, on the other hand, has been associated with sporadic human illness and deaths over a wide area particularly where domestic fowl are reared at home.\n\nAccording to the WHO (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf), Egypt ranks 2nd (after Indonesia) among the 15 countries where H5N1 avian influenza virus has been responsible for human cases (and deaths from) of avian H5N1 avian influenza virus infection. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/37853.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (115): Egypt (AT,MN) H5N1, new cases 20141116.2960328\nAvian influenza, human "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2965663", "date": "2014-11-18 12:53:05", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (116): EGYPT (ASSIUT) H5N1, NEW FATALITY\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Nov 2014\nSource: BBC News, Middle East [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-30086364\n\n\nAn Egyptian woman has died after coming into contact with birds infected with the H5N1 avian influenza virus. The 19-year-old woman died in hospital in the region of Assiut in the south of the country. It was the 2nd death in Egypt this year [2014] out of a total of 7 confirmed cases, said Egyptian health officials.\n\nIt comes after several cases of birds infected with a different type of the virus were discovered in commercial farms in England, Germany, and the Netherlands. [H5N8 avian influenza virus in Germany and the Netherlands, and probably in England]. There have been 667 human cases of H5N1 worldwide since 2003, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). Egypt's health ministry said 2 other people were infected, according to Reuters news agency. One of them was a 3-year-old child who was recovering well in hospital and the other was a 30-year-old woman, the news agency added. Health ministry official Amr Kandil said the 1st death from H5N1 in Egypt this year [2014] had happened in June.\n\nH5N1 was first seen in a human patient in Hong Kong in 1993 but has since spread worldwide. It has a death rate of about 60 percent in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The current outbreaks of H5 high pathogenicity avian influenza virus infection affecting commercial poultry flocks in Germany and the Netherlands, (and now probably England) have been characterised as a strain of H5N8 avian influenza virus, probably originating in the Far East and transmitted by migratory birds.\n\nThe H5N1 virus responsible for current illness and death in Egypt, on the other hand, has been associated with sporadic human illness and deaths over a wide area particularly where domestic fowl are reared at home.\n\nAccording to the WHO (http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/EN_GIP_20140124CumulativeNumberH5N1cases.pdf), Egypt ranks 2nd (after Indonesia) among the 15 countries where H5N1 avian influenza virus has been responsible for human cases (and deaths from) of avian H5N1 avian influenza virus infection. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/37853.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (115): Egypt (AT,MN) H5N1, new cases 20141116.2960328\nAvian influenza, human "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2960328", "date": "2014-06-18 18:11:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (102): INDONESIA, H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 18 Apr 2014\nSource: Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/18/avian-flu-claims-victim-jakarta.html\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has confirmed the 2nd case of human infection from avian influenza H5N1 in the country this year [2014], which claimed the life of a 33-year-old man in Jakarta.\n\nThe ministry's health research and development center head, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, said that the victim was pronounced dead at Pondok Kopi Islamic Hospital, East Jakarta, last month [May 2014].\n\n\"The laboratory confirmed the H5N1 [infection], based on real-time and conventional PCR [polymerase chain reaction] diagnostics on the victim's specimen,\" he said in a press statement released on Tuesday [17 Jun 2014].\n\nIt is the 2nd laboratory-confirmed case of human infection of avian influenza following a case in Wonogiri, Central Java.\n\nOn [20 Apr 2014], a 2-year-old toddler died of avian flu following exposure to live poultry. An inquiry by the Health Ministry found that prior to RNA's death, almost 70 chickens had died from apparent avian flu infection.\n\nAccording to Tjandra, there have been 17 confirmed cases worldwide of avian flu in humans this year [2014]. Cambodia has recorded the most so far, with 9 cases, while Indonesia, Egypt, Viet Nam and China have recorded 2 cases each.\n\nCumulatively, Indonesia has witnessed 197 cases of humans infected with avian flu, making it the nation with the highest number of H5N1 human infection cases to date. Egypt and Viet Nam follow with 175 cases and 127 cases, respectively.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[As mentioned above, this is the 2nd reported case of human infection with influenza A, H5N1 in Indonesia this year (2014). Since 2003, Indonesia has reported 197 human cases of H5N1 infection, including 164 deaths.\n\nAccording to the most recent H5N1 human case summary report from WHO dated 5 May 2014, since 2003 through 5 May 2014, there were 665 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection from 15 countries that were officially reported to WHO, including 392 deaths (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_5May14.pdf?ua=1).\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January 2014; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February 2014; in Cambodia and Egypt in March 2014; in Egypt in April 2014 and in Indonesia in May 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts below).\n\nFor a map of Indonesia, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184. Maps showing the locations of human cases of H5N1 can be found at http://gamapserver.who.int/mapLibrary/app/searchResults.aspx. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (97): Indonesia (JT) H5N1 "2916917", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (111): Indonesia (Jakarta), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2916917", "date": "2014-06-18 18:11:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (102): INDONESIA, H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 18 Apr 2014\nSource: Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/18/avian-flu-claims-victim-jakarta.html\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has confirmed the 2nd case of human infection from avian influenza H5N1 in the country this year [2014], which claimed the life of a 33-year-old man in Jakarta.\n\nThe ministry's health research and development center head, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, said that the victim was pronounced dead at Pondok Kopi Islamic Hospital, East Jakarta, last month [May 2014].\n\n\"The laboratory confirmed the H5N1 [infection], based on real-time and conventional PCR [polymerase chain reaction] diagnostics on the victim's specimen,\" he said in a press statement released on Tuesday [17 Jun 2014].\n\nIt is the 2nd laboratory-confirmed case of human infection of avian influenza following a case in Wonogiri, Central Java.\n\nOn [20 Apr 2014], a 2-year-old toddler died of avian flu following exposure to live poultry. An inquiry by the Health Ministry found that prior to RNA's death, almost 70 chickens had died from apparent avian flu infection.\n\nAccording to Tjandra, there have been 17 confirmed cases worldwide of avian flu in humans this year [2014]. Cambodia has recorded the most so far, with 9 cases, while Indonesia, Egypt, Viet Nam and China have recorded 2 cases each.\n\nCumulatively, Indonesia has witnessed 197 cases of humans infected with avian flu, making it the nation with the highest number of H5N1 human infection cases to date. Egypt and Viet Nam follow with 175 cases and 127 cases, respectively.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[As mentioned above, this is the 2nd reported case of human infection with influenza A, H5N1 in Indonesia this year (2014). Since 2003, Indonesia has reported 197 human cases of H5N1 infection, including 164 deaths.\n\nAccording to the most recent H5N1 human case summary report from WHO dated 5 May 2014, since 2003 through 5 May 2014, there were 665 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection from 15 countries that were officially reported to WHO, including 392 deaths (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_5May14.pdf?ua=1).\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January 2014; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February 2014; in Cambodia and Egypt in March 2014; in Egypt in April 2014 and in Indonesia in May 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts below).\n\nFor a map of Indonesia, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184. Maps showing the locations of human cases of H5N1 can be found at http://gamapserver.who.int/mapLibrary/app/searchResults.aspx. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (97): Indonesia (JT) H5N1 "2898069", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (78): China, poultry, HPAI H5N3, H5N8, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2898069", "date": "2014-06-18 18:11:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (102): INDONESIA, H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 18 Apr 2014\nSource: Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/18/avian-flu-claims-victim-jakarta.html\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has confirmed the 2nd case of human infection from avian influenza H5N1 in the country this year [2014], which claimed the life of a 33-year-old man in Jakarta.\n\nThe ministry's health research and development center head, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, said that the victim was pronounced dead at Pondok Kopi Islamic Hospital, East Jakarta, last month [May 2014].\n\n\"The laboratory confirmed the H5N1 [infection], based on real-time and conventional PCR [polymerase chain reaction] diagnostics on the victim's specimen,\" he said in a press statement released on Tuesday [17 Jun 2014].\n\nIt is the 2nd laboratory-confirmed case of human infection of avian influenza following a case in Wonogiri, Central Java.\n\nOn [20 Apr 2014], a 2-year-old toddler died of avian flu following exposure to live poultry. An inquiry by the Health Ministry found that prior to RNA's death, almost 70 chickens had died from apparent avian flu infection.\n\nAccording to Tjandra, there have been 17 confirmed cases worldwide of avian flu in humans this year [2014]. Cambodia has recorded the most so far, with 9 cases, while Indonesia, Egypt, Viet Nam and China have recorded 2 cases each.\n\nCumulatively, Indonesia has witnessed 197 cases of humans infected with avian flu, making it the nation with the highest number of H5N1 human infection cases to date. Egypt and Viet Nam follow with 175 cases and 127 cases, respectively.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[As mentioned above, this is the 2nd reported case of human infection with influenza A, H5N1 in Indonesia this year (2014). Since 2003, Indonesia has reported 197 human cases of H5N1 infection, including 164 deaths.\n\nAccording to the most recent H5N1 human case summary report from WHO dated 5 May 2014, since 2003 through 5 May 2014, there were 665 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection from 15 countries that were officially reported to WHO, including 392 deaths (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_5May14.pdf?ua=1).\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January 2014; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February 2014; in Cambodia and Egypt in March 2014; in Egypt in April 2014 and in Indonesia in May 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts below).\n\nFor a map of Indonesia, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184. Maps showing the locations of human cases of H5N1 can be found at http://gamapserver.who.int/mapLibrary/app/searchResults.aspx. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (97): Indonesia (JT) H5N1 "2571119", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (103): Egypt, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2571119", "date": "2014-06-18 18:11:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (102): INDONESIA, H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 18 Apr 2014\nSource: Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/18/avian-flu-claims-victim-jakarta.html\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has confirmed the 2nd case of human infection from avian influenza H5N1 in the country this year [2014], which claimed the life of a 33-year-old man in Jakarta.\n\nThe ministry's health research and development center head, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, said that the victim was pronounced dead at Pondok Kopi Islamic Hospital, East Jakarta, last month [May 2014].\n\n\"The laboratory confirmed the H5N1 [infection], based on real-time and conventional PCR [polymerase chain reaction] diagnostics on the victim's specimen,\" he said in a press statement released on Tuesday [17 Jun 2014].\n\nIt is the 2nd laboratory-confirmed case of human infection of avian influenza following a case in Wonogiri, Central Java.\n\nOn [20 Apr 2014], a 2-year-old toddler died of avian flu following exposure to live poultry. An inquiry by the Health Ministry found that prior to RNA's death, almost 70 chickens had died from apparent avian flu infection.\n\nAccording to Tjandra, there have been 17 confirmed cases worldwide of avian flu in humans this year [2014]. Cambodia has recorded the most so far, with 9 cases, while Indonesia, Egypt, Viet Nam and China have recorded 2 cases each.\n\nCumulatively, Indonesia has witnessed 197 cases of humans infected with avian flu, making it the nation with the highest number of H5N1 human infection cases to date. Egypt and Viet Nam follow with 175 cases and 127 cases, respectively.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[As mentioned above, this is the 2nd reported case of human infection with influenza A, H5N1 in Indonesia this year (2014). Since 2003, Indonesia has reported 197 human cases of H5N1 infection, including 164 deaths.\n\nAccording to the most recent H5N1 human case summary report from WHO dated 5 May 2014, since 2003 through 5 May 2014, there were 665 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection from 15 countries that were officially reported to WHO, including 392 deaths (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_5May14.pdf?ua=1).\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January 2014; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February 2014; in Cambodia and Egypt in March 2014; in Egypt in April 2014 and in Indonesia in May 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts below).\n\nFor a map of Indonesia, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184. Maps showing the locations of human cases of H5N1 can be found at http://gamapserver.who.int/mapLibrary/app/searchResults.aspx. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (97): Indonesia (JT) H5N1 "2550053", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (102): Indonesia, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2550053", "date": "2014-06-18 18:11:48", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (102): INDONESIA, H5N1\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 18 Apr 2014\nSource: Jakarta Post [edited]\nhttp://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/18/avian-flu-claims-victim-jakarta.html\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has confirmed the 2nd case of human infection from avian influenza H5N1 in the country this year [2014], which claimed the life of a 33-year-old man in Jakarta.\n\nThe ministry's health research and development center head, Tjandra Yoga Aditama, said that the victim was pronounced dead at Pondok Kopi Islamic Hospital, East Jakarta, last month [May 2014].\n\n\"The laboratory confirmed the H5N1 [infection], based on real-time and conventional PCR [polymerase chain reaction] diagnostics on the victim's specimen,\" he said in a press statement released on Tuesday [17 Jun 2014].\n\nIt is the 2nd laboratory-confirmed case of human infection of avian influenza following a case in Wonogiri, Central Java.\n\nOn [20 Apr 2014], a 2-year-old toddler died of avian flu following exposure to live poultry. An inquiry by the Health Ministry found that prior to RNA's death, almost 70 chickens had died from apparent avian flu infection.\n\nAccording to Tjandra, there have been 17 confirmed cases worldwide of avian flu in humans this year [2014]. Cambodia has recorded the most so far, with 9 cases, while Indonesia, Egypt, Viet Nam and China have recorded 2 cases each.\n\nCumulatively, Indonesia has witnessed 197 cases of humans infected with avian flu, making it the nation with the highest number of H5N1 human infection cases to date. Egypt and Viet Nam follow with 175 cases and 127 cases, respectively.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[As mentioned above, this is the 2nd reported case of human infection with influenza A, H5N1 in Indonesia this year (2014). Since 2003, Indonesia has reported 197 human cases of H5N1 infection, including 164 deaths.\n\nAccording to the most recent H5N1 human case summary report from WHO dated 5 May 2014, since 2003 through 5 May 2014, there were 665 laboratory-confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1) virus infection from 15 countries that were officially reported to WHO, including 392 deaths (see http://who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/Influenza_Summary_IRA_HA_interface_5May14.pdf?ua=1).\n\nIn 2014, ProMED-mail has reported on human infections with H5N1 in a Canadian with a history of visiting China, Egypt and Viet Nam in January 2014; in Viet Nam, China and Cambodia in February 2014; in Cambodia and Egypt in March 2014; in Egypt in April 2014 and in Indonesia in May 2014 (see prior ProMED-mail posts below).\n\nFor a map of Indonesia, see http://healthmap.org/promed/p/184. Maps showing the locations of human cases of H5N1 can be found at http://gamapserver.who.int/mapLibrary/app/searchResults.aspx. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (97): Indonesia (JT) H5N1 "2497716", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (97): Indonesia (JT) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2497716", "date": "2014-03-13 11:26:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (40): GERMANY (LOWER SAXONY) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 12 Mar 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2014; 27(11) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14940\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Germany\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 Mar 2014 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Ministerial Director and Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, [Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection] (BMELV), Bonn, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 9 Mar 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 Mar 2014\nReport date: 12 Mar 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Dec 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (14-614-00002): Laar, Vorwald (bei Emlichheim), [County of Bentheim, Lower Saxony]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 9 Mar 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 38 323 / 48 / 48 / 38 275 / 0 /\nAffected population: clinical signs: decrease of egg production. Free-range laying hens. 48 animals were already dead. 5 animals have been culled for diagnostic purposes and safely disposed of. The other 38 270 animals have also been culled and safely disposed of.\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.13 percent / 0.13 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: no movement of laying hens to other regions in Germany, Member States, or Third Countries. Contact with wild species cannot be excluded. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 Mar 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the last 2 years LPAI H5N1 has been reported in the provinces of Brandenburg, Lower Saxony (Niedersachsen), North Rhine-Westphalia (Nordrhein-Westfalen), Schleswig-Holstein, and Thuringen.\n\nFurther information on these outbreaks can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports (Note: to view the information on LPAI choose the region, country, and time period) and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (Note: to view the information on LPAI, choose the country, and scroll down to the name of the disease and time period). For further information on the outbreak in Thuringen, see Mod.CRD's comment in the ProMED-mail post 20131118.2061861.\n\nA map showing the outbreaks of LPAI in the European region can be obtained from http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseaseoutbreakmaps (Note: to view the information on LPAI, scroll down to the name of the disease, time period, and zoom in over the country of interest within that region).\n\nA map of the Germany's administrative divisions can be seen at http://www.ephotopix.com/germany_political_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/awB5. - Mod.CRD]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (35): Netherlands (FL) poultry, LPAI, H5N1, OIE 20140303.2307538\n2013\n----\nAvian influenza (99): Germany (BW) poultry, influenza (60): Germany (NI) poultry, H7N7, LPAI, OIE, RFI 20130516.1717982\nAvian influenza (42): Germany (NI) turkey, H7, LPAI 20130421.1661902\nAvian influenza (13): Germany (BB) poultry, LPAI
