"2014-03-13 11:26:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (40): GERMANY (LOWER SAXONY) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 12 Mar 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2014; 27(11) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14940\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Germany\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 Mar 2014 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Ministerial Director and Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, [Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection] (BMELV), Bonn, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 9 Mar 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 Mar 2014\nReport date: 12 Mar 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Dec 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (14-614-00002): Laar, Vorwald (bei Emlichheim), [County of Bentheim, Lower Saxony]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 9 Mar 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 38 323 / 48 / 48 / 38 275 / 0 /\nAffected population: clinical signs: decrease of egg production. Free-range laying hens. 48 animals were already dead. 5 animals have been culled for diagnostic purposes and safely disposed of. The other 38 270 animals have also been culled and safely disposed of.\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.13 percent / 0.13 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: no movement of laying hens to other regions in Germany, Member States, or Third Countries. Contact with wild species cannot be excluded. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 Mar 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the last 2 years LPAI H5N1 has been reported in the provinces of Brandenburg, Lower Saxony (Niedersachsen), North Rhine-Westphalia (Nordrhein-Westfalen), Schleswig-Holstein, and Thuringen.\n\nFurther information on these outbreaks can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports (Note: to view the information on LPAI choose the region, country, and time period) and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (Note: to view the information on LPAI, choose the country, and scroll down to the name of the disease and time period). For further information on the outbreak in Thuringen, see Mod.CRD's comment in the ProMED-mail post 20131118.2061861.\n\nA map showing the outbreaks of LPAI in the European region can be obtained from http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseaseoutbreakmaps (Note: to view the information on LPAI, scroll down to the name of the disease, time period, and zoom in over the country of interest within that region).\n\nA map of the Germany's administrative divisions can be seen at http://www.ephotopix.com/germany_political_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive 11:26:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (40): GERMANY (LOWER SAXONY) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 12 Mar 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2014; 27(11) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14940\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Germany\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 Mar 2014 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Ministerial Director and Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, [Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection] (BMELV), Bonn, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 9 Mar 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 Mar 2014\nReport date: 12 Mar 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Dec 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (14-614-00002): Laar, Vorwald (bei Emlichheim), [County of Bentheim, Lower Saxony]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 9 Mar 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 38 323 / 48 / 48 / 38 275 / 0 /\nAffected population: clinical signs: decrease of egg production. Free-range laying hens. 48 animals were already dead. 5 animals have been culled for diagnostic purposes and safely disposed of. The other 38 270 animals have also been culled and safely disposed of.\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.13 percent / 0.13 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: no movement of laying hens to other regions in Germany, Member States, or Third Countries. Contact with wild species cannot be excluded. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 Mar 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the last 2 years LPAI H5N1 has been reported in the provinces of Brandenburg, Lower Saxony (Niedersachsen), North Rhine-Westphalia (Nordrhein-Westfalen), Schleswig-Holstein, and Thuringen.\n\nFurther information on these outbreaks can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports (Note: to view the information on LPAI choose the region, country, and time period) and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (Note: to view the information on LPAI, choose the country, and scroll down to the name of the disease and time period). For further information on the outbreak in Thuringen, see Mod.CRD's comment in the ProMED-mail post 20131118.2061861.\n\nA map showing the outbreaks of LPAI in the European region can be obtained from http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseaseoutbreakmaps (Note: to view the information on LPAI, scroll down to the name of the disease, time period, and zoom in over the country of interest within that region).\n\nA map of the Germany's administrative divisions can be seen at http://www.ephotopix.com/germany_political_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/awB5. - Mod.CRD]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (35): Netherlands (FL) poultry, LPAI, H5N1, OIE 20140303.2307538\n2013\n----\nAvian influenza (99): Germany (BW) poultry, 11:26:56", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (40): GERMANY (LOWER SAXONY) POULTRY, LPAI H5N1, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 12 Mar 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2014; 27(11) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14940\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Germany\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 Mar 2014 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Ministerial Director and Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, [Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection] (BMELV), Bonn, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 9 Mar 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 Mar 2014\nReport date: 12 Mar 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Dec 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (14-614-00002): Laar, Vorwald (bei Emlichheim), [County of Bentheim, Lower Saxony]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 9 Mar 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 38 323 / 48 / 48 / 38 275 / 0 /\nAffected population: clinical signs: decrease of egg production. Free-range laying hens. 48 animals were already dead. 5 animals have been culled for diagnostic purposes and safely disposed of. The other 38 270 animals have also been culled and safely disposed of.\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.13 percent / 0.13 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: no movement of laying hens to other regions in Germany, Member States, or Third Countries. Contact with wild species cannot be excluded. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 Mar 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the last 2 years LPAI H5N1 has been reported in the provinces of Brandenburg, Lower Saxony (Niedersachsen), North Rhine-Westphalia (Nordrhein-Westfalen), Schleswig-Holstein, and Thuringen.\n\nFurther information on these outbreaks can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports (Note: to view the information on LPAI choose the region, country, and time period) and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (Note: to view the information on LPAI, choose the country, and scroll down to the name of the disease and time period). For further information on the outbreak in Thuringen, see Mod.CRD's comment in the ProMED-mail post 20131118.2061861.\n\nA map showing the outbreaks of LPAI in the European region can be obtained from http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseaseoutbreakmaps (Note: to view the information on LPAI, scroll down to the name of the disease, time period, and zoom in over the country of interest within that region).\n\nA map of the Germany's administrative divisions can be seen at http://www.ephotopix.com/germany_political_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/awB5. - Mod.CRD]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (35): Netherlands (FL) poultry, LPAI, H5N1, OIE 20140303.2307538\n2013\n----\nAvian influenza (99): Germany (BW) poultry, influenza (60): Germany (NI) poultry, H7N7, LPAI, OIE, RFI 20130516.1717982\nAvian influenza (42): Germany (NI) turkey, H7, LPAI 20130421.1661902\nAvian influenza (13): Germany (BB) poultry, LPAI H5N1, OIE 20130219.1550283\n2012\n----\nAvian influenza (69): Germany (SH) poultry, LPAI, H5, OIE 20121222.1464172\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (52): Germany (SN) LPAI, H7N7, OIE 20110708.2067\nAvian Information Database), weekly disease information 2014; 27(11) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14940\n\n\nLow pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Germany\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 Mar 2014 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Ministerial Director and Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, [Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection] (BMELV), Bonn, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 9 Mar 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 Mar 2014\nReport date: 12 Mar 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Dec 2013\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (14-614-00002): Laar, Vorwald (bei Emlichheim), [County of Bentheim, Lower Saxony]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 9 Mar 2014\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 38 323 / 48 / 48 / 38 275 / 0 /\nAffected population: clinical signs: decrease of egg production. Free-range laying hens. 48 animals were already dead. 5 animals have been culled for diagnostic purposes and safely disposed of. The other 38 270 animals have also been culled and safely disposed of.\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.13 percent / 0.13 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: no movement of laying hens to other regions in Germany, Member States, or Third Countries. Contact with wild species cannot be excluded. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 Mar 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the last 2 years LPAI H5N1 has been reported in the provinces of Brandenburg, Lower Saxony (Niedersachsen), North Rhine-Westphalia (Nordrhein-Westfalen), Schleswig-Holstein, and Thuringen.\n\nFurther information on these outbreaks can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports (Note: to view the information on LPAI choose the region, country, and time period) and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (Note: to view the information on LPAI, choose the country, and scroll down to the name of the disease and time period). For further information on the outbreak in Thuringen, see Mod.CRD's comment in the ProMED-mail post 20131118.2061861.\n\nA map showing the outbreaks of LPAI in the European region can be obtained from http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseaseoutbreakmaps (Note: to view the information on LPAI, scroll down to the name of the disease, time period, and zoom in over the country of interest within that region).\n\nA map of the Germany's administrative divisions can be seen at http://www.ephotopix.com/germany_political_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Germany\n-------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 12 Mar 2014 from Dr Karin Schwabenbauer, Ministerial Director and Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, [Federal Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Consumer Protection] (BMELV), Bonn, Germany\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 9 Mar 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 11 Mar 2014\nReport date: 12 Mar 2014\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (14-614-00002): Laar, Vorwald (bei Emlichheim), [County of Bentheim, Lower Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 38 323 / 48 / 48 / 38 275 / 0 /\nAffected population: clinical signs: decrease of egg production. Free-range laying hens. 48 animals were already dead. 5 animals have been culled for diagnostic purposes and safely disposed of. The other 38 270 animals have also been culled and safely disposed of.\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 0.13 percent / 0.13 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: no movement of laying hens to other regions in Germany, Member States, or Third Countries. Contact with wild species cannot be excluded. Note by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2013).\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time (PCR) / 11 Mar 2014 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During the last 2 years LPAI H5N1 has been reported in the provinces of Brandenburg, Lower Saxony (Niedersachsen), North Rhine-Westphalia (Nordrhein-Westfalen), Schleswig-Holstein, and Thuringen.\n\nFurther information on these outbreaks can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Countryreports (Note: to view the information on LPAI choose the region, country, and time period) and http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail (Note: to view the information on LPAI, choose the country, and scroll down to the name of the disease and time period). "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2329866", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (39): Libya (Tubruq) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2329866", "date": "2014-02-26 22:07:39", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (30): NEPAL (LALITPUR), H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Feb 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2014; 27(09) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14843\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 26 Feb 2014 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal.\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 18 Feb 2014\nReport date: 26 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Oct 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Itahari Municipality 7, Itahari, Sunsari, Koshi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2000 / 570 / 570 / 1430 / 0\nAffected population: A commercial layer farm in production stage kept in deep litter system.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 28.5 percent / 28.5 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Birds showed depression, decreased egg production followed by death with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and paralysis.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral veterinary laboratory (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 18 Feb 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Feb 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease Nepal\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 26 Feb 2014 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal.\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 18 Feb 2014\nReport date: 26 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Oct 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Itahari Municipality 7, Itahari, Sunsari, Koshi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2000 / 570 / 570 / 1430 / 0\nAffected population: A commercial layer farm in production stage kept in deep litter system.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 28.5 percent / 28.5 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Birds showed depression, decreased egg production followed by death with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and paralysis.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral veterinary laboratory (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 18 Feb 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to information found in the WAHID database, on 27 Aug 2012, Nepal reported an event of HPAI, subtype H5N1. 22:07:39", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (30): NEPAL (LALITPUR), H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Feb 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2014; 27(09) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14843\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 26 Feb 2014 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal.\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 18 Feb 2014\nReport date: 26 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Oct 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Itahari Municipality 7, Itahari, Sunsari, Koshi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2000 / 570 / 570 / 1430 / 0\nAffected population: A commercial layer farm in production stage kept in deep litter system.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 28.5 percent / 28.5 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Birds showed depression, decreased egg production followed by death with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and paralysis.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral veterinary laboratory (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 18 Feb 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to information found in the WAHID database, on 27 Aug 2012, Nepal reported an event of HPAI, subtype H5N1. The last outbreak reported during this event was dated 14 Sep 2013. A total of 210 outbreaks were reported in the zones of Bagmati, Bheri Gandaki, Janakpur, Lumbini, Mechi, Narayani, and Seti.\n\nThe affected population was:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2 076 755 / 184 776 / 184 776 / 1 891 879 / 0\nHouse Crow / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\n\nIn their final report sent on 3 Jan 2014, Nepal declared the event as resolved in October 2013. See the report at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000014609_20140103_132713.pdf.\n\nNepal is now organized into 14 zones. See http://www.statoids.com/unp.html. A map of the zone divisions is available at, http://www.ephotopix.com/image/asia/nepal_zone_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/9Xpf.]\nSee {"archive_id": "2302681", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (30): Nepal (LL) H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2302681", "date": "2014-02-26 22:07:39", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (30): NEPAL (LALITPUR), H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Feb 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2014; 27(09) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14843\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 26 Feb 2014 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal.\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Feb 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 18 Feb 2014\nReport date: 26 Feb 2014\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Feb 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 10 Oct 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Itahari Municipality 7, Itahari, Sunsari, Koshi\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Feb 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2000 / 570 / 570 / 1430 / 0\nAffected population: A commercial layer farm in production stage kept in deep litter system.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 28.5 percent / 28.5 percent / 100 percent / 100 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: Birds showed depression, decreased egg production followed by death with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and paralysis.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping/spraying\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral veterinary laboratory (National laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 18 Feb 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to information found in the WAHID database, on 27 Aug 2012, Nepal reported an event of HPAI, subtype H5N1. The last outbreak reported during this event was dated 14 Sep 2013. A total of 210 outbreaks were reported in the zones of Bagmati, Bheri Gandaki, Janakpur, Lumbini, Mechi, Narayani, and Seti.\n\nThe affected population was:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 2 076 755 / 184 776 / 184 776 / 1 891 879 / 0\nHouse Crow / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0\n\nIn their final report sent on 3 Jan 2014, Nepal declared the event as resolved in October 2013. See the report at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000014609_20140103_132713.pdf.\n\nNepal is now organized into 14 zones. See http://www.statoids.com/unp.html. A map of the zone divisions is available at, http://www.ephotopix.com/image/asia/nepal_zone_map.gif. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/9Xpf.]\nSee {"archive_id": "2297478", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (29): Viet Nam, H5N1, spread, poultry, OIE, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2297478", "date": "2014-02-14 15:26:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (21): VIET NAM, H5N1 SPREAD, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Feb 2014\nSource: Radio The Voice of Viet Nam (VOV) [in Vietnamese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://vov.vn/Xa-hoi/Chu-dong-ngan-chan-cum-AH7N9-lay-lan-vao-Viet-Nam/310449.vov\n\n\n[The VOV reporter interviewed Viet Nam's Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Cao Duc Phat, on the issue of Viet Nam's preparedness for possible introduction of A/H7N9 from China. The last question addressed H5N1].\n\nQ: Apart from the risk of A/H7N9 flu, the Central and Central Highland provinces of our country currently have an A/H5N1 influenza outbreak. What can the minister recommend to the people in this respect?\n\nMinister Cao Duc Phat: During this time, the influenza A/H5N1 is on the drive [upswing]. The prevention of this virus has been ascribed to the local authorities who are directed to coordinate the implementation of the relevant regulations. Special attention should be paid to the organization of surveillance activities to detect outbreaks promptly and to handle them thoroughly. In particular, we conduct vaccination in accordance with the provisions of the veterinary authority. Regarding the ongoing outbreak, we suggest that farmers comply with recommendations of the veterinary surgeons concerning disinfection measures to prevent the spread of the virus to poultry. In particular, be wary of the virus capacity to infect humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viet Nam has submitted its follow-up report no 4 on the recent epizootic on Thu 13 Feb 2014. The current epizootic reportedly started in October 2013 and has caused, so far, 11 outbreaks, including the 6 new outbreaks covered in the current report, which are located in 6 separate provinces distributed throughout the country, from north to south (Nam Dinh, Khanh Hoa, Tay Ninh, Quang Ngai, Ca Mau, and Kon Tum).\n\nThe report does not specify the species affected (that is, chickens, ducks, geese, etc.).\n\nAccording to the report above, Viet Nam's applied control measures are: stamping out, movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s).\n\nViet Nam is known to be infected by HPAI H5N1 since 2003. Its last major epizootic reportedly started in December 2006, with 360 outbreaks reported to the OIE throughout the years 2007-2012. Several outbreaks have been reported since. In September 2012, the Vietnamese noted the spread in the north of a new, extremely pathogenic strain of the H5N1 virus, suspected to have originated in China (see ProMED-mail posts 20120908.1286497, 20120910.1288966, and 20120920.1300398).\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has reported 126 human cases of avian influenza H5N1, of which 63 died. Of the 126, a total of 112 were recorded in the year 2003. Since that time, there have only been sporadic human cases of H5N1 virus infection in Viet Nam. As noted by Mod.CP (in ProMED-mail post 20140201.2248635) \"...therefore, it is too early to conclude that the human case in 2014 is the harbinger of a new outbreak.\"\n\nFor an updated event summary with links to all follow-up reports and an interactive map, please go to http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=14229 (click for a larger map, zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (51): Viet Nam (DT) H5N1, fatal 20140201.2248635\nAvian influenza, human (29): Viet Nam (BP) H5N1, fatal 20140121.2221781\nAvian influenza (20): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, poultry, OIE 20140213.2275510\nAvian influenza (18): Viet Nam (KT,TH) H5N1, poultry, susp, RFI 20140212.2273278\nAvian influenza (04): China (HU) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE, RFI 20140114.2170865\nAvian influenza (01): China (GZ) HPAI H5N1, poultry 20140103.2149620\n2013\n----\nAvian influenza OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious the issue of Viet Nam's preparedness for possible introduction of A/H7N9 from China. The last question addressed H5N1].\n\nQ: Apart from the risk of A/H7N9 flu, the Central and Central Highland provinces of our country currently have an A/H5N1 influenza outbreak. The prevention of this virus has been ascribed to the local authorities who are directed to coordinate the implementation of the relevant regulations. Special attention should be paid to the organization of surveillance activities to detect outbreaks promptly and to handle them thoroughly. In particular, we conduct vaccination in accordance with the provisions of the veterinary authority. Regarding the ongoing outbreak, we suggest that farmers comply with recommendations of the veterinary surgeons concerning disinfection measures to prevent the spread of the virus to poultry. In particular, be wary of the virus capacity to infect humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viet Nam has submitted its follow-up report no 4 on the recent epizootic on Thu 13 Feb 2014. The current epizootic reportedly started in October 2013 and has caused, so far, 11 outbreaks, including the 6 new outbreaks covered in the current report, which are located in 6 separate provinces distributed throughout the country, from north to south (Nam Dinh, Khanh Hoa, Tay Ninh, Quang Ngai, Ca Mau, and Kon Tum).\n\nThe report does not specify the species affected (that is, chickens, ducks, geese, etc.).\n\nAccording to the report above, Viet Nam's applied control measures are: stamping out, movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s).\n\nViet Nam is known to be infected by HPAI H5N1 since 2003. Its last major epizootic reportedly started in December 2006, with 360 outbreaks reported to the OIE throughout the years 2007-2012. Several outbreaks have been reported since. In September 2012, the Vietnamese noted the spread in the north of a new, extremely pathogenic strain of the H5N1 virus, suspected to have originated in China (see ProMED-mail posts 20120908.1286497, 20120910.1288966, and 20120920.1300398).\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has reported 126 human cases of avian influenza H5N1, of which 63 died. Of the 126, a total of 112 were recorded in the year 2003. Since that time, there have only been sporadic human cases of H5N1 virus infection in Viet Nam. As noted by Mod.CP (in ProMED-mail post 20140201.2248635) \"...therefore, it is too early to conclude that the human case in 2014 is the harbinger of a new outbreak.\"\n\nFor an updated event summary with links to all follow-up reports and an interactive map, please go to http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=14229 (click for a larger map, zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (51): Viet Nam (DT) H5N1, fatal 20140201.2248635\nAvian influenza, human (29): Viet Nam (BP) H5N1, fatal 20140121.2221781\nAvian influenza (20): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, poultry, OIE 20140213.2275510\nAvian influenza (18): Viet Nam (KT,TH) H5N1, poultry, susp, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2287700", "date": "2014-02-14 15:26:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (21): VIET NAM, H5N1 SPREAD, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Feb 2014\nSource: Radio The Voice of Viet Nam (VOV) [in Vietnamese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://vov.vn/Xa-hoi/Chu-dong-ngan-chan-cum-AH7N9-lay-lan-vao-Viet-Nam/310449.vov\n\n\n[The VOV reporter interviewed Viet Nam's Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Cao Duc Phat, on the issue of Viet Nam's preparedness for possible introduction of A/H7N9 from China. The last question addressed H5N1].\n\nQ: Apart from the risk of A/H7N9 flu, the Central and Central Highland provinces of our country currently have an A/H5N1 influenza outbreak. What can the minister recommend to the people in this respect?\n\nMinister Cao Duc Phat: During this time, the influenza A/H5N1 is on the drive [upswing]. The prevention of this virus has been ascribed to the local authorities who are directed to coordinate the implementation of the relevant regulations. Special attention should be paid to the organization of surveillance activities to detect outbreaks promptly and to handle them thoroughly. In particular, we conduct vaccination in accordance with the provisions of the veterinary authority. Regarding the ongoing outbreak, we suggest that farmers comply with recommendations of the veterinary surgeons concerning disinfection measures to prevent the spread of the virus to poultry. In particular, be wary of the virus capacity to infect humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viet Nam has submitted its follow-up report no 4 on the recent epizootic on Thu 13 Feb 2014. The current epizootic reportedly started in October 2013 and has caused, so far, 11 outbreaks, including the 6 new outbreaks covered in the current report, which are located in 6 separate provinces distributed throughout the country, from north to south (Nam Dinh, Khanh Hoa, Tay Ninh, Quang Ngai, Ca Mau, and Kon Tum).\n\nThe report does not specify the species affected (that is, chickens, ducks, geese, etc.).\n\nAccording to the report above, Viet Nam's applied control measures are: stamping out, movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s).\n\nViet Nam is known to be infected by HPAI H5N1 since 2003. Its last major epizootic reportedly started in December 2006, with 360 outbreaks reported to the OIE throughout the years 2007-2012. Several outbreaks have been reported since. In September 2012, the Vietnamese noted the spread in the north of a new, extremely pathogenic strain of the H5N1 virus, suspected to have originated in China (see ProMED-mail posts 20120908.1286497, 20120910.1288966, and 20120920.1300398).\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has reported 126 human cases of avian influenza H5N1, of which 63 died. Of the 126, a total of 112 were recorded in the year 2003. Since that time, there have only been sporadic human cases of H5N1 virus infection in Viet Nam. As noted by Mod.CP (in ProMED-mail post 20140201.2248635) \"...therefore, it is too early to conclude that the human case in 2014 is the harbinger of a new outbreak.\"\n\nFor an updated event summary with links to all follow-up reports and an interactive map, please go to http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=14229 (click for a larger map, zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (51): Viet Nam (DT) H5N1, fatal 20140201.2248635\nAvian "Vietnam"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "POULTRY", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2278294", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (21): Viet Nam, H5N1 spread, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2278294", "date": "2014-02-14 15:26:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (21): VIET NAM, H5N1 SPREAD, POULTRY, OIE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Feb 2014\nSource: Radio The Voice of Viet Nam (VOV) [in Vietnamese, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://vov.vn/Xa-hoi/Chu-dong-ngan-chan-cum-AH7N9-lay-lan-vao-Viet-Nam/310449.vov\n\n\n[The VOV reporter interviewed Viet Nam's Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Cao Duc Phat, on the issue of Viet Nam's preparedness for possible introduction of A/H7N9 from China. The last question addressed H5N1].\n\nQ: Apart from the risk of A/H7N9 flu, the Central and Central Highland provinces of our country currently have an A/H5N1 influenza outbreak. What can the minister recommend to the people in this respect?\n\nMinister Cao Duc Phat: During this time, the influenza A/H5N1 is on the drive [upswing]. The prevention of this virus has been ascribed to the local authorities who are directed to coordinate the implementation of the relevant regulations. Special attention should be paid to the organization of surveillance activities to detect outbreaks promptly and to handle them thoroughly. In particular, we conduct vaccination in accordance with the provisions of the veterinary authority. Regarding the ongoing outbreak, we suggest that farmers comply with recommendations of the veterinary surgeons concerning disinfection measures to prevent the spread of the virus to poultry. In particular, be wary of the virus capacity to infect humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Viet Nam has submitted its follow-up report no 4 on the recent epizootic on Thu 13 Feb 2014. The current epizootic reportedly started in October 2013 and has caused, so far, 11 outbreaks, including the 6 new outbreaks covered in the current report, which are located in 6 separate provinces distributed throughout the country, from north to south (Nam Dinh, Khanh Hoa, Tay Ninh, Quang Ngai, Ca Mau, and Kon Tum).\n\nThe report does not specify the species affected (that is, chickens, ducks, geese, etc.).\n\nAccording to the report above, Viet Nam's applied control measures are: stamping out, movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s).\n\nViet Nam is known to be infected by HPAI H5N1 since 2003. Its last major epizootic reportedly started in December 2006, with 360 outbreaks reported to the OIE throughout the years 2007-2012. Several outbreaks have been reported since. In September 2012, the Vietnamese noted the spread in the north of a new, extremely pathogenic strain of the H5N1 virus, suspected to have originated in China (see ProMED-mail posts 20120908.1286497, 20120910.1288966, and 20120920.1300398).\n\nSince 2003, Viet Nam has reported 126 human cases of avian influenza H5N1, of which 63 died. Of the 126, a total of 112 were recorded in the year 2003. Since that time, there have only been sporadic human cases of H5N1 virus infection in Viet Nam. As noted by Mod.CP (in ProMED-mail post 20140201.2248635) \"...therefore, it is too early to conclude that the human case in 2014 is the harbinger of a new outbreak.\"\n\nFor an updated event summary with links to all follow-up reports and an interactive map, please go to http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=14229 (click for a larger map, zoom in). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (51): Viet Nam (DT) H5N1, fatal 20140201.2248635\nAvian influenza, human (29): Viet Nam (BP) H5N1, fatal 20140121.2221781\nAvian influenza (20): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, poultry, OIE 20140213.2275510\nAvian influenza (18): Viet Nam (KT,TH) H5N1, poultry, susp, RFI 20140212.2273278\nAvian influenza (04): China (HU) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE, RFI 20140114.2170865\nAvian influenza (01): China (GZ) HPAI H5N1, poultry 20140103.2149620\n2013\n----\nAvian influenza a/h5n1"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2014-02-13 00:00:00", "2013-10-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-12-16 00:00:00", "2012-09-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 "Vietnam"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "POULTRY", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2275510", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (20): Cambodia (KC) H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2275510", "date": "2014-01-21 15:46:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (29): VIET NAM (BINH PHUOC), H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-01/20/c_133060530.htm\n\n\nThe 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday [20 Jan 2014].\n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient was later confirmed infected with the virus, said the announcement, adding that his lung was damaged quickly. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. When poultry are detected sick or dead, local authorities should be informed immediately.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. The patient was moved to Binh Phuoc provincial General Hospital 6 days later, yet his health continued deteriorating quickly. He was then brought to HCM City Hospital for Tropical Diseases on 18 Jan 2014 for emergency treatment, but he died on the same day. His blood sample tested positive for the deadly virulent strain A/H5N1. He was said to have slaughtered ducks and eaten duck meat. Epidemiological examinations show that a number of chickens raised by the patient's family and neighbours died of unknown causes.\n\nThe Preventive Medicine Department directed the Binh Phuoc provincial Department of Health to conduct epidemiological tests and intensify measures against a possible outbreak of bird flu in the locality. The HCM City Pasteur Institute was required to fan out to the affected commune to help with prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. It is surrounded by Cambodia on the north and northwest, Dak Nong and Lam Dong provinces on the east, Dong Nai and Binh Duong provinces on the south, and Tay Ninh Province on the west. Binh Phuoc has plenty of forests with industrial trees such as rubber, coffee, cashew nut, and pepper. The main rivers are Saigon, Be, and Dong Nai.\n\nIts location can be found in the map at: http://www.vietnamtourism.com/e_pages/country/province.asp?mt=84651&uid=1238. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (28): China H7N9 WHO update 20140120.2219294\nAvian influenza, human (27): China victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2273521", "date": "2014-01-21 15:46:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (29): VIET NAM (BINH PHUOC), H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-01/20/c_133060530.htm\n\n\nThe 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday [20 Jan 2014].\n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient was later confirmed infected with the virus, said the announcement, adding that his lung was damaged quickly. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. When poultry are detected sick or dead, local authorities should be informed immediately.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. The patient was moved to Binh Phuoc provincial General Hospital 6 days later, yet his health continued deteriorating quickly. He was then brought to HCM City Hospital for Tropical Diseases on 18 Jan 2014 for emergency treatment, but he died on the same day. His blood sample tested positive for the deadly virulent strain A/H5N1. He was said to have slaughtered ducks and eaten duck meat. Epidemiological examinations show that a number of chickens raised by the patient's family and neighbours died of unknown causes.\n\nThe Preventive Medicine Department directed the Binh Phuoc provincial Department of Health to conduct epidemiological tests and intensify measures against a possible outbreak of bird flu in the locality. The HCM City Pasteur Institute was required to fan out to the affected commune to help with prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. It is surrounded by Cambodia on the north and northwest, Dak Nong and Lam Dong provinces on the east, Dong Nai and Binh Duong provinces on the south, and Tay Ninh Province on the west. Binh Phuoc has plenty of forests with industrial trees such as rubber, coffee, cashew nut, and pepper. "country": "Armenia"}, {"location": "GD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "JS", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2273278", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (18): Viet Nam (KT,TH) H5N1, poultry, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2273278", "date": "2014-01-21 15:46:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (29): VIET NAM (BINH PHUOC), H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-01/20/c_133060530.htm\n\n\nThe 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday [20 Jan 2014].\n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient was later confirmed infected with the virus, said the announcement, adding that his lung was damaged quickly. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. When poultry are detected sick or dead, local authorities should be informed immediately.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. The patient was moved to Binh Phuoc provincial General Hospital 6 days later, yet his health continued deteriorating quickly. He was then brought to HCM City Hospital for Tropical Diseases on 18 Jan 2014 for emergency treatment, but he died on the same day. His blood sample tested positive for the deadly virulent strain A/H5N1. He was said to have slaughtered ducks and eaten duck meat. Epidemiological examinations show that a number of chickens raised by the patient's family and neighbours died of unknown causes.\n\nThe Preventive Medicine Department directed the Binh Phuoc provincial Department of Health to conduct epidemiological tests and intensify measures against a possible outbreak of bird flu in the locality. The HCM City Pasteur Institute was required to fan out to the affected commune to help with prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. It is surrounded by Cambodia on the north and northwest, Dak Nong and Lam Dong provinces on the east, Dong Nai and Binh Duong provinces on the south, and Tay Ninh Province on the west. Binh Phuoc has plenty of forests with industrial trees such as rubber, coffee, cashew nut, and pepper. The main rivers are Saigon, Be, and Dong Nai.\n\nIts location can be found in the map at: http://www.vietnamtourism.com/e_pages/country/province.asp?mt=84651&uid=1238. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (28): China H7N9 WHO update 20140120.2219294\nAvian influenza, human (27): China Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-01/20/c_133060530.htm\n\n\nThe 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday [20 Jan 2014].\n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient was later confirmed infected with the virus, said the announcement, adding that his lung was damaged quickly. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. When poultry are detected sick or dead, local authorities should be informed immediately.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. The patient was moved to Binh Phuoc provincial General Hospital 6 days later, yet his health continued deteriorating quickly. He was then brought to HCM City Hospital for Tropical Diseases on 18 Jan 2014 for emergency treatment, but he died on the same day. His blood sample tested positive for the deadly virulent strain A/H5N1. He was said to have slaughtered ducks and eaten duck meat. Epidemiological examinations show that a number of chickens raised by the patient's family and neighbours died of unknown causes.\n\nThe Preventive Medicine Department directed the Binh Phuoc provincial Department of Health to conduct epidemiological tests and intensify measures against a possible outbreak of bird flu in the locality. The HCM City Pasteur Institute was required to fan out to the affected commune to help with prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. Binh Phuoc has plenty of forests with industrial trees such as rubber, coffee, cashew nut, and pepper. "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "JS", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2248635", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (51): Viet Nam (DT) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2248635", "date": "2014-01-21 15:46:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (29): VIET NAM (BINH PHUOC), H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-01/20/c_133060530.htm\n\n\nThe 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday [20 Jan 2014].\n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient was later confirmed infected with the virus, said the announcement, adding that his lung was damaged quickly. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. When poultry are detected sick or dead, local authorities should be informed immediately.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. The patient was moved to Binh Phuoc provincial General Hospital 6 days later, yet his health continued deteriorating quickly. He was then brought to HCM City Hospital for Tropical Diseases on 18 Jan 2014 for emergency treatment, but he died on the same day. His blood sample tested positive for the deadly virulent strain A/H5N1. He was said to have slaughtered ducks and eaten duck meat. Epidemiological examinations show that a number of chickens raised by the patient's family and neighbours died of unknown causes.\n\nThe Preventive Medicine Department directed the Binh Phuoc provincial Department of Health to conduct epidemiological tests and intensify measures against a possible outbreak of bird flu in the locality. The HCM City Pasteur Institute was required to fan out to the affected commune to help with prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. It is surrounded by Cambodia on the north and northwest, Dak Nong and Lam Dong provinces on the east, Dong Nai and Binh Duong provinces on the south, and Tay Ninh Province on the west. Binh Phuoc has plenty of forests with industrial trees such as rubber, coffee, cashew nut, and pepper. The main rivers are Saigon, Be, and Dong Nai.\n\nIts location can be found in the map at: http://www.vietnamtourism.com/e_pages/country/province.asp?mt=84651&uid=1238. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1jtz.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (28): China H7N9 WHO update 20140120.2219294\nAvian influenza, human (27): China "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2221781", "date": "2014-01-21 15:46:08", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (29): VIET NAM (BINH PHUOC), H5N1, FATAL\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua, English News [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-01/20/c_133060530.htm\n\n\nThe 1st death caused by H5N1 bird flu in Viet Nam in 2014 has been reported in southern Binh Phuc province, the country's Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health announced late Monday [20 Jan 2014].\n\nThe victim, a man aged 52, was hospitalized on 11 Jan 2014 due to symptoms of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. The patient was later confirmed infected with the virus, said the announcement, adding that his lung was damaged quickly. He died on 18 Jan 2014, the 1st death in Viet Nam in 2014 after 9 months without any H5N1 bird flu cases reported in humans.\n\nThe department recommended that local people should not eat sick, dead, or unknown-origin poultry. When poultry are detected sick or dead, local authorities should be informed immediately.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 20 Jan 3014\nSource: Xinhuanet, English news [edited]\nhttp://english.vov.vn/Society/Health/Vietnam-reports-1st-H5N1-birth-flu-death/272538.vov\n\n\nViet Nam's health officials on 20 Jan 2014 confirmed a 1st H5N1 avian flu death in the southern province of Binh Phuoc, the 1st in 2014.\n\nThe 52-year-old man, living in Binh Minh commune, Bu Dang district, was hospitalised on 11 Jan 2014, showing flu-like symptoms such as fever, coughing, and breathing difficulties. The patient was moved to Binh Phuoc provincial General Hospital 6 days later, yet his health continued deteriorating quickly. He was then brought to HCM City Hospital for Tropical Diseases on 18 Jan 2014 for emergency treatment, but he died on the same day. His blood sample tested positive for the deadly virulent strain A/H5N1. He was said to have slaughtered ducks and eaten duck meat. Epidemiological examinations show that a number of chickens raised by the patient's family and neighbours died of unknown causes.\n\nThe Preventive Medicine Department directed the Binh Phuoc provincial Department of Health to conduct epidemiological tests and intensify measures against a possible outbreak of bird flu in the locality. The HCM City Pasteur Institute was required to fan out to the affected commune to help with prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Binh Phuoc is in the south of Viet Nam. It is surrounded by Cambodia on the north and northwest, Dak Nong and Lam Dong provinces on the east, Dong Nai and Binh Duong provinces on the south, and Tay Ninh Province on the west. Binh Phuoc has plenty of forests with industrial trees such as rubber, coffee, cashew nut, and pepper. The main rivers are Saigon, Be, and Dong Nai.\n\nIts location can be found in the map at: http://www.vietnamtourism.com/e_pages/country/province.asp?mt=84651&uid=1238. - Mod.CP\n\nA "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2184238", "date": "2014-01-03 11:11:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-01/02/c_133014326.htm\n\n\nThe southwest China province of Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\n[Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already reported to the OIE the new HPAI H5N1 outbreak described above and its stamping out; see the immediate notification, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue village, Libo, Qiannan, Guizhou province.\nStarted: 27 Dec 2013\nPre-confirmed: 2 Jan 2014\nSubmitted to OIE: 3 Jan 2014\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). See, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=13445. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5kNo.]\nSee China (Tibet) HPAI H5N1, poultry 20130513.1710726\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (GZ) 20130211.1538795\nAvian influenza (08): China (HK) H5N1, gull, OIE 20130204.1528327\n2012\n----\nAvian population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet.
