"date": "2014-01-03 11:11:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-01/02/c_133014326.htm\n\n\nThe southwest China province of Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\n[Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already reported to the OIE the new HPAI H5N1 outbreak described above and its stamping out; see the immediate notification, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue village, Libo, Qiannan, Guizhou province.\nStarted: 27 Dec 2013\nPre-confirmed: 2 Jan 2014\nSubmitted to OIE: 3 Jan 2014\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). See, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=13445. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5kNo.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nAvian influenza, human (141): China: southern, H5N1 seroprevalence 20131117.2060088\nAvian influenza, human (109) China: H5N1 & H7N9 emergence 20130822.1892436\nAvian influenza (57): China (Tibet) HPAI H5N1, poultry 20130513.1710726\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (GZ) 20130211.1538795\nAvian influenza (08): China (HK) H5N1, gull, OIE 20130204.1528327\n2012\n----\nAvian influenza (55): China (GD) H5N1, poultry 20120918.1298881\nAvian influenza (42): China (XJ) H5N1, poultry 20120703.1188082\nAvian influenza (36): China (GS) H5N1, poultry 20120607.1158815\n.................................................arn/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2014-01-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2014-01-02 00:00:00", "2013-12-27 00:00:00", "2014-01-02 00:00:00", "2014-01-03 00:00:00", "4569-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-05-13 00:00:00", "2013-06-18 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2055-03-16 00:00:00", "2042-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Libo County", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Qiannan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Libo", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guizhou", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2167852", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (14): Canada ex China (BJ) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2167852", "date": "2014-01-03 11:11:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-01/02/c_133014326.htm\n\n\nThe southwest China province of Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\n[Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already reported to the OIE the new HPAI H5N1 outbreak described above and its stamping out; see the immediate notification, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue village, Libo, Qiannan, Guizhou province.\nStarted: 27 Dec 2013\nPre-confirmed: 2 Jan 2014\nSubmitted to OIE: 3 Jan 2014\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). See, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=13445. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5kNo.]\nSee China (Tibet) HPAI H5N1, poultry 20130513.1710726\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (GZ) 20130211.1538795\nAvian influenza (08): China (HK) H5N1, gull, OIE 20130204.1528327\n2012\n----\nAvian influenza (55): China (GD) H5N1, poultry 20120918.1298881\nAvian influenza (42): China (XJ) H5N1, poultry 20120703.1188082\nAvian influenza (36): China (GS) H5N1, poultry "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2167282", "date": "2014-01-03 11:11:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-01/02/c_133014326.htm\n\n\nThe southwest China province of Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\n[Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already reported to the OIE the new HPAI H5N1 outbreak described above and its stamping out; see the immediate notification, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue village, Libo, Qiannan, Guizhou province.\nStarted: 27 Dec 2013\nPre-confirmed: 2 Jan 2014\nSubmitted to OIE: 3 Jan 2014\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). See, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=13445. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5kNo.]\nSee POULTRY\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-01/02/c_133014326.htm\n\n\nThe southwest China province of Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\n[Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already reported to the OIE the new HPAI H5N1 outbreak described above and its stamping out; see the immediate notification, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue village, Libo, Qiannan, Guizhou province.\nStarted: 27 Dec 2013\nPre-confirmed: 2 Jan 2014\nSubmitted to OIE: 3 Jan 2014\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). See, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=13445. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5kNo.]\nSee Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). "2014-01-03 11:11:29", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (01): CHINA (GUIZHOU) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jan 2014\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english/health/2014-01/02/c_133014326.htm\n\n\nThe southwest China province of Guizhou has reported an outbreak of H5N1 [avian influenza infection] in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced Thursday [2 Jan 2014].\n\nSome chickens at a farm in a village of Libo County in the prefecture of Qiannan in Guizhou showed symptoms of suspected avian flu and 8500 chickens died on 27 Dec 2013.\n\nThe National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, according to the MOA.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 23 067 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\n[Editor: Zhu Ningzhu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[China has already reported to the OIE the new HPAI H5N1 outbreak described above and its stamping out; see the immediate notification, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14598.\n\nThe immediate notification included the following outbreak data:\n\nLocation: Yijue village, Libo, Qiannan, Guizhou province.\nStarted: 27 Dec 2013\nPre-confirmed: 2 Jan 2014\nSubmitted to OIE: 3 Jan 2014\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 31 567 / 9300 / 8500 / 23 067 / 0\n\nAll the cases (9300) were recorded in chickens; 18 250 chickens, 4569 ducks, and 248 geese were destroyed.\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBirds / 29.46 percent / 26.93 percent / 91.40 percent / 100 percent.\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n\nThe very high case fatality rate is typical for HPAI outbreaks in susceptible birds (chickens).\n\nThe previous HPAI H5N1 outbreak in poultry took place in a small holding in Tibet. Reportedly, it started on 13 May 2013 and was declared resolved on 18 Jun 2013. Out of 376 birds there were 35 cases (died). The 341 remaining chickens and 31 geese were destroyed (see ProMED-mail post 20130513.1710726). See, with map, at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=13445. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/5kNo.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nAvian influenza, human (141): China: southern, H5N1 seroprevalence 20131117.2060088\nAvian influenza, human (109) China: H5N1 & H7N9 emergence 20130822.1892436\nAvian influenza (57): China (Tibet) HPAI H5N1, poultry 20130513.1710726\nAvian influenza, human (05): China (GZ) 20130211.1538795\nAvian influenza (08): China (HK) H5N1, gull, OIE 20130204.1528327\n2012\n----\nAvian "2013-11-01 14:48:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (131): CAMBODIA (BATTAMBANG) H5N1\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Oct 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/h5n1-avian-influenza-cambodia-reports-22nd-case-in-girl-from-battambang-province-38291/\n\n\nCambodia Reports 22nd Case of H5N1 in Battambang Province\n---------------------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia has announced a new human case of H5N1 avian influenza, according to a ministry press release Wednesday [30 Oct 2013]. According to the release (http://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/43-Pressrelease_Eg.pdf): The case is a 6-year-old girl from Romdoul village, Romdoul commune, Phnom Preuk district, Battambang province confirmed positive for H5N avian influenza virus infection on 24 Oct 2013 by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge. The girl developed fever on 14 Oct 2013. On 15 Oct 2013, her parents sought treatment for her in the village. The girl's condition worsened and the girl was referred to the Jayavarman VII Hospital in Siem Reap. On 19 Oct 2013 she was admitted to the Jayavarman VII Hospital with fever, cough, abdominal pain, running nose, sore throat and dyspnea. Laboratory samples were taken on 22 Oct 2013 and Tamiflu administered on 24 Oct 2013. The girl is currently in a stable condition.\n\nThis brings the total number of human H5N1 avian influenza cases to 22 this year [2013]. The investigation reveals that chickens and ducks have recently died in the girl's neighbor's house and in nearly villages. Health officials in Cambodia are identifying the child's close contacts as well as studying whether there are any epidemiologic links among the 22 patients infected this year. Animal health workers are investigating deaths in birds in the area. A statement from Minister of Health Dr. Mam Bunheng points out the special danger of H5N1 to children in that they commonly care for, feed, and clean the cages of domestic poultry and often treat them as pets. Parents are being urged through public health education campaigns to keep children away from sick or dead poultry, not allow them to play with chickens and ducks, and make sure they wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after contact with poultry.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 33 confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus recorded globally during 2013, a total of 22 have occurred in Cambodia.\n\nA map of the administrative divisions of Cambodia, showing the location of Battambang province, can be accessed at: http://www.vidiani.com/?p=3257. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/90qV.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (130): China, H7N9, CDC "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2046967", "date": "2013-11-01 14:48:12", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (131): CAMBODIA (BATTAMBANG) H5N1\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Oct 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/h5n1-avian-influenza-cambodia-reports-22nd-case-in-girl-from-battambang-province-38291/\n\n\nCambodia Reports 22nd Case of H5N1 in Battambang Province\n---------------------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health (MoH) of the Kingdom of Cambodia has announced a new human case of H5N1 avian influenza, according to a ministry press release Wednesday [30 Oct 2013]. According to the release (http://www.cdcmoh.gov.kh/PressRelease/43-Pressrelease_Eg.pdf): The case is a 6-year-old girl from Romdoul village, Romdoul commune, Phnom Preuk district, Battambang province confirmed positive for H5N avian influenza virus infection on 24 Oct 2013 by Institut Pasteur du Cambodge. The girl developed fever on 14 Oct 2013. On 15 Oct 2013, her parents sought treatment for her in the village. The girl's condition worsened and the girl was referred to the Jayavarman VII Hospital in Siem Reap. On 19 Oct 2013 she was admitted to the Jayavarman VII Hospital with fever, cough, abdominal pain, running nose, sore throat and dyspnea. Laboratory samples were taken on 22 Oct 2013 and Tamiflu administered on 24 Oct 2013. The girl is currently in a stable condition.\n\nThis brings the total number of human H5N1 avian influenza cases to 22 this year [2013]. The investigation reveals that chickens and ducks have recently died in the girl's neighbor's house and in nearly villages. Health officials in Cambodia are identifying the child's close contacts as well as studying whether there are any epidemiologic links among the 22 patients infected this year. Animal health workers are investigating deaths in birds in the area. A statement from Minister of Health Dr. Mam Bunheng points out the special danger of H5N1 to children in that they commonly care for, feed, and clean the cages of domestic poultry and often treat them as pets. Parents are being urged through public health education campaigns to keep children away from sick or dead poultry, not allow them to play with chickens and ducks, and make sure they wash their hands with soap and water before eating and after contact with poultry.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of the 33 confirmed human cases of H5N1 avian influenza virus recorded globally during 2013, a total of 22 have occurred in Cambodia.\n\nA map of the administrative divisions of Cambodia, showing the location of Battambang province, can be accessed at: http://www.vidiani.com/?p=3257. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/90qV.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (130): China, H7N9, CDC "country": "China"}, {"location": "Romdoul village", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2016517", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (124): Cambodia (KT) H5N1, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2016517", "date": "2013-08-14 14:33:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (82): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR, KAVREPALANCHOK) H5N1 SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 13 Aug 2013\nSource: e-Kantipur [summ., edited]\nhttp://ekantipur.com/2013/08/13/top-story/more-flu-cases-confirmed-kavre-hit/376335.html\n\n\nMore flu cases confirmed; Kavre hit\n-----------------------------------\nA day after the government failed to declare bird flu emergency in Bhaktapur, the H5N1 strain of [avian influenza] was confirmed in chickens on 5 poultry farms in the district on Monday [12 Aug 2013], the day the flu was also confirmed in 3 farms in adjoining Kavre [Kavrepalanchok] district.\n\nIn Bhaktapur, chickens in farms belonging to [5 names withheld] were found to have been infected with the flu.\n\nThe government's preparations to declare Bhaktapur a bird flu emergency zone hit a roadblock on Sunday [11 Aug 2013] after the poultry sector objected to the idea. The District Avian Influenza Technical Coordination Committee of Bhaktapur, chaired by chief district officer (CDO) Himnath Dawadi had then concluded that the district will be kept under 'closer surveillance' for 3 more days before taking further steps.\n\nSpokesperson of the Department of Livestock Services (DoLS) Dr Narayan Ghimire said they will have no option but to declare emergency and go for blanket slaughtering of the fowls if the situation does not change much after the 3-day surveillance.\n\nHowever, CDO Dawadi claimed that Monday's [12 Aug 2013] confirmation was made in samples sent for tests some days ago and that they are not fresh outbreaks. \"There is no need to worry. Rapid tests conducted in 19 poultry farms on Monday confirmed only one case of bird flu,\" he said. Government inspection teams have been visiting every farm in Bhaktapur since Thursday [8 Aug 2013] and conducting on-the-spot tests with a special kit they now have.\n\nMeanwhile, in Kavre, over 32 000 chickens have been infected in the 3 poultry farms, according to the district veterinary office there. Dr Ghimire attributed the spread of the flu to the mobility of the owners and workers from one farm to another without adopting bio-safety measures. \"One person owns many farms and labourers are shared. As such, chances of the virus spreading from one farm to another are high,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation or otherwise of the apparently new outbreaks described above is anticipated.\n\nThe most recent OIE follow-up report (no. 9) from Nepal on H5N1 was submitted on 30 Jun 2013. The report included the following epidemiological comments: \"Birds showed respiratory distress, nervous signs, and all affected birds died. Cleaning and disinfection activities in the infected premises are completed. Intensive surveillance activities are ongoing throughout the country.\" The report, with a map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13682.\n\nSince the start of the current H5N1 epizootic in Nepal in August 2012, 61 outbreaks have been reported as of 30 Jun 2013, involving a total of 170 607 susceptible birds (poultry), of which 61 577 cases died; the remaining 108 930 birds were, reportedly, destroyed. An OIE summary report with a map is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000013682_20130701_152420.pdf.\n\nEarlier H5N1 outbreaks affecting domestic poultry in Nepal were recorded between January 2009 and October 2010. No case has been recorded in Nepal in wild birds or in humans. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Nepal can be seen at http://ncthakur.itgo.com/map04.htm and http://healthmap.org/r/7_Be. Bhaktapur and Kavrepalanchok districts are located in the Bagmati Zone of the Central Region of Nepal. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (76): Nepal (MM) H5N1, poultry 20130702.1804274\nAvian influenza (01): Nepal (MM) H5N1 20130103.1480226\n2012\n---\nAvian influenza (70): Nepal (MM) H5N1, OIE 20121229.1474284\nAvian influenza (57): Nepal (LL) H5N1, OIE 20121015.1344616\n2011\n---\nAvian influenza (74): Nepal (BK), recurrence, RFI Bhaktapur\n2010\n---\nAvian influenza (59): Nepal (CH) H5N1, OIE 20101208.4376\nAvian influenza (22): Nepal, update "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Bhaktapur", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/r/7_Be", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kavre", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "BHAKTAPUR", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Kavrepalanchok", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "KAVREPALANCHOK", "country": "Nepal"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1990523", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (119): Indonesia (WJ) H5N1, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1990523", "date": "2013-08-14 14:33:59", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (82): NEPAL (BHAKTAPUR, KAVREPALANCHOK) H5N1 SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 13 Aug 2013\nSource: e-Kantipur [summ., edited]\nhttp://ekantipur.com/2013/08/13/top-story/more-flu-cases-confirmed-kavre-hit/376335.html\n\n\nMore flu cases confirmed; Kavre hit\n-----------------------------------\nA day after the government failed to declare bird flu emergency in Bhaktapur, the H5N1 strain of [avian influenza] was confirmed in chickens on 5 poultry farms in the district on Monday [12 Aug 2013], the day the flu was also confirmed in 3 farms in adjoining Kavre [Kavrepalanchok] district.\n\nIn Bhaktapur, chickens in farms belonging to [5 names withheld] were found to have been infected with the flu.\n\nThe government's preparations to declare Bhaktapur a bird flu emergency zone hit a roadblock on Sunday [11 Aug 2013] after the poultry sector objected to the idea. The District Avian Influenza Technical Coordination Committee of Bhaktapur, chaired by chief district officer (CDO) Himnath Dawadi had then concluded that the district will be kept under 'closer surveillance' for 3 more days before taking further steps.\n\nSpokesperson of the Department of Livestock Services (DoLS) Dr Narayan Ghimire said they will have no option but to declare emergency and go for blanket slaughtering of the fowls if the situation does not change much after the 3-day surveillance.\n\nHowever, CDO Dawadi claimed that Monday's [12 Aug 2013] confirmation was made in samples sent for tests some days ago and that they are not fresh outbreaks. \"There is no need to worry. Rapid tests conducted in 19 poultry farms on Monday confirmed only one case of bird flu,\" he said. Government inspection teams have been visiting every farm in Bhaktapur since Thursday [8 Aug 2013] and conducting on-the-spot tests with a special kit they now have.\n\nMeanwhile, in Kavre, over 32 000 chickens have been infected in the 3 poultry farms, according to the district veterinary office there. Dr Ghimire attributed the spread of the flu to the mobility of the owners and workers from one farm to another without adopting bio-safety measures. \"One person owns many farms and labourers are shared. As such, chances of the virus spreading from one farm to another are high,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation or otherwise of the apparently new outbreaks described above is anticipated.\n\nThe most recent OIE follow-up report (no. 9) from Nepal on H5N1 was submitted on 30 Jun 2013. The report included the following epidemiological comments: \"Birds showed respiratory distress, nervous signs, and all affected birds died. Cleaning and disinfection activities in the infected premises are completed. Intensive surveillance activities are ongoing throughout the country.\" The report, with a map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13682.\n\nSince the start of the current H5N1 epizootic in Nepal in August 2012, 61 outbreaks have been reported as of 30 Jun 2013, involving a total of 170 607 susceptible birds (poultry), of which 61 577 cases died; the remaining 108 930 birds were, reportedly, destroyed. An OIE summary report with a map is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000013682_20130701_152420.pdf.\n\nEarlier H5N1 outbreaks affecting domestic poultry in Nepal were recorded between January 2009 and October 2010. No case has been recorded in Nepal in wild birds or in humans. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of Nepal can be seen at http://ncthakur.itgo.com/map04.htm and http://healthmap.org/r/7_Be. Bhaktapur and Kavrepalanchok districts are located in the Bagmati Zone of the Central Region of Nepal. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (76): Nepal (MM) H5N1, poultry 20130702.1804274\nAvian influenza (01): Nepal (MM) H5N1 20130103.1480226\n2012\n---\nAvian influenza (70): Nepal (MM) H5N1, OIE 20121229.1474284\nAvian influenza (57): Nepal (LL) H5N1, OIE 20121015.1344616\n2011\n---\nAvian influenza (74): Nepal (BK), recurrence, RFI Bhaktapur\n2010\n---\nAvian influenza (59): Nepal (CH) H5N1, OIE 20101208.4376\nAvian influenza (22): Nepal, update 20100331.1013\nAvian influenza (10): Cambodia, Myanmar, Nepal, Viet Nam 20100210.0457\n2009\n---\nAvian influenza (15): Nepal, Viet Nam 20090221.0730\nAvian influenza (08): Nepal, control was also confirmed in 3 farms in adjoining Kavre [Kavrepalanchok] district.\n\nIn Bhaktapur, chickens in farms belonging to [5 names withheld] were found to have been infected with the flu.\n\nThe Dr Ghimire attributed the spread of the flu to the mobility of the owners and workers from one farm to another without adopting bio-safety measures. \"One person owns many farms and labourers are shared. As such, chances of the virus spreading from one farm to another are high,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation or otherwise of the apparently new outbreaks described above is anticipated.\n\nThe most recent OIE follow-up report (no. 9) from Nepal on H5N1 was submitted on 30 Jun 2013. Cleaning and disinfection activities in the infected premises are completed. Intensive surveillance activities are ongoing throughout the country.\" The report, with a map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13682.\n\nSince the start of the current H5N1 epizootic in Nepal in August 2012, 61 outbreaks have been reported as of 30 Jun 2013, involving a total of 170 607 susceptible birds (poultry), of which 61 577 cases died; the remaining 108 930 birds were, reportedly, destroyed. was also confirmed in 3 farms in adjoining Kavre [Kavrepalanchok] district.\n\nIn Bhaktapur, chickens in farms belonging to [5 names withheld] were found to have been infected with the flu.\n\nThe government's preparations to declare Bhaktapur a bird flu emergency zone hit a roadblock on Sunday [11 Aug 2013] after the poultry sector objected to the idea. The District Avian Influenza Technical Coordination Committee of Bhaktapur, chaired by chief district officer (CDO) Himnath Dawadi had then concluded that the district will be kept under 'closer surveillance' for 3 more days before taking further steps.\n\nSpokesperson of the Department of Livestock Services (DoLS) Dr Narayan Ghimire said they will have no option but to declare emergency and go for blanket slaughtering of the fowls if the situation does not change much after the 3-day surveillance.\n\nHowever, CDO Dawadi claimed that Monday's [12 Aug 2013] confirmation was made in samples sent for tests some days ago and that they are not fresh outbreaks. \"There is no need to worry. Rapid tests conducted in 19 poultry farms on Monday confirmed only one case of bird flu,\" he said. Dr Ghimire attributed the spread of the flu to the mobility of the owners and workers from one farm to another without adopting bio-safety measures. \"One person owns many farms and labourers are shared. As such, chances of the virus spreading from one farm to another are high,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Confirmation or otherwise of the apparently new outbreaks described above is anticipated.\n\nThe most recent OIE follow-up report (no. 9) from Nepal on H5N1 was submitted on 30 Jun 2013. Cleaning and disinfection activities in the infected premises are completed. Intensive surveillance activities are ongoing throughout the country.\" The report, with a map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13682.\n\nSince the start of the current H5N1 epizootic in Nepal in August 2012, 61 outbreaks have been reported as of 30 Jun 2013, involving a total of 170 607 susceptible birds (poultry), of which 61 577 cases died; the remaining 108 930 birds were, reportedly, destroyed. "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Bhaktapur", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/r/7_Be", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kavre", "country": "Nepal"}, "BHAKTAPUR", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "Kavrepalanchok", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "KAVREPALANCHOK", "country": "Nepal"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1879077", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (107): Cambodia, H5N1, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1879077", "date": "2013-05-13 15:41:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): NORTH KOREA (PYONGYANG) HPAI H5N1, DUCK, OIE\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(20) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13447\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n\"Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n\"On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n\"Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea\".\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) (137): Canada, North Korea 20091231.4403\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) 2009 (126): PAHO, North Korea 20091209.4200\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (78): North Korea, RFI, China (HK) 20080614.1877\n2005\n----\nAvian influenza, H7 - North Korea (07) 20050707.1927\nAvian influenza, H7 - North Korea (06) 20050425.1152\nAvian influenza, H7 - North Korea (05): regional cooperation 20050422.1126\nAvian influenza, H7 - North Korea (04): EU import restrict. 20050415.1084\nAvian influenza, H7 - North Korea (03) 20050409.1027\nAvian influenza, H7 - North Korea (02): OIE 20050408.1016\nAvian influenza, H7 - North Korea 20050405.0978\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (41): North Korea 20050401.0938\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (40): North Korea 20050330.0918\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (39): North Korea 20050329.0903\nAvian influenza - North Korea (04): conf. 20050327.0883\nAvian influenza - North Korea (03): susp. 20050320.0810\nAvian influenza - North Korea (02): susp. 20050317.0774\nAvian "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2040-03-16 00:00:00", "2039-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1866838", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (81): India (CT) H5N1, poultry, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1866838", "date": "2013-05-13 15:41:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): NORTH KOREA (PYONGYANG) HPAI H5N1, DUCK, OIE\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(20) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13447\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n\"Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n\"On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n\"Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea\".\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) (137): Canada, North Korea People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n\"Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n\"On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n\"Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea\".\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) (137): Canada, North Korea ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13447\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n\"Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n\"On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n\"Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea\".\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) (137): Canada, North Korea 20091231.4403\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) 2009 (126): PAHO, North Korea 20091209.4200\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (78): North Korea, RFI, China (HK) 20080614.1877\n2005\n----\nAvian influenza, H7 - 15:41:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): NORTH KOREA (PYONGYANG) HPAI H5N1, DUCK, OIE\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(20) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13447\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n\"Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n\"On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n\"Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea\".\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) (137): Canada, North Korea ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13447\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n\"Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n\"On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n\"Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea\".\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) (137): Canada, North Korea 15:41:25", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (56): NORTH KOREA (PYONGYANG) HPAI H5N1, DUCK, OIE\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(20) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13447\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 13 May 2013 from Mr Ri Kyong Gun, Director of the Veterinary and Anti-Epizootic Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Pyongyang, Korea (Dem. People's Rep.)\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 19 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 2 May 2013\nReport date: 13 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 May 2013\nReason for notification: new strain of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: (Tudan Duck Factory) [Pyongyang]\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds / 164 000 / ** / - / - / -\nAffected population: ducks in one of the 20 cages showed clinical signs on 19 Apr 2013 but recovered 3-4 days later. As mortality increased, samples were sent to the Central Veterinary Station on 2 May 2013. In total, one adult cage, 12 fattening cages, and 7 duckling cages were infected. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks and 120 000 ducklings younger than 20 days were dead or killed.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive; contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Station (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 2 May 2013 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Institute of the Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following, gratefully acknowledged, additional information has been kindly provided by 'FAO EMPRES - AH' [Emergency Prevention System for Animal Health]:\n\n\"Democratic People's Republic of Korea, confirmed H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in poultry:\n\n\"On 19 Apr 2013, a decrease in appetite and egg production was noticed in ducks in one of 20 cages of a duck factory in Pyongyang. Soon after, other ducks in fattening cages also showed the same signs with some mortalities. Initially, these signs were thought to be due to a problem in the feed. On 2 May 2013, with increasing mortality noticed in the ducks, the Central Veterinary Station (CVS) was informed and some samples were sent for testing. Testing confirmed the samples to be positive for H5 HPAI. Follow-up testing with RT-PCR on 7 May 2013, confirmed the samples as positive for H5N1. More than 2000 adult ducks, 42 000 fattening ducks, and 129 000 ducklings (younger than 20 days) died or were culled. It is assumed that some ducks were free-range and might have had the opportunity to contact H5N1 infected wild birds.\n\n\"Disease control measures were strictly taken and appropriate biosecurity was strictly enforced. Public awareness activities for the factory workers and residents around, as well as an epidemiological survey, have vigorously been conducted, and to date [9 May 2013], no human illness due to H5N1 has been found. Delay in testing and confirmation was related to the lack of appropriate reagents. A request has been made to FAO and OIE to provide needed laboratory, field control support, and technical training support, so the country may be appropriately prepared for the next potential incursion of H5N1 HPAI. [9 May 2013, National authority].\nNote: This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI since the H7N7 outbreak in February 2007 in the DPR Korea. In 2011, a number of H5N1 HPAI outbreaks were reported in the Republic of Korea\".\n\nThe current OIE notification includes an interactive map (available at the source URL above) showing the location of the new outbreak. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/6Vb5.]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) (137): Canada, North Korea 20091231.4403\nInfluenza pandemic (H1N1) 2009 (126): PAHO, North Korea 20091209.4200\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (78): North Korea, RFI, China (HK) 20080614.1877\n2005\n----\nAvian influenza, H7 - of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1 (13-614-00001) Seelow, Markisch-Oderland, Brandenburg\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Feb 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies/ Susceptible/ Cases/ Deaths/ Destroyed/ Slaughtered\nBirds/ 14 500/ 22/ 0/ 14 500/ 0\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1 [data as above]\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments\nNote by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2012).\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Control of wildlife reservoirs, Stamping out, Quarantine, Movement control inside the country, Screening, Zoning, Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), Vaccination prohibited\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Friedrich-Loeffler Institute (National laboratory)\nSpecies/ Test/ Test date/ Result\nBirds/ real-time PCR/ 15 Feb 2013/ Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the absence of an immediate official report, ProMED-mail had to base its earlier reports on the described event upon Reuters' reports. This outbreak of a low-pathogenic H5N1 in the East German state of Brandenburg (see map at the source URL) was thus initially reported as suspected with request for information and later as refuted. The current OIE report provides the official, apparently correct information. Since the species in this and other OIE reports addressing poultry/avians is unspecified (are \"birds\" conceived, systematically, as 'species'?!), it will be helpful to obtain from the authorities/OIE information on the affected population (according to the Reuters reports, the outbreak occurred on \"a duck farm, which was carrying out its own tests\").\n\nWe are grateful to Sabine Zentis for providing another, earlier source confirming the outbreak's diagnosis http://www.mugv.brandenburg.de/cms/detail.php/bb1.c.322948.de. - Mod.AS.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJl.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (12): Germany (BB) poultry, NOT 20130218.1548446\nAvian influenza (10): Germany (BB) poultry, susp.
