avian influenza (poultry), Germany, (Follow-up report No. 1)\n-------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 18 Feb 2013 from Dr. Karin Schwabenbauer, Ministerial Dirigentin and Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, Bundesministerium fur Ernahrung, Landwirtschaft und Verbraucherschutz (BMELV), Bonn, Germany\nSummary\nReport type: Follow-up report No. 1\nDate of start of the event: 18 Dec 2012\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 20 Dec 2012\nReport date: 18 Feb 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 18 Feb 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 12 Aug 2011\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1 (13-614-00001) Seelow, Markisch-Oderland, Brandenburg\nDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Feb 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies/ Susceptible/ Cases/ Deaths/ Destroyed/ Slaughtered\nBirds/ 14 500/ 22/ 0/ 14 500/ 0\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1 [data as above]\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments\nNote by the OIE Animal Health Information Department: H5 and H7 avian influenza in its low pathogenic form in poultry is a notifiable disease as per Chapter 10.4. on avian influenza of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (2012).\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Control of wildlife reservoirs, Stamping out, Quarantine, Movement control inside the country, Screening, Zoning, Disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), Vaccination prohibited\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Friedrich-Loeffler Institute (National laboratory)\nSpecies/ Test/ Test date/ Result\nBirds/ real-time PCR/ 15 Feb 2013/ Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the absence of an immediate official report, ProMED-mail had to base its earlier reports on the described event upon Reuters' reports. This outbreak of a low-pathogenic H5N1 in the East German state of Brandenburg (see map at the source URL) was thus initially reported as suspected with request for information and later as refuted. The current OIE report provides the official, apparently correct information. Since the species in this and other OIE reports addressing poultry/avians is unspecified (are \"birds\" conceived, systematically, as 'species'?!), it will be helpful to obtain from the authorities/OIE information on the affected population (according to the Reuters reports, the outbreak occurred on \"a duck farm, which was carrying out its own tests\").\n\nWe are grateful to Sabine Zentis for providing another, earlier source confirming the outbreak's diagnosis http://www.mugv.brandenburg.de/cms/detail.php/bb1.c.322948.de. - Mod.AS.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJl.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (12): Germany (BB) poultry, NOT 20130218.1548446\nAvian influenza (10): Germany (BB) poultry, susp. RFI 20130217.1546695\n2012\n----\nAvian influenza (69): Germany (SH) poultry, LPAI, H5, OIE 20121222.1464172\n.................................................arn/ejp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": 25(42) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=12441\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 14 Oct 2012 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 27 Aug 2012\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 3 Sep 2012\nReport date: 14 Oct 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 14 Oct 2012\nDate event resolved: 4 Oct 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Mar 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 Sanepa-2, Sanchal, Lalitpur, Bagmati\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Aug 2012\nOutbreak status: resolved (04 Oct 2012)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds [see comment] / 2500 / 2500 / 2500 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: a commercial layer farm rearing dual purpose breed of different age group.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: stamping out followed by cleaning, disinfection, disposal, and sealing of the infected premises has been completed. Post-operative surveillance activities are being intensively carried out throughout the country.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping-spraying/vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 3 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Geelong, Australia (OIE's reference laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Nepal Vet Services commendably applied immediate stamping out, the outbreak thus resolved. For its location, please refer to the interactive map at the source URL above.\n\nThe \"birds\" species affected is not specified; avian influenza virus has been shown to be able to infect various species of birds. The affected population in the outbreak above is, reportedly, \"a commercial layer farm rearing dual purpose breed of different age group\"; most probably, chickens (_Gallus gallus domesticus_). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3IfJ.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (74): Nepal (BK), recurrence, RFI 20111129.3487\n2010\n----\nAvian influenza (59): Nepal (CH) H5N1, OIE 20101208.4376\nAvian influenza (22): Nepal, update 20100331.1013\nAvian influenza (10): Cambodia, Myanmar, Nepal, Viet Nam 20100210.0457\n2009\n----\nAvian influenza (15): Nepal, Viet Nam 20090221.0730\nAvian influenza (08): Nepal, control 20090126.0346\nAvian influenza (05): Nepal, 1st outbreak 20090116.0180\n.................................................arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "gallus", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1507896", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (05): Indonesia, duck, H5N1 2.3.2 clade", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1507896", "date": "2012-10-15 13:26:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (57): NEPAL (LALITPUR) H5N1, OIE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 14 Oct 2012\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2012; Post-operative surveillance activities are being intensively carried out throughout the country.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping-spraying/vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 3 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Geelong, Australia (OIE's reference laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Nepal Vet Services commendably applied immediate stamping out, the outbreak thus resolved. The affected population in the outbreak above is, reportedly, \"a commercial layer farm rearing dual purpose breed of different age group\"; most probably, chickens (_Gallus gallus domesticus_). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3IfJ.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (74): Nepal (BK), recurrence, RFI 20111129.3487\n2010\n----\nAvian influenza (59): Nepal (CH) H5N1, OIE 20101208.4376\nAvian influenza (22): Nepal, update 20100331.1013\nAvian influenza (10): Cambodia, Myanmar, Nepal, Viet Nam 20100210.0457\n2009\n----\nAvian influenza (15): Nepal, Viet Nam 20090221.0730\nAvian influenza (08): Nepal, control 20090126.0346\nAvian influenza (05): Nepal, 1st outbreak 20090116.0180\n.................................................arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "gallus", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1494731", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (03): USA (NY) H5N1 LPAI, poultry, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1494731", "date": "2012-10-15 13:26:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (57): NEPAL (LALITPUR) H5N1, OIE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 14 Oct 2012\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2012; The affected population in the outbreak above is, reportedly, \"a commercial layer farm rearing dual purpose breed of different age group\"; most probably, chickens (_Gallus gallus domesticus_). - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3IfJ.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (74): Nepal (BK), recurrence, RFI 20111129.3487\n2010\n----\nAvian influenza (59): Nepal (CH) H5N1, OIE 20101208.4376\nAvian influenza (22): Nepal, update 20100331.1013\nAvian influenza (10): Cambodia, Myanmar, Nepal, Viet Nam 20100210.0457\n2009\n----\nAvian influenza (15): Nepal, Viet Nam 20090221.0730\nAvian influenza (08): Nepal, control 20090126.0346\nAvian influenza (05): Nepal, 1st outbreak 20090116.0180\n.................................................arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1974-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "Nepal"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "gallus", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1344616", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (57): Nepal (LL) H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1344616", "date": "2012-10-15 13:26:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (57): NEPAL (LALITPUR) H5N1, OIE\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 14 Oct 2012\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2012; 25(42) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=12441\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Nepal\n-----------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 14 Oct 2012 from Dr Nar Bahadur Rajwar, Director General, Department of Livestock Services, Department of Livestock Services, Lalitpur, Nepal\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 27 Aug 2012\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 3 Sep 2012\nReport date: 14 Oct 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 14 Oct 2012\nDate event resolved: 4 Oct 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 30 Mar 2012\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 Sanepa-2, Sanchal, Lalitpur, Bagmati\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Aug 2012\nOutbreak status: resolved (04 Oct 2012)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBirds [see comment] / 2500 / 2500 / 2500 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: a commercial layer farm rearing dual purpose breed of different age group.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: stamping out followed by cleaning, disinfection, disposal, and sealing of the infected premises has been completed. Post-operative surveillance activities are being intensively carried out throughout the country.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out; quarantine; movement control inside the country; screening; zoning; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); dipping-spraying/vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals.\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory (national laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 3 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Geelong, Australia (OIE's reference laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 Sep 2012 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Nepal Vet Services commendably applied immediate stamping out, the outbreak thus resolved. "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1300398", "date": "2012-07-03 13:17:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (42): CHINA (XINJIANG) H5N1, POULTRY\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jul 2012\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://english.cri.cn/6909/2012/07/02/3241s709736.htm\n\n\nChina's north western Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region has reported an outbreak of H5N1 in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced on Monday [2 Jul 2012]. The disease has killed 1600 chickens raised by the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (XPCC), a unique economic and semi-military government organization of about 2.5 million people.\n\nA total of 5500 XPCC-farmed chickens showed symptoms of suspected avian flu on 20 Jun 2012, according to the MOA. The National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory on Monday [2 Jul 2012] confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, the MOA said.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 156 439 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<nati@poultrymed.com>\n\n[The outbreak, diagnosed by the Harbin Veterinary Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national reference laboratory for avian influenza) (OIE's Reference Laboratory), has been duly reported to the OIE on 2 Jul 2012; see, with an interactive map, at http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=12085.\n\nThe report has also been received from ProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall, who is gratefully acknowledged. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1g0m.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (36): China (GS) H5N1, poultry 20120607.1158815\n2011\n---\nAvian influenza (77): China, H5N1, OIE 20111214.3592\n.................................................arn/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2012-06-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Xinjiang", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1298881", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (55): China (GD) H5N1, poultry", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1298881", "date": "2012-07-03 13:17:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (42): CHINA (XINJIANG) H5N1, POULTRY\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jul 2012\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://english.cri.cn/6909/2012/07/02/3241s709736.htm\n\n\nChina's north western Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region has reported an outbreak of H5N1 in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced on Monday [2 Jul 2012]. The disease has killed 1600 chickens raised by the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (XPCC), a unique economic and semi-military government organization of about 2.5 million people.\n\nA total of 5500 XPCC-farmed chickens showed symptoms of suspected avian flu on 20 Jun 2012, according to the MOA. The National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory on Monday [2 Jul 2012] confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, the MOA said.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 156 439 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<nati@poultrymed.com>\n\n[The outbreak, diagnosed by the Harbin Veterinary Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national reference laboratory for avian influenza) (OIE's Reference Laboratory), has been duly reported to the OIE on 2 Jul 2012; see, with an interactive map, at http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=12085.\n\nThe report has also been received from ProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall, who is gratefully acknowledged. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1g0m.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (36): China (GS) H5N1, poultry 20120607.1158815\n2011\n---\nAvian influenza (77): China, H5N1, OIE 20111214.3592\n.................................................arn/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2012-06-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Xinjiang", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1188082", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (42): China (XJ) H5N1, poultry", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1188082", "date": "2012-07-03 13:17:52", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (42): CHINA (XINJIANG) H5N1, POULTRY\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jul 2012\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://english.cri.cn/6909/2012/07/02/3241s709736.htm\n\n\nChina's north western Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region has reported an outbreak of H5N1 in poultry, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) announced on Monday [2 Jul 2012]. The disease has killed 1600 chickens raised by the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (XPCC), a unique economic and semi-military government organization of about 2.5 million people.\n\nA total of 5500 XPCC-farmed chickens showed symptoms of suspected avian flu on 20 Jun 2012, according to the MOA. The National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory on Monday [2 Jul 2012] confirmed the epidemic was H5N1 bird flu after testing samples collected at the farm, the MOA said.\n\nLocal authorities have sealed off and sterilized the infected area, where a total of 156 439 chickens have been culled and safely disposed of to prevent the disease from spreading, according to the MOA.\n\nBird flu, or avian influenza, is a contagious disease of animal origin caused by viruses that normally infect only birds and, less commonly, pigs. It can be fatal to humans.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nNati Elkin\n<nati@poultrymed.com>\n\n[The outbreak, diagnosed by the Harbin Veterinary Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (national reference laboratory for avian influenza) (OIE's Reference Laboratory), has been duly reported to the OIE on 2 Jul 2012; see, with an interactive map, at http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=12085.\n\nThe report has also been received from ProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall, who is gratefully acknowledged. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1g0m.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (36): China (GS) H5N1, poultry 20120607.1158815\n2011\n---\nAvian influenza (77): China, H5N1, OIE 20111214.3592\n.................................................arn/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2042-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2012-06-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1977-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Xinjiang", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1158815", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (36): China (GS) H5N1, poultry", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1158815", "date": "2012-03-02 11:07:43", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: MYANMAR (SAGAING), H5N1, POULTRY, OIE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Mar 2012\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2012; 25(9) [edited]\nhttp://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11686\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Myanmar\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 29 Feb 2012 from Prof Dr Myint Thein, Director General, Livestock Breeding and Veterinary Department, Ministry of Livestock & Fisheries, Yangon, Myanmar\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 20 Feb 2012\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 24 Feb 2012\nReport date: 28 Feb 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 29 Feb 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 14 Apr 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (10317): Myothit Quarter, Chaung U, Monywa, Sagaing\nDate of start of the outbreak: 20 Feb 2012\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 1060\nCases: 61\nDeaths: 61\nDestroyed: 999\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: layers\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: 5-month and 18-month-old layer chickens in 2 establishments, with a total of 1060 chickens. A few chickens were found dead on 20 Feb 2012. A total of 61 chickens died within 4 days. There are 40 000 chickens reared in 139 farms in Chaung U township. All are layers and broilers of different ages.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Regional Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Mandalay (local laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 24/02/2012 / Positive\nBirds / rapid tests / 24 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Yangon (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time PCR / 26 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since 2005, Myanmar has reported 10 outbreaks of avian influenza. They occurred in 2009 and 2010, and all but one occurred during the period from January to March. But from looking at the reporting in both animals and humans from surrounding countries such as Cambodia, Bangladesh, Viet Nam, Nepal, Bhutan, and China, it is clear that highly pathogenic avian influenza still lurks in the background and deserves our attention and surveillance.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Myanmar can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1VM0. - Mod PC]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (23): Viet Nam (BD) 20120226.1053320\nAvian influenza, clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (10317): animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 1060\nCases: 61\nDeaths: 61\nDestroyed: 999\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: layers\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: 5-month and 18-month-old layer chickens in 2 establishments, with a total of 1060 chickens. A few chickens were found dead on 20 Feb 2012. A total of 61 chickens died within 4 days. There are 40 000 chickens reared in 139 farms in Chaung U township. All are layers and broilers of different ages.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Regional Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Mandalay (local laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 24/02/2012 / Positive\nBirds / rapid tests / 24 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Yangon (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time PCR / 26 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since 2005, Myanmar has reported 10 outbreaks of avian influenza. They occurred in 2009 and 2010, and all but one occurred during the period from January to March. But from looking at the reporting in both animals and humans from surrounding countries such as Cambodia, Bangladesh, Viet Nam, Nepal, Bhutan, and China, it is clear that highly pathogenic avian influenza still lurks in the background and deserves our attention and surveillance.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Myanmar can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1VM0. - Mod PC]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (23): Viet Nam (BD) 20120226.1053320\nAvian influenza, on 29 Feb 2012 from Prof Dr Myint Thein, Director General, Livestock Breeding and Veterinary Department, Ministry of Livestock & Fisheries, Yangon, Myanmar\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 20 Feb 2012\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 24 Feb 2012\nReport date: 28 Feb 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 29 Feb 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 14 Apr 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (10317): Myothit Quarter, Chaung U, Monywa, Sagaing\nDate of start of the outbreak: 20 Feb 2012\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 1060\nCases: 61\nDeaths: 61\nDestroyed: 999\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: layers\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: 5-month and 18-month-old layer chickens in 2 establishments, with a total of 1060 chickens. A few chickens were found dead on 20 Feb 2012. A total of 61 chickens died within 4 days. There are 40 000 chickens reared in 139 farms in Chaung U township. All are layers and broilers of different ages.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Regional Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Mandalay (local laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 24/02/2012 / Positive\nBirds / rapid tests / 24 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Yangon (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time PCR / 26 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since 2005, Myanmar has reported 10 outbreaks of avian influenza. on 29 Feb 2012 from Prof Dr Myint Thein, Director General, Livestock Breeding and Veterinary Department, Ministry of Livestock & Fisheries, Yangon, Myanmar\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 20 Feb 2012\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 24 Feb 2012\nReport date: 28 Feb 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 29 Feb 2012\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 14 Apr 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype: H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced), necropsy\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (10317): Myothit Quarter, Chaung U, Monywa, Sagaing\nDate of start of the outbreak: 20 Feb 2012\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals\nSpecies: birds\nSusceptible: 1060\nCases: 61\nDeaths: 61\nDestroyed: 999\nSlaughtered: 0\nAffected population: layers\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: 5-month and 18-month-old layer chickens in 2 establishments, with a total of 1060 chickens. A few chickens were found dead on 20 Feb 2012. A total of 61 chickens died within 4 days. There are 40 000 chickens reared in 139 farms in Chaung U township. All are layers and broilers of different ages.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: stamping out, quarantine, movement control inside the country, zoning, disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s), dipping/spraying, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Regional Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Mandalay (local laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 24/02/2012 / Positive\nBirds / rapid tests / 24 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Yangon (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBirds / real-time PCR / 26 Feb 2012 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since 2005, Myanmar has reported 10 outbreaks of avian influenza. They occurred in 2009 and 2010, and all but one occurred during the period from January to March. But from looking at the reporting in both animals and humans from surrounding countries such as Cambodia, Bangladesh, Viet Nam, Nepal, Bhutan, and China, it is clear that highly pathogenic avian influenza still lurks in the background and deserves our attention and surveillance.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Myanmar can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1VM0. - Mod PC]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza, human (23): Viet Nam (BD) 20120226.1053320\nAvian influenza, human (22): Viet Nam (ST) 20120225.1052590\nAvian influenza, human (16): Viet Nam: (ST) fatal 20120201.1028827\nAvian influenza, human (12): Viet Nam, background 20120123.1019444\nAvian influenza, human (09): Cambodia, Egypt, Indonesia, Viet Nam 20120119.1015836\nAvian influenza, human: China (GD) H5N1 20120102.0012\nAvian influenza (09): Sri Lanka (NW) LPAI, conf., H5N2, OIE 20120203.1031876\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (04): Myanmar (RA) H5, OIE 20110119.0223\nAvian influenza, human (75): China (GG) H5N1 20111231.3714\nAvian influenza (75): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1046187", "date": "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. RFI\n20111221.3654\nAvian influenza, human (72): China (HK), human NOT 20111216.3611\n2006\n----\nAvian influenza, Eurasia (25): Hong Kong, China "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1032857", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (10): H5N1 research controversy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1032857", "date": "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. RFI\n20111221.3654\nAvian influenza, human (72): China (HK), human NOT 20111216.3611\n2006\n----\nAvian influenza, Eurasia (25): Hong Kong, China 20060120.0183\n.................................................pmb/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-01-03 00:00:00", "2012-01-03 00:00:00", "2012-01-01 00:00:00", "1823-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-12-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1979-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1031448", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (07): China (HK) H5N1, gull, peregrine falcon", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1031448", "date": "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. RFI\n20111221.3654\nAvian influenza, human (72): China (HK), human NOT 20111216.3611\n2006\n----\nAvian influenza, Eurasia (25): Hong Kong, China 20060120.0183\n.................................................pmb/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-01-03 00:00:00", "2012-01-03 00:00:00", "2012-01-01 00:00:00", "1823-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-12-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1979-03-16 00:00:00", "1978-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1029495", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (06): China (HK) H5N1, gull, peregrine falcon", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1029495", "date": "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp. RFI\n20111221.3654\nAvian influenza, human (72): China (HK), human NOT 20111216.3611\n2006\n----\nAvian influenza, Eurasia (25): Hong Kong, China "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "999620", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza: China (HK) H5N1, gull", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=999620", "date": "2012-01-04 12:32:50", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA: CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N1, GULL\n*********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Jan 2012\nSource: GovHK (Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government)\npress release [edited]\nhttp://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201201/03/P201201030396.htm\n\n\nBlack-headed gulls test positive for H5 virus\n---------------------------------------------\nA spokesman for the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\n(AFCD) said today (3 Jan 2012) that 2 dead black-headed gulls found in\nTuen Mun and Lantau have tested positive for the H5 avian influenza\nvirus in preliminary testing, adding that further confirmatory tests\nare being conducted.\n\nThe 1st gull was collected at EcoPark, 133 Lung Mun Road, Tuen Mun, on\n30 Dec 2011 while the 2nd one was found at a drain near Sha Lo Wan\nSoccer Pitch, Lantau, on 1 Jan 2012.\n\nThe black-headed gull is a common winter visitor.\n\nThe spokesman said there were no poultry farms within 3 kilometres [2\nmi] of where the dead birds were found.\n\nThe AFCD has phoned poultry farmers to remind them to strengthen\nprecautionary and biosecurity measures against avian influenza.\nLetters have been issued to farmers, pet bird shop owners and licence\nholders of pet poultry and racing pigeons, reminding them that proper\nprecautions must be taken.\n\nThe spokesman said the department would conduct frequent inspections\nof poultry farms and the wholesale market to ensure that proper\nprecautions against avian influenza have been implemented. The\ndepartment will continue its wild bird monitoring and surveillance.\n\n\"People should avoid personal contact with wild birds and live poultry\nand their droppings. They should clean their hands thoroughly after\ncoming into contact with them. The public can call 1823 for follow-up\nif they come across suspicious sick or dead birds, including the\ncarcasses of wild birds and poultry,\" the spokesman said.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) will continue to\nbe vigilant over imported live poultry as well as live poultry stalls.\nIt will also remind stall operators to maintain good hygiene.\n\nThe Department of Health will keep up with its health education to\nremind the public to maintain strict personal and environmental\nhygiene to prevent avian influenza.\n\nThe AFCD, the FEHD, the Customs and Excise Department, and the Police\nwill strive to deter the illegal import of poultry and birds into Hong\nKong to minimise the risk of avian influenza outbreaks caused by\nimported poultry and birds that have not gone through inspection and\nquarantine.\n\nAll relevant government departments will continue to remain highly\nvigilant and strictly enforce preventive measures against avian\ninfluenza.\n\nHealth advice is available from the \"H5N1 Health Advice\" on the AFCD\nwebsite at http://www.afcd.gov.hk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Two H5N1 outbreaks involving poultry and wild birds in Hong Kong were\nreported to OIE in December 2011\n(http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=11404).\n\nThe black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus [=Larus] ridibundus_) is a\nsmall gull which breeds in much of Europe and Asia, and also in\ncoastal eastern Canada. Most of the population is migratory, wintering\nfurther south, but some birds in the milder westernmost areas of\nEurope are resident. A picture of this species can be found at\nhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chroicocephalus_ridibundus_(summer).jpg.\nBecause gulls are very susceptible to H5N1, it is very unlikely that\nthey can carry the virus long distances through migration.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the area can be found at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1BC7. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nAvian influenza (80): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, wild bird\n20111224.3666\nAvian influenza (79): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, conf. 20111222.3658\nAvian influenza (78): China (HK) H5N1, poultry, susp.
