Carcasses have been\nspotted in Jamshedpur, Bokaro, Hazaribagh, and other areas. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000.\n\nScientists at National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have found\nthe virus to be H5N1. It is a highly pathogenic virus that can even\nspread to humans.\n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. However, the event captured media\nattention only towards the end of November [2011]. Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. The IVRI results are still\nawaited. NIV, in the meanwhile, has confirmed the presence of the HN51\nvirus in the dead crows.\n\nThe crows tested negative for Japanese encephalitis or West Nile\nvirus. M Sharma at IVRI Bareilly says the report will be out in a\ncouple of days. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before.\n\nMD Dwivedi, bird watcher and researcher at Vinobha Bhave University in\nHazaribagh in Jharkhand, claims he has seen several crows die.\nExplaining their symptoms, he says, \"It appears the right side of\ntheir body is not working. They seem to have concussion.\" After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region.\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). However, no associated poultry cases\nwere reported in this episode. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. The\nresults of tests being carried out by IVRI will clarify the situation.\nHPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak\nin people would depend on the exposure to sick reservoir hosts. -\nMod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1vLj. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (75): India (JH), crows, susp. RFI 20111202.3517\nAvian influenza (60): India (WB) H5N1 conf, RFI 20110923.2882\nAvian influenza (59): India (WB), susp. RFI 20110921.2868\nAvian influenza (57): India (Assam) new outbreak, OIE 20110909.2747\n2006\n---\nBird die-off - Nepal 20060330.0958\nAvian influenza (29): India (TR) new outbreak 20110322.0902\nAvian influenza (27): Bangladesh, India 20110306.0745\n2010\n---\nAvian influenza (17): India (TR), H5, OIE 20110219.0548\nAvian influenza (03): India (WB) OIE 20100115.0184\n.................................................pmb/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00", "2060-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "997708", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human: China (GD) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=997708", "date": "2011-12-05 14:19:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (76) - INDIA: (JHARKHAND) CROW, H5N1\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Dec 2011\nSource: Downtoearth.org [edited]\nhttp://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/avian-flu-killing-jharkhand-crows-virology-institute\n\n\n\nAvian flu killing Jharkhand crows: virology institute\n-----------------------------------------------------\nDeaths of crows have been reported in large numbers across Jharkhand\nin the past week [last week of November 2011]. Carcasses have been\nspotted in Jamshedpur, Bokaro, Hazaribagh, and other areas. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000.\n\nScientists at National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have found\nthe virus to be H5N1. It is a highly pathogenic virus that can even\nspread to humans.\n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. However, the event captured media\nattention only towards the end of November [2011]. Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. The IVRI results are still\nawaited. NIV, in the meanwhile, has confirmed the presence of the HN51\nvirus in the dead crows.\n\nThe crows tested negative for Japanese encephalitis or West Nile\nvirus. M Sharma at IVRI Bareilly says the report will be out in a\ncouple of days. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before.\n\nMD Dwivedi, bird watcher and researcher at Vinobha Bhave University in\nHazaribagh in Jharkhand, claims he has seen several crows die.\nExplaining their symptoms, he says, \"It appears the right side of\ntheir body is not working. They seem to have concussion.\" After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region.\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). However, no associated poultry cases\nwere reported in this episode. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. The\nresults of tests being carried out by IVRI will clarify the situation.\nHPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak\nin people would depend on the exposure to sick reservoir hosts. -\nMod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1vLj. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (75): India (JH), crows, susp. RFI 20111202.3517\nAvian influenza (60): India (WB) H5N1 conf, RFI 20110923.2882\nAvian influenza (59): India (WB), susp. RFI 20110921.2868\nAvian influenza (57): India (Assam) new outbreak, OIE 20110909.2747\n2006\n---\nBird die-off - Nepal 20060330.0958\nAvian influenza (29): India (TR) new outbreak 20110322.0902\nAvian influenza (27): Bangladesh, India 20110306.0745\n2010\n---\nAvian influenza (17): India (TR), H5, OIE 20110219.0548\nAvian influenza (03): India (WB) OIE 20100115.0184\n.................................................pmb/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00", "2060-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "996088", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (75): China (GG) H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=996088", "date": "2011-12-05 14:19:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (76) - INDIA: (JHARKHAND) CROW, H5N1\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Dec 2011\nSource: Downtoearth.org [edited]\nhttp://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/avian-flu-killing-jharkhand-crows-virology-institute\n\n\n\nAvian flu killing Jharkhand crows: virology institute\n-----------------------------------------------------\nDeaths of crows have been reported in large numbers across Jharkhand\nin the past week [last week of November 2011]. Carcasses have been\nspotted in Jamshedpur, Bokaro, Hazaribagh, and other areas. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000.\n\nScientists at National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have found\nthe virus to be H5N1. It is a highly pathogenic virus that can even\nspread to humans.\n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. However, the event captured media\nattention only towards the end of November [2011]. Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. The IVRI results are still\nawaited. NIV, in the meanwhile, has confirmed the presence of the HN51\nvirus in the dead crows.\n\nThe crows tested negative for Japanese encephalitis or West Nile\nvirus. M Sharma at IVRI Bareilly says the report will be out in a\ncouple of days. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before.\n\nMD Dwivedi, bird watcher and researcher at Vinobha Bhave University in\nHazaribagh in Jharkhand, claims he has seen several crows die.\nExplaining their symptoms, he says, \"It appears the right side of\ntheir body is not working. They seem to have concussion.\" After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region.\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). However, no associated poultry cases\nwere reported in this episode. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. The\nresults of tests being carried out by IVRI will clarify the situation.\nHPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak\nin people would depend on the exposure to sick reservoir hosts. -\nMod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1vLj. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (75): India (JH), crows, susp. Carcasses have been\nspotted in Jamshedpur, Bokaro, Hazaribagh, and other areas. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000.\n\nScientists at National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have found\nthe virus to be H5N1. It is a highly pathogenic virus that can even\nspread to humans.\n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. However, the event captured media\nattention only towards the end of November [2011]. Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. The IVRI results are still\nawaited. NIV, in the meanwhile, has confirmed the presence of the HN51\nvirus in the dead crows.\n\nThe crows tested negative for Japanese encephalitis or West Nile\nvirus. M Sharma at IVRI Bareilly says the report will be out in a\ncouple of days. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before.\n\nMD Dwivedi, bird watcher and researcher at Vinobha Bhave University in\nHazaribagh in Jharkhand, claims he has seen several crows die.\nExplaining their symptoms, he says, \"It appears the right side of\ntheir body is not working. They seem to have concussion.\" After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region.\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). However, no associated poultry cases\nwere reported in this episode. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. Carcasses have been\nspotted in Jamshedpur, Bokaro, Hazaribagh, and other areas. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000.\n\nScientists at National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have found\nthe virus to be H5N1. It is a highly pathogenic virus that can even\nspread to humans.\n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. However, the event captured media\nattention only towards the end of November [2011]. Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. The IVRI results are still\nawaited. NIV, in the meanwhile, has confirmed the presence of the HN51\nvirus in the dead crows.\n\nThe crows tested negative for Japanese encephalitis or West Nile\nvirus. M Sharma at IVRI Bareilly says the report will be out in a\ncouple of days. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before.\n\nMD Dwivedi, bird watcher and researcher at Vinobha Bhave University in\nHazaribagh in Jharkhand, claims he has seen several crows die.\nExplaining their symptoms, he says, \"It appears the right side of\ntheir body is not working. They seem to have concussion.\" After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region.\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). However, no associated poultry cases\nwere reported in this episode. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. The\nresults of tests being carried out by IVRI will clarify the situation.\nHPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak\nin people would depend on the exposure to sick reservoir hosts. -\nMod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1vLj. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (75): India (JH), crows, susp. RFI 20111202.3517\nAvian influenza (60): India (WB) H5N1 conf, RFI 20110923.2882\nAvian influenza (59): India (WB), susp. RFI 20110921.2868\nAvian influenza (57): India (Assam) new outbreak, OIE 20110909.2747\n2006\n---\nBird die-off - Nepal 20060330.0958\nAvian influenza (29): India (TR) new outbreak 20110322.0902\nAvian influenza (27): Bangladesh, India 20110306.0745\n2010\n---\nAvian influenza (17): India (TR), H5, OIE 20110219.0548\nAvian influenza (03): India (WB) OIE 20100115.0184\n.................................................pmb/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00", "2060-03-16 00:00:00", "2059-03-16 00:00:00", "2057-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "969083", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (76): India (JH) crow, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=969083", "date": "2011-12-05 14:19:18", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (76) - INDIA: (JHARKHAND) CROW, H5N1\n****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 3 Dec 2011\nSource: Downtoearth.org [edited]\nhttp://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/avian-flu-killing-jharkhand-crows-virology-institute\n\n\n\nAvian flu killing Jharkhand crows: virology institute\n-----------------------------------------------------\nDeaths of crows have been reported in large numbers across Jharkhand\nin the past week [last week of November 2011]. Carcasses have been\nspotted in Jamshedpur, Bokaro, Hazaribagh, and other areas. Media\nreports estimate the number of crow deaths to be between 500 and\n1000.\n\nScientists at National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have found\nthe virus to be H5N1. It is a highly pathogenic virus that can even\nspread to humans.\n\nResidents report that incidents of crow deaths started surfacing in\nthe beginning of September [2011]. However, the event captured media\nattention only towards the end of November [2011]. Several teams,\nincluding that of the Indian Institute of Veterinary Research (IVRI)\nin Bareilly, have collected carcasses and are presently conducting\ntests to ascertain the cause of the deaths. The IVRI results are still\nawaited. NIV, in the meanwhile, has confirmed the presence of the HN51\nvirus in the dead crows.\n\nThe crows tested negative for Japanese encephalitis or West Nile\nvirus. M Sharma at IVRI Bareilly says the report will be out in a\ncouple of days. He says the deaths of crows in such huge numbers have\nnot been reported before.\n\nMD Dwivedi, bird watcher and researcher at Vinobha Bhave University in\nHazaribagh in Jharkhand, claims he has seen several crows die.\nExplaining their symptoms, he says, \"It appears the right side of\ntheir body is not working. They seem to have concussion.\" After\nspeaking to labourers in the Bokaro steel plant, he concluded there\nhave been 500 deaths in the region.\n\n[byline: Dinsa Sachan]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Avian influenza outbreaks in poultry caused by H5N1 highly pathogenic\navian influenza (HPAI) virus were confirmed in a neighboring state,\nWest Bengal, in August/September 2011 (see ProMED-mail archives\n20110909.2747 and 20110923.2882). However, no associated poultry cases\nwere reported in this episode. Since 2002, a substantial number of\ndeaths associated with H5N1 HPAI virus infection were reported in\nseveral domestic and wildlife species. This virus strain proved to be\npathogenic to a majority of the species exposed to it, and thus it is\nsurprising that only crows are reported affected in this die-off. The\nresults of tests being carried out by IVRI will clarify the situation.\nHPAI H5N1 virus is not transmitted from human to human, so an outbreak\nin people would depend on the exposure to sick reservoir hosts. -\nMod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be seen at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1vLj. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (75): India (JH), crows, susp. RFI 20111202.3517\nAvian influenza (60): India (WB) H5N1 conf, RFI 20110923.2882\nAvian influenza (59): India (WB), susp. Mod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.moag.gov.il/NR/exeres/B217BA1D-5BA5-4D55-95E7-396176E0CBDA,frame\n\nless.htm?NRMODE=Published>\n\n\nAvian influenza suspected in Rosh Zurim; preliminary notification\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\nAvian influenza H5 has been diagnosed in a turkey farm in the Kibbutz\nRosh Zurim, district BetLehem, province of Judea and Samaria. The\naffected farm includes 13 400 birds. Quarantine measures and\nsurveillance have immediately been applied.\n\nNo unusual mortality has been detected in poultry farms 10 km [6 mi]\naround the affected farm. Veterinarians, to whom the circular is being\nelectronically distributed, are called to alertness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Israeli Veterinary Services have kindly provided the following\nadditional information, for which ProMED-mail is grateful:\n\n\"H5N1 has been confirmed by PCR. Virus isolation is pending. Out of\nthe 13 400 14 week old turkeys in the infected flock, about 1000\nshowed clinical disease, of which 200 died.\n\n\"The entire affected flock, as well as 2 additional turkey flocks on\nthe same farm (14 000 each, one 6 weeks old and the other 4 days old)\nare to be immediately culled. An immediate notification has already\nbeen submitted to the OIE\".\n\nA map showing the location of Rosh Zurim is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0yWZ>. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (25): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, H5N1, OIE\n20110306.0737\nAvian influenza (24): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, H5N1 conf.\n20110305.0719\nAvian influenza (22): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, RFI\n20110303.0695\n2010\n---\nAvian influenza (30): Israel (HD), emu, OIE, resolved 20100515.1594\nAvian influenza (26): Israel (HD), emu, OIE 20100507.1486\nAvian influenza (36): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, RFI\n20100522.1698\nAvian influenza (31): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, RFI\n20100519.1647\nAvian influenza (30): Israel (HD), emu, OIE, resolved 20100515.1594\nAvian influenza (28): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, susp. The\naffected farm includes 13 400 birds. Quarantine measures and\nsurveillance have immediately been applied.\n\nNo unusual mortality has been detected in poultry farms 10 km [6 mi]\naround the affected farm. Veterinarians, to whom the circular is being\nelectronically distributed, are called to alertness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Israeli Veterinary Services have kindly provided the following\nadditional information, for which ProMED-mail is grateful:\n\n\"H5N1 has been confirmed by PCR. Virus isolation is pending. Out of\nthe 13 400 14 week old turkeys in the infected flock, about 1000\nshowed clinical disease, of which 200 died.\n\n\"The entire affected flock, as well as 2 additional turkey flocks on\nthe same farm (14 000 each, one 6 weeks old and the other 4 days old)\nare to be immediately culled. An immediate notification has already\nbeen submitted to the OIE\".\n\nA map showing the location of Rosh Zurim is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0yWZ>. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (25): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, H5N1, OIE\n20110306.0737\nAvian influenza (24): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, H5N1 conf.\n20110305.0719\nAvian influenza (22): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, RFI\n20110303.0695\n2010\n---\nAvian influenza (30): Israel (HD), emu, OIE, resolved 20100515.1594\nAvian influenza (26): Israel (HD), emu, OIE 20100507.1486\nAvian influenza (36): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, RFI\n20100522.1698\nAvian influenza (31): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, RFI\n20100519.1647\nAvian influenza (30): Israel (HD), emu, OIE, resolved 20100515.1594\nAvian influenza (28): Palestinian Authority, West Bank, susp. 24(3) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10174>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n--------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 21 Jan 2011 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief\nVeterinary Officer / Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine),\nAgriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region Government, Hong Kong , Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date 17 Jan 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 19 Jan 2011\nReport date 21 Jan 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 21 Jan 2011\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 18 Dec 2010\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Tai O, Lantau Island, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 18 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status: Resolved (18 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population A Large-billed Crow (Corvus macrorhynchus)\ncarcass was collected on 18 Jan 2011 at Tai O. Large-billed Crow is a\ncommon and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nOutbreak 2 Fairview Park, Yuen Long, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 17 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status Resolved (17 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population An Oriental Magpie Robin (Copsychus saularis)\nwas collected on 17 Jan 2011 at the Fairview Park. Oriental Magpie\nRobin is a common and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: An intensive surveillance system is in\nplace for all poultry farms, poultry markets, pet bird shops and wild\nbirds in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected wild birds were detected in our\nongoing surveillance programme on wild birds. No spread of disease\nwas evident. As this report concerns wild birds, the dates of end of\nthe outbreaks are the same as the dates on which the birds were found\n(17 and 18 Jan 2011, respectively).\n\nControl measures - Measures applied. Screening; Disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 21 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Department of Microbiology, University of\nHong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date\nResult Pending\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oriental Magpie Robins are a common bird in Hong Kong and have\npreviously yielded H5N1 virus in 2009, 2008 and 2006. A Large Billed\nCrow also yielded H5N1 virus in 2009 in Hong Kong. H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance.\n\nFor pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - Mod.PC]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (66): Hong Kong, HPAI H5, chicken, OIE 20101224.4529\nAvian influenza, human (60): China (Hong Kong) 20101122.4228\nAvian influenza (56): Japan (SM) HPAI H5, OIE 20101202.4330\nAvian influenza (55): Japan (SM) susp, RFI 20101130.4303\nAvian influenza (62): South Korea (GN) H5N1, wild bird, RFI 20101212.4417\nAvian influenza (61): South Korea (CB), H5N1, OIE 20101211.4410\nAvian influenza (60): South Korea (CB) H5N1, wild bird, RFI 20101208.4377\nAvian influenza (49): South Korea, LPAI ,H7N6, ducks, OIE 20101105.4014\nAvian influenza (48): South Korea, LPAI, H7N7, ducks, OIE 20101019.3790\nAvian influenza (35): S Korea (CN) LPNAI H7N7, OIE 20100521.1685\n2009\n----\nAvian influenza, human (124): H9N2 China (HK) 20091224.4328\nAvian influenza, human (115): H9, China (HK ex GD) 20091103.3802\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (106): Bangladesh, China (Hong Kong) 20081019.3312\nAvian influenza (87): China (Hong Kong), vaccine efficacy 20080711.2121\nAvian influenza (80): China (Hong Kong, Guandong), UK 20080617.1900\nAvian influenza (75): China (Hong Kong) 20080607.1814\nAvian influenza (41): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20080308.0951\nAvian influenza (34): China (Hong Kong), Laos 20080213.0574\n2007\n----\nAvian influenza (94): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20070602.1786\nAvian influenza (40): Pakistan, China (Hong Kong), Russia 20070222.0658\nAvian influenza (32): UK (England), China (Hong Kong), Turkey 20070212.0534\n2005\n----\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus - Bank, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=668916", "date": "2011-01-22 16:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (07): HONG KONG, H5N1, WILD BIRDS, OIE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 22 Jan 2011\nSource: OIE WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database) Disease\nInformation 2011; 24(3) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10174>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n--------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 21 Jan 2011 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief\nVeterinary Officer / Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine),\nAgriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region Government, Hong Kong , Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date 17 Jan 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 19 Jan 2011\nReport date 21 Jan 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 21 Jan 2011\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 18 Dec 2010\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Tai O, Lantau Island, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 18 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status: Resolved (18 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population A Large-billed Crow (Corvus macrorhynchus)\ncarcass was collected on 18 Jan 2011 at Tai O. Large-billed Crow is a\ncommon and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nOutbreak 2 Fairview Park, Yuen Long, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 17 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status Resolved (17 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population An Oriental Magpie Robin (Copsychus saularis)\nwas collected on 17 Jan 2011 at the Fairview Park. Oriental Magpie\nRobin is a common and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: An intensive surveillance system is in\nplace for all poultry farms, poultry markets, pet bird shops and wild\nbirds in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected wild birds were detected in our\nongoing surveillance programme on wild birds. No spread of disease\nwas evident. As this report concerns wild birds, the dates of end of\nthe outbreaks are the same as the dates on which the birds were found\n(17 and 18 Jan 2011, respectively).\n\nControl measures - Measures applied. Screening; Disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 21 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Department of Microbiology, University of\nHong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date\nResult Pending\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oriental Magpie Robins are a common bird in Hong Kong and have\npreviously yielded H5N1 virus in 2009, 2008 and 2006. A Large Billed\nCrow also yielded H5N1 virus in 2009 in Hong Kong. H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance.\n\nFor pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - Mod.PC]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (66): Hong Kong, HPAI H5, chicken, OIE 20101224.4529\nAvian influenza, human (60): China (Hong Kong) 20101122.4228\nAvian influenza (56): Japan (SM) HPAI H5, OIE 20101202.4330\nAvian influenza (55): Japan (SM) susp, RFI 20101130.4303\nAvian influenza (62): South Korea (GN) H5N1, wild bird, RFI 20101212.4417\nAvian influenza (61): South Korea (CB), H5N1, OIE 20101211.4410\nAvian influenza (60): South Korea (CB) H5N1, wild bird, RFI 20101208.4377\nAvian influenza (49): South Korea, LPAI ,H7N6, ducks, OIE 20101105.4014\nAvian influenza (48): South Korea, LPAI, H7N7, ducks, OIE 20101019.3790\nAvian influenza (35): S Korea (CN) LPNAI H7N7, OIE 20100521.1685\n2009\n----\nAvian influenza, human (124): H9N2 China (HK) 20091224.4328\nAvian influenza, human (115): H9, China (HK ex GD) 20091103.3802\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (106): Bangladesh, China (Hong Kong) 20081019.3312\nAvian influenza (87): China (Hong Kong), vaccine efficacy 20080711.2121\nAvian influenza (80): China (Hong Kong, Guandong), UK 20080617.1900\nAvian influenza (75): China (Hong Kong) 20080607.1814\nAvian influenza (41): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20080308.0951\nAvian influenza (34): China (Hong Kong), Laos 20080213.0574\n2007\n----\nAvian influenza (94): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20070602.1786\nAvian influenza (40): Pakistan, China (Hong Kong), Russia 20070222.0658\nAvian influenza (32): UK (England), China (Hong Kong), Turkey 20070212.0534\n2005\n----\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus - China (Hong Kong): 2003 20050718.2068\n2004\n----\nAvian influenza, falcon - China (Hong Kong)(02): OIE 20040127.0314\nAvian influenza, falcon - China (Hong Kong) 20040121.0243\n2003\n----\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (13) 20021222.6112\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (14) 20021228.6144\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20010518.0973\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (04) 20010519.0978\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (04) 19980119.0156\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (30) 19971231.2566\n...................pc/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. was collected on 18 Jan 2011 at Tai O. Large-billed Crow is a\ncommon and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nOutbreak 2 Fairview Park, Yuen Long, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 17 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status Resolved (17 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population An Oriental Magpie Robin (Copsychus saularis)\nwas collected on 17 Jan 2011 at the Fairview Park. Oriental Magpie\nRobin is a common and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: An intensive surveillance system is in\nplace for all poultry farms, poultry markets, pet bird shops and wild\nbirds in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected wild birds were detected in our\nongoing surveillance programme on wild birds. No spread of disease\nwas evident. As this report concerns wild birds, the dates of end of\nthe outbreaks are the same as the dates on which the birds were found\n(17 and 18 Jan 2011, respectively).\n\nControl measures - Measures applied. Screening; Disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 21 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Department of Microbiology, University of\nHong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date\nResult Pending\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oriental Magpie Robins are a common bird in Hong Kong and have\npreviously yielded H5N1 virus in 2009, 2008 and 2006. A Large Billed\nCrow also yielded H5N1 virus in 2009 in Hong Kong. H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance.\n\nFor pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 22 Jan 2011\nSource: OIE WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database) Disease\nInformation 2011; 24(3) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10174>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n--------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 21 Jan 2011 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief\nVeterinary Officer / Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine),\nAgriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region Government, Hong Kong , Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date 17 Jan 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 19 Jan 2011\nReport date 21 Jan 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 21 Jan 2011\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 18 Dec 2010\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Tai O, Lantau Island, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 18 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status: Resolved (18 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population A Large-billed Crow (Corvus macrorhynchus)\ncarcass was collected on 18 Jan 2011 at Tai O. Large-billed Crow is a\ncommon and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nOutbreak 2 Fairview Park, Yuen Long, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 17 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status Resolved (17 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population An Oriental Magpie Robin (Copsychus saularis)\nwas collected on 17 Jan 2011 at the Fairview Park. Oriental Magpie\nRobin is a common and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: An intensive surveillance system is in\nplace for all poultry farms, poultry markets, pet bird shops and wild\nbirds in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected wild birds were detected in our\nongoing surveillance programme on wild birds. No spread of disease\nwas evident. As this report concerns wild birds, the dates of end of\nthe outbreaks are the same as the dates on which the birds were found\n(17 and 18 Jan 2011, respectively).\n\nControl measures - Measures applied. Screening; Disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 21 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Department of Microbiology, University of\nHong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date\nResult Pending\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oriental Magpie Robins are a common bird in Hong Kong and have\npreviously yielded H5N1 virus in 2009, 2008 and 2006. A Large Billed\nCrow also yielded H5N1 virus in 2009 in Hong Kong. H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance.\n\nFor pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance.\n\nFor pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - birds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=637269", "date": "2011-01-22 16:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (07): HONG KONG, H5N1, WILD BIRDS, OIE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 22 Jan 2011\nSource: OIE WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database) Disease\nInformation 2011; 24(3) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=10174>\n\n\nHighly pathogenic avian influenza, Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n--------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 21 Jan 2011 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief\nVeterinary Officer / Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine),\nAgriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region Government, Hong Kong , Hong Kong (SAR - PRC)\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date 17 Jan 2011\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event 19 Jan 2011\nReport date 21 Jan 2011\nDate submitted to OIE 21 Jan 2011\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 18 Dec 2010\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus\nSerotype H5N1\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Tai O, Lantau Island, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 18 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status: Resolved (18 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population A Large-billed Crow (Corvus macrorhynchus)\ncarcass was collected on 18 Jan 2011 at Tai O. Large-billed Crow is a\ncommon and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nOutbreak 2 Fairview Park, Yuen Long, Hong Kong\nDate of start of the outbreak 17 Jan 2011\nOutbreak status Resolved (17 Jan 2011)\nEpidemiological unit Not applicable\nSpecies Wild species\nSusceptible\nCases 1\nDeaths 1\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected Population An Oriental Magpie Robin (Copsychus saularis)\nwas collected on 17 Jan 2011 at the Fairview Park. Oriental Magpie\nRobin is a common and widespread resident in Hong Kong.\n\nEpidemiology - Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection.\nUnknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: An intensive surveillance system is in\nplace for all poultry farms, poultry markets, pet bird shops and wild\nbirds in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected wild birds were detected in our\nongoing surveillance programme on wild birds. No spread of disease\nwas evident. As this report concerns wild birds, the dates of end of\nthe outbreaks are the same as the dates on which the birds were found\n(17 and 18 Jan 2011, respectively).\n\nControl measures - Measures applied. Screening; Disinfection of\ninfected premises/establishment(s); No vaccination; No treatment of\naffected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied - No other measures\n\nLaboratory name and type Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture,\nFisheries and Conservation Department (National laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 19 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest polymerase chain reaction (PCR)\nTest date 20 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Wild species\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 21 Jan 2011\nResult Positive\n\nLaboratory name and type Department of Microbiology, University of\nHong Kong (Regional Reference Laboratory)\nSpecies Wild species\nTest gene sequencing\nTest date\nResult Pending\n\nFuture Reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Oriental Magpie Robins are a common bird in Hong Kong and have\npreviously yielded H5N1 virus in 2009, 2008 and 2006. A Large Billed\nCrow also yielded H5N1 virus in 2009 in Hong Kong. H5N1 has also been\nisolated from both of these wild bird species in Japan and other\nsites in Asia, so the current isolation of virus from these birds is\nfar from unprecedented. It does serve to remind us that we have seen\ndead poultry, wild birds and a person this season in Hong Kong and\ntherefore, Avian influenza still requires intensive surveillance as\nis being done in this instance.\n\nFor pictures of the Oriental Magpie Robin and Large Billed Crows see:\n<http://www.thaibirding.com/features/commonbirdsofthailand.htm>\n\nFor the location of the outbreak, see the map appended to the OIE\nWAHID report or the Healthmap website at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0nTt> - "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=634098", "date": "2010-12-06 18:00:04", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (58): JAPAN (SHIMANE), HPAI H5N1\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 6 Dec 2010\nSource: USAgNet via Wisconsin Ag connection [edited]\n<http://www.wisconsinagconnection.com/story-national.php?Id=2425&yr=2010>\n\n\nAuthorities in Japan have confirmed that the earlier outbreak of bird\nflu on a layer farm was caused by the H5N1 sub-type of the highly\npathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus.\n\nThe veterinary authorities sent an immediate notification last week\nto the World Organisation for Animal Health [see comment].\n\nThe report confirms that the outbreak of bird flu at a layer farm at\nYasugi city in Shimane prefecture in the southwest of Honshu was\ncaused by the H5N1 HPAI virus. The outbreak started on 27 Nov 2010.\nIn total, 57 birds died, but the remaining 21 549 layers have been destroyed.\n\nAccording to the report, the outbreak of HPAI was confirmed on 2 Dec\n2010 in Shimane prefecture. The previous outbreak of HPAI in Japan\nstarted in April 2008.\n\nThe event has been contained in the affected farm by control measures\nincluding stamping-out and movement restrictions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japan's immediate OIE notification on this outbreak, dated 2 Dec\n2010, was included in posting 20101202.4330; it referred to the\ncausative agent as HPAI H5. Subscribers are referred to the\ncomprehensive commentary by Mod.PC, included in the said posting.\n\nThe current newswire completes the identification of the virus. An\nofficial confirmation is to be included in the follow-up report,\nanticipated soon. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (56): Japan (SM) HPAI H5, OIE 20101202.4330\nAvian influenza (55): Japan (SM) susp, RFI 20101130.4303\n2009\n----\nAvian influenza (33): Japan, raccoons, serology 20090409.1368\nAvian influenza (32): Japan, raccoons, serology 20090407.1348\nAvian influenza (25): Germany, wild duck, H5N1, Japan, H7 20090311.1005\nAvian influenza (24): Japan (AI) LPNAI H7N6 20090309.0980\nAvian influenza (22): Japan (AI) LPNAI H7N6 1st rep. 20090306.0927\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (68): Japan, S.Korea, Viet Nam, India 20080511.1605\nAvian influenza (66): Japan, swan, Denmark, LPAI H7, OIE 20080430.1484\nAvian influenza (65): Japan, swan, Denmark, LPAI, H7 20080429.1479\nAvian influenza, human (46): Japan, Egypt WHO 20080418.1389\nAvian influenza, human (45): Egypt, Japan 20080416.1370\n2007\n----\nAvian influenza (55): Nigeria, VietNam, Myanmar, Japan, Thailand 20070320.0986\nAvian influenza (31): Pakistan, S. The outbreak started on 27 Nov 2010.\nIn total, 57 birds died, but the remaining 21 549 layers have been destroyed.\n\nAccording to the report, the outbreak of HPAI was confirmed on 2 Dec\n2010 in Shimane prefecture. The previous outbreak of HPAI in Japan\nstarted in April 2008.\n\nThe event has been contained in the affected farm by control measures\nincluding stamping-out and movement restrictions.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japan's immediate OIE notification on this outbreak, dated 2 Dec\n2010, was included in posting 20101202.4330; it referred to the\ncausative agent as HPAI H5. Subscribers are referred to the\ncomprehensive commentary by Mod.PC, included in the said posting.\n\nThe current newswire completes the identification of the virus. An\nofficial confirmation is to be included in the follow-up report,\nanticipated soon. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (56): Japan (SM) HPAI H5, OIE 20101202.4330\nAvian influenza (55): Japan (SM) susp, RFI 20101130.4303\n2009\n----\nAvian influenza (33): Japan, raccoons, serology 20090409.1368\nAvian influenza (32): Japan, raccoons, serology 20090407.1348\nAvian influenza (25): Germany, wild duck, H5N1, Japan, H7 20090311.1005\nAvian influenza (24): Japan (AI) LPNAI H7N6 20090309.0980\nAvian influenza (22): Japan (AI) LPNAI H7N6 1st rep. 20090306.0927\n2008\n----\nAvian influenza (68): Japan, S.Korea, Viet Nam, India 20080511.1605\nAvian influenza (66): Japan, swan, Denmark, LPAI H7, OIE 20080430.1484\nAvian influenza (65): Japan, swan, Denmark, LPAI, H7 20080429.1479\nAvian influenza, human (46): Japan, Egypt WHO 20080418.1389\nAvian influenza, human (45): Egypt, Japan 20080416.1370\n2007\n----\nAvian influenza (55): Nigeria, VietNam, Myanmar, Japan, Thailand 20070320.0986\nAvian influenza (31): Pakistan, S. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-04-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2056-03-16 00:00:00", "2055-03-16 00:00:00", "2032-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2068-03-16 00:00:00", "2046-03-16 00:00:00", "2045-03-16 00:00:00", "2055-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "S.Korea", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "Shimane", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "JAPAN", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "S. Korea", "country": "North Korea"}, {"location": "Myanmar", "country": "Myanmar"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pakistan", "country": "Pakistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "445995", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (37): China (Tibet) wild birds, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=445995", "date": "2008-12-12 15:00:42", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (117): CHINA (HONG KONG), H5N1, INDIA (ASSAM)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\n[2] India, Assam - spread\n\n******\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1108birds-jw.html>\n\n\nTests confirm H5N1 in Hong Kong outbreak\n----------------------------------------\nAgriculture officials in Hong Kong today [11 Dec 2008] confirmed that the\navian influenza virus that recently hit a large commercial chicken farm was\nthe lethal H5N1 strain, as authorities vowed to explore potential\nprotection gaps in the poultry vaccine and the possibility that smuggled\neggs might be a source of the virus.\n\nJolly Choi, spokeswoman for Hong Kong's agriculture, fisheries, and\nconservation department said earlier tests on 9 Dec 2008 were positive for\nan H5 virus, but further testing showed that 3 chickens found dead on the\nfarm had the H5N1 subtype, according to a report today from the Associated\nPress.\n\nMeanwhile, York Chow, Hong Kong's secretary for food and health, told\nreporters at a press conference yesterday [Wed 10 Dec 2008; see posting\n20081210.3879 - Mod.AS] that experts are focusing on 2 lines of\ninvestigation: a possible biosecurity lapse at the farm and if a change in\nthe circulating virus has hobbled Hong Kong's poultry vaccine.\n\nThe outbreak, China's 1st on a farm since 2003, prompted the culling of\nmore than 80 000 birds and restrictions on poultry imports.\n\nChow said Hong Kong been using an H5N2 vaccine manufactured in the\nNetherlands since 2003. \"Over the last few years it has been proven to be\neffective, but we also think that because the change of the virus, we might\nhave to look for a more appropriate vaccine,\" he said in a government press\nrelease.\n\nThe Chinese mainland has been using H5N1 vaccine for poultry over the past\nfew years, which is modified periodically, Chow said, adding that\nveterinary officials have contacted mainland authorities to explore if a\nswitch to the H5N1 vaccine would be more protective. He said that\ngovernment officials would also be seeking guidance from experts at Hong\nKong University, where vaccine studies in poultry have already been under\nway since June [2008].\n\nSo far there is no evidence that the virus has spread to other farms, Chow\nsaid in the statement. Investigators have collected samples from farms to\nconduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing, and the results should be\navailable in a day or 2.\n\nIn other developments, poultry trade representatives in Hong Kong said\ntoday that smuggled fertilized eggs from China could be the source of the\nrecent H5N1 outbreak, according to a report today from Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe Hong Kong Poultry Wholesalers Association said smuggling has become\nmore common since the government banned the import of 1-day-old chickens\nfrom China as an H5N1 prevention measure earlier this year [2008], the AFP\nreport said.\n\nThe South China Morning Post reported today that the eggs, ostensibly\nimported as food, contain potentially infected embryos that are less than a\nweek from hatching, according to AFP. However, the owner of the farm that\nwas struck by the H5N1 virus denied having smuggled any fertilized eggs\nfrom China, the report said.\n\nElsewhere, health ministry officials in India said today that the H5N1\nvirus has now spread to 6 of 27 districts in Assam state, according to a\nreport from Indo-Asian News Service (IANS) [see item 2, below]. Parthajyoti\nGogoi, a health ministry official, told IANS that more than 200 000\nchickens and ducks have been culled since the outbreak was 1st detected 2\nweeks ago. The culling activities have affected 200 villages in Kamrup\n(Metro), Kamrup (Rural), Dibrugarh, Nalbari, Barpeta, and Chirang districts.\n\nTeams of doctors and paramedics are taking measures to prevent human H5N1\ninfections, the report said.\n\n[byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] India, Assam - spread\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: ZeeNews [edited]\n<http://www.zeenews.com/states/2008-12-11/490211news.html>\n\n\nBird flu spreads its wings, affects 9 Assam districts\n-----------------------------------------------------\nWith the avian influenza spreading to fresh areas, 9 Assam districts are\nnow bird flu affected and health minister Himanta Biswa Sarma on Thursday\n[11 Dec 2008] warned that it could become a major human disaster. The\naffected districts were Kamrup (Rural), Kamrup (Metro), Barpeta, Nalbari,\nChirang, Baksa, Dibrugarh, Goalpara and Bongaigaon, official sources said.\n\nSale of poultry and eggs, either cooked or raw, has been banned in Guwahati\nand Kamrup (Metro) district which comprises Guwahati and adjoining areas.\n\nCulling of poultry, ducks and other birds has been continuing in the\naffected districts with over 1.5 lakh [150 000] birds killed so far, the\nsources said.\n\n\"People are taking the disease very casually. Chicken and ducks are being\nkept away from culling without realising the seriousness of the disease,\"\nSarma told reporters here. \"We will not be able to handle it, if the\ndisease spreads to humans from the birds. The way the disease is spreading,\nit will be a greater disaster than bomb blasts or floods,\" Sarma said. \"The\nhuman disaster will be immense. The health department is very worried about\nhuman transmission of the disease as it is not 100 percent equipped to\nhandle a large scale outbreak as there are no isolation facilities here,\"\nhe said.\n\nThe disease, starting from Hajo revenue circle in Kamrup (Rural) district\nabout 20 km [12.4 miles] from here [Guwahati] on 2 Dec 2008 and spread to\nGuwahati in Kamrup (Metro) district, Nalbari, Barpeta, Chirang, Baksa,\nBongaigaon and Goalpara districts in Lower Assam spreading to Dibrugarh\ndistrict in Upper Assam.\n\nTaking in view that the bird flu is spreading to new areas in neighbouring\nAssam, Meghalaya banned the entry of poultry and poultry products from\nAssam and Bangladesh.\n\n\"The ban comes into force with immediate effect. However, the ban does not\nimply to the sale of poultry and poultry products produced within the\nstate,\" a Veterinary Department release here said. A senior veterinary\nofficial told media that they were preparing to cull birds and poultry in\nthe bordering areas with Assam as soon as the centre asks to do so.\n\n\"Normally culling operations are done in a radius of 3 km [1.8 miles] of\nthe place of disease outbreak. With the bird flu outbreak in Assam's\nKhanapara, lying along Assam-Meghalaya border, it is likely that culling\nwould be done in the bordering areas of Meghalaya too,\" he said.\n\nDeputy commissioner of Ri Bhoi district that borders Khanapara in Assam's\nKamrup (Rural) district is on a visit to the bordering areas along with a\nteam of veterinary officials to take stock of the situation. The government\nhas set up control rooms in all districts to facilitate information to the\npoultry farms. Veterinary officials have been regularly adopting measures\nto prevent spread of the disease into the state and deputy commissioners of\nall the districts have been alerted, sources said. Meghalaya already has in\nplace 150 rapid response teams along with 2170 personnel protective\nequipment that were constituted last year [2007] after the outbreak of\navian flu in West Bengal.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since January 2006, India reported 51 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; its current\nspread in Assam seems to become India's 2nd major outbreak, following the\none observed in January 2008 on its north eastern regions, bordering\n(infected) Bangladesh. The previous outbreaks occurred in Jan-Apr 2006 (7\noutbreaks); see OIE's time-series analysis for the period Jan 2005-Dec 2008\nby inserting India at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=country_disease_time_series&disease_id=15&disease_type=Terrestrial&selected_analysis=tot_new&selected_start_month=7&selected_start_year=2005&selected_end_month=12&selected_end_year=2008>.\n\n\nIndia's last report to the OIE on H5N1 in the Assam state was submitted on\n28 Nov 2008, addressing an outbreak in Hajo (Rajabazar, Kamrup). It\nincluded the following epidemiological commentary:\n\n\"Epidemiological investigation is ongoing. Stamping out of all domestic\npoultry is being applied in an approximately 5-km-radius [3.1 mile] zone\naround the outbreaks followed by compensation of the owners. An intensive\nsurveillance campaign has been launched in a 10-km-radius [6.2 mile] zone\nincluding:\n- closure of poultry markets and prohibition on sale and transportation of\npoultry products in the infected zone;\n- disinfection of premises after culling and sealing of premises where\nappropriate.\nRestocking will be applied in accordance with a specific protocol.\"\n\nFor the report, including map, see\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=7566> and\nposting 20081129.3757. In view of avian influenza's pattern of seasonal\nactivity, further spread during the coming winter months may be\nanticipated, requiring enhanced and drastic control measures. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (116): China (Hong Kong), H5 20081210.3879\nAvian influenza (115): China (JS, HB, HE) susp, RFI 20081204.3813\nAvian influenza (114): India (AS) HPAI OIE 20081129.3757\nAvian influenza (106): Bangladesh, China (Hong Kong) 20081019.3312\nAvian influenza (87): China (Hong Kong), vaccine efficacy 20080711.2121\nAvian influenza (80): China (Hong Kong, Guandong), UK 20080617.1900\nAvian influenza (75): China (Hong Kong) 20080607.1814\nAvian influenza (41): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20080308.0951\nAvian influenza (34): China (Hong Kong), Laos 20080213.0574\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
