For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2170-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kamrup", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Baksa", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Laos", "country": "Laos"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Guandong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Dibrugarh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "JS", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "253647", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Influenza pandemic (H1N1) 2009 (19): Viet Nam, H1N1, H5N1 (susp)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=253647", "date": "2008-12-12 15:00:42", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (117): CHINA (HONG KONG), H5N1, INDIA (ASSAM)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\n[2] India, Assam - spread\n\n******\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1108birds-jw.html>\n\n\nTests confirm H5N1 in Hong Kong outbreak\n----------------------------------------\nAgriculture officials in Hong Kong today [11 Dec 2008] confirmed that the\navian influenza virus that recently hit a large commercial chicken farm was\nthe lethal H5N1 strain, as authorities vowed to explore potential\nprotection gaps in the poultry vaccine and the possibility that smuggled\neggs might be a source of the virus.\n\nJolly Choi, spokeswoman for Hong Kong's agriculture, fisheries, and\nconservation department said earlier tests on 9 Dec 2008 were positive for\nan H5 virus, but further testing showed that 3 chickens found dead on the\nfarm had the H5N1 subtype, according to a report today from the Associated\nPress.\n\nMeanwhile, York Chow, Hong Kong's secretary for food and health, told\nreporters at a press conference yesterday [Wed 10 Dec 2008; see posting\n20081210.3879 - Mod.AS] that experts are focusing on 2 lines of\ninvestigation: a possible biosecurity lapse at the farm and if a change in\nthe circulating virus has hobbled Hong Kong's poultry vaccine.\n\nThe outbreak, China's 1st on a farm since 2003, prompted the culling of\nmore than 80 000 birds and restrictions on poultry imports.\n\nChow said Hong Kong been using an H5N2 vaccine manufactured in the\nNetherlands since 2003. \"Over the last few years it has been proven to be\neffective, but we also think that because the change of the virus, we might\nhave to look for a more appropriate vaccine,\" he said in a government press\nrelease.\n\nThe Chinese mainland has been using H5N1 vaccine for poultry over the past\nfew years, which is modified periodically, Chow said, adding that\nveterinary officials have contacted mainland authorities to explore if a\nswitch to the H5N1 vaccine would be more protective. He said that\ngovernment officials would also be seeking guidance from experts at Hong\nKong University, where vaccine studies in poultry have already been under\nway since June [2008].\n\nSo far there is no evidence that the virus has spread to other farms, Chow\nsaid in the statement. Investigators have collected samples from farms to\nconduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing, and the results should be\navailable in a day or 2.\n\nIn other developments, poultry trade representatives in Hong Kong said\ntoday that smuggled fertilized eggs from China could be the source of the\nrecent H5N1 outbreak, according to a report today from Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe Hong Kong Poultry Wholesalers Association said smuggling has become\nmore common since the government banned the import of 1-day-old chickens\nfrom China as an H5N1 prevention measure earlier this year [2008], the AFP\nreport said.\n\nThe South China Morning Post reported today that the eggs, ostensibly\nimported as food, contain potentially infected embryos that are less than a\nweek from hatching, according to AFP. However, the owner of the farm that\nwas struck by the H5N1 virus denied having smuggled any fertilized eggs\nfrom China, the report said.\n\nElsewhere, health ministry officials in India said today that the H5N1\nvirus has now spread to 6 of 27 districts in Assam state, according to a\nreport from Indo-Asian News Service (IANS) [see item 2, below]. Parthajyoti\nGogoi, a health ministry official, told IANS that more than 200 000\nchickens and ducks have been culled since the outbreak was 1st detected 2\nweeks ago. The culling activities have affected 200 villages in Kamrup\n(Metro), Kamrup (Rural), Dibrugarh, Nalbari, Barpeta, and Chirang districts.\n\nTeams of doctors and paramedics are taking measures to prevent human H5N1\ninfections, the report said.\n\n[byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] India, Assam - spread\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: ZeeNews [edited]\n<http://www.zeenews.com/states/2008-12-11/490211news.html>\n\n\nBird flu spreads its wings, affects 9 Assam districts\n-----------------------------------------------------\nWith the avian influenza spreading to fresh areas, 9 Assam districts are\nnow bird flu affected and health minister Himanta Biswa Sarma on Thursday\n[11 Dec 2008] warned that it could become a major human disaster. The\naffected districts were Kamrup (Rural), Kamrup (Metro), Barpeta, Nalbari,\nChirang, Baksa, Dibrugarh, Goalpara and Bongaigaon, official sources said.\n\nSale of poultry and eggs, either cooked or raw, has been banned in Guwahati\nand Kamrup (Metro) district which comprises Guwahati and adjoining areas.\n\nCulling of poultry, ducks and other birds has been continuing in the\naffected districts with over 1.5 lakh [150 000] birds killed so far, the\nsources said.\n\n\"People are taking the disease very casually. Chicken and ducks are being\nkept away from culling without realising the seriousness of the disease,\"\nSarma told reporters here. \"We will not be able to handle it, if the\ndisease spreads to humans from the birds. The way the disease is spreading,\nit will be a greater disaster than bomb blasts or floods,\" Sarma said. \"The\nhuman disaster will be immense. The health department is very worried about\nhuman transmission of the disease as it is not 100 percent equipped to\nhandle a large scale outbreak as there are no isolation facilities here,\"\nhe said.\n\nThe disease, starting from Hajo revenue circle in Kamrup (Rural) district\nabout 20 km [12.4 miles] from here [Guwahati] on 2 Dec 2008 and spread to\nGuwahati in Kamrup (Metro) district, Nalbari, Barpeta, Chirang, Baksa,\nBongaigaon and Goalpara districts in Lower Assam spreading to Dibrugarh\ndistrict in Upper Assam.\n\nTaking in view that the bird flu is spreading to new areas in neighbouring\nAssam, Meghalaya banned the entry of poultry and poultry products from\nAssam and Bangladesh.\n\n\"The ban comes into force with immediate effect. However, the ban does not\nimply to the sale of poultry and poultry products produced within the\nstate,\" a Veterinary Department release here said. A senior veterinary\nofficial told media that they were preparing to cull birds and poultry in\nthe bordering areas with Assam as soon as the centre asks to do so.\n\n\"Normally culling operations are done in a radius of 3 km [1.8 miles] of\nthe place of disease outbreak. With the bird flu outbreak in Assam's\nKhanapara, lying along Assam-Meghalaya border, it is likely that culling\nwould be done in the bordering areas of Meghalaya too,\" he said.\n\nDeputy commissioner of Ri Bhoi district that borders Khanapara in Assam's\nKamrup (Rural) district is on a visit to the bordering areas along with a\nteam of veterinary officials to take stock of the situation. The government\nhas set up control rooms in all districts to facilitate information to the\npoultry farms. Veterinary officials have been regularly adopting measures\nto prevent spread of the disease into the state and deputy commissioners of\nall the districts have been alerted, sources said. Meghalaya already has in\nplace 150 rapid response teams along with 2170 personnel protective\nequipment that were constituted last year [2007] after the outbreak of\navian flu in West Bengal.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since January 2006, India reported 51 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; its current\nspread in Assam seems to become India's 2nd major outbreak, following the\none observed in January 2008 on its north eastern regions, bordering\n(infected) Bangladesh. The previous outbreaks occurred in Jan-Apr 2006 (7\noutbreaks); see OIE's time-series analysis for the period Jan 2005-Dec 2008\nby inserting India at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=country_disease_time_series&disease_id=15&disease_type=Terrestrial&selected_analysis=tot_new&selected_start_month=7&selected_start_year=2005&selected_end_month=12&selected_end_year=2008>.\n\n\nIndia's last report to the OIE on H5N1 in the Assam state was submitted on\n28 Nov 2008, addressing an outbreak in Hajo (Rajabazar, Kamrup). It\nincluded the following epidemiological commentary:\n\n\"Epidemiological investigation is ongoing. Stamping out of all domestic\npoultry is being applied in an approximately 5-km-radius [3.1 mile] zone\naround the outbreaks followed by compensation of the owners. An intensive\nsurveillance campaign has been launched in a 10-km-radius [6.2 mile] zone\nincluding:\n- closure of poultry markets and prohibition on sale and transportation of\npoultry products in the infected zone;\n- disinfection of premises after culling and sealing of premises where\nappropriate.\nRestocking will be applied in accordance with a specific protocol.\"\n\nFor the report, including map, see\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=7566> and\nposting 20081129.3757. In view of avian influenza's pattern of seasonal\nactivity, further spread during the coming winter months may be\nanticipated, requiring enhanced and drastic control measures. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (116): China (Hong Kong), H5 20081210.3879\nAvian influenza (115): China (JS, HB, HE) susp, RFI 20081204.3813\nAvian influenza (114): India (AS) HPAI OIE 20081129.3757\nAvian influenza (106): Bangladesh, China (Hong Kong) 20081019.3312\nAvian influenza (87): China (Hong Kong), vaccine efficacy 20080711.2121\nAvian influenza (80): China (Hong Kong, Guandong), UK 20080617.1900\nAvian influenza (75): China (Hong Kong) 20080607.1814\nAvian influenza (41): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20080308.0951\nAvian influenza (34): China (Hong Kong), Laos 20080213.0574\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2170-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kamrup", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Baksa", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Laos", "country": "Laos"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Guandong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Dibrugarh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "JS", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "167018", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (26): France, LPAI, (CV) H5N1, (PC) H5", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=167018", "date": "2008-12-12 15:00:42", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (117): CHINA (HONG KONG), H5N1, INDIA (ASSAM)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\n[2] India, Assam - spread\n\n******\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1108birds-jw.html>\n\n\nTests confirm H5N1 in Hong Kong outbreak\n----------------------------------------\nAgriculture officials in Hong Kong today [11 Dec 2008] confirmed that the\navian influenza virus that recently hit a large commercial chicken farm was\nthe lethal H5N1 strain, as authorities vowed to explore potential\nprotection gaps in the poultry vaccine and the possibility that smuggled\neggs might be a source of the virus.\n\nJolly Choi, spokeswoman for Hong Kong's agriculture, fisheries, and\nconservation department said earlier tests on 9 Dec 2008 were positive for\nan H5 virus, but further testing showed that 3 chickens found dead on the\nfarm had the H5N1 subtype, according to a report today from the Associated\nPress.\n\nMeanwhile, York Chow, Hong Kong's secretary for food and health, told\nreporters at a press conference yesterday [Wed 10 Dec 2008; see posting\n20081210.3879 - Mod.AS] that experts are focusing on 2 lines of\ninvestigation: a possible biosecurity lapse at the farm and if a change in\nthe circulating virus has hobbled Hong Kong's poultry vaccine.\n\nThe outbreak, China's 1st on a farm since 2003, prompted the culling of\nmore than 80 000 birds and restrictions on poultry imports.\n\nChow said Hong Kong been using an H5N2 vaccine manufactured in the\nNetherlands since 2003. \"Over the last few years it has been proven to be\neffective, but we also think that because the change of the virus, we might\nhave to look for a more appropriate vaccine,\" he said in a government press\nrelease.\n\nThe Chinese mainland has been using H5N1 vaccine for poultry over the past\nfew years, which is modified periodically, Chow said, adding that\nveterinary officials have contacted mainland authorities to explore if a\nswitch to the H5N1 vaccine would be more protective. He said that\ngovernment officials would also be seeking guidance from experts at Hong\nKong University, where vaccine studies in poultry have already been under\nway since June [2008].\n\nSo far there is no evidence that the virus has spread to other farms, Chow\nsaid in the statement. Investigators have collected samples from farms to\nconduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing, and the results should be\navailable in a day or 2.\n\nIn other developments, poultry trade representatives in Hong Kong said\ntoday that smuggled fertilized eggs from China could be the source of the\nrecent H5N1 outbreak, according to a report today from Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe Hong Kong Poultry Wholesalers Association said smuggling has become\nmore common since the government banned the import of 1-day-old chickens\nfrom China as an H5N1 prevention measure earlier this year [2008], the AFP\nreport said.\n\nThe South China Morning Post reported today that the eggs, ostensibly\nimported as food, contain potentially infected embryos that are less than a\nweek from hatching, according to AFP. However, the owner of the farm that\nwas struck by the H5N1 virus denied having smuggled any fertilized eggs\nfrom China, the report said.\n\nElsewhere, health ministry officials in India said today that the H5N1\nvirus has now spread to 6 of 27 districts in Assam state, according to a\nreport from Indo-Asian News Service (IANS) [see item 2, below]. Parthajyoti\nGogoi, a health ministry official, told IANS that more than 200 000\nchickens and ducks have been culled since the outbreak was 1st detected 2\nweeks ago. The culling activities have affected 200 villages in Kamrup\n(Metro), Kamrup (Rural), Dibrugarh, Nalbari, Barpeta, and Chirang districts.\n\nTeams of doctors and paramedics are taking measures to prevent human H5N1\ninfections, the report said.\n\n[byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] India, Assam - spread\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: ZeeNews [edited]\n<http://www.zeenews.com/states/2008-12-11/490211news.html>\n\n\nBird flu spreads its wings, affects 9 Assam districts\n-----------------------------------------------------\nWith the avian influenza spreading to fresh areas, 9 Assam districts are\nnow bird flu affected and health minister Himanta Biswa Sarma on Thursday\n[11 Dec 2008] warned that it could become a major human disaster. The\naffected districts were Kamrup (Rural), Kamrup (Metro), Barpeta, Nalbari,\nChirang, Baksa, Dibrugarh, Goalpara and Bongaigaon, official sources said.\n\nSale of poultry and eggs, either cooked or raw, has been banned in Guwahati\nand Kamrup (Metro) district which comprises Guwahati and adjoining areas.\n\nCulling of poultry, ducks and other birds has been continuing in the\naffected districts with over 1.5 lakh [150 000] birds killed so far, the\nsources said.\n\n\"People are taking the disease very casually. Chicken and ducks are being\nkept away from culling without realising the seriousness of the disease,\"\nSarma told reporters here. \"We will not be able to handle it, if the\ndisease spreads to humans from the birds. The way the disease is spreading,\nit will be a greater disaster than bomb blasts or floods,\" Sarma said. \"The\nhuman disaster will be immense. The health department is very worried about\nhuman transmission of the disease as it is not 100 percent equipped to\nhandle a large scale outbreak as there are no isolation facilities here,\"\nhe said.\n\nThe disease, starting from Hajo revenue circle in Kamrup (Rural) district\nabout 20 km [12.4 miles] from here [Guwahati] on 2 Dec 2008 and spread to\nGuwahati in Kamrup (Metro) district, Nalbari, Barpeta, Chirang, Baksa,\nBongaigaon and Goalpara districts in Lower Assam spreading to Dibrugarh\ndistrict in Upper Assam.\n\nTaking in view that the bird flu is spreading to new areas in neighbouring\nAssam, Meghalaya banned the entry of poultry and poultry products from\nAssam and Bangladesh.\n\n\"The ban comes into force with immediate effect. However, the ban does not\nimply to the sale of poultry and poultry products produced within the\nstate,\" a Veterinary Department release here said. A senior veterinary\nofficial told media that they were preparing to cull birds and poultry in\nthe bordering areas with Assam as soon as the centre asks to do so.\n\n\"Normally culling operations are done in a radius of 3 km [1.8 miles] of\nthe place of disease outbreak. With the bird flu outbreak in Assam's\nKhanapara, lying along Assam-Meghalaya border, it is likely that culling\nwould be done in the bordering areas of Meghalaya too,\" he said.\n\nDeputy commissioner of Ri Bhoi district that borders Khanapara in Assam's\nKamrup (Rural) district is on a visit to the bordering areas along with a\nteam of veterinary officials to take stock of the situation. The government\nhas set up control rooms in all districts to facilitate information to the\npoultry farms. Veterinary officials have been regularly adopting measures\nto prevent spread of the disease into the state and deputy commissioners of\nall the districts have been alerted, sources said. Meghalaya already has in\nplace 150 rapid response teams along with 2170 personnel protective\nequipment that were constituted last year [2007] after the outbreak of\navian flu in West Bengal.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since January 2006, India reported 51 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; its current\nspread in Assam seems to become India's 2nd major outbreak, following the\none observed in January 2008 on its north eastern regions, bordering\n(infected) Bangladesh. The previous outbreaks occurred in Jan-Apr 2006 (7\noutbreaks); see OIE's time-series analysis for the period Jan 2005-Dec 2008\nby inserting India at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=country_disease_time_series&disease_id=15&disease_type=Terrestrial&selected_analysis=tot_new&selected_start_month=7&selected_start_year=2005&selected_end_month=12&selected_end_year=2008>.\n\n\nIndia's last report to the OIE on H5N1 in the Assam state was submitted on\n28 Nov 2008, addressing an outbreak in Hajo (Rajabazar, Kamrup). It\nincluded the following epidemiological commentary:\n\n\"Epidemiological investigation is ongoing. Stamping out of all domestic\npoultry is being applied in an approximately 5-km-radius [3.1 mile] zone\naround the outbreaks followed by compensation of the owners. An intensive\nsurveillance campaign has been launched in a 10-km-radius [6.2 mile] zone\nincluding:\n- closure of poultry markets and prohibition on sale and transportation of\npoultry products in the infected zone;\n- disinfection of premises after culling and sealing of premises where\nappropriate.\nRestocking will be applied in accordance with a specific protocol.\"\n\nFor the report, including map, see\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=7566> and\nposting 20081129.3757. In view of avian influenza's pattern of seasonal\nactivity, further spread during the coming winter months may be\nanticipated, requiring enhanced and drastic control measures. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (116): China (Hong Kong), H5 20081210.3879\nAvian influenza (115): China (JS, HB, HE) susp, RFI 20081204.3813\nAvian influenza (114): India (AS) HPAI OIE 20081129.3757\nAvian influenza (106): Bangladesh, China (Hong Kong) 20081019.3312\nAvian influenza (87): China (Hong Kong), vaccine efficacy 20080711.2121\nAvian influenza (80): China (Hong Kong, Guandong), UK 20080617.1900\nAvian influenza (75): China (Hong Kong) 20080607.1814\nAvian influenza (41): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20080308.0951\nAvian influenza (34): China (Hong Kong), Laos 20080213.0574\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Chicken and ducks are being\nkept away from culling without realising the seriousness of the disease,\"\nSarma told reporters here. \"We will not be able to handle it, if the\ndisease spreads to humans from the birds. The way the disease is spreading,\nit will be a greater disaster than bomb blasts or floods,\" Sarma said. \"The\nhuman disaster will be immense. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2170-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kamrup", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Baksa", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Laos", "country": "Laos"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Guandong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Dibrugarh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "JS", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "158383", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (14): S Korea LPNAI H5, Viet Nam HPNAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=158383", "date": "2008-12-12 15:00:42", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (117): CHINA (HONG KONG), H5N1, INDIA (ASSAM)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\n[2] India, Assam - spread\n\n******\n[1] Hong Kong - H5N1 confirmed\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1108birds-jw.html>\n\n\nTests confirm H5N1 in Hong Kong outbreak\n----------------------------------------\nAgriculture officials in Hong Kong today [11 Dec 2008] confirmed that the\navian influenza virus that recently hit a large commercial chicken farm was\nthe lethal H5N1 strain, as authorities vowed to explore potential\nprotection gaps in the poultry vaccine and the possibility that smuggled\neggs might be a source of the virus.\n\nJolly Choi, spokeswoman for Hong Kong's agriculture, fisheries, and\nconservation department said earlier tests on 9 Dec 2008 were positive for\nan H5 virus, but further testing showed that 3 chickens found dead on the\nfarm had the H5N1 subtype, according to a report today from the Associated\nPress.\n\nMeanwhile, York Chow, Hong Kong's secretary for food and health, told\nreporters at a press conference yesterday [Wed 10 Dec 2008; see posting\n20081210.3879 - Mod.AS] that experts are focusing on 2 lines of\ninvestigation: a possible biosecurity lapse at the farm and if a change in\nthe circulating virus has hobbled Hong Kong's poultry vaccine.\n\nThe outbreak, China's 1st on a farm since 2003, prompted the culling of\nmore than 80 000 birds and restrictions on poultry imports.\n\nChow said Hong Kong been using an H5N2 vaccine manufactured in the\nNetherlands since 2003. \"Over the last few years it has been proven to be\neffective, but we also think that because the change of the virus, we might\nhave to look for a more appropriate vaccine,\" he said in a government press\nrelease.\n\nThe Chinese mainland has been using H5N1 vaccine for poultry over the past\nfew years, which is modified periodically, Chow said, adding that\nveterinary officials have contacted mainland authorities to explore if a\nswitch to the H5N1 vaccine would be more protective. He said that\ngovernment officials would also be seeking guidance from experts at Hong\nKong University, where vaccine studies in poultry have already been under\nway since June [2008].\n\nSo far there is no evidence that the virus has spread to other farms, Chow\nsaid in the statement. Investigators have collected samples from farms to\nconduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing, and the results should be\navailable in a day or 2.\n\nIn other developments, poultry trade representatives in Hong Kong said\ntoday that smuggled fertilized eggs from China could be the source of the\nrecent H5N1 outbreak, according to a report today from Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe Hong Kong Poultry Wholesalers Association said smuggling has become\nmore common since the government banned the import of 1-day-old chickens\nfrom China as an H5N1 prevention measure earlier this year [2008], the AFP\nreport said.\n\nThe South China Morning Post reported today that the eggs, ostensibly\nimported as food, contain potentially infected embryos that are less than a\nweek from hatching, according to AFP. However, the owner of the farm that\nwas struck by the H5N1 virus denied having smuggled any fertilized eggs\nfrom China, the report said.\n\nElsewhere, health ministry officials in India said today that the H5N1\nvirus has now spread to 6 of 27 districts in Assam state, according to a\nreport from Indo-Asian News Service (IANS) [see item 2, below]. Parthajyoti\nGogoi, a health ministry official, told IANS that more than 200 000\nchickens and ducks have been culled since the outbreak was 1st detected 2\nweeks ago. The culling activities have affected 200 villages in Kamrup\n(Metro), Kamrup (Rural), Dibrugarh, Nalbari, Barpeta, and Chirang districts.\n\nTeams of doctors and paramedics are taking measures to prevent human H5N1\ninfections, the report said.\n\n[byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] India, Assam - spread\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2008\nSource: ZeeNews [edited]\n<http://www.zeenews.com/states/2008-12-11/490211news.html>\n\n\nBird flu spreads its wings, affects 9 Assam districts\n-----------------------------------------------------\nWith the avian influenza spreading to fresh areas, 9 Assam districts are\nnow bird flu affected and health minister Himanta Biswa Sarma on Thursday\n[11 Dec 2008] warned that it could become a major human disaster. The\naffected districts were Kamrup (Rural), Kamrup (Metro), Barpeta, Nalbari,\nChirang, Baksa, Dibrugarh, Goalpara and Bongaigaon, official sources said.\n\nSale of poultry and eggs, either cooked or raw, has been banned in Guwahati\nand Kamrup (Metro) district which comprises Guwahati and adjoining areas.\n\nCulling of poultry, ducks and other birds has been continuing in the\naffected districts with over 1.5 lakh [150 000] birds killed so far, the\nsources said.\n\n\"People are taking the disease very casually. Chicken and ducks are being\nkept away from culling without realising the seriousness of the disease,\"\nSarma told reporters here. \"We will not be able to handle it, if the\ndisease spreads to humans from the birds. The way the disease is spreading,\nit will be a greater disaster than bomb blasts or floods,\" Sarma said. \"The\nhuman disaster will be immense. The health department is very worried about\nhuman transmission of the disease as it is not 100 percent equipped to\nhandle a large scale outbreak as there are no isolation facilities here,\"\nhe said.\n\nThe disease, starting from Hajo revenue circle in Kamrup (Rural) district\nabout 20 km [12.4 miles] from here [Guwahati] on 2 Dec 2008 and spread to\nGuwahati in Kamrup (Metro) district, Nalbari, Barpeta, Chirang, Baksa,\nBongaigaon and Goalpara districts in Lower Assam spreading to Dibrugarh\ndistrict in Upper Assam.\n\nTaking in view that the bird flu is spreading to new areas in neighbouring\nAssam, Meghalaya banned the entry of poultry and poultry products from\nAssam and Bangladesh.\n\n\"The ban comes into force with immediate effect. However, the ban does not\nimply to the sale of poultry and poultry products produced within the\nstate,\" a Veterinary Department release here said. A senior veterinary\nofficial told media that they were preparing to cull birds and poultry in\nthe bordering areas with Assam as soon as the centre asks to do so.\n\n\"Normally culling operations are done in a radius of 3 km [1.8 miles] of\nthe place of disease outbreak. With the bird flu outbreak in Assam's\nKhanapara, lying along Assam-Meghalaya border, it is likely that culling\nwould be done in the bordering areas of Meghalaya too,\" he said.\n\nDeputy commissioner of Ri Bhoi district that borders Khanapara in Assam's\nKamrup (Rural) district is on a visit to the bordering areas along with a\nteam of veterinary officials to take stock of the situation. The government\nhas set up control rooms in all districts to facilitate information to the\npoultry farms. Veterinary officials have been regularly adopting measures\nto prevent spread of the disease into the state and deputy commissioners of\nall the districts have been alerted, sources said. Meghalaya already has in\nplace 150 rapid response teams along with 2170 personnel protective\nequipment that were constituted last year [2007] after the outbreak of\navian flu in West Bengal.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Since January 2006, India reported 51 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1; its current\nspread in Assam seems to become India's 2nd major outbreak, following the\none observed in January 2008 on its north eastern regions, bordering\n(infected) Bangladesh. The previous outbreaks occurred in Jan-Apr 2006 (7\noutbreaks); see OIE's time-series analysis for the period Jan 2005-Dec 2008\nby inserting India at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=country_disease_time_series&disease_id=15&disease_type=Terrestrial&selected_analysis=tot_new&selected_start_month=7&selected_start_year=2005&selected_end_month=12&selected_end_year=2008>.\n\n\nIndia's last report to the OIE on H5N1 in the Assam state was submitted on\n28 Nov 2008, addressing an outbreak in Hajo (Rajabazar, Kamrup). It\nincluded the following epidemiological commentary:\n\n\"Epidemiological investigation is ongoing. Stamping out of all domestic\npoultry is being applied in an approximately 5-km-radius [3.1 mile] zone\naround the outbreaks followed by compensation of the owners. An intensive\nsurveillance campaign has been launched in a 10-km-radius [6.2 mile] zone\nincluding:\n- closure of poultry markets and prohibition on sale and transportation of\npoultry products in the infected zone;\n- disinfection of premises after culling and sealing of premises where\nappropriate.\nRestocking will be applied in accordance with a specific protocol.\"\n\nFor the report, including map, see\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=7566> and\nposting 20081129.3757. In view of avian influenza's pattern of seasonal\nactivity, further spread during the coming winter months may be\nanticipated, requiring enhanced and drastic control measures. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (116): China (Hong Kong), H5 20081210.3879\nAvian influenza (115): China (JS, HB, HE) susp, RFI 20081204.3813\nAvian influenza (114): India (AS) HPAI OIE 20081129.3757\nAvian influenza (106): Bangladesh, China (Hong Kong) 20081019.3312\nAvian influenza (87): China (Hong Kong), vaccine efficacy 20080711.2121\nAvian influenza (80): China (Hong Kong, Guandong), UK 20080617.1900\nAvian influenza (75): China (Hong Kong) 20080607.1814\nAvian influenza (41): Viet Nam, China (Hong Kong) 20080308.0951\nAvian influenza (34): China (Hong Kong), Laos 20080213.0574\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Chicken and ducks are being\nkept away from culling without realising the seriousness of the disease,\"\nSarma told reporters here. \"We will not be able to handle it, if the\ndisease spreads to humans from the birds. The way the disease is spreading,\nit will be a greater disaster than bomb blasts or floods,\" Sarma said. \"The\nhuman disaster will be immense. "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (103): Germany (SN), HPAI H5N1 confirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=118681", "date": "2007-12-20 16:00:19", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (191): BENIN, H5N1 CONFIRMED\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 17 Dec 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1707benin.html>\n\n\nTests in Italy have confirmed the 1st poultry outbreaks of H5N1 avian\ninfluenza in the West African country of Benin, according to news services.\n\nAgriculture minister Robert Dovonou said that suspected cases found on 2\nfarms earlier this month [December 2007] were confirmed by the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health (Office International des Epizooties; OIE)\nin Padua, Italy, according to a 15 Dec 2007 report by Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe farms are north of Porto Novo, the capital, and in Cotonou, the\ncommercial capital, both in Benin's southern coastal strip, AFP and Reuters\nreported.\n\nBenin is surrounded by countries that have faced poultry outbreaks within\nthe last 2 years: Nigeria, Togo, Niger, and Burkina Faso. Nigeria has had\none human H5N1 case. Ivory Coast and Ghana are other West African states\nthat have had poultry outbreaks.\n\nBenin officials reported the 2 suspected outbreaks to the OIE on 5 Dec\n2007, saying 100 birds had died and 245 had been killed to stop the\noutbreak. Most of the birds were chickens, but 8 turkeys were among\naffected poultry on the Cotonou farm.\n\nAccording to the Reuters report, published today [17 Dec 2007], health\nexperts have expressed concern that Benin's Voodoo priests could be at risk\nfor avian flu because of their practice of tearing out the throats of live\nchickens in ritual sacrifices.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In its \"immediate notification\" to the OIE on 5 Dec 2007, Benin reported\nthe identification of 2 outbreaks caused by the highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza virus (see 20071206.3934). One outbreak involved a layer chicken\nflock into which there had been illegal introduction of poultry from Ghana.\nThe other (earlier) outbreak occurred in a small flock wandering in the\nvillage.\n\nThe diagnosis was performed by the national laboratory; the serotype of the\nvirus was, reportedly, \"pending\". ProMED-mail commented: \"It may be assumed\nthat the virus involved is similar to the one in neighbouring Ghana, namely\nH5N1; however, this should be verified and confirmed by a reference\nlaboratory.\" The current information provides the said anticipated piece of\ninformation. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (183): Benin, Poland, OIE, Saudi Arabia 20071206.3934\n\n....................arn/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. OIE)\nin Padua, Italy, according to a 15 Dec 2007 report by Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe farms are north of Porto Novo, the capital, and in Cotonou, the\ncommercial capital, both in Benin's southern coastal strip, AFP and Reuters\nreported.\n\nBenin is surrounded by countries that have faced poultry outbreaks within\nthe last 2 years: Nigeria, Togo, Niger, and Burkina Faso. Nigeria has had\none human H5N1 case. Ivory Coast and Ghana are other West African states\nthat have had poultry outbreaks.\n\nBenin officials reported the 2 suspected outbreaks to the OIE on 5 Dec\n2007, saying 100 birds had died and 245 had been killed to stop the\noutbreak. Most of the birds were chickens, but 8 turkeys were among\naffected poultry on the Cotonou farm.\n\nAccording to the Reuters report, published today [17 Dec 2007], health\nexperts have expressed concern that Benin's Voodoo priests could be at risk\nfor avian flu because of their practice of tearing out the throats of live\nchickens in ritual sacrifices.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In its \"immediate notification\" to the OIE on 5 Dec 2007, Benin reported\nthe identification of 2 outbreaks caused by the highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza virus (see 20071206.3934). One outbreak involved a layer chicken\nflock into which there had been illegal introduction of poultry from Ghana.\nThe other (earlier) outbreak occurred in a small flock wandering in the\nvillage.\n\nThe diagnosis was performed by the national laboratory; the serotype of the\nvirus was, reportedly, \"pending\". ProMED-mail commented: \"It may be assumed\nthat the virus involved is similar to the one in neighbouring Ghana, namely\nH5N1; however, this should be verified and confirmed by a reference\nlaboratory.\" The current information provides the said anticipated piece of\ninformation. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (183): Benin, Poland, OIE, Saudi Arabia 20071206.3934\n\n....................arn/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. OIE)\nin Padua, Italy, according to a 15 Dec 2007 report by Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe farms are north of Porto Novo, the capital, and in Cotonou, the\ncommercial capital, both in Benin's southern coastal strip, AFP and Reuters\nreported.\n\nBenin is surrounded by countries that have faced poultry outbreaks within\nthe last 2 years: Nigeria, Togo, Niger, and Burkina Faso. Nigeria has had\none human H5N1 case. Ivory Coast and Ghana are other West African states\nthat have had poultry outbreaks.\n\nBenin officials reported the 2 suspected outbreaks to the OIE on 5 Dec\n2007, saying 100 birds had died and 245 had been killed to stop the\noutbreak. ProMED-mail commented: \"It may be assumed\nthat the virus involved is similar to the one in neighbouring Ghana, namely\nH5N1; however, this should be verified and confirmed by a reference\nlaboratory.\" The current information provides the said anticipated piece of\ninformation. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (183): Benin, Poland, OIE, Saudi Arabia 20071206.3934\n\n....................arn/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-12-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "Poland"}, {"location": "Benin", "country": "Benin"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Padua", "country": "Italy"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "47420", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (08): Israel (H5N1), Portugal (LP H5N2), OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=47420", "date": "2007-12-20 16:00:19", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (191): BENIN, H5N1 CONFIRMED\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 17 Dec 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CIDRAP News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/dec1707benin.html>\n\n\nTests in Italy have confirmed the 1st poultry outbreaks of H5N1 avian\ninfluenza in the West African country of Benin, according to news services.\n\nAgriculture minister Robert Dovonou said that suspected cases found on 2\nfarms earlier this month [December 2007] were confirmed by the World\nOrganisation for Animal Health (Office International des Epizooties; OIE)\nin Padua, Italy, according to a 15 Dec 2007 report by Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe farms are north of Porto Novo, the capital, and in Cotonou, the\ncommercial capital, both in Benin's southern coastal strip, AFP and Reuters\nreported.\n\nBenin is surrounded by countries that have faced poultry outbreaks within\nthe last 2 years: Nigeria, Togo, Niger, and Burkina Faso. Nigeria has had\none human H5N1 case. Ivory Coast and Ghana are other West African states\nthat have had poultry outbreaks.\n\nBenin officials reported the 2 suspected outbreaks to the OIE on 5 Dec\n2007, saying 100 birds had died and 245 had been killed to stop the\noutbreak. Most of the birds were chickens, but 8 turkeys were among\naffected poultry on the Cotonou farm.\n\nAccording to the Reuters report, published today [17 Dec 2007], health\nexperts have expressed concern that Benin's Voodoo priests could be at risk\nfor avian flu because of their practice of tearing out the throats of live\nchickens in ritual sacrifices.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In its \"immediate notification\" to the OIE on 5 Dec 2007, Benin reported\nthe identification of 2 outbreaks caused by the highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza virus (see 20071206.3934). One outbreak involved a layer chicken\nflock into which there had been illegal introduction of poultry from Ghana.\nThe other (earlier) outbreak occurred in a small flock wandering in the\nvillage.\n\nThe diagnosis was performed by the national laboratory; the serotype of the\nvirus was, reportedly, \"pending\". ProMED-mail commented: \"It may be assumed\nthat the virus involved is similar to the one in neighbouring Ghana, namely\nH5N1; however, this should be verified and confirmed by a reference\nlaboratory.\" The current information provides the said anticipated piece of\ninformation. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (183): Benin, Poland, OIE, Saudi Arabia 20071206.3934\n\n....................arn/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. OIE)\nin Padua, Italy, according to a 15 Dec 2007 report by Agence France-Presse\n(AFP).\n\nThe farms are north of Porto Novo, the capital, and in Cotonou, the\ncommercial capital, both in Benin's southern coastal strip, AFP and Reuters\nreported.\n\nBenin is surrounded by countries that have faced poultry outbreaks within\nthe last 2 years: Nigeria, Togo, Niger, and Burkina Faso. Nigeria has had\none human H5N1 case. Ivory Coast and Ghana are other West African states\nthat have had poultry outbreaks.\n\nBenin officials reported the 2 suspected outbreaks to the OIE on 5 Dec\n2007, saying 100 birds had died and 245 had been killed to stop the\noutbreak. Most of the birds were chickens, but 8 turkeys were among\naffected poultry on the Cotonou farm.\n\nAccording to the Reuters report, published today [17 Dec 2007], health\nexperts have expressed concern that Benin's Voodoo priests could be at risk\nfor avian flu because of their practice of tearing out the throats of live\nchickens in ritual sacrifices.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In its \"immediate notification\" to the OIE on 5 Dec 2007, Benin reported\nthe identification of 2 outbreaks caused by the highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza virus (see 20071206.3934). One outbreak involved a layer chicken\nflock into which there had been illegal introduction of poultry from Ghana.\nThe other (earlier) outbreak occurred in a small flock wandering in the\nvillage.\n\nThe diagnosis was performed by the national laboratory; the serotype of the\nvirus was, reportedly, \"pending\". ProMED-mail commented: \"It may be assumed\nthat the virus involved is similar to the one in neighbouring Ghana, namely\nH5N1; however, this should be verified and confirmed by a reference\nlaboratory.\" The current information provides the said anticipated piece of\ninformation. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (183): Benin, Poland, OIE, Saudi Arabia 20071206.3934\n\n....................arn/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-12-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "Poland"}, {"location": "Benin", "country": "Benin"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "Ghana"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Padua", "country": "Italy"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "37048", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (170): UK (England), turkeys, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=37048", "date": "2006-08-30 00:00:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (188) - NETHERLANDS, H5N1: NOT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[ProMED-mail's posting \"Avian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI\n20060827.2439\", dated 27 Aug 2006, included the following request for\ninformation: \"The current news release mentions investigations in 2 birds.\nResults pertaining to tests (if carried out) of the other 2 allegedly\ninvolved birds and the postulated cause of death of all 4 if H5N1 is\nexcluded will be helpful in the final accomplishment of the investigation\nof this unusual event.\" We are glad to publish the following response,\nreceived on 30 Aug 2006. - Mod.AS]\nDate: Wed 30 Aug 2006\nFrom: Joost Philippa <j.philippa@erasmusmc.nl>\n\nResponse to \"Avian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI\"\n-----------------------------------------------\nWe hereby respond to the request for information in the recent post (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI) about suspected H5N1 virus\ninfection in northern hawk owls (_Surnia ulula_) from Rotterdam Zoo.\nIn total, 4 hawk owls were examined. As reported previously (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI), 2 of these birds (birds 2\nand 3), which died with neurological signs, were initially suspected of\ninfection with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of the subtype H5N1,\nbut no influenza virus could be isolated from their tissues. Tissues of the\n2 other birds (birds 1 and 4), which also showed neurological signs and\nwere euthanized, tested negative in PCRs for the influenza virus matrix\ngene and for subtype H5 of the hemagglutinin gene, and no further\nvirological tests were performed.\nBased on histopathology and bacteriology, bird 3 had a meningo-encephalitis\nand septicemia due to _Escherichia coli_ infection. Bird 2 had an\nencephalitis of unknown origin.\nThe cause of neurological disease in the remaining 3 birds is still open.\nThe tissues of birds 2 and 3 tested negative in PCRs for Newcastle disease\nvirus, paramyxovirus, and West Nile virus. Further tests are ongoing and\nwill be reported if a diagnosis is made.\nAn extensive epidemiological investigation was started in the zoo. In\nthroat and cloaca swabs of 72 birds that were looked after by the same\nanimal care takers as the PCR-positive owls all tested negative by PCR. In\naddition, sera of 50 non-vaccinated birds housed in the same cages tested\nnegative in the hemagglutination inhibition test against H5N1 antigen.\nJoost Philippa(1), Ron Fouchier(1), Francis Balk(2), Hans Kramps(2), Guus\nKoch(2), Thijs Kuiken(1), Ab Osterhaus(1). (1) Department of Virology\nEramus MC, Rotterdam (2) Central institute of animal disease control\n(CIDC-Lelystad), Wageningen UR.\n--\nJoost Philippa\nDepartment of Virology Eramus MC, Rotterdam\n<j.philippa@erasmusmc.nl>\n[This is a prompt response to our request, providing detailed, firsthand\ninformation. ProMED-mail is very grateful for this exemplary expression of\ntransparency and professionalism. We look forward to the results of the\nongoing tests. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI 20060827.2439\nAvian influenza (184) - Viet Nam, Netherlands 20060823.2379\nAvian influenza (181) - Netherlands, H5N1 suspected 20060814.2276\nAvian influenza (180) - Netherlands, H5N1 suspected 20060813.2271\n...................arn/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. As reported previously (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI), 2 of these birds (birds 2\nand 3), which died with neurological signs, were initially suspected of\ninfection with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of the subtype H5N1,\nbut no influenza virus could be isolated from their tissues. Bird 2 had an\nencephalitis of unknown origin.\nThe cause of neurological disease in the remaining 3 birds is still open.\nThe tissues of birds 2 and 3 tested negative in PCRs for Newcastle disease\nvirus, paramyxovirus, and West Nile virus. Further tests are ongoing and\nwill be reported if a diagnosis is made.\nAn extensive epidemiological investigation was started in the zoo. In\nthroat and cloaca swabs of 72 birds that were looked after by the same\nanimal care takers as the PCR-positive owls all tested negative by PCR. In\naddition, sera of 50 non-vaccinated birds housed in the same cages tested\nnegative in the hemagglutination inhibition test against H5N1 antigen.\nJoost Philippa(1), Ron Fouchier(1), Francis Balk(2), Hans Kramps(2), Guus\nKoch(2), Thijs Kuiken(1), Ab Osterhaus(1). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Newcastle", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6795", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (13): Japan H5N1, Viet Nam, Indonesia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6795", "date": "2006-08-30 00:00:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA (188) - NETHERLANDS, H5N1: NOT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[ProMED-mail's posting \"Avian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI\n20060827.2439\", dated 27 Aug 2006, included the following request for\ninformation: \"The current news release mentions investigations in 2 birds.\nResults pertaining to tests (if carried out) of the other 2 allegedly\ninvolved birds and the postulated cause of death of all 4 if H5N1 is\nexcluded will be helpful in the final accomplishment of the investigation\nof this unusual event.\" We are glad to publish the following response,\nreceived on 30 Aug 2006. - Mod.AS]\nDate: Wed 30 Aug 2006\nFrom: Joost Philippa <j.philippa@erasmusmc.nl>\n\nResponse to \"Avian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI\"\n-----------------------------------------------\nWe hereby respond to the request for information in the recent post (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI) about suspected H5N1 virus\ninfection in northern hawk owls (_Surnia ulula_) from Rotterdam Zoo.\nIn total, 4 hawk owls were examined. As reported previously (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI), 2 of these birds (birds 2\nand 3), which died with neurological signs, were initially suspected of\ninfection with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of the subtype H5N1,\nbut no influenza virus could be isolated from their tissues. Tissues of the\n2 other birds (birds 1 and 4), which also showed neurological signs and\nwere euthanized, tested negative in PCRs for the influenza virus matrix\ngene and for subtype H5 of the hemagglutinin gene, and no further\nvirological tests were performed.\nBased on histopathology and bacteriology, bird 3 had a meningo-encephalitis\nand septicemia due to _Escherichia coli_ infection. Bird 2 had an\nencephalitis of unknown origin.\nThe cause of neurological disease in the remaining 3 birds is still open.\nThe tissues of birds 2 and 3 tested negative in PCRs for Newcastle disease\nvirus, paramyxovirus, and West Nile virus. Further tests are ongoing and\nwill be reported if a diagnosis is made.\nAn extensive epidemiological investigation was started in the zoo. In\nthroat and cloaca swabs of 72 birds that were looked after by the same\nanimal care takers as the PCR-positive owls all tested negative by PCR. In\naddition, sera of 50 non-vaccinated birds housed in the same cages tested\nnegative in the hemagglutination inhibition test against H5N1 antigen.\nJoost Philippa(1), Ron Fouchier(1), Francis Balk(2), Hans Kramps(2), Guus\nKoch(2), Thijs Kuiken(1), Ab Osterhaus(1). (1) Department of Virology\nEramus MC, Rotterdam (2) Central institute of animal disease control\n(CIDC-Lelystad), Wageningen UR.\n--\nJoost Philippa\nDepartment of Virology Eramus MC, Rotterdam\n<j.philippa@erasmusmc.nl>\n[This is a prompt response to our request, providing detailed, firsthand\ninformation. ProMED-mail is very grateful for this exemplary expression of\ntransparency and professionalism. We look forward to the results of the\nongoing tests. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI 20060827.2439\nAvian influenza (184) - Viet Nam, Netherlands 20060823.2379\nAvian influenza (181) - Netherlands, H5N1 suspected 20060814.2276\nAvian influenza (180) - Netherlands, H5N1 suspected 20060813.2271\n...................arn/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. As reported previously (Avian\ninfluenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI), 2 of these birds (birds 2\nand 3), which died with neurological signs, were initially suspected of\ninfection with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of the subtype H5N1,\nbut no influenza virus could be isolated from their tissues. Tissues of the\n2 other birds (birds 1 and 4), which also showed neurological signs and\nwere euthanized, tested negative in PCRs for the influenza virus matrix\ngene and for subtype H5 of the hemagglutinin gene, and no further\nvirological tests were performed.\nBased on histopathology and bacteriology, bird 3 had a meningo-encephalitis\nand septicemia due to _Escherichia coli_ infection. Bird 2 had an\nencephalitis of unknown origin.\nThe cause of neurological disease in the remaining 3 birds is still open.\nThe tissues of birds 2 and 3 tested negative in PCRs for Newcastle disease\nvirus, paramyxovirus, and West Nile virus. Further tests are ongoing and\nwill be reported if a diagnosis is made.\nAn extensive epidemiological investigation was started in the zoo. In\nthroat and cloaca swabs of 72 birds that were looked after by the same\nanimal care takers as the PCR-positive owls all tested negative by PCR. In\naddition, sera of 50 non-vaccinated birds housed in the same cages tested\nnegative in the hemagglutination inhibition test against H5N1 antigen.\nJoost Philippa(1), Ron Fouchier(1), Francis Balk(2), Hans Kramps(2), Guus\nKoch(2), Thijs Kuiken(1), Ab Osterhaus(1). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Newcastle", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2431", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza (186) - Netherlands, H5N1: NOT, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2431", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
