Avian influenza (181) - Netherlands, H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2230", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "2036-03-16 00:00:00", "2035-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Hunan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Tibet Autonomous Region", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Anhui Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Xinjiang Autonomous Region", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2231", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (180) - Netherlands, H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2231", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Avian influenza (159) - Thailand, H5N1 confirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2022", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1918-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1918-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "2036-03-16 00:00:00", "2035-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Japan", "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Xinjiang Autonomous Region", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5346", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza virus (02): two clades of H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5346", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Avian influenza, cats: H5N1 systemic infection", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3489", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-12-16 00:00:00", "2003-12-16 00:00:00", "2004-01-12 00:00:00", "2004-01-23 00:00:00", 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1918-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1918-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2038-03-16 00:00:00", "2037-03-16 00:00:00", "2036-03-16 00:00:00", "2035-03-16 00:00:00", "2034-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": Avian influenza - Eurasia (61): wild ducks, Italy, LPAI H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2483", "date": "2005-10-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (41): WHO H5N1 TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
