TIMELINE\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nAntiviral Research\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/xrd85>\nDate: Sat, 29 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO EPR web-site, Avian influenza, accessed 29 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/avian_influenza/Timeline_28_10a.pdf>\n\n[The following chronological list, summarising the main events since the\nbeginning of the current H5N1 panzootic as well as relevant research, is\ncopied -- with some editorial modifications -- from the WHO influenza home\npage. Only the animal-health related column is presented here; however,\nresearch from the public-health column is included as well. - Mod.AS]\nH5N1 influenza time-line: 28 Oct 2005\n-------------------------------------\n1.1996 Highly pathogenic H5N1 virus is isolated from a farmed goose in\nGuangdong Province, China.\n2. 1997 Outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 are reported in poultry at\nfarms and wet markets in Hong Kong.\n3. Mid-2003: H5N1 virus begins to cause outbreaks in Asia, but these go\nundetected and unreported.\n4. Dec 2003: 2 tigers and 2 leopards, fed on fresh chicken carcasses, die\nunexpectedly at a zoo in Thailand. Subsequent investigation identifies H5N1\nin tissue samples. This is the 1st report of influenza causing disease and\ndeath in big cats.\n5. 19 Dec 2003: Republic of Korea confirms highly pathogenic H5N1 as cause\nof poultry deaths at 3 farms.\n6. 8 Jan 2004: Viet Nam reports H5N1 in poultry.\n7. 12 Jan 2004: Japan reports H5N1 in poultry.\n8. 23 Jan 2004: Thailand reports H5N1 in poultry.\n9. 24 Jan 2004: Cambodia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n10. 27 Jan 2004: Lao PDR reports H5N1 in poultry.\n11. 2 Feb 2004: Indonesia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n12. 4 Feb 2004: China reports H5N1 in poultry.\n13. 20 Feb 2004: Anecdotal evidences suggests H5N1 infection in a single\nhousehold of domestic cats in Thailand.\n14. 18 Mar 2004: Research (1) case studies of 10 patients in Viet Nam point\nto close contact with infected poultry as the probable source of infection\nin most cases, but conclude that, in 2 family clusters, limited\nhuman-to-human transmission within the family cannot be ruled out.\n15. Jun./Jul 2004: China, Indonesia, Thailand and Viet Nam report\nrecurrence of H5N1 in poultry.\n16. 8 Jul 2004: Research (2) identifies the dominant Z genotype in poultry,\nconsiders possible role of wild birds in spread, and concludes that H5N1\nhas found a new ecological niche in poultry, but is not yet fully adapted\nto this host.\n17. 13 Jul 2004: Research (3) shows that H5N1 has become progressively more\nlethal for mammals and can kill wild waterfowl, long considered a\ndisease-free natural reservoir. Japan announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n18. Jul 2004: Research (4).A case report is published indicating atypical\nhuman H5N1 infection in Thailand (from Mar 04), with fever and diarrhoea\nbut no respiratory symptoms. The report suggests that the clinical spectrum\nof disease may be broader than previously thought.\n19. 7 Aug 2004: Malaysia reports H5N1 in poultry.\n20. 20 Aug 2004: Research (5). Chinese researchers report preliminary\nfindings of H5N1 infection in pigs. No evidence suggests that pig\ninfections are widespread, and the finding appears to have limited\nepidemiological significance.\n21. 2 Sep 2004: Research (6) shows that domestic cats experimentally\ninfected with H5N1 develop severe disease and can spread infection to other\ncats. Prior to this research, domestic cats were considered resistant to\ndisease from all influenza A viruses.\n22. 21 Sep 2004: Republic of Korea announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is considered disease-free by OIE.\n23. 11 Oct 2004: Outbreak begins in zoo tigers in Thailand said to have\nbeen fed chicken carcasses. Altogether, 147 tigers out of a population of\n441 die or are euthanized.\n24. 22 Oct 2004: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in 2 eagles illegally\nimported into Europe (Brussels) from Thailand.\n25. 29 Oct 2004: Research (7) confirms that domestic ducks can act as\nsilent reservoirs,\nexcreting large quantities of highly pathogenic virus yet showing few if\nany signs of illness.\n26. December 2004: Poultry outbreaks ongoing in Indonesia, Thailand, and\nVietnam and possibly also in Cambodia and Lao PDR.\n27. 3 Jan 2005: Malaysia (Peninsular) announces control of the H5N1 poultry\noutbreak and is now considered disease-free by OIE.\n28. 27 Jan 2005: Research (8) concludes that a girl in Thailand probably\npassed the virus to at least her mother in September 2004, causing fatal\ndisease. This is the 1st published account of probable secondary human\ntransmission, resulting in severe disease, of any avian influenza virus.\n29. 17 Feb 2005: Research (9) retrospectively identifies at least one fatal\natypical case in\nViet Nam (from February 2004), presenting with diarrhoea and encephalitis,\nbut normal chest X-rays.\n30. 30 April 2005: Wild birds begin dying at Qinghai Lake in central China,\nwhere hundreds of thousands of migratory birds congregate. Altogether, 6345\nbirds from different species die in the coming weeks.\n31. 8 June 2005: China reports poultry outbreak in Xinjiang Autonomous Region.\n32. 6 Jul 2005: Research (10) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake suggests the outbreak was caused by a new H5N1 variant that\nmay be more lethal to wild birds and experimentally infected mice.\n33. 14 Jul 2005: Research (11) on viruses isolated from dead birds in\nQinghai Lake demonstrates transmission of the virus among migratory geese\nand suggests that the virus may be carried along winter migratory routes.\n34. 15 Jul 2005: Tests on 3 civets that died in late June in Viet Nam\ndetect H5N1, marking the 1st infection of this species with the virus. The\nendangered Owston's palm civets were raised in captivity; source of\ninfection is unknown.\n35. 23 Jul 2005: Russia reports outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in western Siberia.\nThe outbreak spreads to affect 6 administrative regions in Siberia. Dead\nmigratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n36. 2 Aug 2005: Kazakhstan reports an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian\ninfluenza, subsequently confirmed as H5N1, in poultry in areas adjacent to\nSiberia. Dead migratory birds are reported in the vicinity of outbreaks.\n37. 10 Aug 2005: China reports outbreak in Tibet Autonomous Region.\n38. 12 Aug 2005: Mongolia reports the death of 89 migratory birds at 2\nlakes. H5N1 is subsequently identified in these birds.\n39. 29 Sep 2005: Research (12) describes the clinical features of H5N1\ninfection in humans and reviews recommendations for the management of cases.\n40. October 2005: Research (13) on the evolution of human and animal\nviruses circulating in Asia in 2005 suggests that several amino acids\nlocated near the receptor-binding site are undergoing change, some of which\nmay affect antigenicity or transmissibility.\n41. 6 Oct 2005: Research (14, 15) describes reconstruction of the lethal\n1918 pandemic virus, concludes that this virus was entirely avian, and\nfinds some similarities with H5N1.\n42. 13 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Turkey.\n43. 15 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in poultry in Romania.\n44. 20 Oct 05: Taiwan, China, reports the detection of highly pathogenic\nH5N1 in a cargo of exotic songbirds smuggled from mainland China. Thailand\nreports its 1st new case since 8 Oct 2004.\n45. 23 Oct 2005: Highly pathogenic H5N1 is confirmed in an imported parrot,\nheld in quarantine in the UK, that died 3 days earlier.\n46. 24 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Anhui Province. Thailand and\nIndonesia report more cases.\n47. 26 Oct 2005: China reports outbreak in Hunan, making this the 6th\nprovince reporting outbreaks during 2005. Croatia confirms H5N1 in wild birds.\nReferences\n----------\n1 Hien TT et al. Avian influenza A (H5N1) in 10 patients in Vietnam. N Engl\nJ Med 2004; 350:1179-88.\n2 Li KS et al. Genesis of a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic\ninfluenza virus in eastern Asia. Nature 2004; 430: 209-213.\n3 Chen H et al. The evolution of H5N1 influenza viruses in ducks in\nsouthern China. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 2004; 101: 10452-57.\n4 Apisarnthanarak A et al. Atypical avian influenza (H5N1). Emerg Infect\nDis 2004; 10: 1321-24.\n5 Verbal report at WHO international consultation.\n6 Kuiken T et al. Avian H5N1 influenza in cats. Published online by Science:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1102287>\n7 Issued (prior to publication) on WHO website: Avian influenza - situation\nin Asia: altered role of domestic ducks, 29 Oct 2004; available online at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_10_29/en/index.html>\n8 Ungchusak K et al. Probable person-to-person transmission of avian\ninfluenza A (H5N1). N Engl J Med 2005; 352:4 333-40.\n9 De Jong M et al. Fatal avian influenza A (H5N1) in a child presenting\nwith diarrhea followed by coma. N Engl J Med 2005; 352:7 686-91.\n10 Liu J et al. Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus infection in\nmigratory birds. Science 2005. Published by Science online at:\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/contents/abstract/1115273>.\n11 Chen H et al. H5N1 virus outbreak in migratory waterfowl. Nature 2005;\n436: 191-92.\n12 Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on\nHuman Influenza A/H5. N Engl J Med 2005; 353:13 54-65.\n13 World Health Organization Global Influenza Program Surveillance Network.\nEmerg Infect Dis 2005; 11: 1515-21.\n14 Taubenberger JK et al. Characterization of the 1918 influenza virus\npolymerase genes. Nature 2005; 437: 889-93.\n15 Tumpey et al. Characterization of the reconstructed 1918 Spanish\ninfluenza pandemic virus. Science 2005; 310: 77-80.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (38): Iraq, suspected, RFI 20051029.3149\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (37): OIE, multicountry 20051028.3148\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (36): Europe, China 20051028.3147\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (35): Europe, EU update 20051027.3134\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (34): Sweden, mallard, H5N3 20051027.3128\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (33) : Indonesia, UK, EU 20051026.3122\n...............arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Avian influenza - Eurasia (23): Croatia, H5N1, swan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1512", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\nBut encouraging news came from China, where state media said\na new, improved vaccine for birds had been developed, a\nlow-cost spray that could protect them from the H5N1 strain\nof avian flu.\nThe spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\nIn Turkey, the state Anatolian news agency reported that\nnearly 1000 chickens had died in the east, near the Iranian\nborder, after being transported from the west of the\ncountry. It said samples had been sent for tests for\npossible bird flu, but did not say where exactly the birds\nhad been moved from. [Updated information on this event\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.AS]. Turkish officials also said\nthe incubation period for the avian flu found on a farm in\nthe north west was over, and the danger to humans had\npassed.\nThe EU Commission in Brussels confirmed that the H5N1 strain\nfound in Romanian ducks was exactly the same as that\ndetected in Turkish birds. \"The link has now been\nconfirmed,\" Health and Consumer Protection Commissioner\nMarkos Kyprianou said in a statement. Kyprianou said the\nEuropean Union had already banned poultry and live bird\nimports from Romania, so no further measures were needed. EU\nveterinary experts will meet on Thu 20 Oct 2005 to review\nthe situation, he added.\nIn Romania, pharmacies ran out of regular flu vaccine and\nlocal media reported that worried citizens had bought up to\n2 million doses of the vaccine in the past few days.\nFlu vaccine protects people only against the latest strain\nof regular flu. Only if H5N1 mutates into a form that passes\neasily between humans will pharmaceutical firms be able to\ndevelop a vaccine specifically against that strain.\nIn Romania's south east Danube delta area, 6 counties were\ncordoned off. Television footage showed masked and gloved\nveterinarians gassing poultry and disinfecting farms in the\ndelta village of Ceamurlia de Jos, part of a cull of more\nthan 60 000 birds aimed at stopping the virus from\nspreading. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter.\nPoland, responding to European Commission calls, said all\npoultry must be kept indoors from Monday [17 Oct 2005] to\nkeep it away from migratory wild birds. \"The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,\" Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n[byline: Martin Dokoupil]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Haaretz, 16 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArtVty.jhtml?sw=avian&itemNo=635329>\n\nAgriculture ministry buys 8 million doses of avian flu\nvaccine\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Agriculture Ministry has purchased 8 million doses of\nvaccine for the 2 violent strains of avian flu, H-7 and H-5,\nit was reported on Sunday [16 Oct 2005]. The ministry has\nalso purchased a protective kit prepared for ministry\nemployees who could have contact with infected birds. The\nvaccine and the kit come from the Netherlands, Israel Radio\nreported.\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\nSpeaking at a meeting of Health Ministry officials, Naveh\nsaid he will tell the government how the ministry is\npreparing for a possible outbreak of the pandemic in Israel.\nThe preparations were being made in the wake of fears that\nthe strain of bird flu currently circulating in the world\nhas mutated into a strain that is dangerous for humans, in\nwhich case it could be immune to known drugs.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has also opened a 24-hour,\n7-day-a-week hotline to report birds suspected of being\ninfected with avian flu. The public is asked to call\n03-968-1609 to report the location of straying birds that\nappear to be sick or bird carcasses.\nThe ministry announced it has been testing migratory birds\nand poultry in collaboration with the Israel Nature and\nParks Authority to locate infections and examine bird\ncarcasses. So far, all tests have been negative.\nThe director general of the Health Ministry, Professor Avi\nYisraeli, told Haaretz over the weekend that the main thing\nIsrael has to do now is to have Agriculture Ministry\nofficials watch out for possible cases of avian flu among\nmigratory birds and domesticated birds in agricultural\ncommunities.\nYisraeli also recommended that residents of Israel go to\ntheir health clinics to get the regular flu shot\nadministered around this time every year to babies, the\nelderly and health care workers.\nOfficials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu.\nFears for an outbreak of the pandemic in Israel emerged\nafter the World Organization for Animal Health released\nfindings indicating flocks of migratory birds nesting in\nChina were responsible for the outbreak outside South East\nAsia. Israel faces this risk since it is located on one of\nthe major seasonal migratory routes of birds.\n[byline: Ran Reznik, Amiram Cohen and Assaf Oni]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The concern of the Israeli authorities is understandable in\nview of Israel's geographical situation as a crossway of\nmigratory birds on their route from Asia and Europe to\nAfrica. The number of birds annually migrating through\nIsrael in each direction is estimated to be around 500\nmillion; see map\nat<http://www.eilat-guide.com/images/maps/bird_map.gif>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (12): Romania, H5N1 20051016.3016\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (11): Romania, H5N1 20051015.3009\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (10): Turkey, OIE 20051015.3008\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (09): Romania, OIE 20051015.3007\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (08): Russia, OIE 20051015.3004\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (07): OIE 20051014.2995\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (06): H5N1 20051014.2994\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (05): Turkey, H5N1 20051013.2989\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (04): Romania, conf 20051013.2988\nAvian influenza - Europe (09): EU, preventive measures\n20050922.2802\nAvian influenza - Europe (05): EU, preventive measures\n20050825.2511\nAvian influenza - Europe (04): EU, preventive measures\n20050824.2498\n...................arn/msp/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Poland", "country": "Poland"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1511", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, Eurasia (22): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1511", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\nBut encouraging news came from China, where state media said\na new, improved vaccine for birds had been developed, a\nlow-cost spray that could protect them from the H5N1 strain\nof avian flu.\nThe spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\nIn Turkey, the state Anatolian news agency reported that\nnearly 1000 chickens had died in the east, near the Iranian\nborder, after being transported from the west of the\ncountry. It said samples had been sent for tests for\npossible bird flu, but did not say where exactly the birds\nhad been moved from. [Updated information on this event\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.AS]. Turkish officials also said\nthe incubation period for the avian flu found on a farm in\nthe north west was over, and the danger to humans had\npassed.\nThe EU Commission in Brussels confirmed that the H5N1 strain\nfound in Romanian ducks was exactly the same as that\ndetected in Turkish birds. \"The link has now been\nconfirmed,\" Health and Consumer Protection Commissioner\nMarkos Kyprianou said in a statement. Kyprianou said the\nEuropean Union had already banned poultry and live bird\nimports from Romania, so no further measures were needed. EU\nveterinary experts will meet on Thu 20 Oct 2005 to review\nthe situation, he added.\nIn Romania, pharmacies ran out of regular flu vaccine and\nlocal media reported that worried citizens had bought up to\n2 million doses of the vaccine in the past few days.\nFlu vaccine protects people only against the latest strain\nof regular flu. Only if H5N1 mutates into a form that passes\neasily between humans will pharmaceutical firms be able to\ndevelop a vaccine specifically against that strain.\nIn Romania's south east Danube delta area, 6 counties were\ncordoned off. Television footage showed masked and gloved\nveterinarians gassing poultry and disinfecting farms in the\ndelta village of Ceamurlia de Jos, part of a cull of more\nthan 60 000 birds aimed at stopping the virus from\nspreading. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter.\nPoland, responding to European Commission calls, said all\npoultry must be kept indoors from Monday [17 Oct 2005] to\nkeep it away from migratory wild birds. \"The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,\" Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n[byline: Martin Dokoupil]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Haaretz, 16 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArtVty.jhtml?sw=avian&itemNo=635329>\n\nAgriculture ministry buys 8 million doses of avian flu\nvaccine\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Agriculture Ministry has purchased 8 million doses of\nvaccine for the 2 violent strains of avian flu, H-7 and H-5,\nit was reported on Sunday [16 Oct 2005]. The ministry has\nalso purchased a protective kit prepared for ministry\nemployees who could have contact with infected birds. The\nvaccine and the kit come from the Netherlands, Israel Radio\nreported.\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\nSpeaking at a meeting of Health Ministry officials, Naveh\nsaid he will tell the government how the ministry is\npreparing for a possible outbreak of the pandemic in Israel.\nThe preparations were being made in the wake of fears that\nthe strain of bird flu currently circulating in the world\nhas mutated into a strain that is dangerous for humans, in\nwhich case it could be immune to known drugs.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has also opened a 24-hour,\n7-day-a-week hotline to report birds suspected of being\ninfected with avian flu. The public is asked to call\n03-968-1609 to report the location of straying birds that\nappear to be sick or bird carcasses.\nThe ministry announced it has been testing migratory birds\nand poultry in collaboration with the Israel Nature and\nParks Authority to locate infections and examine bird\ncarcasses. So far, all tests have been negative.\nThe director general of the Health Ministry, Professor Avi\nYisraeli, told Haaretz over the weekend that the main thing\nIsrael has to do now is to have Agriculture Ministry\nofficials watch out for possible cases of avian flu among\nmigratory birds and domesticated birds in agricultural\ncommunities.\nYisraeli also recommended that residents of Israel go to\ntheir health clinics to get the regular flu shot\nadministered around this time every year to babies, the\nelderly and health care workers.\nOfficials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu.\nFears for an outbreak of the pandemic in Israel emerged\nafter the World Organization for Animal Health released\nfindings indicating flocks of migratory birds nesting in\nChina were responsible for the outbreak outside South East\nAsia. Israel faces this risk since it is located on one of\nthe major seasonal migratory routes of birds.\n[byline: Ran Reznik, Amiram Cohen and Assaf Oni]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The concern of the Israeli authorities is understandable in\nview of Israel's geographical situation as a crossway of\nmigratory birds on their route from Asia and Europe to\nAfrica. The number of birds annually migrating through\nIsrael in each direction is estimated to be around 500\nmillion; see map\nat<http://www.eilat-guide.com/images/maps/bird_map.gif>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (12): Romania, H5N1 20051016.3016\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (11): Romania, H5N1 20051015.3009\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (10): Turkey, OIE 20051015.3008\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (09): Romania, OIE 20051015.3007\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (08): Russia, OIE 20051015.3004\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (07): OIE 20051014.2995\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (06): H5N1 20051014.2994\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (05): Turkey, H5N1 20051013.2989\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (04): Romania, conf 20051013.2988\nAvian influenza - Europe (09): EU, preventive measures\n20050922.2802\nAvian influenza - Europe (05): EU, preventive measures\n20050825.2511\nAvian influenza - Europe (04): EU, preventive measures\n20050824.2498\n...................arn/msp/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Poland", "country": "Poland"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2154", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (17): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2154", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\nBut encouraging news came from China, where state media said\na new, improved vaccine for birds had been developed, a\nlow-cost spray that could protect them from the H5N1 strain\nof avian flu.\nThe spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\nIn Turkey, the state Anatolian news agency reported that\nnearly 1000 chickens had died in the east, near the Iranian\nborder, after being transported from the west of the\ncountry. It said samples had been sent for tests for\npossible bird flu, but did not say where exactly the birds\nhad been moved from. [Updated information on this event\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.AS]. Turkish officials also said\nthe incubation period for the avian flu found on a farm in\nthe north west was over, and the danger to humans had\npassed.\nThe EU Commission in Brussels confirmed that the H5N1 strain\nfound in Romanian ducks was exactly the same as that\ndetected in Turkish birds. \"The link has now been\nconfirmed,\" Health and Consumer Protection Commissioner\nMarkos Kyprianou said in a statement. Kyprianou said the\nEuropean Union had already banned poultry and live bird\nimports from Romania, so no further measures were needed. EU\nveterinary experts will meet on Thu 20 Oct 2005 to review\nthe situation, he added.\nIn Romania, pharmacies ran out of regular flu vaccine and\nlocal media reported that worried citizens had bought up to\n2 million doses of the vaccine in the past few days.\nFlu vaccine protects people only against the latest strain\nof regular flu. Only if H5N1 mutates into a form that passes\neasily between humans will pharmaceutical firms be able to\ndevelop a vaccine specifically against that strain.\nIn Romania's south east Danube delta area, 6 counties were\ncordoned off. Television footage showed masked and gloved\nveterinarians gassing poultry and disinfecting farms in the\ndelta village of Ceamurlia de Jos, part of a cull of more\nthan 60 000 birds aimed at stopping the virus from\nspreading. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter.\nPoland, responding to European Commission calls, said all\npoultry must be kept indoors from Monday [17 Oct 2005] to\nkeep it away from migratory wild birds. \"The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,\" Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n[byline: Martin Dokoupil]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Haaretz, 16 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArtVty.jhtml?sw=avian&itemNo=635329>\n\nAgriculture ministry buys 8 million doses of avian flu\nvaccine\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Agriculture Ministry has purchased 8 million doses of\nvaccine for the 2 violent strains of avian flu, H-7 and H-5,\nit was reported on Sunday [16 Oct 2005]. The ministry has\nalso purchased a protective kit prepared for ministry\nemployees who could have contact with infected birds. The\nvaccine and the kit come from the Netherlands, Israel Radio\nreported.\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\nSpeaking at a meeting of Health Ministry officials, Naveh\nsaid he will tell the government how the ministry is\npreparing for a possible outbreak of the pandemic in Israel.\nThe preparations were being made in the wake of fears that\nthe strain of bird flu currently circulating in the world\nhas mutated into a strain that is dangerous for humans, in\nwhich case it could be immune to known drugs.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has also opened a 24-hour,\n7-day-a-week hotline to report birds suspected of being\ninfected with avian flu. The public is asked to call\n03-968-1609 to report the location of straying birds that\nappear to be sick or bird carcasses.\nThe ministry announced it has been testing migratory birds\nand poultry in collaboration with the Israel Nature and\nParks Authority to locate infections and examine bird\ncarcasses. So far, all tests have been negative.\nThe director general of the Health Ministry, Professor Avi\nYisraeli, told Haaretz over the weekend that the main thing\nIsrael has to do now is to have Agriculture Ministry\nofficials watch out for possible cases of avian flu among\nmigratory birds and domesticated birds in agricultural\ncommunities.\nYisraeli also recommended that residents of Israel go to\ntheir health clinics to get the regular flu shot\nadministered around this time every year to babies, the\nelderly and health care workers.\nOfficials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu.\nFears for an outbreak of the pandemic in Israel emerged\nafter the World Organization for Animal Health released\nfindings indicating flocks of migratory birds nesting in\nChina were responsible for the outbreak outside South East\nAsia. Israel faces this risk since it is located on one of\nthe major seasonal migratory routes of birds.\n[byline: Ran Reznik, Amiram Cohen and Assaf Oni]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The concern of the Israeli authorities is understandable in\nview of Israel's geographical situation as a crossway of\nmigratory birds on their route from Asia and Europe to\nAfrica. The number of birds annually migrating through\nIsrael in each direction is estimated to be around 500\nmillion; see map\nat<http://www.eilat-guide.com/images/maps/bird_map.gif>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (12): Romania, H5N1 20051016.3016\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (11): Romania, H5N1 20051015.3009\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (10): Turkey, OIE 20051015.3008\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (09): Romania, OIE 20051015.3007\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (08): Russia, OIE 20051015.3004\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (07): OIE 20051014.2995\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (06): H5N1 20051014.2994\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (05): Turkey, H5N1 20051013.2989\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (04): Romania, conf 20051013.2988\nAvian influenza - Europe (09): EU, preventive measures\n20050922.2802\nAvian influenza - Europe (05): EU, preventive measures\n20050825.2511\nAvian influenza - Europe (04): EU, preventive measures\n20050824.2498\n...................arn/msp/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Eurasia (15): Romania, H5N1 conf., OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1494", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\nBut encouraging news came from China, where state media said\na new, improved vaccine for birds had been developed, a\nlow-cost spray that could protect them from the H5N1 strain\nof avian flu.\nThe spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\nIn Turkey, the state Anatolian news agency reported that\nnearly 1000 chickens had died in the east, near the Iranian\nborder, after being transported from the west of the\ncountry. It said samples had been sent for tests for\npossible bird flu, but did not say where exactly the birds\nhad been moved from. [Updated information on this event\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.AS]. Turkish officials also said\nthe incubation period for the avian flu found on a farm in\nthe north west was over, and the danger to humans had\npassed.\nThe EU Commission in Brussels confirmed that the H5N1 strain\nfound in Romanian ducks was exactly the same as that\ndetected in Turkish birds. \"The link has now been\nconfirmed,\" Health and Consumer Protection Commissioner\nMarkos Kyprianou said in a statement. Kyprianou said the\nEuropean Union had already banned poultry and live bird\nimports from Romania, so no further measures were needed. EU\nveterinary experts will meet on Thu 20 Oct 2005 to review\nthe situation, he added.\nIn Romania, pharmacies ran out of regular flu vaccine and\nlocal media reported that worried citizens had bought up to\n2 million doses of the vaccine in the past few days.\nFlu vaccine protects people only against the latest strain\nof regular flu. Only if H5N1 mutates into a form that passes\neasily between humans will pharmaceutical firms be able to\ndevelop a vaccine specifically against that strain.\nIn Romania's south east Danube delta area, 6 counties were\ncordoned off. Television footage showed masked and gloved\nveterinarians gassing poultry and disinfecting farms in the\ndelta village of Ceamurlia de Jos, part of a cull of more\nthan 60 000 birds aimed at stopping the virus from\nspreading. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter.\nPoland, responding to European Commission calls, said all\npoultry must be kept indoors from Monday [17 Oct 2005] to\nkeep it away from migratory wild birds. \"The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,\" Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n[byline: Martin Dokoupil]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Haaretz, 16 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArtVty.jhtml?sw=avian&itemNo=635329>\n\nAgriculture ministry buys 8 million doses of avian flu\nvaccine\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Agriculture Ministry has purchased 8 million doses of\nvaccine for the 2 violent strains of avian flu, H-7 and H-5,\nit was reported on Sunday [16 Oct 2005]. The ministry has\nalso purchased a protective kit prepared for ministry\nemployees who could have contact with infected birds. The\nvaccine and the kit come from the Netherlands, Israel Radio\nreported.\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\nSpeaking at a meeting of Health Ministry officials, Naveh\nsaid he will tell the government how the ministry is\npreparing for a possible outbreak of the pandemic in Israel.\nThe preparations were being made in the wake of fears that\nthe strain of bird flu currently circulating in the world\nhas mutated into a strain that is dangerous for humans, in\nwhich case it could be immune to known drugs.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has also opened a 24-hour,\n7-day-a-week hotline to report birds suspected of being\ninfected with avian flu. The public is asked to call\n03-968-1609 to report the location of straying birds that\nappear to be sick or bird carcasses.\nThe ministry announced it has been testing migratory birds\nand poultry in collaboration with the Israel Nature and\nParks Authority to locate infections and examine bird\ncarcasses. So far, all tests have been negative.\nThe director general of the Health Ministry, Professor Avi\nYisraeli, told Haaretz over the weekend that the main thing\nIsrael has to do now is to have Agriculture Ministry\nofficials watch out for possible cases of avian flu among\nmigratory birds and domesticated birds in agricultural\ncommunities.\nYisraeli also recommended that residents of Israel go to\ntheir health clinics to get the regular flu shot\nadministered around this time every year to babies, the\nelderly and health care workers.\nOfficials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu.\nFears for an outbreak of the pandemic in Israel emerged\nafter the World Organization for Animal Health released\nfindings indicating flocks of migratory birds nesting in\nChina were responsible for the outbreak outside South East\nAsia. Israel faces this risk since it is located on one of\nthe major seasonal migratory routes of birds.\n[byline: Ran Reznik, Amiram Cohen and Assaf Oni]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The concern of the Israeli authorities is understandable in\nview of Israel's geographical situation as a crossway of\nmigratory birds on their route from Asia and Europe to\nAfrica. The number of birds annually migrating through\nIsrael in each direction is estimated to be around 500\nmillion; see map\nat<http://www.eilat-guide.com/images/maps/bird_map.gif>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (12): Romania, H5N1 20051016.3016\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (11): Romania, H5N1 20051015.3009\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (10): Turkey, OIE 20051015.3008\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (09): Romania, OIE 20051015.3007\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (08): Russia, OIE 20051015.3004\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (07): OIE 20051014.2995\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (06): H5N1 20051014.2994\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (05): Turkey, H5N1 20051013.2989\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (04): Romania, conf 20051013.2988\nAvian influenza - Europe (09): EU, preventive measures\n20050922.2802\nAvian influenza - Europe (05): EU, preventive measures\n20050825.2511\nAvian influenza - Europe (04): EU, preventive measures\n20050824.2498\n...................arn/msp/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Poland", "country": "Poland"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1968", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Eurasia (15): Romania, H5N1 conf., OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1968", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\nBut encouraging news came from China, where state media said\na new, improved vaccine for birds had been developed, a\nlow-cost spray that could protect them from the H5N1 strain\nof avian flu.\nThe spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\nIn Turkey, the state Anatolian news agency reported that\nnearly 1000 chickens had died in the east, near the Iranian\nborder, after being transported from the west of the\ncountry. It said samples had been sent for tests for\npossible bird flu, but did not say where exactly the birds\nhad been moved from. [Updated information on this event\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.AS]. Turkish officials also said\nthe incubation period for the avian flu found on a farm in\nthe north west was over, and the danger to humans had\npassed.\nThe EU Commission in Brussels confirmed that the H5N1 strain\nfound in Romanian ducks was exactly the same as that\ndetected in Turkish birds. \"The link has now been\nconfirmed,\" Health and Consumer Protection Commissioner\nMarkos Kyprianou said in a statement. Kyprianou said the\nEuropean Union had already banned poultry and live bird\nimports from Romania, so no further measures were needed. EU\nveterinary experts will meet on Thu 20 Oct 2005 to review\nthe situation, he added.\nIn Romania, pharmacies ran out of regular flu vaccine and\nlocal media reported that worried citizens had bought up to\n2 million doses of the vaccine in the past few days.\nFlu vaccine protects people only against the latest strain\nof regular flu. Only if H5N1 mutates into a form that passes\neasily between humans will pharmaceutical firms be able to\ndevelop a vaccine specifically against that strain.\nIn Romania's south east Danube delta area, 6 counties were\ncordoned off. Television footage showed masked and gloved\nveterinarians gassing poultry and disinfecting farms in the\ndelta village of Ceamurlia de Jos, part of a cull of more\nthan 60 000 birds aimed at stopping the virus from\nspreading. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter.\nPoland, responding to European Commission calls, said all\npoultry must be kept indoors from Monday [17 Oct 2005] to\nkeep it away from migratory wild birds. \"The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,\" Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n[byline: Martin Dokoupil]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Haaretz, 16 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArtVty.jhtml?sw=avian&itemNo=635329>\n\nAgriculture ministry buys 8 million doses of avian flu\nvaccine\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Agriculture Ministry has purchased 8 million doses of\nvaccine for the 2 violent strains of avian flu, H-7 and H-5,\nit was reported on Sunday [16 Oct 2005]. The ministry has\nalso purchased a protective kit prepared for ministry\nemployees who could have contact with infected birds. The\nvaccine and the kit come from the Netherlands, Israel Radio\nreported.\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\nSpeaking at a meeting of Health Ministry officials, Naveh\nsaid he will tell the government how the ministry is\npreparing for a possible outbreak of the pandemic in Israel.\nThe preparations were being made in the wake of fears that\nthe strain of bird flu currently circulating in the world\nhas mutated into a strain that is dangerous for humans, in\nwhich case it could be immune to known drugs.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has also opened a 24-hour,\n7-day-a-week hotline to report birds suspected of being\ninfected with avian flu. The public is asked to call\n03-968-1609 to report the location of straying birds that\nappear to be sick or bird carcasses.\nThe ministry announced it has been testing migratory birds\nand poultry in collaboration with the Israel Nature and\nParks Authority to locate infections and examine bird\ncarcasses. So far, all tests have been negative.\nThe director general of the Health Ministry, Professor Avi\nYisraeli, told Haaretz over the weekend that the main thing\nIsrael has to do now is to have Agriculture Ministry\nofficials watch out for possible cases of avian flu among\nmigratory birds and domesticated birds in agricultural\ncommunities.\nYisraeli also recommended that residents of Israel go to\ntheir health clinics to get the regular flu shot\nadministered around this time every year to babies, the\nelderly and health care workers.\nOfficials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu.\nFears for an outbreak of the pandemic in Israel emerged\nafter the World Organization for Animal Health released\nfindings indicating flocks of migratory birds nesting in\nChina were responsible for the outbreak outside South East\nAsia. Israel faces this risk since it is located on one of\nthe major seasonal migratory routes of birds.\n[byline: Ran Reznik, Amiram Cohen and Assaf Oni]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The concern of the Israeli authorities is understandable in\nview of Israel's geographical situation as a crossway of\nmigratory birds on their route from Asia and Europe to\nAfrica. The number of birds annually migrating through\nIsrael in each direction is estimated to be around 500\nmillion; see map\nat<http://www.eilat-guide.com/images/maps/bird_map.gif>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (12): Romania, H5N1 20051016.3016\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (11): Romania, H5N1 20051015.3009\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (10): Turkey, OIE 20051015.3008\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (09): Romania, OIE 20051015.3007\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (08): Russia, OIE 20051015.3004\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (07): OIE 20051014.2995\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (06): H5N1 20051014.2994\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (05): Turkey, H5N1 20051013.2989\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (04): Romania, conf 20051013.2988\nAvian influenza - Europe (09): EU, preventive measures\n20050922.2802\nAvian influenza - Europe (05): EU, preventive measures\n20050825.2511\nAvian influenza - Europe (04): EU, preventive measures\n20050824.2498\n...................arn/msp/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Eurasia (13): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1631", "date": "2005-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - EURASIA (13): H5N1\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnet, 15 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L15489494.htm>\n\nThe World Health Organization's top influenza expert,\nechoing previous warnings, said the virus could mutate into\na form that could kill thousands or millions of people\naround the world and urged governments to prepare for such a\npandemic.\nBut encouraging news came from China, where state media said\na new, improved vaccine for birds had been developed, a\nlow-cost spray that could protect them from the H5N1 strain\nof avian flu.\nThe spread of the virus in Asia has been blamed on backyard\nfarms and open-air markets where humans and birds mingle in\noften unsanitary conditions, and authorities have been\nunable to wipe it out despite large-scale culling and\nvaccination.\nIn Turkey, the state Anatolian news agency reported that\nnearly 1000 chickens had died in the east, near the Iranian\nborder, after being transported from the west of the\ncountry. It said samples had been sent for tests for\npossible bird flu, but did not say where exactly the birds\nhad been moved from. [Updated information on this event\nwould be appreciated. - Mod.AS]. Turkish officials also said\nthe incubation period for the avian flu found on a farm in\nthe north west was over, and the danger to humans had\npassed.\nThe EU Commission in Brussels confirmed that the H5N1 strain\nfound in Romanian ducks was exactly the same as that\ndetected in Turkish birds. \"The link has now been\nconfirmed,\" Health and Consumer Protection Commissioner\nMarkos Kyprianou said in a statement. Kyprianou said the\nEuropean Union had already banned poultry and live bird\nimports from Romania, so no further measures were needed. EU\nveterinary experts will meet on Thu 20 Oct 2005 to review\nthe situation, he added.\nIn Romania, pharmacies ran out of regular flu vaccine and\nlocal media reported that worried citizens had bought up to\n2 million doses of the vaccine in the past few days.\nFlu vaccine protects people only against the latest strain\nof regular flu. Only if H5N1 mutates into a form that passes\neasily between humans will pharmaceutical firms be able to\ndevelop a vaccine specifically against that strain.\nIn Romania's south east Danube delta area, 6 counties were\ncordoned off. Television footage showed masked and gloved\nveterinarians gassing poultry and disinfecting farms in the\ndelta village of Ceamurlia de Jos, part of a cull of more\nthan 60 000 birds aimed at stopping the virus from\nspreading. The Danube delta contains Europe's largest\nwetlands and is a major resting place for migratory wild\nbirds -- the carriers of the virus -- coming from Russia,\nScandinavia, Poland and Germany and heading for North Africa\nfor winter.\nPoland, responding to European Commission calls, said all\npoultry must be kept indoors from Monday [17 Oct 2005] to\nkeep it away from migratory wild birds. \"The situation means\nquite a large danger for poultry in Poland, so I decided to\nimpose some restrictions ... including a ban on keeping\npoultry in open spaces,\" Farm Minister Jerzy Pilarczyk told\na news conference.\n[byline: Martin Dokoupil]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Haaretz, 16 Oct 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArtVty.jhtml?sw=avian&itemNo=635329>\n\nAgriculture ministry buys 8 million doses of avian flu\nvaccine\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Agriculture Ministry has purchased 8 million doses of\nvaccine for the 2 violent strains of avian flu, H-7 and H-5,\nit was reported on Sunday [16 Oct 2005]. The ministry has\nalso purchased a protective kit prepared for ministry\nemployees who could have contact with infected birds. The\nvaccine and the kit come from the Netherlands, Israel Radio\nreported.\nHealth Minister Dan Naveh told Haaretz on Sunday [16 Oct\n2005] that the government will discuss in its next meeting a\nrequest by his ministry to allocate ILS 150 million [USD 181\nmillion] for medication that combats the avian flu.\nSpeaking at a meeting of Health Ministry officials, Naveh\nsaid he will tell the government how the ministry is\npreparing for a possible outbreak of the pandemic in Israel.\nThe preparations were being made in the wake of fears that\nthe strain of bird flu currently circulating in the world\nhas mutated into a strain that is dangerous for humans, in\nwhich case it could be immune to known drugs.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has also opened a 24-hour,\n7-day-a-week hotline to report birds suspected of being\ninfected with avian flu. The public is asked to call\n03-968-1609 to report the location of straying birds that\nappear to be sick or bird carcasses.\nThe ministry announced it has been testing migratory birds\nand poultry in collaboration with the Israel Nature and\nParks Authority to locate infections and examine bird\ncarcasses. So far, all tests have been negative.\nThe director general of the Health Ministry, Professor Avi\nYisraeli, told Haaretz over the weekend that the main thing\nIsrael has to do now is to have Agriculture Ministry\nofficials watch out for possible cases of avian flu among\nmigratory birds and domesticated birds in agricultural\ncommunities.\nYisraeli also recommended that residents of Israel go to\ntheir health clinics to get the regular flu shot\nadministered around this time every year to babies, the\nelderly and health care workers.\nOfficials believe that a dose of the regular seasonal flu\nvaccine may reduce the incidence of sickness in case of an\navian flu epidemic, and that the ordinary flu shot could\nlessen the chance of contracting both viruses together,\nordinary influenza and avian flu.\nFears for an outbreak of the pandemic in Israel emerged\nafter the World Organization for Animal Health released\nfindings indicating flocks of migratory birds nesting in\nChina were responsible for the outbreak outside South East\nAsia. Israel faces this risk since it is located on one of\nthe major seasonal migratory routes of birds.\n[byline: Ran Reznik, Amiram Cohen and Assaf Oni]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The concern of the Israeli authorities is understandable in\nview of Israel's geographical situation as a crossway of\nmigratory birds on their route from Asia and Europe to\nAfrica. The number of birds annually migrating through\nIsrael in each direction is estimated to be around 500\nmillion; see map\nat<http://www.eilat-guide.com/images/maps/bird_map.gif>. -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (12): Romania, H5N1 20051016.3016\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (11): Romania, H5N1 20051015.3009\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (10): Turkey, OIE 20051015.3008\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (09): Romania, OIE 20051015.3007\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (08): Russia, OIE 20051015.3004\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (07): OIE 20051014.2995\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (06): H5N1 20051014.2994\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (05): Turkey, H5N1 20051013.2989\nAvian influenza - Eurasia (04): Romania, conf 20051013.2988\nAvian influenza - Europe (09): EU, preventive measures\n20050922.2802\nAvian influenza - Europe (05): EU, preventive measures\n20050825.2511\nAvian influenza - Europe (04): EU, preventive measures\n20050824.2498\n...................arn/msp/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Eurasia (12): Romania, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1630", "date": "2005-09-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (17): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\nDate: 2 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 26 Aug 2005 Vol. 18 - No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\nSee also: 19 Aug 2005, 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 18 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [33],\n272, dated 19 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 27 Aug 2005.\nWith regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species / Location / virus subtype\nNo. 1/bar-headed goose (Anser indicus)/Erhel lake,Huvsgel province/ H5N1\nNo. 3/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 4/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 6/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. As pointed out by Mod.AS, the important\nnews is that an H5N1 -- most likely the same one currently circulating in\nSoutheast Asia -- has extended its geographic range.\nThe challenge now is to gather good information and understand the evolving\nepidemiology in the newly established geographic location. Foremost among\nthese unanswered questions is the prevalence of infection in the migratory\nbird population. As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease.\nComprehensive surveillance is the key to this question. Given the stakes, the\ncollective effort in surveillance has been weak. Additionally, surveillance\nshould not be limited to wildlife populations. We have already seen this\noutbreak show up in commercial poultry in Kazakhstan and various places in\nRussia. Surveillance will best tell us how firm the H5N1 viral foothold is in\nboth poultry and migratory bird populations.\nPrevious cases of human infection in this pandemic resulted from either direct\nor indirect contact with commercial poultry. How efficiently the H5N1 virus\ncrosses the interface between wildlife and domestic poultry is salient in\npredicting the magnitude of the eventual threat to people. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased.\nThe OIE in a recent press release entitled, \"Evolution of the animal health\nsituation with regard to avian influenza,\" puts it well:\n\"The OIE is vigilantly following the international animal health situation\nwith regard to avian influenza. Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries.\nThis represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....\".\nFor the full statement see: <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_050829.htm>\n- Mod.PC.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds,H5N1 20050831.2578\nAvian influenza - Asia (06): Mongolia, migratory b... 20050819.2443\nAvian influenza - Asia (10): migratory birds 20050824.2492\nAvian influenza - Asia (15): migratory birds 20050827.2536\nAvian influenza, migrating birds - Asia 20050812.2354\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia (02) 20050812.2362\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE 20050808.2317\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE (03) 20050813.2367\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Asia(02): Kazakhstan (North), poultry, H5N1 20050817.2407\n................pc/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Eurasia (11): Romania, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1484", "date": "2005-09-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (17): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\nDate: 2 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 26 Aug 2005 Vol. 18 - No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\nSee also: 19 Aug 2005, 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 18 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [33],\n272, dated 19 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 27 Aug 2005.\nWith regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species / Location / virus subtype\nNo. 1/bar-headed goose (Anser indicus)/Erhel lake,Huvsgel province/ H5N1\nNo. 3/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 4/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 6/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. As pointed out by Mod.AS, the important\nnews is that an H5N1 -- most likely the same one currently circulating in\nSoutheast Asia -- has extended its geographic range.\nThe challenge now is to gather good information and understand the evolving\nepidemiology in the newly established geographic location. Foremost among\nthese unanswered questions is the prevalence of infection in the migratory\nbird population. As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease.\nComprehensive surveillance is the key to this question. Given the stakes, the\ncollective effort in surveillance has been weak. Additionally, surveillance\nshould not be limited to wildlife populations. We have already seen this\noutbreak show up in commercial poultry in Kazakhstan and various places in\nRussia. Surveillance will best tell us how firm the H5N1 viral foothold is in\nboth poultry and migratory bird populations.\nPrevious cases of human infection in this pandemic resulted from either direct\nor indirect contact with commercial poultry. How efficiently the H5N1 virus\ncrosses the interface between wildlife and domestic poultry is salient in\npredicting the magnitude of the eventual threat to people. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased.\nThe OIE in a recent press release entitled, \"Evolution of the animal health\nsituation with regard to avian influenza,\" puts it well:\n\"The OIE is vigilantly following the international animal health situation\nwith regard to avian influenza. Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries.\nThis represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....\".\nFor the full statement see: <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_050829.htm>\n- Mod.PC.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds,H5N1 20050831.2578\nAvian influenza - Asia (06): Mongolia, migratory b... 20050819.2443\nAvian influenza - Asia (10): migratory birds 20050824.2492\nAvian influenza - Asia (15): migratory birds 20050827.2536\nAvian influenza, migrating birds - Asia 20050812.2354\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia (02) 20050812.2362\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE 20050808.2317\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE (03) 20050813.2367\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Asia(02): Kazakhstan (North), poultry, H5N1 20050817.2407\n................pc/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
