Eurasia (05): Turkey, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1474", "date": "2005-09-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (17): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\nDate: 2 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 26 Aug 2005 Vol. 18 - No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\nSee also: 19 Aug 2005, 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 18 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [33],\n272, dated 19 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 27 Aug 2005.\nWith regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species / Location / virus subtype\nNo. 1/bar-headed goose (Anser indicus)/Erhel lake,Huvsgel province/ H5N1\nNo. 3/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 4/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 6/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. As pointed out by Mod.AS, the important\nnews is that an H5N1 -- most likely the same one currently circulating in\nSoutheast Asia -- has extended its geographic range.\nThe challenge now is to gather good information and understand the evolving\nepidemiology in the newly established geographic location. Foremost among\nthese unanswered questions is the prevalence of infection in the migratory\nbird population. As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease.\nComprehensive surveillance is the key to this question. Given the stakes, the\ncollective effort in surveillance has been weak. Additionally, surveillance\nshould not be limited to wildlife populations. We have already seen this\noutbreak show up in commercial poultry in Kazakhstan and various places in\nRussia. Surveillance will best tell us how firm the H5N1 viral foothold is in\nboth poultry and migratory bird populations.\nPrevious cases of human infection in this pandemic resulted from either direct\nor indirect contact with commercial poultry. How efficiently the H5N1 virus\ncrosses the interface between wildlife and domestic poultry is salient in\npredicting the magnitude of the eventual threat to people. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased.\nThe OIE in a recent press release entitled, \"Evolution of the animal health\nsituation with regard to avian influenza,\" puts it well:\n\"The OIE is vigilantly following the international animal health situation\nwith regard to avian influenza. Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries.\nThis represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....\".\nFor the full statement see: <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_050829.htm>\n- Mod.PC.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds,H5N1 20050831.2578\nAvian influenza - Asia (06): Mongolia, migratory b... 20050819.2443\nAvian influenza - Asia (10): migratory birds 20050824.2492\nAvian influenza - Asia (15): migratory birds 20050827.2536\nAvian influenza, migrating birds - Asia 20050812.2354\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia (02) 20050812.2362\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE 20050808.2317\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE (03) 20050813.2367\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Asia(02): Kazakhstan (North), poultry, H5N1 20050817.2407\n................pc/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\nSee also: 19 Aug 2005, 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 18 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [33],\n272, dated 19 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 27 Aug 2005.\nWith regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species / Location / virus subtype\nNo. 1/bar-headed goose (Anser indicus)/Erhel lake,Huvsgel province/ H5N1\nNo. 3/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 4/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 6/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. As pointed out by Mod.AS, the important\nnews is that an H5N1 -- most likely the same one currently circulating in\nSoutheast Asia -- has extended its geographic range.\nThe challenge now is to gather good information and understand the evolving\nepidemiology in the newly established geographic location. Foremost among\nthese unanswered questions is the prevalence of infection in the migratory\nbird population. As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease.\nComprehensive surveillance is the key to this question. Given the stakes, the\ncollective effort in surveillance has been weak. Additionally, surveillance\nshould not be limited to wildlife populations. We have already seen this\noutbreak show up in commercial poultry in Kazakhstan and various places in\nRussia. Surveillance will best tell us how firm the H5N1 viral foothold is in\nboth poultry and migratory bird populations.\nPrevious cases of human infection in this pandemic resulted from either direct\nor indirect contact with commercial poultry. How efficiently the H5N1 virus\ncrosses the interface between wildlife and domestic poultry is salient in\npredicting the magnitude of the eventual threat to people. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased.\nThe OIE in a recent press release entitled, \"Evolution of the animal health\nsituation with regard to avian influenza,\" puts it well:\n\"The OIE is vigilantly following the international animal health situation\nwith regard to avian influenza. Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries.\nThis represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....\".\nFor the full statement see: <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_050829.htm>\n- Mod.PC.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds,H5N1 20050831.2578\nAvian influenza - Asia (06): Mongolia, migratory b... 20050819.2443\nAvian influenza - Asia (10): migratory birds 20050824.2492\nAvian influenza - Asia (15): migratory birds 20050827.2536\nAvian influenza, migrating birds - Asia 20050812.2354\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia (02) 20050812.2362\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE 20050808.2317\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE (03) 20050813.2367\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Asia(02): Kazakhstan (North), poultry, H5N1 20050817.2407\n................pc/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\nSee also: 19 Aug 2005, 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 18 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [33],\n272, dated 19 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 27 Aug 2005.\nWith regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species / Location / virus subtype\nNo. 1/bar-headed goose (Anser indicus)/Erhel lake,Huvsgel province/ H5N1\nNo. 3/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 4/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 6/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. As pointed out by Mod.AS, the important\nnews is that an H5N1 -- most likely the same one currently circulating in\nSoutheast Asia -- has extended its geographic range.\nThe challenge now is to gather good information and understand the evolving\nepidemiology in the newly established geographic location. Foremost among\nthese unanswered questions is the prevalence of infection in the migratory\nbird population. As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease.\nComprehensive surveillance is the key to this question. Given the stakes, the\ncollective effort in surveillance has been weak. Additionally, surveillance\nshould not be limited to wildlife populations. We have already seen this\noutbreak show up in commercial poultry in Kazakhstan and various places in\nRussia. Surveillance will best tell us how firm the H5N1 viral foothold is in\nboth poultry and migratory bird populations.\nPrevious cases of human infection in this pandemic resulted from either direct\nor indirect contact with commercial poultry. How efficiently the H5N1 virus\ncrosses the interface between wildlife and domestic poultry is salient in\npredicting the magnitude of the eventual threat to people. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased.\nThe OIE in a recent press release entitled, \"Evolution of the animal health\nsituation with regard to avian influenza,\" puts it well:\n\"The OIE is vigilantly following the international animal health situation\nwith regard to avian influenza. Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries.\nThis represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....\".\nFor the full statement see: <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_050829.htm>\n- Mod.PC.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds,H5N1 20050831.2578\nAvian influenza - Asia (06): Mongolia, migratory b... 20050819.2443\nAvian influenza - Asia (10): migratory birds 20050824.2492\nAvian influenza - Asia (15): migratory birds 20050827.2536\nAvian influenza, migrating birds - Asia 20050812.2354\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia (02) 20050812.2362\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE 20050808.2317\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE (03) 20050813.2367\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Asia(02): Kazakhstan (North), poultry, H5N1 20050817.2407\n................pc/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Asia (17): Mongolia, migratory birds, H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1185", "date": "2005-09-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA (17): MONGOLIA, MIGRATORY BIRDS, H5N1, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\nDate: 2 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE Disease Information 26 Aug 2005 Vol. 18 - No. 35 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/a_current.htm#Sec0>\n\nHighly Pathogenic Avian Influenza in Mongolia in migratory birds (OIE follow-\nup report No. 2)\nSee also: 19 Aug 2005, 12 Aug 2005\nInformation received on 27 Aug 2005 from Dr Doloonjin Orgil, Director,\nDepartment of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Food and Agriculture,\nUlaanbaatar:\nEnd of previous report period: 18 Aug 2005 (see Disease Information, 18 [33],\n272, dated 19 Aug 2005).\nEnd of this report period: 27 Aug 2005.\nWith regard to the suspicious samples sent on 15 Aug 2005 to the OIE Reference\nLaboratory for avian influenza at Hokkaido University, Japan, the following\nadditional test results were received on 24 Aug 2005:\nSample / Bird species / Location / virus subtype\nNo. 1/bar-headed goose (Anser indicus)/Erhel lake,Huvsgel province/ H5N1\nNo. 3/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 4/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\nNo. 6/ whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus)/ Erhel lake, Huvsgel province /H5N1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report confirms previous postings and information obtained by the joint\nmission that included the Wildlife Conservation Society -- see references\nbelow, particularly 20050831.2578. As pointed out by Mod.AS, the important\nnews is that an H5N1 -- most likely the same one currently circulating in\nSoutheast Asia -- has extended its geographic range.\nThe challenge now is to gather good information and understand the evolving\nepidemiology in the newly established geographic location. Foremost among\nthese unanswered questions is the prevalence of infection in the migratory\nbird population. As put elegantly in previous moderator comments, dead birds\ndon't migrate -- i.e., waterfowl species typically identified in recent\noutbreaks appear to be victims rather than effective carriers of the disease.\nComprehensive surveillance is the key to this question. Given the stakes, the\ncollective effort in surveillance has been weak. Additionally, surveillance\nshould not be limited to wildlife populations. We have already seen this\noutbreak show up in commercial poultry in Kazakhstan and various places in\nRussia. Surveillance will best tell us how firm the H5N1 viral foothold is in\nboth poultry and migratory bird populations.\nPrevious cases of human infection in this pandemic resulted from either direct\nor indirect contact with commercial poultry. How efficiently the H5N1 virus\ncrosses the interface between wildlife and domestic poultry is salient in\npredicting the magnitude of the eventual threat to people. Migratory birds\nalone will not likely threaten people, but if poultry farms or backyard\npoultry become infected because migratory birds have spread the H5N1 virus to\na new geographic region, then the risk to humans has indeed increased.\nThe OIE in a recent press release entitled, \"Evolution of the animal health\nsituation with regard to avian influenza,\" puts it well:\n\"The OIE is vigilantly following the international animal health situation\nwith regard to avian influenza. Following the recent concerns caused by\noutbreaks of avian influenza in Russia and Kazakhstan and by the risk of\nspread of the virus to other regions of the world by migratory birds, the OIE\nrecalls the necessity of intensifying the fight against the disease at its\nsource -- that is in the avian production plants in contaminated countries.\nThis represents the best way of limiting the spread of the disease, of\neradicating it and of reducing the risk of the virus concerned acquiring the\nattributes necessary for a human pandemic to occur....\".\nFor the full statement see: <http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_050829.htm>\n- Mod.PC.]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds,H5N1 20050831.2578\nAvian influenza - Asia (06): Mongolia, migratory b... 20050819.2443\nAvian influenza - Asia (10): migratory birds 20050824.2492\nAvian influenza - Asia (15): migratory birds 20050827.2536\nAvian influenza, migrating birds - Asia 20050812.2354\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia (02) 20050812.2362\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE 20050808.2317\nAvian influenza, migratory birds - Mongolia: OIE (03) 20050813.2367\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Asia(02): Kazakhstan (North), poultry, H5N1 20050817.2407\n................pc/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-08-27 00:00:00", "2005-08-18 00:00:00", "2005-08-19 00:00:00", "2005-08-15 00:00:00", "2005-08-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Huvsgel province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1180", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (16): Mongolia, migratory birds, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1180", "date": "2005-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA: RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. In order to simplify the threads we are\nstarting a new unifying thread, \"Avian influenza - Asia\", which will\nencompass much of what before had been in an ever increasing number of\nthreads. - Mod.DK]\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnews, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L16296660.htm>\n\nRussia says dangerous bird flu outbreak spreads\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia said on Tuesday [16 Aug 2005] an outbreak of bird flu in Chelyabinsk\nwas dangerous to humans, as teams of sanitary workers destroyed birds\n[domestic? wild? - see comment] in Siberia in an attempt to prevent the\nwestward spread of the deadly virus.\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu is behind the outbreak in Chelyabinsk, a city\nin the Ural mountains, the Emergencies Ministry said in a statement.\nIt said no cases among humans have been confirmed in Russia.\n\"Measures are being taken to prevent the spreading of the infection among\ndomestic birds and to exclude the possibility of the infection moving to\nhumans,\" the statement added. Russia is battling to contain a bird flu\noutbreak, which top health officials say has killed more than 11 000 birds\ncountrywide and could spread westwards to Europe, the Middle East and Africa.\nThe outbreak was discovered in mid-July 2005 in Novosibirsk and has spread\nthrough Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan, Altai and now Chelyabinsk, which is about\n1000 km (600 miles) from Novosibirsk.\nSenior agricultural officials believe the flu was brought by migrating\nbirds from Asia, where more than 50 people have died from the deadly H5N1\nstrain since 2003.\nOfficials fear that the virus could spread to Europe and Africa as tens of\nmillions of birds continue their migration to warmer climates from next\nmonth ahead of Russia's harsh winter.\nChelyabinsk lies in the Ural mountains, the geographic divide between Asia\nand Europe. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia.\nBut the diversity of Siberia's bird species makes plotting the flight paths\nof the birds difficult, specialists in Moscow said.\n\"There are about 800 different species of birds in Russia and so there are\nmany different migration flows which criss-cross Russian territory,\" said\nDr. Pavel Tomkovich, a senior ornithologist at Moscow's Zoological Museum.\nHe said water fowl will leave to winter in warmer climates, flying through\nRussia's southern regions, northern Kazakhstan, the Caspian and Black seas\ntowards the Mediterranean and north Africa. That would/could take infected\nbirds through Russia's agricultural heartland in the south.\nHealth officials were meeting in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the\nsituation, the state's consumer watchdog said.\nIn parts of Chelyabinsk, barriers were placed on roads and local officials\nimposed a ban on the sale of all poultry products, the Itar-Tass news\nagency reported. Farmers are being compensated for birds which were being\ndestroyed, the agency said.\nBird flu comes in different stains, such as H5 and H7, which have 9\ndifferent subtypes. The H5N1 subtype is highly pathogenic and can be passed\nfrom birds to humans, though there have been no cases of human-to-human\ntransmission.\n[Byline: Guy Faulconbridge; additional reporting by Maria Kiselyova]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug1505avian.html>\n\nAvian flu spreads westward in Russia\n-------------------------------------\nAvian influenza has cropped up in chickens near Russia's Ural Mountains,\npossibly signaling a continued westward march of the deadly H5N1 virus,\nnews services in Russia reported today.\nThe Chelyabinsk region along the southern end of the Urals is the 6th area\nin Russia to have been hit by avian flu outbreaks recently, according to\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) and Reuters. The Urals separate Siberia from\nEuropean Russia.\nA regional official said 60 chickens in the village of Oktyabrskoye died\nover the weekend, according to an online report by Mosnews.com. The report\nsaid testing had detected an H5N1 virus in the dead birds. However, the AFP\nand Reuters reports said it was not yet known if the virus was H5N1.\nOther parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. But the H5N1 strain has been\nidentified only in the Novosibirsk, Altai, and Omsk outbreaks, the report said.\nThe Siberian outbreaks have killed 10 896 wild and domestic birds,\naccording to an RIA Novosti news agency report quoted by AFP. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. No human cases have been reported.\nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall.\n\"An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,\" said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. \"Some birds nesting in the affected regions (the Novosibirsk and\nAltai territory) migrate to the above-mentioned areas for winter or stop\nthere on their way to Africa or Europe.\"\nHe added that bird migration routes run through Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine, and Mediterranean countries, raising a risk of outbreaks\nthere as well, according to the story. Onischenko made the statements in a\nletter to regional directors of the Federal Service for the Oversight of\nConsumer Protection and Welfare.\nRussia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters.\nA Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\nMeanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Results of the test are\nexpected later this week.\nMosnews.com reported that Pashkova had already recovered from her illness.\n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. It would\nalso help to know if virological/serological surveillance in wildfowl is\nbeing undertaken. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(02): H5N2 20050723.2127\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(03): human risk 20050724.2135\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(04): OIE 20050725.2150\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(05): H5N1 susp. 20050729.2212\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(06): H5N1 susp. 20050730.2216\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2232\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(08): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2235\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(09): H5N1 susp. 20050802.2239\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1 20050811.2346\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(13): H5N1, OIE 20050813.2369\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(14): H5N1 20050815.2389\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia): susp 20050722.2113\n..................arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2005-07-21 00:00:00", "2005-08-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "siberia)(04", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Chelyabinsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1179", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (13): Russia (Siberia, Urals), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1179", "date": "2005-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA: RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. In order to simplify the threads we are\nstarting a new unifying thread, \"Avian influenza - Asia\", which will\nencompass much of what before had been in an ever increasing number of\nthreads. - Mod.DK]\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnews, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L16296660.htm>\n\nRussia says dangerous bird flu outbreak spreads\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia said on Tuesday [16 Aug 2005] an outbreak of bird flu in Chelyabinsk\nwas dangerous to humans, as teams of sanitary workers destroyed birds\n[domestic? wild? - see comment] in Siberia in an attempt to prevent the\nwestward spread of the deadly virus.\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu is behind the outbreak in Chelyabinsk, a city\nin the Ural mountains, the Emergencies Ministry said in a statement.\nIt said no cases among humans have been confirmed in Russia.\n\"Measures are being taken to prevent the spreading of the infection among\ndomestic birds and to exclude the possibility of the infection moving to\nhumans,\" the statement added. Russia is battling to contain a bird flu\noutbreak, which top health officials say has killed more than 11 000 birds\ncountrywide and could spread westwards to Europe, the Middle East and Africa.\nThe outbreak was discovered in mid-July 2005 in Novosibirsk and has spread\nthrough Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan, Altai and now Chelyabinsk, which is about\n1000 km (600 miles) from Novosibirsk.\nSenior agricultural officials believe the flu was brought by migrating\nbirds from Asia, where more than 50 people have died from the deadly H5N1\nstrain since 2003.\nOfficials fear that the virus could spread to Europe and Africa as tens of\nmillions of birds continue their migration to warmer climates from next\nmonth ahead of Russia's harsh winter.\nChelyabinsk lies in the Ural mountains, the geographic divide between Asia\nand Europe. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia.\nBut the diversity of Siberia's bird species makes plotting the flight paths\nof the birds difficult, specialists in Moscow said.\n\"There are about 800 different species of birds in Russia and so there are\nmany different migration flows which criss-cross Russian territory,\" said\nDr. Pavel Tomkovich, a senior ornithologist at Moscow's Zoological Museum.\nHe said water fowl will leave to winter in warmer climates, flying through\nRussia's southern regions, northern Kazakhstan, the Caspian and Black seas\ntowards the Mediterranean and north Africa. That would/could take infected\nbirds through Russia's agricultural heartland in the south.\nHealth officials were meeting in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the\nsituation, the state's consumer watchdog said.\nIn parts of Chelyabinsk, barriers were placed on roads and local officials\nimposed a ban on the sale of all poultry products, the Itar-Tass news\nagency reported. Farmers are being compensated for birds which were being\ndestroyed, the agency said.\nBird flu comes in different stains, such as H5 and H7, which have 9\ndifferent subtypes. The H5N1 subtype is highly pathogenic and can be passed\nfrom birds to humans, though there have been no cases of human-to-human\ntransmission.\n[Byline: Guy Faulconbridge; additional reporting by Maria Kiselyova]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug1505avian.html>\n\nAvian flu spreads westward in Russia\n-------------------------------------\nAvian influenza has cropped up in chickens near Russia's Ural Mountains,\npossibly signaling a continued westward march of the deadly H5N1 virus,\nnews services in Russia reported today.\nThe Chelyabinsk region along the southern end of the Urals is the 6th area\nin Russia to have been hit by avian flu outbreaks recently, according to\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) and Reuters. The Urals separate Siberia from\nEuropean Russia.\nA regional official said 60 chickens in the village of Oktyabrskoye died\nover the weekend, according to an online report by Mosnews.com. The report\nsaid testing had detected an H5N1 virus in the dead birds. However, the AFP\nand Reuters reports said it was not yet known if the virus was H5N1.\nOther parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. But the H5N1 strain has been\nidentified only in the Novosibirsk, Altai, and Omsk outbreaks, the report said.\nThe Siberian outbreaks have killed 10 896 wild and domestic birds,\naccording to an RIA Novosti news agency report quoted by AFP. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. No human cases have been reported.\nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall.\n\"An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,\" said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. \"Some birds nesting in the affected regions (the Novosibirsk and\nAltai territory) migrate to the above-mentioned areas for winter or stop\nthere on their way to Africa or Europe.\"\nHe added that bird migration routes run through Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine, and Mediterranean countries, raising a risk of outbreaks\nthere as well, according to the story. Onischenko made the statements in a\nletter to regional directors of the Federal Service for the Oversight of\nConsumer Protection and Welfare.\nRussia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters.\nA Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\nMeanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Results of the test are\nexpected later this week.\nMosnews.com reported that Pashkova had already recovered from her illness.\n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2005-07-21 00:00:00", "2005-08-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "siberia)(04", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Chelyabinsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1172", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (12): Viet Nam, civets, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1172", "date": "2005-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA: RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. In order to simplify the threads we are\nstarting a new unifying thread, \"Avian influenza - Asia\", which will\nencompass much of what before had been in an ever increasing number of\nthreads. - Mod.DK]\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnews, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L16296660.htm>\n\nRussia says dangerous bird flu outbreak spreads\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia said on Tuesday [16 Aug 2005] an outbreak of bird flu in Chelyabinsk\nwas dangerous to humans, as teams of sanitary workers destroyed birds\n[domestic? wild? - see comment] in Siberia in an attempt to prevent the\nwestward spread of the deadly virus.\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu is behind the outbreak in Chelyabinsk, a city\nin the Ural mountains, the Emergencies Ministry said in a statement.\nIt said no cases among humans have been confirmed in Russia.\n\"Measures are being taken to prevent the spreading of the infection among\ndomestic birds and to exclude the possibility of the infection moving to\nhumans,\" the statement added. Russia is battling to contain a bird flu\noutbreak, which top health officials say has killed more than 11 000 birds\ncountrywide and could spread westwards to Europe, the Middle East and Africa.\nThe outbreak was discovered in mid-July 2005 in Novosibirsk and has spread\nthrough Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan, Altai and now Chelyabinsk, which is about\n1000 km (600 miles) from Novosibirsk.\nSenior agricultural officials believe the flu was brought by migrating\nbirds from Asia, where more than 50 people have died from the deadly H5N1\nstrain since 2003.\nOfficials fear that the virus could spread to Europe and Africa as tens of\nmillions of birds continue their migration to warmer climates from next\nmonth ahead of Russia's harsh winter.\nChelyabinsk lies in the Ural mountains, the geographic divide between Asia\nand Europe. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia.\nBut the diversity of Siberia's bird species makes plotting the flight paths\nof the birds difficult, specialists in Moscow said.\n\"There are about 800 different species of birds in Russia and so there are\nmany different migration flows which criss-cross Russian territory,\" said\nDr. Pavel Tomkovich, a senior ornithologist at Moscow's Zoological Museum.\nHe said water fowl will leave to winter in warmer climates, flying through\nRussia's southern regions, northern Kazakhstan, the Caspian and Black seas\ntowards the Mediterranean and north Africa. That would/could take infected\nbirds through Russia's agricultural heartland in the south.\nHealth officials were meeting in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the\nsituation, the state's consumer watchdog said.\nIn parts of Chelyabinsk, barriers were placed on roads and local officials\nimposed a ban on the sale of all poultry products, the Itar-Tass news\nagency reported. Farmers are being compensated for birds which were being\ndestroyed, the agency said.\nBird flu comes in different stains, such as H5 and H7, which have 9\ndifferent subtypes. The H5N1 subtype is highly pathogenic and can be passed\nfrom birds to humans, though there have been no cases of human-to-human\ntransmission.\n[Byline: Guy Faulconbridge; additional reporting by Maria Kiselyova]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug1505avian.html>\n\nAvian flu spreads westward in Russia\n-------------------------------------\nAvian influenza has cropped up in chickens near Russia's Ural Mountains,\npossibly signaling a continued westward march of the deadly H5N1 virus,\nnews services in Russia reported today.\nThe Chelyabinsk region along the southern end of the Urals is the 6th area\nin Russia to have been hit by avian flu outbreaks recently, according to\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) and Reuters. The Urals separate Siberia from\nEuropean Russia.\nA regional official said 60 chickens in the village of Oktyabrskoye died\nover the weekend, according to an online report by Mosnews.com. The report\nsaid testing had detected an H5N1 virus in the dead birds. However, the AFP\nand Reuters reports said it was not yet known if the virus was H5N1.\nOther parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. But the H5N1 strain has been\nidentified only in the Novosibirsk, Altai, and Omsk outbreaks, the report said.\nThe Siberian outbreaks have killed 10 896 wild and domestic birds,\naccording to an RIA Novosti news agency report quoted by AFP. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. No human cases have been reported.\nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall.\n\"An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,\" said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. \"Some birds nesting in the affected regions (the Novosibirsk and\nAltai territory) migrate to the above-mentioned areas for winter or stop\nthere on their way to Africa or Europe.\"\nHe added that bird migration routes run through Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine, and Mediterranean countries, raising a risk of outbreaks\nthere as well, according to the story. Onischenko made the statements in a\nletter to regional directors of the Federal Service for the Oversight of\nConsumer Protection and Welfare.\nRussia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters.\nA Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\nMeanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Results of the test are\nexpected later this week.\nMosnews.com reported that Pashkova had already recovered from her illness.\n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. It would\nalso help to know if virological/serological surveillance in wildfowl is\nbeing undertaken. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(02): H5N2 20050723.2127\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(03): human risk 20050724.2135\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(04): OIE 20050725.2150\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(05): H5N1 susp. 20050729.2212\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(06): H5N1 susp. 20050730.2216\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2232\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(08): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2235\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(09): H5N1 susp. 20050802.2239\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1 20050811.2346\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(13): H5N1, OIE 20050813.2369\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(14): H5N1 20050815.2389\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia): susp 20050722.2113\n..................arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2005-07-21 00:00:00", "2005-08-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "siberia)(04", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Chelyabinsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1171", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (12): Russia (Siberia), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1171", "date": "2005-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA: RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia.\nBut the diversity of Siberia's bird species makes plotting the flight paths\nof the birds difficult, specialists in Moscow said.\n\"There are about 800 different species of birds in Russia and so there are\nmany different migration flows which criss-cross Russian territory,\" said\nDr. Pavel Tomkovich, a senior ornithologist at Moscow's Zoological Museum.\nHe said water fowl will leave to winter in warmer climates, flying through\nRussia's southern regions, northern Kazakhstan, the Caspian and Black seas\ntowards the Mediterranean and north Africa. The Urals separate Siberia from\nEuropean Russia.\nA regional official said 60 chickens in the village of Oktyabrskoye died\nover the weekend, according to an online report by Mosnews.com. The report\nsaid testing had detected an H5N1 virus in the dead birds. However, the AFP\nand Reuters reports said it was not yet known if the virus was H5N1.\nOther parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. But the H5N1 strain has been\nidentified only in the Novosibirsk, Altai, and Omsk outbreaks, the report said.\nThe Siberian outbreaks have killed 10 896 wild and domestic birds,\naccording to an RIA Novosti news agency report quoted by AFP. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. No human cases have been reported.\nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall.\n\"An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,\" said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. \"Some birds nesting in the affected regions (the Novosibirsk and\nAltai territory) migrate to the above-mentioned areas for winter or stop\nthere on their way to Africa or Europe.\"\nHe added that bird migration routes run through Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine, and Mediterranean countries, raising a risk of outbreaks\nthere as well, according to the story. Onischenko made the statements in a\nletter to regional directors of the Federal Service for the Oversight of\nConsumer Protection and Welfare.\nRussia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters.\nA Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\nMeanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Results of the test are\nexpected later this week.\nMosnews.com reported that Pashkova had already recovered from her illness.\n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. It would\nalso help to know if virological/serological surveillance in wildfowl is\nbeing undertaken. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(02): H5N2 20050723.2127\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(03): human risk 20050724.2135\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(04): OIE 20050725.2150\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(05): H5N1 susp. 20050729.2212\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(06): H5N1 susp. 20050730.2216\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2232\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(08): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2235\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(09): H5N1 susp. 20050802.2239\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1 20050811.2346\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(13): H5N1, OIE 20050813.2369\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(14): H5N1 20050815.2389\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia): susp 20050722.2113\n..................arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2005-07-21 00:00:00", "2005-08-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "siberia)(04", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Chelyabinsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1156", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia (04): EU update, H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1156", "date": "2005-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA: RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. In order to simplify the threads we are\nstarting a new unifying thread, \"Avian influenza - Asia\", which will\nencompass much of what before had been in an ever increasing number of\nthreads. - Mod.DK]\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnews, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L16296660.htm>\n\nRussia says dangerous bird flu outbreak spreads\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia said on Tuesday [16 Aug 2005] an outbreak of bird flu in Chelyabinsk\nwas dangerous to humans, as teams of sanitary workers destroyed birds\n[domestic? wild? - see comment] in Siberia in an attempt to prevent the\nwestward spread of the deadly virus.\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu is behind the outbreak in Chelyabinsk, a city\nin the Ural mountains, the Emergencies Ministry said in a statement.\nIt said no cases among humans have been confirmed in Russia.\n\"Measures are being taken to prevent the spreading of the infection among\ndomestic birds and to exclude the possibility of the infection moving to\nhumans,\" the statement added. Russia is battling to contain a bird flu\noutbreak, which top health officials say has killed more than 11 000 birds\ncountrywide and could spread westwards to Europe, the Middle East and Africa.\nThe outbreak was discovered in mid-July 2005 in Novosibirsk and has spread\nthrough Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan, Altai and now Chelyabinsk, which is about\n1000 km (600 miles) from Novosibirsk.\nSenior agricultural officials believe the flu was brought by migrating\nbirds from Asia, where more than 50 people have died from the deadly H5N1\nstrain since 2003.\nOfficials fear that the virus could spread to Europe and Africa as tens of\nmillions of birds continue their migration to warmer climates from next\nmonth ahead of Russia's harsh winter.\nChelyabinsk lies in the Ural mountains, the geographic divide between Asia\nand Europe. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia.\nBut the diversity of Siberia's bird species makes plotting the flight paths\nof the birds difficult, specialists in Moscow said.\n\"There are about 800 different species of birds in Russia and so there are\nmany different migration flows which criss-cross Russian territory,\" said\nDr. Pavel Tomkovich, a senior ornithologist at Moscow's Zoological Museum.\nHe said water fowl will leave to winter in warmer climates, flying through\nRussia's southern regions, northern Kazakhstan, the Caspian and Black seas\ntowards the Mediterranean and north Africa. That would/could take infected\nbirds through Russia's agricultural heartland in the south.\nHealth officials were meeting in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the\nsituation, the state's consumer watchdog said.\nIn parts of Chelyabinsk, barriers were placed on roads and local officials\nimposed a ban on the sale of all poultry products, the Itar-Tass news\nagency reported. Farmers are being compensated for birds which were being\ndestroyed, the agency said.\nBird flu comes in different stains, such as H5 and H7, which have 9\ndifferent subtypes. The H5N1 subtype is highly pathogenic and can be passed\nfrom birds to humans, though there have been no cases of human-to-human\ntransmission.\n[Byline: Guy Faulconbridge; additional reporting by Maria Kiselyova]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug1505avian.html>\n\nAvian flu spreads westward in Russia\n-------------------------------------\nAvian influenza has cropped up in chickens near Russia's Ural Mountains,\npossibly signaling a continued westward march of the deadly H5N1 virus,\nnews services in Russia reported today.\nThe Chelyabinsk region along the southern end of the Urals is the 6th area\nin Russia to have been hit by avian flu outbreaks recently, according to\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) and Reuters. The Urals separate Siberia from\nEuropean Russia.\nA regional official said 60 chickens in the village of Oktyabrskoye died\nover the weekend, according to an online report by Mosnews.com. The report\nsaid testing had detected an H5N1 virus in the dead birds. However, the AFP\nand Reuters reports said it was not yet known if the virus was H5N1.\nOther parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. But the H5N1 strain has been\nidentified only in the Novosibirsk, Altai, and Omsk outbreaks, the report said.\nThe Siberian outbreaks have killed 10 896 wild and domestic birds,\naccording to an RIA Novosti news agency report quoted by AFP. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. No human cases have been reported.\nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall.\n\"An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,\" said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. \"Some birds nesting in the affected regions (the Novosibirsk and\nAltai territory) migrate to the above-mentioned areas for winter or stop\nthere on their way to Africa or Europe.\"\nHe added that bird migration routes run through Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine, and Mediterranean countries, raising a risk of outbreaks\nthere as well, according to the story. Onischenko made the statements in a\nletter to regional directors of the Federal Service for the Oversight of\nConsumer Protection and Welfare.\nRussia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters.\nA Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\nMeanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Results of the test are\nexpected later this week.\nMosnews.com reported that Pashkova had already recovered from her illness.\n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. It would\nalso help to know if virological/serological surveillance in wildfowl is\nbeing undertaken. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(02): H5N2 20050723.2127\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(03): human risk 20050724.2135\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(04): OIE 20050725.2150\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(05): H5N1 susp. 20050729.2212\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(06): H5N1 susp. 20050730.2216\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2232\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(08): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2235\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(09): H5N1 susp. 20050802.2239\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1 20050811.2346\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(13): H5N1, OIE 20050813.2369\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(14): H5N1 20050815.2389\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia): susp 20050722.2113\n..................arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-08-16 00:00:00", "2005-07-21 00:00:00", "2005-08-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iraq", "country": "Iraq"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "siberia)(04", "country": "Cuba"}, {"location": "Altai", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Chelyabinsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Novosibirsk", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1151", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Asia: Russia (Siberia), H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1151", "date": "2005-08-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA - ASIA: RUSSIA (SIBERIA), H5N1\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n[As the H5N1 avian influenza virus has spread thoughout Asia, our posts on\nnon-humans have spread to different threads for different geographical\nareas and different avian species. In order to simplify the threads we are\nstarting a new unifying thread, \"Avian influenza - Asia\", which will\nencompass much of what before had been in an ever increasing number of\nthreads. - Mod.DK]\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters alertnews, 16 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L16296660.htm>\n\nRussia says dangerous bird flu outbreak spreads\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia said on Tuesday [16 Aug 2005] an outbreak of bird flu in Chelyabinsk\nwas dangerous to humans, as teams of sanitary workers destroyed birds\n[domestic? wild? - see comment] in Siberia in an attempt to prevent the\nwestward spread of the deadly virus.\nThe H5N1 strain of bird flu is behind the outbreak in Chelyabinsk, a city\nin the Ural mountains, the Emergencies Ministry said in a statement.\nIt said no cases among humans have been confirmed in Russia.\n\"Measures are being taken to prevent the spreading of the infection among\ndomestic birds and to exclude the possibility of the infection moving to\nhumans,\" the statement added. Russia is battling to contain a bird flu\noutbreak, which top health officials say has killed more than 11 000 birds\ncountrywide and could spread westwards to Europe, the Middle East and Africa.\nThe outbreak was discovered in mid-July 2005 in Novosibirsk and has spread\nthrough Tyumen, Omsk, Kurgan, Altai and now Chelyabinsk, which is about\n1000 km (600 miles) from Novosibirsk.\nSenior agricultural officials believe the flu was brought by migrating\nbirds from Asia, where more than 50 people have died from the deadly H5N1\nstrain since 2003.\nOfficials fear that the virus could spread to Europe and Africa as tens of\nmillions of birds continue their migration to warmer climates from next\nmonth ahead of Russia's harsh winter.\nChelyabinsk lies in the Ural mountains, the geographic divide between Asia\nand Europe. Russia's top state epidemiologist, Gennady Onishchenko, said\nmigratory birds move on to warmer areas in southern Russia, Africa and\nEurope in the autumn after nesting in Siberia.\nBut the diversity of Siberia's bird species makes plotting the flight paths\nof the birds difficult, specialists in Moscow said.\n\"There are about 800 different species of birds in Russia and so there are\nmany different migration flows which criss-cross Russian territory,\" said\nDr. Pavel Tomkovich, a senior ornithologist at Moscow's Zoological Museum.\nHe said water fowl will leave to winter in warmer climates, flying through\nRussia's southern regions, northern Kazakhstan, the Caspian and Black seas\ntowards the Mediterranean and north Africa. That would/could take infected\nbirds through Russia's agricultural heartland in the south.\nHealth officials were meeting in Moscow on Tuesday to discuss the\nsituation, the state's consumer watchdog said.\nIn parts of Chelyabinsk, barriers were placed on roads and local officials\nimposed a ban on the sale of all poultry products, the Itar-Tass news\nagency reported. Farmers are being compensated for birds which were being\ndestroyed, the agency said.\nBird flu comes in different stains, such as H5 and H7, which have 9\ndifferent subtypes. The H5N1 subtype is highly pathogenic and can be passed\nfrom birds to humans, though there have been no cases of human-to-human\ntransmission.\n[Byline: Guy Faulconbridge; additional reporting by Maria Kiselyova]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue, 16 Aug 2005\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: CIDRAP News, 15 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug1505avian.html>\n\nAvian flu spreads westward in Russia\n-------------------------------------\nAvian influenza has cropped up in chickens near Russia's Ural Mountains,\npossibly signaling a continued westward march of the deadly H5N1 virus,\nnews services in Russia reported today.\nThe Chelyabinsk region along the southern end of the Urals is the 6th area\nin Russia to have been hit by avian flu outbreaks recently, according to\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) and Reuters. The Urals separate Siberia from\nEuropean Russia.\nA regional official said 60 chickens in the village of Oktyabrskoye died\nover the weekend, according to an online report by Mosnews.com. The report\nsaid testing had detected an H5N1 virus in the dead birds. However, the AFP\nand Reuters reports said it was not yet known if the virus was H5N1.\nOther parts of southwestern Siberia that have reported recent outbreaks of\navian flu include Novosibirsk, Altai, Omsk, Tyumen, and Kurgan, all to the\neast of Chelyabinsk, according to AFP. But the H5N1 strain has been\nidentified only in the Novosibirsk, Altai, and Omsk outbreaks, the report said.\nThe Siberian outbreaks have killed 10 896 wild and domestic birds,\naccording to an RIA Novosti news agency report quoted by AFP. Hundreds of\nthousands of birds have been culled since the 1st in the series of Russian\noutbreaks was reported in Novosibirsk on 21 Jul 2005, according to\nMosnews.com. No human cases have been reported.\nRussia's top government epidemiologist, Gennady Onischenko, warned that\nmigrating birds could spread avian flu to Russia's major agricultural\nregion and on to the Middle East and Mediterranean Sea this fall.\n\"An analysis of bird migration routes has shown that the contagious A\n(H5N1) virus may spread from western Siberia to the Caspian and Black Sea\nareas this fall,\" said Onischenko, as quoted by an RIA Novosti report\ntoday. \"Some birds nesting in the affected regions (the Novosibirsk and\nAltai territory) migrate to the above-mentioned areas for winter or stop\nthere on their way to Africa or Europe.\"\nHe added that bird migration routes run through Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq,\nGeorgia, Ukraine, and Mediterranean countries, raising a risk of outbreaks\nthere as well, according to the story. Onischenko made the statements in a\nletter to regional directors of the Federal Service for the Oversight of\nConsumer Protection and Welfare.\nRussia's Agriculture Ministry said all sick and infected birds in\nChelyabinsk were being destroyed, and Russian media reported that roads\nleading to the affected village were cordoned off in an effort to contain\nthe outbreak, according to Reuters.\nA Russian agricultural official said the Chelyabinsk outbreak is near a\nlake that borders the Kurgan region and Kazakhstan, where other avian flu\noutbreaks have been reported recently, according to the Mosnews.com report.\nMeanwhile, a Russian journalist named Maria Pashkova, who was hospitalized\nafter visiting an area affected by avian flu, has been tested for the\nillness, according to an RIA Novosti report today. Results of the test are\nexpected later this week.\nMosnews.com reported that Pashkova had already recovered from her illness.\n4 other Russians were hospitalized with suspected avian flu recently, but\nall 4 tested negative, the RIA Novosti story said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the absence of an official OIE update since 5 Aug 2005, it is not clear\nwhat measures are currently being undertaken by the Russian authorities to\ncontrol the disease within the 5 regions (oblasts) situated west of the 1st\naffected region, Novosibirsk, and to prevent its further spread. It would\nalso help to know if virological/serological surveillance in wildfowl is\nbeing undertaken. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(02): H5N2 20050723.2127\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(03): human risk 20050724.2135\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(04): OIE 20050725.2150\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(05): H5N1 susp. 20050729.2212\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(06): H5N1 susp. 20050730.2216\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2232\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(08): H5N1 susp. 20050801.2235\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(09): H5N1 susp. 20050802.2239\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE 20050808.2315\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1 20050811.2346\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(13): H5N1, OIE 20050813.2369\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(14): H5N1 20050815.2389\nAvian influenza - Russia (Siberia): susp 20050722.2113\n..................arn/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
