Russia (Siberia)(11): H5N1", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1136", "date": "2005-08-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE PROSPECTS\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTransactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/trst>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 7 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News online, Fri 5 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4747909.stm>\n\nA Vaccine for All Types of Influenza\n-----------------------------------------\nScientists are making a vaccine that could give lifelong protection\nagainst all types of flu in a single jab. Currently, at risk people\nin the UK -- the elderly and ill -- need annual flu jabs, and there\nis no jab available yet guaranteed to beat avian influenza.\nBiotechnology firm Acambis, in Cambridge, UK says it hopes its jab\nwill target numerous mutations that presently allow flu to evade\nattack. However, the work is very early and is years off being tested\nin humans.\nEach year, winter flu kills around 4000 people in the UK. Globally,\nbetween 500 000 and one million people die each year from influenza.\nIf the avian influenza virus currently circulating in Asia were to\nmutate and spread from person to person, it could kill as many people\nas the 1918 Spanish flu, which claimed between 20 and 40 million\nlives, experts have warned.\nCurrent influenza vaccines work by giving immunity to 2 proteins\ncalled hemagglutinin and neuraminidase, which are found on the\nsurface of flu viruses. However, these proteins keep mutating, which\nmeans doctors have to keep making new vaccines to keep up. Scientists\nat Acambis' laboratory in the US, together with Belgian researchers\nat Flanders Interuniversity Institute for Biotechnology, are focusing\ntheir efforts on a different protein, called M2, which does not\nmutate, as well as other technology that they cannot disclose yet for\ncommercial reasons. If successful, a single shot of the vaccine could\nprotect a person against all strains of influenza virus, they\nbelieve. Dr. Thomas Monath, chief scientific officer at Acambis,\nsaid: \"We aim to avoid the need for annual re-engineering and\nmanufacture of the new product, something that is not yet possible\nwith existing vaccines. The need to develop a new vaccine each time a\ndifferent influenza strain emerges often results in long delays\nbefore a population can be protected. The technology also has special\nimportance as a potential means of protecting human populations\nagainst pandemic influenza strains. So far, the vaccine has only been\ntested in animals. The scientists said it would take several years\nbefore large-scale human trials could be done.\nProfessor Maria Zambon, a flu expert at the Health Protection Agency,\nsaid: \"We welcome advances in the process of developing novel flu\nvaccines and vaccination techniques. However, this vaccine is still\nvery early in a vaccine development pipeline, and it will take some\ntime to establish how this vaccine performs in human trials and\nwhether it can proceed to being licensed for use in the UK.\"\nProfessor Karl Nicholson, professor of infectious diseases at\nLeicester University, said: \"It would be enormously helpful to\nmankind to have just the one vaccine, but, sadly, I think it is a\nlong way off.\" He said it might be 10 years before any such product\ncould be ready for widespread use in humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 7 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The New York Times, Sun 7 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/07/health/07vaccine.html?th&emc=th>\n\nAvian Influenza Vaccine Called Effective in Human Testing\n-----------------------------------------------\nGovernment scientists say they have successfully tested in people a\nvaccine that they believe can protect against the strain of avian\ninfluenza that is spreading in birds through Asia and Russia. Health\nofficials have been racing to develop a vaccine because they worry\nthat, if that strain mutated and combined with a human influenza\nvirus to create a new virus, it could spread rapidly through the\nworld. (The vaccine cannot lead to such a situation, because it is\nmade from killed virus.) Tens of millions of birds have died from\ninfection with the virus and culling to prevent the spread of the\nvirus. About 100 people have been infected, and about 50 [112 and 57\nas of 5 Aug 2005 - Mod.CP] have died from this strain of the avian\ninfluenza virus, called A(H5N1). So far, there has been no sustained\nhuman-to-human transmission, but that is what health officials fear,\nbecause it could cause a pandemic. And that fear has driven the\nintense research to develop a vaccine.\nThe Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious\nDiseases, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, said that while the vaccine that has\nundergone preliminary tests could be used on an emergency basis if a\npandemic developed, it would still be several months before that\nvaccine is tested further and, if licensed, offered to the public. He\ncautioned: \"We don't have all the vaccine we need to meet the\npossible demand. The critical issue now is, can we make enough\nvaccine, given the well-known inability of the vaccine industry to\nmake enough vaccine.\"\nAn earlier human vaccine against A(H5N1) avian influenza virus was\nprepared after it 1st appeared in the world, in Hong Kong in 1997.\nThat vaccine was never fully developed or used, and the strain has\nmutated since then. In interviews over recent days, Dr. Fauci has\nsaid that tests so far have shown that the new vaccine produced a\nstrong immune response among the small group of healthy adults under\nage 65 who volunteered to receive it, although the doses needed were\nhigher than in the standard influenza vaccine offered each year. The\nvaccine, developed with genetic engineering techniques, is intended\nto protect against infection, not to treat those who are sick.\nFurther tests are expected to be conducted among 2 groups -- people\n65 and older, and children -- over the next several months. Dr. Fauci\nexpressed confidence that they would confirm the success of the 1st\ntests and answer remaining scientific questions.\nBecause the vaccine is made in chicken eggs, \"a potential major\nstumbling block\" to successful mass production is the number of eggs\nfarmers can supply to vaccine manufacturers, Dr. Fauci said. If\nmanufacturers can overcome such hurdles, the new vaccine could go far\nin averting a possible pandemic of human influenza, Dr. Fauci said.\nOnly a small number of human cases of A(H5N1) influenza have been\nfound. Although a few cases may have been transmitted from person to\nperson in Asia, the A(H5N1) strain has not garnered enough strength\nto spread widely among humans anywhere. As of Friday [5 Aug 2005]\nnight, according to the World Health Organization in Geneva, the\navian strain has killed 57 of the 112 people it has been known to\ninfect in 4 countries. They are Cambodia (4 cases), Indonesia (one\ncase), Thailand (17 cases), and Viet Nam (90 cases).\nThe additional tests are needed in part to determine the optimal dose\nof vaccine; how many shots people will need for protection; and\nwhether adding another ingredient called an adjuvant to the vaccine\ncould raise the potency of lower doses, stretching the number of\npeople that could be protected. Even when these tests are completed,\nmore time will be needed before the Food and Drug Administration can\nlicense the human vaccine and before policy makers determine the when\nand how it should be administered.\nGovernment researchers and others developed the vaccine, which is\nproduced by Sanofi-Pasteur, a French vaccine company that is now part\nof Aventis. The government could decide to release the product under\nemergency conditions if an A(H5N1) influenza pandemic struck before\nthe testing process was completed. Although cautioning that the\nvaccine has not been fully tested, Dr. Fauci said that the initial\ntest findings have given the federal government enough confidence to\nstart the process of adding millions more doses of the vaccine to the\n2 million it has bought. The present supply is stored in bulk form,\nand \"we cannot put it in vials until we find out what the right dose\nis,\" Dr. Fauci said. The manufacturer needs to know the dose and\nregimen to determine how much more vaccine it can produce and make\navailable to the United States and other customers.\nScientists had to test the human avian influenza vaccine on\nvolunteers, because the A(H5N1) strain differs in significant ways\nfrom the conventional strains that cause human influenza. Also, the\ninfluenza shots that are offered each year are derived from the human\nstrains that are circulating most widely at the time experts choose\nthe components of the next vaccine. Human influenza viruses mutate\nenough each year to force changes in the standard vaccines. Such\nvaccines produce a broader and stronger immunity, because recipients\nbuild up an immunity to influenza from repeated immunizations and\nexposure to the influenza virus. In a sense, the standard annual\ninfluenza shots are booster doses. But the A(H5N1) vaccine is a\nprimary immunization because, having had no exposure to that virus,\npeople lack any immunity to the avian strain.\nThe United States is thought to be the only country that has produced\na human vaccine against the A(H5N1) influenza strain. Australia,\nCanada, France, Japan [and the UK] are among countries where\nscientists are trying to develop human avian influenza vaccines,\naccording to the World Health Organization.\nDr. Fauci's institute also contracted with Chiron, which is based in\nEmeryville, California to make another A(H5N1) vaccine. But tests of\nthe Chiron vaccine have not started because of delays related to\nprior contamination found in Chiron's plants. Dr. Fauci said his\ninstitute has 8000 doses of the Chiron human A(H5N1) vaccine and\nhopes to start testing it in volunteers in late fall. The tests will\nfollow the same steps taken with the Sanofi-Pasteur vaccine, he said.\n[Byline: Lawrence K. Altman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has no commercial or other association with any of the\ngovernmental agencies or commercial companies mentioned in these\nreports. The information is posted merely to give an impression of\nthe state of progress in development of vaccine for use in\ncontainment of a possible pandemic influenza virus arising in the\ncourse of the current H5N1 avian influenza outbreak in East Asia.\nThe problem with the approach described in the 1st report is that it\nis innovative and a long way from resolution and, therefore, an\nunlikely option for containment of a pandemic strain whose appearance\nmay be imminent. Its advantage is that it does not depend on close\nmatching of the H (or N) antigens. The approach described in the 2nd\nreport is disadvantaged by the lapse of time between choice of\nvaccine strain and appearance of a pandemic virus which may have\ndiverged by progressive genetic mutation, or may even have acquired\nnon-homologous H (and/or N) antigens by reassortment. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (06) 20040410.0975\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus: request for isolates 20040203.0407\n..................cp/msp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1918-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Emeryville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "United Kingdom"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1133", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(10): H5N1, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1133", "date": "2005-08-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE PROSPECTS\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTransactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/trst>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 7 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News online, Fri 5 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4747909.stm>\n\nA Vaccine for All Types of Influenza\n-----------------------------------------\nScientists are making a vaccine that could give lifelong protection\nagainst all types of flu in a single jab. Currently, at risk people\nin the UK -- the elderly and ill -- need annual flu jabs, and there\nis no jab available yet guaranteed to beat avian influenza.\nBiotechnology firm Acambis, in Cambridge, UK says it hopes its jab\nwill target numerous mutations that presently allow flu to evade\nattack. However, the work is very early and is years off being tested\nin humans.\nEach year, winter flu kills around 4000 people in the UK. Globally,\nbetween 500 000 and one million people die each year from influenza.\nIf the avian influenza virus currently circulating in Asia were to\nmutate and spread from person to person, it could kill as many people\nas the 1918 Spanish flu, which claimed between 20 and 40 million\nlives, experts have warned.\nCurrent influenza vaccines work by giving immunity to 2 proteins\ncalled hemagglutinin and neuraminidase, which are found on the\nsurface of flu viruses. However, these proteins keep mutating, which\nmeans doctors have to keep making new vaccines to keep up. Scientists\nat Acambis' laboratory in the US, together with Belgian researchers\nat Flanders Interuniversity Institute for Biotechnology, are focusing\ntheir efforts on a different protein, called M2, which does not\nmutate, as well as other technology that they cannot disclose yet for\ncommercial reasons. If successful, a single shot of the vaccine could\nprotect a person against all strains of influenza virus, they\nbelieve. Dr. Thomas Monath, chief scientific officer at Acambis,\nsaid: \"We aim to avoid the need for annual re-engineering and\nmanufacture of the new product, something that is not yet possible\nwith existing vaccines. The need to develop a new vaccine each time a\ndifferent influenza strain emerges often results in long delays\nbefore a population can be protected. The technology also has special\nimportance as a potential means of protecting human populations\nagainst pandemic influenza strains. So far, the vaccine has only been\ntested in animals. The scientists said it would take several years\nbefore large-scale human trials could be done.\nProfessor Maria Zambon, a flu expert at the Health Protection Agency,\nsaid: \"We welcome advances in the process of developing novel flu\nvaccines and vaccination techniques. However, this vaccine is still\nvery early in a vaccine development pipeline, and it will take some\ntime to establish how this vaccine performs in human trials and\nwhether it can proceed to being licensed for use in the UK.\"\nProfessor Karl Nicholson, professor of infectious diseases at\nLeicester University, said: \"It would be enormously helpful to\nmankind to have just the one vaccine, but, sadly, I think it is a\nlong way off.\" He said it might be 10 years before any such product\ncould be ready for widespread use in humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 7 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The New York Times, Sun 7 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/07/health/07vaccine.html?th&emc=th>\n\nAvian Influenza Vaccine Called Effective in Human Testing\n-----------------------------------------------\nGovernment scientists say they have successfully tested in people a\nvaccine that they believe can protect against the strain of avian\ninfluenza that is spreading in birds through Asia and Russia. Health\nofficials have been racing to develop a vaccine because they worry\nthat, if that strain mutated and combined with a human influenza\nvirus to create a new virus, it could spread rapidly through the\nworld. (The vaccine cannot lead to such a situation, because it is\nmade from killed virus.) Tens of millions of birds have died from\ninfection with the virus and culling to prevent the spread of the\nvirus. About 100 people have been infected, and about 50 [112 and 57\nas of 5 Aug 2005 - Mod.CP] have died from this strain of the avian\ninfluenza virus, called A(H5N1). So far, there has been no sustained\nhuman-to-human transmission, but that is what health officials fear,\nbecause it could cause a pandemic. And that fear has driven the\nintense research to develop a vaccine.\nThe Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious\nDiseases, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, said that while the vaccine that has\nundergone preliminary tests could be used on an emergency basis if a\npandemic developed, it would still be several months before that\nvaccine is tested further and, if licensed, offered to the public. He\ncautioned: \"We don't have all the vaccine we need to meet the\npossible demand. The critical issue now is, can we make enough\nvaccine, given the well-known inability of the vaccine industry to\nmake enough vaccine.\"\nAn earlier human vaccine against A(H5N1) avian influenza virus was\nprepared after it 1st appeared in the world, in Hong Kong in 1997.\nThat vaccine was never fully developed or used, and the strain has\nmutated since then. In interviews over recent days, Dr. Fauci has\nsaid that tests so far have shown that the new vaccine produced a\nstrong immune response among the small group of healthy adults under\nage 65 who volunteered to receive it, although the doses needed were\nhigher than in the standard influenza vaccine offered each year. The\nvaccine, developed with genetic engineering techniques, is intended\nto protect against infection, not to treat those who are sick.\nFurther tests are expected to be conducted among 2 groups -- people\n65 and older, and children -- over the next several months. Dr. Fauci\nexpressed confidence that they would confirm the success of the 1st\ntests and answer remaining scientific questions.\nBecause the vaccine is made in chicken eggs, \"a potential major\nstumbling block\" to successful mass production is the number of eggs\nfarmers can supply to vaccine manufacturers, Dr. Fauci said. If\nmanufacturers can overcome such hurdles, the new vaccine could go far\nin averting a possible pandemic of human influenza, Dr. Fauci said.\nOnly a small number of human cases of A(H5N1) influenza have been\nfound. Although a few cases may have been transmitted from person to\nperson in Asia, the A(H5N1) strain has not garnered enough strength\nto spread widely among humans anywhere. As of Friday [5 Aug 2005]\nnight, according to the World Health Organization in Geneva, the\navian strain has killed 57 of the 112 people it has been known to\ninfect in 4 countries. They are Cambodia (4 cases), Indonesia (one\ncase), Thailand (17 cases), and Viet Nam (90 cases).\nThe additional tests are needed in part to determine the optimal dose\nof vaccine; how many shots people will need for protection; and\nwhether adding another ingredient called an adjuvant to the vaccine\ncould raise the potency of lower doses, stretching the number of\npeople that could be protected. Even when these tests are completed,\nmore time will be needed before the Food and Drug Administration can\nlicense the human vaccine and before policy makers determine the when\nand how it should be administered.\nGovernment researchers and others developed the vaccine, which is\nproduced by Sanofi-Pasteur, a French vaccine company that is now part\nof Aventis. The government could decide to release the product under\nemergency conditions if an A(H5N1) influenza pandemic struck before\nthe testing process was completed. Although cautioning that the\nvaccine has not been fully tested, Dr. Fauci said that the initial\ntest findings have given the federal government enough confidence to\nstart the process of adding millions more doses of the vaccine to the\n2 million it has bought. The present supply is stored in bulk form,\nand \"we cannot put it in vials until we find out what the right dose\nis,\" Dr. Fauci said. The manufacturer needs to know the dose and\nregimen to determine how much more vaccine it can produce and make\navailable to the United States and other customers.\nScientists had to test the human avian influenza vaccine on\nvolunteers, because the A(H5N1) strain differs in significant ways\nfrom the conventional strains that cause human influenza. Also, the\ninfluenza shots that are offered each year are derived from the human\nstrains that are circulating most widely at the time experts choose\nthe components of the next vaccine. Human influenza viruses mutate\nenough each year to force changes in the standard vaccines. Such\nvaccines produce a broader and stronger immunity, because recipients\nbuild up an immunity to influenza from repeated immunizations and\nexposure to the influenza virus. In a sense, the standard annual\ninfluenza shots are booster doses. But the A(H5N1) vaccine is a\nprimary immunization because, having had no exposure to that virus,\npeople lack any immunity to the avian strain.\nThe United States is thought to be the only country that has produced\na human vaccine against the A(H5N1) influenza strain. Australia,\nCanada, France, Japan [and the UK] are among countries where\nscientists are trying to develop human avian influenza vaccines,\naccording to the World Health Organization.\nDr. Fauci's institute also contracted with Chiron, which is based in\nEmeryville, California to make another A(H5N1) vaccine. But tests of\nthe Chiron vaccine have not started because of delays related to\nprior contamination found in Chiron's plants. Dr. Fauci said his\ninstitute has 8000 doses of the Chiron human A(H5N1) vaccine and\nhopes to start testing it in volunteers in late fall. The tests will\nfollow the same steps taken with the Sanofi-Pasteur vaccine, he said.\n[Byline: Lawrence K. Altman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has no commercial or other association with any of the\ngovernmental agencies or commercial companies mentioned in these\nreports. The information is posted merely to give an impression of\nthe state of progress in development of vaccine for use in\ncontainment of a possible pandemic influenza virus arising in the\ncourse of the current H5N1 avian influenza outbreak in East Asia.\nThe problem with the approach described in the 1st report is that it\nis innovative and a long way from resolution and, therefore, an\nunlikely option for containment of a pandemic strain whose appearance\nmay be imminent. Its advantage is that it does not depend on close\nmatching of the H (or N) antigens. The approach described in the 2nd\nreport is disadvantaged by the lapse of time between choice of\nvaccine strain and appearance of a pandemic virus which may have\ndiverged by progressive genetic mutation, or may even have acquired\nnon-homologous H (and/or N) antigens by reassortment. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (06) 20040410.0975\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus: request for isolates 20040203.0407\n..................cp/msp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE PROSPECTS\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTransactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/trst>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 7 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News online, Fri 5 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4747909.stm>\n\nA Vaccine for All Types of Influenza\n-----------------------------------------\nScientists are making a vaccine that could give lifelong protection\nagainst all types of flu in a single jab. Currently, at risk people\nin the UK -- the elderly and ill -- need annual flu jabs, and there\nis no jab available yet guaranteed to beat avian influenza.\nBiotechnology firm Acambis, in Cambridge, UK says it hopes its jab\nwill target numerous mutations that presently allow flu to evade\nattack. However, the work is very early and is years off being tested\nin humans.\nEach year, winter flu kills around 4000 people in the UK. Globally,\nbetween 500 000 and one million people die each year from influenza.\nIf the avian influenza virus currently circulating in Asia were to\nmutate and spread from person to person, it could kill as many people\nas the 1918 Spanish flu, which claimed between 20 and 40 million\nlives, experts have warned.\nCurrent influenza vaccines work by giving immunity to 2 proteins\ncalled hemagglutinin and neuraminidase, which are found on the\nsurface of flu viruses. However, these proteins keep mutating, which\nmeans doctors have to keep making new vaccines to keep up. Scientists\nat Acambis' laboratory in the US, together with Belgian researchers\nat Flanders Interuniversity Institute for Biotechnology, are focusing\ntheir efforts on a different protein, called M2, which does not\nmutate, as well as other technology that they cannot disclose yet for\ncommercial reasons. If successful, a single shot of the vaccine could\nprotect a person against all strains of influenza virus, they\nbelieve. Dr. Thomas Monath, chief scientific officer at Acambis,\nsaid: \"We aim to avoid the need for annual re-engineering and\nmanufacture of the new product, something that is not yet possible\nwith existing vaccines. The need to develop a new vaccine each time a\ndifferent influenza strain emerges often results in long delays\nbefore a population can be protected. The technology also has special\nimportance as a potential means of protecting human populations\nagainst pandemic influenza strains. So far, the vaccine has only been\ntested in animals. The scientists said it would take several years\nbefore large-scale human trials could be done.\nProfessor Maria Zambon, a flu expert at the Health Protection Agency,\nsaid: \"We welcome advances in the process of developing novel flu\nvaccines and vaccination techniques. However, this vaccine is still\nvery early in a vaccine development pipeline, and it will take some\ntime to establish how this vaccine performs in human trials and\nwhether it can proceed to being licensed for use in the UK.\"\nProfessor Karl Nicholson, professor of infectious diseases at\nLeicester University, said: \"It would be enormously helpful to\nmankind to have just the one vaccine, but, sadly, I think it is a\nlong way off.\" He said it might be 10 years before any such product\ncould be ready for widespread use in humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 7 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The New York Times, Sun 7 Aug 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/07/health/07vaccine.html?th&emc=th>\n\nAvian Influenza Vaccine Called Effective in Human Testing\n-----------------------------------------------\nGovernment scientists say they have successfully tested in people a\nvaccine that they believe can protect against the strain of avian\ninfluenza that is spreading in birds through Asia and Russia. Health\nofficials have been racing to develop a vaccine because they worry\nthat, if that strain mutated and combined with a human influenza\nvirus to create a new virus, it could spread rapidly through the\nworld. (The vaccine cannot lead to such a situation, because it is\nmade from killed virus.) Tens of millions of birds have died from\ninfection with the virus and culling to prevent the spread of the\nvirus. About 100 people have been infected, and about 50 [112 and 57\nas of 5 Aug 2005 - Mod.CP] have died from this strain of the avian\ninfluenza virus, called A(H5N1). So far, there has been no sustained\nhuman-to-human transmission, but that is what health officials fear,\nbecause it could cause a pandemic. And that fear has driven the\nintense research to develop a vaccine.\nThe Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious\nDiseases, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, said that while the vaccine that has\nundergone preliminary tests could be used on an emergency basis if a\npandemic developed, it would still be several months before that\nvaccine is tested further and, if licensed, offered to the public. He\ncautioned: \"We don't have all the vaccine we need to meet the\npossible demand. The critical issue now is, can we make enough\nvaccine, given the well-known inability of the vaccine industry to\nmake enough vaccine.\"\nAn earlier human vaccine against A(H5N1) avian influenza virus was\nprepared after it 1st appeared in the world, in Hong Kong in 1997.\nThat vaccine was never fully developed or used, and the strain has\nmutated since then. In interviews over recent days, Dr. Fauci has\nsaid that tests so far have shown that the new vaccine produced a\nstrong immune response among the small group of healthy adults under\nage 65 who volunteered to receive it, although the doses needed were\nhigher than in the standard influenza vaccine offered each year. The\nvaccine, developed with genetic engineering techniques, is intended\nto protect against infection, not to treat those who are sick.\nFurther tests are expected to be conducted among 2 groups -- people\n65 and older, and children -- over the next several months. Dr. Fauci\nexpressed confidence that they would confirm the success of the 1st\ntests and answer remaining scientific questions.\nBecause the vaccine is made in chicken eggs, \"a potential major\nstumbling block\" to successful mass production is the number of eggs\nfarmers can supply to vaccine manufacturers, Dr. Fauci said. If\nmanufacturers can overcome such hurdles, the new vaccine could go far\nin averting a possible pandemic of human influenza, Dr. Fauci said.\nOnly a small number of human cases of A(H5N1) influenza have been\nfound. Although a few cases may have been transmitted from person to\nperson in Asia, the A(H5N1) strain has not garnered enough strength\nto spread widely among humans anywhere. As of Friday [5 Aug 2005]\nnight, according to the World Health Organization in Geneva, the\navian strain has killed 57 of the 112 people it has been known to\ninfect in 4 countries. They are Cambodia (4 cases), Indonesia (one\ncase), Thailand (17 cases), and Viet Nam (90 cases).\nThe additional tests are needed in part to determine the optimal dose\nof vaccine; how many shots people will need for protection; and\nwhether adding another ingredient called an adjuvant to the vaccine\ncould raise the potency of lower doses, stretching the number of\npeople that could be protected. Even when these tests are completed,\nmore time will be needed before the Food and Drug Administration can\nlicense the human vaccine and before policy makers determine the when\nand how it should be administered.\nGovernment researchers and others developed the vaccine, which is\nproduced by Sanofi-Pasteur, a French vaccine company that is now part\nof Aventis. The government could decide to release the product under\nemergency conditions if an A(H5N1) influenza pandemic struck before\nthe testing process was completed. Although cautioning that the\nvaccine has not been fully tested, Dr. Fauci said that the initial\ntest findings have given the federal government enough confidence to\nstart the process of adding millions more doses of the vaccine to the\n2 million it has bought. The present supply is stored in bulk form,\nand \"we cannot put it in vials until we find out what the right dose\nis,\" Dr. Fauci said. The manufacturer needs to know the dose and\nregimen to determine how much more vaccine it can produce and make\navailable to the United States and other customers.\nScientists had to test the human avian influenza vaccine on\nvolunteers, because the A(H5N1) strain differs in significant ways\nfrom the conventional strains that cause human influenza. Also, the\ninfluenza shots that are offered each year are derived from the human\nstrains that are circulating most widely at the time experts choose\nthe components of the next vaccine. Human influenza viruses mutate\nenough each year to force changes in the standard vaccines. Such\nvaccines produce a broader and stronger immunity, because recipients\nbuild up an immunity to influenza from repeated immunizations and\nexposure to the influenza virus. In a sense, the standard annual\ninfluenza shots are booster doses. But the A(H5N1) vaccine is a\nprimary immunization because, having had no exposure to that virus,\npeople lack any immunity to the avian strain.\nThe United States is thought to be the only country that has produced\na human vaccine against the A(H5N1) influenza strain. Australia,\nCanada, France, Japan [and the UK] are among countries where\nscientists are trying to develop human avian influenza vaccines,\naccording to the World Health Organization.\nDr. Fauci's institute also contracted with Chiron, which is based in\nEmeryville, California to make another A(H5N1) vaccine. But tests of\nthe Chiron vaccine have not started because of delays related to\nprior contamination found in Chiron's plants. Dr. Fauci said his\ninstitute has 8000 doses of the Chiron human A(H5N1) vaccine and\nhopes to start testing it in volunteers in late fall. The tests will\nfollow the same steps taken with the Sanofi-Pasteur vaccine, he said.\n[Byline: Lawrence K. Altman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail has no commercial or other association with any of the\ngovernmental agencies or commercial companies mentioned in these\nreports. The information is posted merely to give an impression of\nthe state of progress in development of vaccine for use in\ncontainment of a possible pandemic influenza virus arising in the\ncourse of the current H5N1 avian influenza outbreak in East Asia.\nThe problem with the approach described in the 1st report is that it\nis innovative and a long way from resolution and, therefore, an\nunlikely option for containment of a pandemic strain whose appearance\nmay be imminent. Its advantage is that it does not depend on close\nmatching of the H (or N) antigens. The approach described in the 2nd\nreport is disadvantaged by the lapse of time between choice of\nvaccine strain and appearance of a pandemic virus which may have\ndiverged by progressive genetic mutation, or may even have acquired\nnon-homologous H (and/or N) antigens by reassortment. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (06) 20040410.0975\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus: request for isolates 20040203.0407\n..................cp/msp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1918-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cambodia", "country": "Cambodia"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Emeryville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Cambridge", "country": "United Kingdom"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1124", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(09): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1124", "date": "2005-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1, 2002 - INDIA (TAMIL NADU): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 12 May 2005 10:44:37 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 12 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.webindia123.com/news/showdetails.asp?id=81845&cat=Health>\n\nTamil Nadu orders probe into bird flu virus report\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe Tamil Nadu government has ordered an inquiry into reports that a strain\nof bird flu was found in this south Indian state by an American laboratory.\nA media report said 2 days ago that the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention had confirmed that it found the H5N1 bird flu virus\nin samples sent by the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) when the\ndisease was raging in many Asian countries last year [2004].\nICMR had sent the samples drawn in 2002 from its referral laboratory at the\nKing Institute of Preventive Medicine in Chennai. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. Only specific protein signatures\nof the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain were spotted at ICMR's influenza\nreferral laboratory in Chennai's King Institute of Preventive Medicine-the\ndisease itself has not been detected.\nResearchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. Dr\nNirmal K Ganguly, director general of ICMR, told this website newspaper\nthat he was not aware of such a finding, suggesting that if such a\nhigh-profile exotic virus were to surface in India, his staff would alert\nhim. However, he was at the moment in total darkness about the discovery.\nDr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Dr Katz added that here is no cause for alarm.\nTill now, only these protein signatures have been found, and irrefutable\nevidence of whether the deadly H5N1 strain is present in humans in India\ncan emerge only when the virus is isolated and sequenced.\nBut virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. While\nnumerous H5N1 outbreaks have been reported since late 2003 in most (if not\nall) East Asian countries, no single report of an avian flu outbreak from\nneighboring India has been documented since 2001. In the above reports it\nis stated that the samples in question were drawn in 2002 from 3 local\npoultry farm workers and that the seropositive results obtained by the CDC\n(Atlanta) have been available in ICMR since late 2004. Poultry is a major\nstate industry for the area, and migratory birds arrive every year on Tamil\nNadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai. Therefore, it is rather\npuzzling that 3 people were infected with the HPAI H5N1 while working in\nthe poultry farm(s), but that no sick or dead birds were ever discovered or\nreported by the local or national health authorities, such as ICMR. Any\nfurther information for clarification of this issue is welcome. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (51): Thailand 20050506.1255\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (47): FAO 20050414.1075\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (30): Viet Nam, Thailand 20050305.0669\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (20): Thailand, Viet Nam 20050212.0481\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (07): EU import policy 20050118.0169\n2004\n---\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, drug resistance (02) 20040127.0316\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 19980404.0621\nInfluenzavirus A/H5N1, pathogenesis, human 19980318.0517\nInfluenzavirus A (H5N1), risk factors 19980313.0477\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong): report 19980307.0438\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China(Hong Kong):serosurvey(02)19980224.0364\nInfluenza A/H5N1, clinical findings 19980213.0283\nInfluenza H5N1, new vaccine development - USA 19980205.0225\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong): serosurvey 19980131.0199\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142\nInfluenzavirus A (H5N1): sequences analyzed 19980117.0139\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (04) 19980115.0113\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (03) 19980115.0112\nInfluenza, H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (02)19980113.0101\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) 19980110.0081\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\nInfluenzavirus A H5N1: responses 19980107.0049\n1997\n---\nInfluenza, human, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (11) 19971208.2449\n..............ry/sh/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. Russia (Siberia)(07): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1121", "date": "2005-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1, 2002 - INDIA (TAMIL NADU): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 12 May 2005 10:44:37 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 12 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.webindia123.com/news/showdetails.asp?id=81845&cat=Health>\n\nTamil Nadu orders probe into bird flu virus report\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe Tamil Nadu government has ordered an inquiry into reports that a strain\nof bird flu was found in this south Indian state by an American laboratory.\nA media report said 2 days ago that the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention had confirmed that it found the H5N1 bird flu virus\nin samples sent by the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) when the\ndisease was raging in many Asian countries last year [2004].\nICMR had sent the samples drawn in 2002 from its referral laboratory at the\nKing Institute of Preventive Medicine in Chennai. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. Only specific protein signatures\nof the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain were spotted at ICMR's influenza\nreferral laboratory in Chennai's King Institute of Preventive Medicine-the\ndisease itself has not been detected.\nResearchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. Dr\nNirmal K Ganguly, director general of ICMR, told this website newspaper\nthat he was not aware of such a finding, suggesting that if such a\nhigh-profile exotic virus were to surface in India, his staff would alert\nhim. However, he was at the moment in total darkness about the discovery.\nDr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Dr Katz added that here is no cause for alarm.\nTill now, only these protein signatures have been found, and irrefutable\nevidence of whether the deadly H5N1 strain is present in humans in India\ncan emerge only when the virus is isolated and sequenced.\nBut virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. While\nnumerous H5N1 outbreaks have been reported since late 2003 in most (if not\nall) East Asian countries, no single report of an avian flu outbreak from\nneighboring India has been documented since 2001. In the above reports it\nis stated that the samples in question were drawn in 2002 from 3 local\npoultry farm workers and that the seropositive results obtained by the CDC\n(Atlanta) have been available in ICMR since late 2004. Poultry is a major\nstate industry for the area, and migratory birds arrive every year on Tamil\nNadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai. Therefore, it is rather\npuzzling that 3 people were infected with the HPAI H5N1 while working in\nthe poultry farm(s), but that no sick or dead birds were ever discovered or\nreported by the local or national health authorities, such as ICMR. Any\nfurther information for clarification of this issue is welcome. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (51): Thailand 20050506.1255\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (47): FAO 20050414.1075\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (30): Viet Nam, Thailand 20050305.0669\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (20): Thailand, Viet Nam 20050212.0481\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (07): EU import policy 20050118.0169\n2004\n---\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, drug resistance (02) 20040127.0316\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (132): Thailand 20041026.2900\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine prospects 20040125.0300\nAvian influenza, Thailand - OIE 20040124.0276\nAvian influenza - Thailand: RFI 20040105.0051\n1998\n---\nInfluenzavirus A H5N1, cohort studies 19981116.2219\nInfluenzavirus A (H5N1): 2 strains - China (Hong Kong) 19980404.0621\nInfluenzavirus A/H5N1, pathogenesis, human 19980318.0517\nInfluenzavirus A (H5N1), risk factors 19980313.0477\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong): report 19980307.0438\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China(Hong Kong):serosurvey(02)19980224.0364\nInfluenza A/H5N1, clinical findings 19980213.0283\nInfluenza H5N1, new vaccine development - USA 19980205.0225\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong): serosurvey 19980131.0199\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142\nInfluenzavirus A (H5N1): sequences analyzed 19980117.0139\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (04) 19980115.0113\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (03) 19980115.0112\nInfluenza, H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (02)19980113.0101\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) 19980110.0081\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\nInfluenzavirus A H5N1: responses 19980107.0049\n1997\n---\nInfluenza, human, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (11) 19971208.2449\n..............ry/sh/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2047-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vedanthangal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Kattangalathur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1118", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza - Russia (Siberia)(06): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1118", "date": "2005-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1, 2002 - INDIA (TAMIL NADU): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 12 May 2005 10:44:37 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 12 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.webindia123.com/news/showdetails.asp?id=81845&cat=Health>\n\nTamil Nadu orders probe into bird flu virus report\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe Tamil Nadu government has ordered an inquiry into reports that a strain\nof bird flu was found in this south Indian state by an American laboratory.\nA media report said 2 days ago that the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention had confirmed that it found the H5N1 bird flu virus\nin samples sent by the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) when the\ndisease was raging in many Asian countries last year [2004].\nICMR had sent the samples drawn in 2002 from its referral laboratory at the\nKing Institute of Preventive Medicine in Chennai. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. Only specific protein signatures\nof the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain were spotted at ICMR's influenza\nreferral laboratory in Chennai's King Institute of Preventive Medicine-the\ndisease itself has not been detected.\nResearchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. Dr\nNirmal K Ganguly, director general of ICMR, told this website newspaper\nthat he was not aware of such a finding, suggesting that if such a\nhigh-profile exotic virus were to surface in India, his staff would alert\nhim. However, he was at the moment in total darkness about the discovery.\nDr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Dr Katz added that here is no cause for alarm.\nTill now, only these protein signatures have been found, and irrefutable\nevidence of whether the deadly H5N1 strain is present in humans in India\ncan emerge only when the virus is isolated and sequenced.\nBut virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. While\nnumerous H5N1 outbreaks have been reported since late 2003 in most (if not\nall) East Asian countries, no single report of an avian flu outbreak from\nneighboring India has been documented since 2001. In the above reports it\nis stated that the samples in question were drawn in 2002 from 3 local\npoultry farm workers and that the seropositive results obtained by the CDC\n(Atlanta) have been available in ICMR since late 2004. Poultry is a major\nstate industry for the area, and migratory birds arrive every year on Tamil\nNadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai. Therefore, it is rather\npuzzling that 3 people were infected with the HPAI H5N1 while working in\nthe poultry farm(s), but that no sick or dead birds were ever discovered or\nreported by the local or national health authorities, such as ICMR. Any\nfurther information for clarification of this issue is welcome. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (51): Thailand 20050506.1255\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (47): FAO 20050414.1075\nAvian influenza -
