Russia (Siberia)(05): H5N1 susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1116", "date": "2005-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1, 2002 - INDIA (TAMIL NADU): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 12 May 2005 10:44:37 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 12 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.webindia123.com/news/showdetails.asp?id=81845&cat=Health>\n\nTamil Nadu orders probe into bird flu virus report\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe Tamil Nadu government has ordered an inquiry into reports that a strain\nof bird flu was found in this south Indian state by an American laboratory.\nA media report said 2 days ago that the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention had confirmed that it found the H5N1 bird flu virus\nin samples sent by the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) when the\ndisease was raging in many Asian countries last year [2004].\nICMR had sent the samples drawn in 2002 from its referral laboratory at the\nKing Institute of Preventive Medicine in Chennai. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. Only specific protein signatures\nof the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain were spotted at ICMR's influenza\nreferral laboratory in Chennai's King Institute of Preventive Medicine-the\ndisease itself has not been detected.\nResearchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. Dr\nNirmal K Ganguly, director general of ICMR, told this website newspaper\nthat he was not aware of such a finding, suggesting that if such a\nhigh-profile exotic virus were to surface in India, his staff would alert\nhim. However, he was at the moment in total darkness about the discovery.\nDr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Dr Katz added that here is no cause for alarm.\nTill now, only these protein signatures have been found, and irrefutable\nevidence of whether the deadly H5N1 strain is present in humans in India\ncan emerge only when the virus is isolated and sequenced.\nBut virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. While\nnumerous H5N1 outbreaks have been reported since late 2003 in most (if not\nall) East Asian countries, no single report of an avian flu outbreak from\nneighboring India has been documented since 2001. In the above reports it\nis stated that the samples in question were drawn in 2002 from 3 local\npoultry farm workers and that the seropositive results obtained by the CDC\n(Atlanta) have been available in ICMR since late 2004. Poultry is a major\nstate industry for the area, and migratory birds arrive every year on Tamil\nNadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai. Therefore, it is rather\npuzzling that 3 people were infected with the HPAI H5N1 while working in\nthe poultry farm(s), but that no sick or dead birds were ever discovered or\nreported by the local or national health authorities, such as ICMR. Any\nfurther information for clarification of this issue is welcome. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (51): Thailand 20050506.1255\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (47): FAO 20050414.1075\nAvian influenza - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142\nInfluenzavirus A (H5N1): sequences analyzed 19980117.0139\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (04) 19980115.0113\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (03) 19980115.0112\nInfluenza, H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (02)19980113.0101\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) 19980110.0081\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\nInfluenzavirus A H5N1: responses 19980107.0049\n1997\n---\nInfluenza, human, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (11) 19971208.2449\n..............ry/sh/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2047-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vedanthangal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Kattangalathur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1093", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza A (H5N1) virus - China (Hong Kong): 2003", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1093", "date": "2005-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1, 2002 - INDIA (TAMIL NADU): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 12 May 2005 10:44:37 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 12 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.webindia123.com/news/showdetails.asp?id=81845&cat=Health>\n\nTamil Nadu orders probe into bird flu virus report\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe Tamil Nadu government has ordered an inquiry into reports that a strain\nof bird flu was found in this south Indian state by an American laboratory.\nA media report said 2 days ago that the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention had confirmed that it found the H5N1 bird flu virus\nin samples sent by the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) when the\ndisease was raging in many Asian countries last year [2004].\nICMR had sent the samples drawn in 2002 from its referral laboratory at the\nKing Institute of Preventive Medicine in Chennai. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. Only specific protein signatures\nof the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain were spotted at ICMR's influenza\nreferral laboratory in Chennai's King Institute of Preventive Medicine-the\ndisease itself has not been detected.\nResearchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. Dr\nNirmal K Ganguly, director general of ICMR, told this website newspaper\nthat he was not aware of such a finding, suggesting that if such a\nhigh-profile exotic virus were to surface in India, his staff would alert\nhim. However, he was at the moment in total darkness about the discovery.\nDr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Dr Katz added that here is no cause for alarm.\nTill now, only these protein signatures have been found, and irrefutable\nevidence of whether the deadly H5N1 strain is present in humans in India\ncan emerge only when the virus is isolated and sequenced.\nBut virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. While\nnumerous H5N1 outbreaks have been reported since late 2003 in most (if not\nall) East Asian countries, no single report of an avian flu outbreak from\nneighboring India has been documented since 2001. In the above reports it\nis stated that the samples in question were drawn in 2002 from 3 local\npoultry farm workers and that the seropositive results obtained by the CDC\n(Atlanta) have been available in ICMR since late 2004. Poultry is a major\nstate industry for the area, and migratory birds arrive every year on Tamil\nNadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai. Therefore, it is rather\npuzzling that 3 people were infected with the HPAI H5N1 while working in\nthe poultry farm(s), but that no sick or dead birds were ever discovered or\nreported by the local or national health authorities, such as ICMR. Any\nfurther information for clarification of this issue is welcome. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (51): Thailand 20050506.1255\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (47): FAO 20050414.1075\nAvian influenza - China 19980108.0055\nInfluenzavirus A H5N1: responses 19980107.0049\n1997\n---\nInfluenza, human, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (11) 19971208.2449\n..............ry/sh/pg/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. Only specific protein signatures\nof the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain were spotted at ICMR's influenza\nreferral laboratory in Chennai's King Institute of Preventive Medicine-the\ndisease itself has not been detected.\nResearchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. Dr\nNirmal K Ganguly, director general of ICMR, told this website newspaper\nthat he was not aware of such a finding, suggesting that if such a\nhigh-profile exotic virus were to surface in India, his staff would alert\nhim. However, he was at the moment in total darkness about the discovery.\nDr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Dr Katz added that here is no cause for alarm.\nTill now, only these protein signatures have been found, and irrefutable\nevidence of whether the deadly H5N1 strain is present in humans in India\ncan emerge only when the virus is isolated and sequenced.\nBut virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2047-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vedanthangal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Kattangalathur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "995", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, H5N1, 2002 - India (Tamil Nadu): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=995", "date": "2005-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1, 2002 - INDIA (TAMIL NADU): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 12 May 2005 10:44:37 -0400 (EDT)\nFrom: A-Lan Banks <A-Lan.Banks@thomson.com>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 12 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.webindia123.com/news/showdetails.asp?id=81845&cat=Health>\n\nTamil Nadu orders probe into bird flu virus report\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe Tamil Nadu government has ordered an inquiry into reports that a strain\nof bird flu was found in this south Indian state by an American laboratory.\nA media report said 2 days ago that the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention had confirmed that it found the H5N1 bird flu virus\nin samples sent by the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) when the\ndisease was raging in many Asian countries last year [2004].\nICMR had sent the samples drawn in 2002 from its referral laboratory at the\nKing Institute of Preventive Medicine in Chennai. The samples were drawn\nfrom 3 poultry farm workers in Kattangalathur, 45 km from here.\nThe report caused alarm in the health department here, as poultry is a\nmajor state industry. Following the report, health secretary Sheela Rani\nChunkath held a meeting with experts on Wednesday. King Institute director\nNalini Ramamurthy was also present.\nThe government has ordered director of medical education P Vijayalakshmi to\ninvestigate the reported bird flu strain found among Tamil Nadu poultry\nworkers. Ramamurthy, however, dismissed the media report as alarmist and\nsaid: \"The disease itself has not been found. The findings were from random\nsamples taken in 2002.\"\nThe 3 poultry workers have not had bird flu and are doing well. Ramamurthy\nhas, however, sought a clinical study of migratory birds that arrive on\nTamil Nadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai, every year saying\nthis could be a source for the virus strain.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, May 11 2005 00:00 IST\nFrom: Ms. Donna Eberwine <eberwind@paho.org>\nSource: Webindia123, India, 11 May 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.newindpress.com/Newsitems.asp?ID=IE320050510121915&Title=Features>\n\nBird flu strain found in 3 Chennai poultry workers\n--------------------------------------------------\nScientists from a partner laboratory of the Indian Council of Medical\nResearch (ICMR) have found the 1st signs of an avian influenza virus in 3\nworkers from a poultry farm near Chennai. Only specific protein signatures\nof the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain were spotted at ICMR's influenza\nreferral laboratory in Chennai's King Institute of Preventive Medicine-the\ndisease itself has not been detected.\nResearchers found the H5N1 signs in samples collected in 2002, which was\nconfirmed by the world's foremost infectious diseases laboratory, the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta late in 2004. Dr\nNirmal K Ganguly, director general of ICMR, told this website newspaper\nthat he was not aware of such a finding, suggesting that if such a\nhigh-profile exotic virus were to surface in India, his staff would alert\nhim. However, he was at the moment in total darkness about the discovery.\nDr Jackie Katz of the CDC's Influenza Branch confirmed to this website\nnewspaper that the 3 people tested positive for antibody to a highly\npathogenic H5N1 virus. Dr Katz added that here is no cause for alarm.\nTill now, only these protein signatures have been found, and irrefutable\nevidence of whether the deadly H5N1 strain is present in humans in India\ncan emerge only when the virus is isolated and sequenced.\nBut virus isolation and sequencing has not been attempted in India, as\nthere is a lack of such a secure bio-safety facility, said Dr A C Mishra,\ndirector of the National Institute of Virology, Pune. He added that a\nhigh-level meeting is being organised at ICMR soon to take stock of the\nsituation and decide on the steps to be taken.\nThe H5N1 strain normally infects only birds -- in poultry it causes\nepidemics -- but is worrisome because it has been found to jump the species\nbarrier and infect humans, like what happened in Hong Kong in 1997, when 6\npeople died and the entire 1.5 million bird poultry stock of the island had\nto culled.\nThe avian influenza virus has been in the headlines since its outbreak in\nEast Asia in 2004, and the World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued a\nglobal alert about this highly contagious bug. The WHO Regional\nRepresentative to India, Dr Salim Habayeb, expressed complete surprise that\nhe was not informed about this finding by the government, even though he\ngets a weekly report of prevalent communicable animal and human diseases.\nExpressing concern, Dr Habayeb said the H5N1 strain is very [virulent], as\nit mutates very quickly -- a benign non-pathogenic strain could quickly\nbecome a deadly virus, since this particular family of bugs are known to\nswap genes at a very rapid pace.\nBut Habayeb says there is no reason to panic, as India has adequate\nmechanisms for control of disease outbreaks, citing the effective handling\nof the SARS incident.\nIndian researcher Dr Nalini Ramamurthy, director of The King Institute of\nPreventive Medicine, Chennai said their group chanced upon these 3 cases of\nseropositivity in a poultry farm in Kattangalathur, about 45 km south of\nChennai, while routinely monitoring the human population for influenza\nantibodies.\nAll 3 who show positivity have never travelled overseas, nor is any poultry\nimported into India from East Asia regions where epidemics have occurred --\nso a native exposure to the virus is the only alternative, she says.\nDr Ramamurthy believes that the nearby Vedanthangal Bird Sanctuary, which\nis visited by many migratory water birds, could be the source of the\ninfection. But a study urgently needs to be undertaken to see if the\nseroprevalence has spread to other farms or not, says Dr Ramamurthy.\nAccording to the WHO's standard operating procedures, whenever signatures\nof such a highly pathogenic strain are found, intensive studies of both the\nbirds and humans in the area should be undertaken so the source can be\nidentified. Even Katz suggests that continued testing of humans and poultry\nneeds to be undertaken so that we may better understand the risks of human\ninfection with avian influenza viruses.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[H5N1 is a highly pathogenic strain of influenza for poultry. While\nnumerous H5N1 outbreaks have been reported since late 2003 in most (if not\nall) East Asian countries, no single report of an avian flu outbreak from\nneighboring India has been documented since 2001. In the above reports it\nis stated that the samples in question were drawn in 2002 from 3 local\npoultry farm workers and that the seropositive results obtained by the CDC\n(Atlanta) have been available in ICMR since late 2004. Poultry is a major\nstate industry for the area, and migratory birds arrive every year on Tamil\nNadu's coast in Vedanthangal, north of Chennai. Therefore, it is rather\npuzzling that 3 people were infected with the HPAI H5N1 while working in\nthe poultry farm(s), but that no sick or dead birds were ever discovered or\nreported by the local or national health authorities, such as ICMR. Any\nfurther information for clarification of this issue is welcome. - Mod.RY]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (51): Thailand 20050506.1255\nAvian influenza - Eastern Asia (47): FAO 20050414.1075\nAvian influenza - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "influenza a/h5n1", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2005-05-12 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2005-05-11 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2047-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vedanthangal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Kattangalathur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "790", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza A/H5N1, migratory birds - Russia (Siberia)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=790", "date": "2004-04-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE (06)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 April 2004\nFrom: Jim Robertson PhD, John Wood PhD <jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n\n[This thread has been temporarily reconnected to enable Dr Jim Robertson\nand Dr John Wood to make the following statement relating to the\nProMED-mail post \"Avian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05)\n20040403.0917\", which contained an article from the Atlanta\nJournal-Constitution under the heading: \"NIBSC Wins Race to Genetically\nEngineer H5N1 Vaccine Strain.\" - Mod.CP]\nWe would like to point out that the only race in developing an H5N1 avian\ninfluenza vaccine strain was against time and nature and not against our\ncolleagues in the USA at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC) and St Jude Children's Research Hospital. The 3 labs concerned have\nworked together, exchanging information and reagents that have accrued in\nthe process of developing the vaccine strain. As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. There is still no guarantee that the virus developed by NIBSC\nwill be an effective vaccine strain, and the strains developed elsewhere\nwill also be evaluated. Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter. We are pleased to have been\nsuccessful, but find it objectionable and disreputable that some have cast\nthe project as a race against our WHO colleagues.\n--\nJim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\nSouth Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n[This thread now resumes its severed status. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\n....................cp/msp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The 3 labs concerned have\nworked together, exchanging information and reagents that have accrued in\nthe process of developing the vaccine strain. As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. There is still no guarantee that the virus developed by NIBSC\nwill be an effective vaccine strain, and the strains developed elsewhere\nwill also be evaluated. Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter. We are pleased to have been\nsuccessful, but find it objectionable and disreputable that some have cast\nthe project as a race against our WHO colleagues.\n--\nJim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\nSouth Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n[This thread now resumes its severed status. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\n....................cp/msp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The 3 labs concerned have\nworked together, exchanging information and reagents that have accrued in\nthe process of developing the vaccine strain. As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. There is still no guarantee that the virus developed by NIBSC\nwill be an effective vaccine strain, and the strains developed elsewhere\nwill also be evaluated. Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter. We are pleased to have been\nsuccessful, but find it objectionable and disreputable that some have cast\nthe project as a race against our WHO colleagues.\n--\nJim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\nSouth Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n[This thread now resumes its severed status. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\n....................cp/msp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-04-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "721", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza, porcine, H5N1 - China (06): OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=721", "date": "2004-04-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA A (H5N1) VIRUS, HUMAN VACCINE (06)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 April 2004\nFrom: Jim Robertson PhD, John Wood PhD <jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n\n[This thread has been temporarily reconnected to enable Dr Jim Robertson\nand Dr John Wood to make the following statement relating to the\nProMED-mail post \"Avian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05)\n20040403.0917\", which contained an article from the Atlanta\nJournal-Constitution under the heading: \"NIBSC Wins Race to Genetically\nEngineer H5N1 Vaccine Strain.\" - Mod.CP]\nWe would like to point out that the only race in developing an H5N1 avian\ninfluenza vaccine strain was against time and nature and not against our\ncolleagues in the USA at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC) and St Jude Children's Research Hospital. The 3 labs concerned have\nworked together, exchanging information and reagents that have accrued in\nthe process of developing the vaccine strain. As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. There is still no guarantee that the virus developed by NIBSC\nwill be an effective vaccine strain, and the strains developed elsewhere\nwill also be evaluated. Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter. We are pleased to have been\nsuccessful, but find it objectionable and disreputable that some have cast\nthe project as a race against our WHO colleagues.\n--\nJim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\nSouth Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n[This thread now resumes its severed status. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\n....................cp/msp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The 3 labs concerned have\nworked together, exchanging information and reagents that have accrued in\nthe process of developing the vaccine strain. As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. There is still no guarantee that the virus developed by NIBSC\nwill be an effective vaccine strain, and the strains developed elsewhere\nwill also be evaluated. Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter. We are pleased to have been\nsuccessful, but find it objectionable and disreputable that some have cast\nthe project as a race against our WHO colleagues.\n--\nJim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\nSouth Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n[This thread now resumes its severed status. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\n....................cp/msp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The 3 labs concerned have\nworked together, exchanging information and reagents that have accrued in\nthe process of developing the vaccine strain. As occurs with the annual\ndevelopment of vaccine reference strains, the development of a pandemic\nstrain should not be left to a single laboratory, as the success in\ndeveloping a strain that is suitable is subject to many factors, some of\nthem unknown. There is still no guarantee that the virus developed by NIBSC\nwill be an effective vaccine strain, and the strains developed elsewhere\nwill also be evaluated. Since the avian influenza in east Asia presented an\nextremely serious public health issue, speed was of the essence, and so it\nwas for this reason, and this reason alone, that the various labs involved\nhave worked non-stop on this matter. We are pleased to have been\nsuccessful, but find it objectionable and disreputable that some have cast\nthe project as a race against our WHO colleagues.\n--\nJim Robertson, PhD\nJohn Wood, PhD\nDivision of Virology\nNational Institute for Biological Standards and Control (NIBSC)\nSouth Mimms\nPotters Bar\nHertfordshire UK\n<jrobertson@nibsc.ac.uk>\n[This thread now resumes its severed status. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05) 20040403.0917\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04) 20040401.0889\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (03) 20040130.0349\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (02) 20040129.0342\nAvian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine pros... 20040125.0300\n....................cp/msp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-04-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "581", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=581", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. The hospital that\ntreated him said he died of severe pneumonia.\nThe man's 9-year-old son remained hospitalized Thursday with the same\nstrain of the bird flu. It is a different strain of the disease than the\none that infected humans in 1997.\nThe man's family visited relatives in southeastern China's Fujian province\nin late January 2003. One of his daughters, an 8-year-old, contracted\npneumonia and died 28 Jan 2003 in a Fujian hospital. Officials were\ninvestigating what caused her death.\nThe man, his son, wife, father and another daughter were hospitalized in\nHong Kong after their return. The wife and father were released Thursday,\nbut the other daughter, 10, remains in the hospital.\nWong said officials believed the disease did not originate in Hong Kong,\nbut declined to say whether the family might have caught it in mainland China.\nMainland health authorities so far found that none of the family's\nrelatives or medical staff caring for them in Fujian had shown similar\nsymptoms.\nThe latest case coincided with reports that 12 chickens were found dead at\nmarket stalls in a Hong Kong suburb Wednesday -- one of numerous outbreaks\nof bird flu in recent months. It was, however, unclear whether the birds\nwere infected with the same strain as the boy and his father, whose home is\nin a different area.\nThe cases have prompted speculation that the bird flu might have originated\nin mainland China. Hong Kong returned almost 10 000 chickens to the\nmainland in 2001 and 2002 after tests indicated they might have been\nexposed to the virus. A mainland Chinese official recently insisted the flu\nwas endemic to Hong Kong.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This newswire confirms a second case of human illness (and first death)\nassociated with an H5N1 infection. In this article there is the additional\nsuggestion that the geographic area of transmission of this infection may\nhave been Fujian, as the entire family had been in Fujian in the immediate\nperiod preceding onset of illness. While it may be too late to obtain\nspecimens from the family member who died while in Fujian, results of\nspecific avian influenza testing from the area in Fujian where the family\nstayed will be of interest and may possibly shed further light on this. To\ndate there has been confirmation of H5N1 activity among poultry in Hong\nKong but not elsewhere in mainland China. Perhaps this current cluster of\nhuman H5N1 infections with associated mortality will lead to more\nwidespread avian testing/monitoring in mainland provinces. We await\nfurther information on this outbreak as it becomes available. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) 20030219.0428\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20030204.0300\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE (02) 20030126.0236\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE 20030120.0186\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20030107.0054\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20030105.0036\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (14) 20021228.6144\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20020206.3492\nAvian influenza? - China (Hong Kong) 20020203.3475\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (07) 20010710.1332\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n1998\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (30) 19971231.2566\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\n.....................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2021-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-17 00:00:00", "2003-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2003-02-04 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 10:28:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-01-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fujian Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Fujian province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "577", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza A (H5N1) virus, human vaccine (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=577", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. The hospital that\ntreated him said he died of severe pneumonia.\nThe man's 9-year-old son remained hospitalized Thursday with the same\nstrain of the bird flu. It is a different strain of the disease than the\none that infected humans in 1997.\nThe man's family visited relatives in southeastern China's Fujian province\nin late January 2003. One of his daughters, an 8-year-old, contracted\npneumonia and died 28 Jan 2003 in a Fujian hospital. Officials were\ninvestigating what caused her death.\nThe man, his son, wife, father and another daughter were hospitalized in\nHong Kong after their return. The wife and father were released Thursday,\nbut the other daughter, 10, remains in the hospital.\nWong said officials believed the disease did not originate in Hong Kong,\nbut declined to say whether the family might have caught it in mainland China.\nMainland health authorities so far found that none of the family's\nrelatives or medical staff caring for them in Fujian had shown similar\nsymptoms.\nThe latest case coincided with reports that 12 chickens were found dead at\nmarket stalls in a Hong Kong suburb Wednesday -- one of numerous outbreaks\nof bird flu in recent months. It was, however, unclear whether the birds\nwere infected with the same strain as the boy and his father, whose home is\nin a different area.\nThe cases have prompted speculation that the bird flu might have originated\nin mainland China. Hong Kong returned almost 10 000 chickens to the\nmainland in 2001 and 2002 after tests indicated they might have been\nexposed to the virus. A mainland Chinese official recently insisted the flu\nwas endemic to Hong Kong.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This newswire confirms a second case of human illness (and first death)\nassociated with an H5N1 infection. In this article there is the additional\nsuggestion that the geographic area of transmission of this infection may\nhave been Fujian, as the entire family had been in Fujian in the immediate\nperiod preceding onset of illness. While it may be too late to obtain\nspecimens from the family member who died while in Fujian, results of\nspecific avian influenza testing from the area in Fujian where the family\nstayed will be of interest and may possibly shed further light on this. To\ndate there has been confirmation of H5N1 activity among poultry in Hong\nKong but not elsewhere in mainland China. Perhaps this current cluster of\nhuman H5N1 infections with associated mortality will lead to more\nwidespread avian testing/monitoring in mainland provinces. We await\nfurther information on this outbreak as it becomes available. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) 20030219.0428\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20030204.0300\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE (02) 20030126.0236\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE 20030120.0186\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20030107.0054\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20030105.0036\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (14) 20021228.6144\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20020206.3492\nAvian influenza? - China (Hong Kong) 20020203.3475\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (07) 20010710.1332\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n1998\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (30) 19971231.2566\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\n.....................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. East Asia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=507", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. Officials were\ninvestigating what caused her death.\nThe man, his son, wife, father and another daughter were hospitalized in\nHong Kong after their return. CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2021-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-17 00:00:00", "2003-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2003-02-04 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 10:28:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-01-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fujian Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Fujian province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "218", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=218", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. The hospital that\ntreated him said he died of severe pneumonia.\nThe man's 9-year-old son remained hospitalized Thursday with the same\nstrain of the bird flu. It is a different strain of the disease than the\none that infected humans in 1997.\nThe man's family visited relatives in southeastern China's Fujian province\nin late January 2003. One of his daughters, an 8-year-old, contracted\npneumonia and died 28 Jan 2003 in a Fujian hospital. Officials were\ninvestigating what caused her death.\nThe man, his son, wife, father and another daughter were hospitalized in\nHong Kong after their return. The wife and father were released Thursday,\nbut the other daughter, 10, remains in the hospital.\nWong said officials believed the disease did not originate in Hong Kong,\nbut declined to say whether the family might have caught it in mainland China.\nMainland health authorities so far found that none of the family's\nrelatives or medical staff caring for them in Fujian had shown similar\nsymptoms.\nThe latest case coincided with reports that 12 chickens were found dead at\nmarket stalls in a Hong Kong suburb Wednesday -- one of numerous outbreaks\nof bird flu in recent months. It was, however, unclear whether the birds\nwere infected with the same strain as the boy and his father, whose home is\nin a different area.\nThe cases have prompted speculation that the bird flu might have originated\nin mainland China. Hong Kong returned almost 10 000 chickens to the\nmainland in 2001 and 2002 after tests indicated they might have been\nexposed to the virus. A mainland Chinese official recently insisted the flu\nwas endemic to Hong Kong.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This newswire confirms a second case of human illness (and first death)\nassociated with an H5N1 infection. In this article there is the additional\nsuggestion that the geographic area of transmission of this infection may\nhave been Fujian, as the entire family had been in Fujian in the immediate\nperiod preceding onset of illness. While it may be too late to obtain\nspecimens from the family member who died while in Fujian, results of\nspecific avian influenza testing from the area in Fujian where the family\nstayed will be of interest and may possibly shed further light on this. To\ndate there has been confirmation of H5N1 activity among poultry in Hong\nKong but not elsewhere in mainland China. Perhaps this current cluster of\nhuman H5N1 infections with associated mortality will lead to more\nwidespread avian testing/monitoring in mainland provinces. We await\nfurther information on this outbreak as it becomes available. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) 20030219.0428\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20030204.0300\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE (02) 20030126.0236\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE 20030120.0186\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20030107.0054\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20030105.0036\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (14) 20021228.6144\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20020206.3492\nAvian influenza? - China (Hong Kong) 20020203.3475\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (07) 20010710.1332\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n1998\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (30) 19971231.2566\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\n.....................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
