China (Hong Kong) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=217", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. The hospital that\ntreated him said he died of severe pneumonia.\nThe man's 9-year-old son remained hospitalized Thursday with the same\nstrain of the bird flu. It is a different strain of the disease than the\none that infected humans in 1997.\nThe man's family visited relatives in southeastern China's Fujian province\nin late January 2003. One of his daughters, an 8-year-old, contracted\npneumonia and died 28 Jan 2003 in a Fujian hospital. Officials were\ninvestigating what caused her death.\nThe man, his son, wife, father and another daughter were hospitalized in\nHong Kong after their return. The wife and father were released Thursday,\nbut the other daughter, 10, remains in the hospital.\nWong said officials believed the disease did not originate in Hong Kong,\nbut declined to say whether the family might have caught it in mainland China.\nMainland health authorities so far found that none of the family's\nrelatives or medical staff caring for them in Fujian had shown similar\nsymptoms.\nThe latest case coincided with reports that 12 chickens were found dead at\nmarket stalls in a Hong Kong suburb Wednesday -- one of numerous outbreaks\nof bird flu in recent months. It was, however, unclear whether the birds\nwere infected with the same strain as the boy and his father, whose home is\nin a different area.\nThe cases have prompted speculation that the bird flu might have originated\nin mainland China. Hong Kong returned almost 10 000 chickens to the\nmainland in 2001 and 2002 after tests indicated they might have been\nexposed to the virus. A mainland Chinese official recently insisted the flu\nwas endemic to Hong Kong.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This newswire confirms a second case of human illness (and first death)\nassociated with an H5N1 infection. In this article there is the additional\nsuggestion that the geographic area of transmission of this infection may\nhave been Fujian, as the entire family had been in Fujian in the immediate\nperiod preceding onset of illness. While it may be too late to obtain\nspecimens from the family member who died while in Fujian, results of\nspecific avian influenza testing from the area in Fujian where the family\nstayed will be of interest and may possibly shed further light on this. To\ndate there has been confirmation of H5N1 activity among poultry in Hong\nKong but not elsewhere in mainland China. China (Hong Kong) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=216", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2021-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-17 00:00:00", "2003-01-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2003-02-04 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 00:00:00", "2003-02-20 10:28:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-01-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fujian Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Fujian province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "213", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=213", "date": "2003-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "INFLUENZA, H5N1 HUMAN CASE - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO / Communicable Disease Surveillance & Response (CSR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_20/en/>\n\nInfluenza A(H5N1) in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 20 February the Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR confirmed that\na 33-year-old man, who died in hospital in Hong Kong on 17 Feb 2003, had\nbeen infected with a strain of the influenza A(H5N1) virus. ( see previous\nreport ). A nasopharyngeal aspirate taken from the man tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) in the Hong Kong SAR Government Virus Unit.\nThe 33-year-old man is the second confirmed case of influenza A(H5N1) virus\nrelated to this outbreak in Hong Kong SAR. The man is known to have been\nthe father of the 9-year-old boy reported as having tested positive for\ninfluenza A(H5N1) yesterday. Both cases had travelled to Fujian Province\n(China) in January 2003, and 2 other members of the family who accompanied\nthe cases to Fujian in January have also been unwell. The mother of the\nfamily has now made a full recovery; the other affected member of the\nfamily (an 8-year-old girl) died on 4 Feb 2003 in Fujian Province. The\nhealth authorities in Hong Kong SAR are continuing laboratory and\nepidemiological investigations to determine the source of infection of this\noutbreak. Further laboratory tests, including gene sequencing, are being\nconducted. The Department of Health in Hong Kong has reported that no\nunusual increase in influenza activity has been detected over the past few\nweeks.\nThe World Health Organization is in close contact with the health\nauthorities in Beijing, China and in Hong Kong, SAR. The WHO Global\nInfluenza Surveillance Network has been alerted, and additional reagents\nfor laboratory diagnosis are being made available to National Influenza\nCentres and other Members of the Global Influenza Surveillance Network.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AP Online 20 Feb 2003 10:28 EST [edited]\n\nBird Flu Death Confirmed in Hong Kong\n----------------------------------------\nA Hong Kong man who died earlier this week had contracted bird flu, health\nofficials confirmed Thursday, in a case that disturbingly echoes a 1997\noutbreak in which the disease first crossed over into humans and killed 6\npeople.\nWhen bird flu hit Hong Kong's populace more than 5 years ago, officials\nkilled all the territory's 1.4 million chickens in an attempt to wipe out\nthe virus.\nHealth Department spokeswoman Eva Wong said the man, whom she did not\nidentify, had been infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus. The hospital that\ntreated him said he died of severe pneumonia.\nThe man's 9-year-old son remained hospitalized Thursday with the same\nstrain of the bird flu. It is a different strain of the disease than the\none that infected humans in 1997.\nThe man's family visited relatives in southeastern China's Fujian province\nin late January 2003. One of his daughters, an 8-year-old, contracted\npneumonia and died 28 Jan 2003 in a Fujian hospital. Officials were\ninvestigating what caused her death.\nThe man, his son, wife, father and another daughter were hospitalized in\nHong Kong after their return. The wife and father were released Thursday,\nbut the other daughter, 10, remains in the hospital.\nWong said officials believed the disease did not originate in Hong Kong,\nbut declined to say whether the family might have caught it in mainland China.\nMainland health authorities so far found that none of the family's\nrelatives or medical staff caring for them in Fujian had shown similar\nsymptoms.\nThe latest case coincided with reports that 12 chickens were found dead at\nmarket stalls in a Hong Kong suburb Wednesday -- one of numerous outbreaks\nof bird flu in recent months. It was, however, unclear whether the birds\nwere infected with the same strain as the boy and his father, whose home is\nin a different area.\nThe cases have prompted speculation that the bird flu might have originated\nin mainland China. Hong Kong returned almost 10 000 chickens to the\nmainland in 2001 and 2002 after tests indicated they might have been\nexposed to the virus. A mainland Chinese official recently insisted the flu\nwas endemic to Hong Kong.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This newswire confirms a second case of human illness (and first death)\nassociated with an H5N1 infection. In this article there is the additional\nsuggestion that the geographic area of transmission of this infection may\nhave been Fujian, as the entire family had been in Fujian in the immediate\nperiod preceding onset of illness. While it may be too late to obtain\nspecimens from the family member who died while in Fujian, results of\nspecific avian influenza testing from the area in Fujian where the family\nstayed will be of interest and may possibly shed further light on this. To\ndate there has been confirmation of H5N1 activity among poultry in Hong\nKong but not elsewhere in mainland China. Perhaps this current cluster of\nhuman H5N1 infections with associated mortality will lead to more\nwidespread avian testing/monitoring in mainland provinces. We await\nfurther information on this outbreak as it becomes available. - Mod.MPP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong) 20030219.0428\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20030204.0300\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE (02) 20030126.0236\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong): OIE 20030120.0186\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20030107.0054\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20030105.0036\n2002\n----\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (14) 20021228.6144\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20020206.3492\nAvian influenza? - China (Hong Kong) 20020203.3475\nAvian influenza, transmission to humans: genetics 20020106.3179\n2001\n----\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (07) 20010710.1332\nAvian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n1998\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (03) 19980118.0142\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (02) 19980116.0130\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (30) 19971231.2566\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\n.....................mpp/pg/dk\n\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fujian Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Fujian province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "fujian", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "212", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Influenza, H5N1 human case - China (Hong Kong)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=212", "date": "2001-05-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1 - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n2000\n----\nAvian influenza, denied - China 20000608.0923\nAvian influenza - China: RFI 20000605.0907\nAvian influenza virus, H5 - China (Hong Kong): NOT 20001122.2025\n1999\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (Hong Kong) 19990329.0490\n1998\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (31) 19980101.0004\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (38) 19980210.0267\nInfluenza, H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980113.0101\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) 19980110.0081\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (04) 19980115.0113\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China(Hong Kong):serosurve... 19980224.0364\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong): serosurvey 19980131.0199\nInfluenza virus A (H5N1): 2 strains - China (Hong Kong) 19980404.0621\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human, China (Hong Kong) (17) 19971216.2484\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, - China (Hong Kong) (12) 19971209.2452\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\nInfluenza, bird-to-man transmission - China (Hong ... 19971206.2438\nInfluenza, human, avian strain - China (Hong Kong) 19971204.2426\n[1\nDate: Thu 17 May 2001\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhopp@iri.ldgo.columbia.edu>\nSource: WHO Disease Outbreaks Report, Thu 17 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.who.int/disease-outbreak-news/n2001/may/17may2001.html>\n\nIsolation of Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry in Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region of China\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nInfluenza A (H5N1) virus was recently detected in 3 retail live-bird\nmarkets in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, with increased\nmortality in the bird population noted in the last few days. No H5N1\nviruses were isolated in other retail markets. No human cases of H5N1 virus\nhave been detected. The strains isolated from the birds differ genetically\nfrom the H5N1 virus, which caused human disease in 1997. There is no cause\nfor public health concern, but as a precautionary measure, the birds at all\n3 retail markets have been destroyed and the markets cleansed and disinfected.\nThe following is the transcript of the English portion of the opening\nremarks made by Mrs Lily Yam, the Secretary for the Environment and Food,\nHong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, at a press briefing held\non Wed 16 May 2001: Precautionary measures taken to prevent spread of\nchicken disease\n\"I have called this press briefing to announce that at 3.30 this afternoon\nthe Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation has issued a notice\ndeclaring the poultry stalls in 3 markets as infected places in accordance\nwith the Public Health (Animals and Birds) Regulations. The 3 markets are\nYeung Luk Road Market in Sheung Wan, Fa Yuen Street Market, and the\nSmithfield Road Market. The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department has\nalready started action to close these poultry stalls and the department has\nrequested all poultry stall-holders to destroy the live birds in their\nstalls, and these stall-holders will be given every assistance and advice\nby members of the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department. The department\nhas also made appropriate arrangements for the destroyed birds to be sent\nright away to a landfill for proper treatment. After all the birds have\nbeen destroyed, the poultry stalls in the markets will be thoroughly\ncleansed and disinfected. We have taken this precautionary measure for 2\nreasons. The first is that since yesterday, in Yeung Luk Road Market, 763\nchickens have died. There are also a number of chicken deaths in the other\n2 markets. Tests by the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\nhave demonstrated that these chickens have died of avian influenza. I have\nto emphasize that there are many strains of H5N1 and according to the\ninformation currently available, only the H5N1 chicken strain that we had\nin Hong Kong in 1997 would affect human beings, and the vast majority of\nH5N1 strains will not affect human beings. From samples we have recently\ncollected from these 3 markets, a few are shown to contain the H5 virus,\nand genes sequencing tests have demonstrated that these viruses are not - I\nrepeat not - the same as the kind of H5N1 chicken virus that we had in Hong\nKong in 1997. Nonetheless, we feel that it is essential for us to take this\nprecautionary measure because there is a need to destroy these viruses\nthoroughly, to prevent their lingering in the market always with the\nprobability, no matter how low the possibility, that they might - they\nmight - combine with other viruses to result in a new strain which may\naffect human beings. I have to reiterate there is no cause for public\nconcern at this stage. This is a precautionary measure. The indication is\nthat there is no evidence that these viruses would affect human beings. Of\ncourse, the public is reminded to observe the usual hygiene standards. The\nmeasures that we have taken and the tests that we have conducted, and the\nresults, show that in Hong Kong we have one of the best and thorough\nsurveillance systems covering not just imported birds but also the\narrangements in our markets, and the public can rest assured that this\nsurveillance system will enable us to detect any problems as soon as they\narise so that we can take the necessary measures.\"\n******\n[2\nDate: Wed 16 May 2001\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times Times, Wed 16 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/16/world/16CND-HONG.html>\n\nHong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu\n-------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in\n1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4700 chickens after public\nhealth officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu. The officials\nsaid that unlike the previous strain, which killed 6 people, there is no\nevidence that this strain affects human beings. But it has killed 797\nchickens in 3 poultry markets over the last several days, prompting the\ngovernment to take what it called precautionary measures. \"We believe we\nneed to adopt a determined effort to stop the spread of this virus,\" said\nLily Yam, the secretary for environment and food. \"Whether this is a strain\nthat could affect humans, we do not know yet. Nobody can ever be sure of\nanything, particularly where viruses are concerned.\"\nIn late 1997, Hong Kong killed every chicken in the territory about 1.2\nmillion birds in an effort to stamp out a strain of [avian influenza\nvirus. The grisly campaign drew unwelcome attention to Hong Kong 6 months\nafter its return to Chinese sovereignty, but succeeded in containing the\nvirus. Hong Kong has inspected poultry markets since then for signs of a\nrecurrence of the virus, known as H5N1. [The designation H5N1 refers to the\nantigenic type of the (H)aemagglutinin and (N)euraminidase proteins of the\nvirus. - Mod.CP. In April, officials found an H5N1 virus similar to the\ncurrent strain. But until this week, they had not found a strain that\nkilled birds, as the 1997 influenza virus did. \"We have birds dying, which\nmakes this different,\" said Leslie D. Sims, an assistant director of the\nagriculture department. Dr. Sims said the influenza was highly virulent,\nkilling virtually all the infected chickens within days. But he added,\n\"Just because it causes death in birds does not mean it causes death in\nhumans.\"\nOfficials said people could continue to buy and eat chickens from Hong\nKong's poultry stalls, except for the 3 infected markets, which were shut\ndown this afternoon. But they acknowledged there was no guarantee that the\nstrain could not be transmitted to humans by other means. \"Up to the\npresent moment, we have had no human cases,\" said Saw Thian-aun, the deputy\ndirector of health. \"But we recognize there is a possibility it could\naffect humans. We learned a bitter lesson in 1997.\" In that outbreak, the\nfirst known case of avian flu was detected in May 1997 in a young boy, who\nsoon died. But health and agriculture officials did not devise a concerted\nresponse to the virus until December, by which time it had spread to farms\nand markets throughout Hong Kong.\nThe bird flu scared away tourists and devastated poultry farmers. Coming on\nthe heels of Asia's economic collapse, it symbolized Hong Kong's painful\npassage from British colony to Chinese possession. Today's action seemed\ndesigned to eradicate the new strain at a much earlier stage. Within an\nhour of the announcement, health officials fanned out to the 3 markets,\nyanking chickens out of cages and slaughtering them. The carcasses were\nstuffed into plastic bags and dumped in a landfill site. Ms. Yam said the\nmarkets, which are in different parts of Hong Kong, would be closed for 3\nweeks. She said the government had not traced the source of the virus. Hong\nKong imports poultry from neighboring Guangdong Province, but also breeds\nchickens on farms in the New Territories. Ms. Yam said Hong Kong had\nalerted health officials in Guangdong to look for signs of the virus in the\nChinese mainland.\n[Byline: Mark Landler\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................cp/mpp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-05-17 00:00:00", "2001-05-17 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special \n Administrative Region of China", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Poultry", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "194", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, H5N1/97-like viruses - China (Hong Kong) 19980404.0621\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human, China (Hong Kong) (17) 19971216.2484\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, - China (Hong Kong) (12) 19971209.2452\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\nInfluenza, bird-to-man transmission - China (Hong ... 19971206.2438\nInfluenza, human, avian strain - China (Hong Kong) 19971204.2426\n[1\nDate: Thu 17 May 2001\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhopp@iri.ldgo.columbia.edu>\nSource: WHO Disease Outbreaks Report, Thu 17 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.who.int/disease-outbreak-news/n2001/may/17may2001.html>\n\nIsolation of Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry in Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region of China\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nInfluenza A (H5N1) virus was recently detected in 3 retail live-bird\nmarkets in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, with increased\nmortality in the bird population noted in the last few days. No H5N1\nviruses were isolated in other retail markets. No human cases of H5N1 virus\nhave been detected. The strains isolated from the birds differ genetically\nfrom the H5N1 virus, which caused human disease in 1997. There is no cause\nfor public health concern, but as a precautionary measure, the birds at all\n3 retail markets have been destroyed and the markets cleansed and disinfected.\nThe following is the transcript of the English portion of the opening\nremarks made by Mrs Lily Yam, the Secretary for the Environment and Food,\nHong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, at a press briefing held\non Wed 16 May 2001: Precautionary measures taken to prevent spread of\nchicken disease\n\"I have called this press briefing to announce that at 3.30 this afternoon\nthe Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation has issued a notice\ndeclaring the poultry stalls in 3 markets as infected places in accordance\nwith the Public Health (Animals and Birds) Regulations. The 3 markets are\nYeung Luk Road Market in Sheung Wan, Fa Yuen Street Market, and the\nSmithfield Road Market. The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department has\nalready started action to close these poultry stalls and the department has\nrequested all poultry stall-holders to destroy the live birds in their\nstalls, and these stall-holders will be given every assistance and advice\nby members of the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department. The department\nhas also made appropriate arrangements for the destroyed birds to be sent\nright away to a landfill for proper treatment. After all the birds have\nbeen destroyed, the poultry stalls in the markets will be thoroughly\ncleansed and disinfected. We have taken this precautionary measure for 2\nreasons. The first is that since yesterday, in Yeung Luk Road Market, 763\nchickens have died. There are also a number of chicken deaths in the other\n2 markets. Tests by the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\nhave demonstrated that these chickens have died of avian influenza. I have\nto emphasize that there are many strains of H5N1 and according to the\ninformation currently available, only the H5N1 chicken strain that we had\nin Hong Kong in 1997 would affect human beings, and the vast majority of\nH5N1 strains will not affect human beings. From samples we have recently\ncollected from these 3 markets, a few are shown to contain the H5 virus,\nand genes sequencing tests have demonstrated that these viruses are not - I\nrepeat not - the same as the kind of H5N1 chicken virus that we had in Hong\nKong in 1997. Nonetheless, we feel that it is essential for us to take this\nprecautionary measure because there is a need to destroy these viruses\nthoroughly, to prevent their lingering in the market always with the\nprobability, no matter how low the possibility, that they might - they\nmight - combine with other viruses to result in a new strain which may\naffect human beings. I have to reiterate there is no cause for public\nconcern at this stage. This is a precautionary measure. The indication is\nthat there is no evidence that these viruses would affect human beings. Of\ncourse, the public is reminded to observe the usual hygiene standards. The\nmeasures that we have taken and the tests that we have conducted, and the\nresults, show that in Hong Kong we have one of the best and thorough\nsurveillance systems covering not just imported birds but also the\narrangements in our markets, and the public can rest assured that this\nsurveillance system will enable us to detect any problems as soon as they\narise so that we can take the necessary measures.\"\n******\n[2\nDate: Wed 16 May 2001\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times Times, Wed 16 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/16/world/16CND-HONG.html>\n\nHong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu\n-------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in\n1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4700 chickens after public\nhealth officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu. The officials\nsaid that unlike the previous strain, which killed 6 people, there is no\nevidence that this strain affects human beings. But it has killed 797\nchickens in 3 poultry markets over the last several days, prompting the\ngovernment to take what it called precautionary measures. \"We believe we\nneed to adopt a determined effort to stop the spread of this virus,\" said\nLily Yam, the secretary for environment and food. \"Whether this is a strain\nthat could affect humans, we do not know yet. Nobody can ever be sure of\nanything, particularly where viruses are concerned.\"\nIn late 1997, Hong Kong killed every chicken in the territory about 1.2\nmillion birds in an effort to stamp out a strain of [avian influenza\nvirus. The grisly campaign drew unwelcome attention to Hong Kong 6 months\nafter its return to Chinese sovereignty, but succeeded in containing the\nvirus. Hong Kong has inspected poultry markets since then for signs of a\nrecurrence of the virus, known as H5N1. [The designation H5N1 refers to the\nantigenic type of the (H)aemagglutinin and (N)euraminidase proteins of the\nvirus. - Mod.CP. In April, officials found an H5N1 virus similar to the\ncurrent strain. But until this week, they had not found a strain that\nkilled birds, as the 1997 influenza virus did. \"We have birds dying, which\nmakes this different,\" said Leslie D. Sims, an assistant director of the\nagriculture department. Dr. Sims said the influenza was highly virulent,\nkilling virtually all the infected chickens within days. But he added,\n\"Just because it causes death in birds does not mean it causes death in\nhumans.\"\nOfficials said people could continue to buy and eat chickens from Hong\nKong's poultry stalls, except for the 3 infected markets, which were shut\ndown this afternoon. But they acknowledged there was no guarantee that the\nstrain could not be transmitted to humans by other means. \"Up to the\npresent moment, we have had no human cases,\" said Saw Thian-aun, the deputy\ndirector of health. \"But we recognize there is a possibility it could\naffect humans. We learned a bitter lesson in 1997.\" In that outbreak, the\nfirst known case of avian flu was detected in May 1997 in a young boy, who\nsoon died. But health and agriculture officials did not devise a concerted\nresponse to the virus until December, by which time it had spread to farms\nand markets throughout Hong Kong.\nThe bird flu scared away tourists and devastated poultry farmers. Coming on\nthe heels of Asia's economic collapse, it symbolized Hong Kong's painful\npassage from British colony to Chinese possession. Today's action seemed\ndesigned to eradicate the new strain at a much earlier stage. Within an\nhour of the announcement, health officials fanned out to the 3 markets,\nyanking chickens out of cages and slaughtering them. The carcasses were\nstuffed into plastic bags and dumped in a landfill site. Ms. Yam said the\nmarkets, which are in different parts of Hong Kong, would be closed for 3\nweeks. She said the government had not traced the source of the virus. Hong\nKong imports poultry from neighboring Guangdong Province, but also breeds\nchickens on farms in the New Territories. Ms. Yam said Hong Kong had\nalerted health officials in Guangdong to look for signs of the virus in the\nChinese mainland.\n[Byline: Mark Landler\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................cp/mpp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-05-17 00:00:00", "2001-05-17 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special \n Administrative Region of China", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Poultry", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "166", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=166", "date": "2001-05-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1 - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n2000\n----\nAvian influenza, denied - China 20000608.0923\nAvian influenza - China: RFI 20000605.0907\nAvian influenza virus, H5 - China (Hong Kong): NOT 20001122.2025\n1999\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (Hong Kong) 19990329.0490\n1998\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (31) 19980101.0004\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (38) 19980210.0267\nInfluenza, H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980113.0101\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) 19980110.0081\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (04) 19980115.0113\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China(Hong Kong):serosurve... 19980224.0364\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong): serosurvey 19980131.0199\nInfluenza virus A (H5N1): 2 strains - China (Hong Kong) 19980404.0621\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human, China (Hong Kong) (17) 19971216.2484\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, - China (Hong Kong) (12) 19971209.2452\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\nInfluenza, bird-to-man transmission - China (Hong ... 19971206.2438\nInfluenza, human, avian strain - China (Hong Kong) 19971204.2426\n[1\nDate: Thu 17 May 2001\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhopp@iri.ldgo.columbia.edu>\nSource: WHO Disease Outbreaks Report, Thu 17 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.who.int/disease-outbreak-news/n2001/may/17may2001.html>\n\nIsolation of Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry in Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region of China\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nInfluenza A (H5N1) virus was recently detected in 3 retail live-bird\nmarkets in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, with increased\nmortality in the bird population noted in the last few days. No H5N1\nviruses were isolated in other retail markets. No human cases of H5N1 virus\nhave been detected. The strains isolated from the birds differ genetically\nfrom the H5N1 virus, which caused human disease in 1997. There is no cause\nfor public health concern, but as a precautionary measure, the birds at all\n3 retail markets have been destroyed and the markets cleansed and disinfected.\nThe following is the transcript of the English portion of the opening\nremarks made by Mrs Lily Yam, the Secretary for the Environment and Food,\nHong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, at a press briefing held\non Wed 16 May 2001: Precautionary measures taken to prevent spread of\nchicken disease\n\"I have called this press briefing to announce that at 3.30 this afternoon\nthe Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation has issued a notice\ndeclaring the poultry stalls in 3 markets as infected places in accordance\nwith the Public Health (Animals and Birds) Regulations. The 3 markets are\nYeung Luk Road Market in Sheung Wan, Fa Yuen Street Market, and the\nSmithfield Road Market. The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department has\nalready started action to close these poultry stalls and the department has\nrequested all poultry stall-holders to destroy the live birds in their\nstalls, and these stall-holders will be given every assistance and advice\nby members of the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department. The department\nhas also made appropriate arrangements for the destroyed birds to be sent\nright away to a landfill for proper treatment. After all the birds have\nbeen destroyed, the poultry stalls in the markets will be thoroughly\ncleansed and disinfected. We have taken this precautionary measure for 2\nreasons. The first is that since yesterday, in Yeung Luk Road Market, 763\nchickens have died. There are also a number of chicken deaths in the other\n2 markets. Tests by the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\nhave demonstrated that these chickens have died of avian influenza. I have\nto emphasize that there are many strains of H5N1 and according to the\ninformation currently available, only the H5N1 chicken strain that we had\nin Hong Kong in 1997 would affect human beings, and the vast majority of\nH5N1 strains will not affect human beings. From samples we have recently\ncollected from these 3 markets, a few are shown to contain the H5 virus,\nand genes sequencing tests have demonstrated that these viruses are not - I\nrepeat not - the same as the kind of H5N1 chicken virus that we had in Hong\nKong in 1997. Nonetheless, we feel that it is essential for us to take this\nprecautionary measure because there is a need to destroy these viruses\nthoroughly, to prevent their lingering in the market always with the\nprobability, no matter how low the possibility, that they might - they\nmight - combine with other viruses to result in a new strain which may\naffect human beings. I have to reiterate there is no cause for public\nconcern at this stage. This is a precautionary measure. The indication is\nthat there is no evidence that these viruses would affect human beings. Of\ncourse, the public is reminded to observe the usual hygiene standards. The\nmeasures that we have taken and the tests that we have conducted, and the\nresults, show that in Hong Kong we have one of the best and thorough\nsurveillance systems covering not just imported birds but also the\narrangements in our markets, and the public can rest assured that this\nsurveillance system will enable us to detect any problems as soon as they\narise so that we can take the necessary measures.\"\n******\n[2\nDate: Wed 16 May 2001\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times Times, Wed 16 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/16/world/16CND-HONG.html>\n\nHong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu\n-------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in\n1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4700 chickens after public\nhealth officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu. The officials\nsaid that unlike the previous strain, which killed 6 people, there is no\nevidence that this strain affects human beings. But it has killed 797\nchickens in 3 poultry markets over the last several days, prompting the\ngovernment to take what it called precautionary measures. \"We believe we\nneed to adopt a determined effort to stop the spread of this virus,\" said\nLily Yam, the secretary for environment and food. \"Whether this is a strain\nthat could affect humans, we do not know yet. Nobody can ever be sure of\nanything, particularly where viruses are concerned.\"\nIn late 1997, Hong Kong killed every chicken in the territory about 1.2\nmillion birds in an effort to stamp out a strain of [avian influenza\nvirus. The grisly campaign drew unwelcome attention to Hong Kong 6 months\nafter its return to Chinese sovereignty, but succeeded in containing the\nvirus. Hong Kong has inspected poultry markets since then for signs of a\nrecurrence of the virus, known as H5N1. [The designation H5N1 refers to the\nantigenic type of the (H)aemagglutinin and (N)euraminidase proteins of the\nvirus. - Mod.CP. In April, officials found an H5N1 virus similar to the\ncurrent strain. But until this week, they had not found a strain that\nkilled birds, as the 1997 influenza virus did. \"We have birds dying, which\nmakes this different,\" said Leslie D. Sims, an assistant director of the\nagriculture department. Dr. Sims said the influenza was highly virulent,\nkilling virtually all the infected chickens within days. But he added,\n\"Just because it causes death in birds does not mean it causes death in\nhumans.\"\nOfficials said people could continue to buy and eat chickens from Hong\nKong's poultry stalls, except for the 3 infected markets, which were shut\ndown this afternoon. But they acknowledged there was no guarantee that the\nstrain could not be transmitted to humans by other means. \"Up to the\npresent moment, we have had no human cases,\" said Saw Thian-aun, the deputy\ndirector of health. \"But we recognize there is a possibility it could\naffect humans. We learned a bitter lesson in 1997.\" In that outbreak, the\nfirst known case of avian flu was detected in May 1997 in a young boy, who\nsoon died. But health and agriculture officials did not devise a concerted\nresponse to the virus until December, by which time it had spread to farms\nand markets throughout Hong Kong.\nThe bird flu scared away tourists and devastated poultry farmers. Coming on\nthe heels of Asia's economic collapse, it symbolized Hong Kong's painful\npassage from British colony to Chinese possession. Today's action seemed\ndesigned to eradicate the new strain at a much earlier stage. Within an\nhour of the announcement, health officials fanned out to the 3 markets,\nyanking chickens out of cages and slaughtering them. The carcasses were\nstuffed into plastic bags and dumped in a landfill site. Ms. Yam said the\nmarkets, which are in different parts of Hong Kong, would be closed for 3\nweeks. She said the government had not traced the source of the virus. Hong\nKong imports poultry from neighboring Guangdong Province, but also breeds\nchickens on farms in the New Territories. Ms. Yam said Hong Kong had\nalerted health officials in Guangdong to look for signs of the virus in the\nChinese mainland.\n[Byline: Mark Landler\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................cp/mpp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. China (Hong ... 19971206.2438\nInfluenza, human, avian strain - China (Hong Kong) 19971204.2426\n[1\nDate: Thu 17 May 2001\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhopp@iri.ldgo.columbia.edu>\nSource: WHO Disease Outbreaks Report, Thu 17 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.who.int/disease-outbreak-news/n2001/may/17may2001.html>\n\nIsolation of Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry in Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region of China\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nInfluenza A (H5N1) virus was recently detected in 3 retail live-bird\nmarkets in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, with increased\nmortality in the bird population noted in the last few days. No H5N1\nviruses were isolated in other retail markets. No human cases of H5N1 virus\nhave been detected. The strains isolated from the birds differ genetically\nfrom the H5N1 virus, which caused human disease in 1997. There is no cause\nfor public health concern, but as a precautionary measure, the birds at all\n3 retail markets have been destroyed and the markets cleansed and disinfected.\nThe following is the transcript of the English portion of the opening\nremarks made by Mrs Lily Yam, the Secretary for the Environment and Food,\nHong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, at a press briefing held\non Wed 16 May 2001: Precautionary measures taken to prevent spread of\nchicken disease\n\"I have called this press briefing to announce that at 3.30 this afternoon\nthe Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation has issued a notice\ndeclaring the poultry stalls in 3 markets as infected places in accordance\nwith the Public Health (Animals and Birds) Regulations. The 3 markets are\nYeung Luk Road Market in Sheung Wan, Fa Yuen Street Market, and the\nSmithfield Road Market. The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department has\nalready started action to close these poultry stalls and the department has\nrequested all poultry stall-holders to destroy the live birds in their\nstalls, and these stall-holders will be given every assistance and advice\nby members of the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department. The department\nhas also made appropriate arrangements for the destroyed birds to be sent\nright away to a landfill for proper treatment. After all the birds have\nbeen destroyed, the poultry stalls in the markets will be thoroughly\ncleansed and disinfected. We have taken this precautionary measure for 2\nreasons. The first is that since yesterday, in Yeung Luk Road Market, 763\nchickens have died. There are also a number of chicken deaths in the other\n2 markets. Tests by the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\nhave demonstrated that these chickens have died of avian influenza. I have\nto emphasize that there are many strains of H5N1 and according to the\ninformation currently available, only the H5N1 chicken strain that we had\nin Hong Kong in 1997 would affect human beings, and the vast majority of\nH5N1 strains will not affect human beings. From samples we have recently\ncollected from these 3 markets, a few are shown to contain the H5 virus,\nand genes sequencing tests have demonstrated that these viruses are not - I\nrepeat not - the same as the kind of H5N1 chicken virus that we had in Hong\nKong in 1997. Nonetheless, we feel that it is essential for us to take this\nprecautionary measure because there is a need to destroy these viruses\nthoroughly, to prevent their lingering in the market always with the\nprobability, no matter how low the possibility, that they might - they\nmight - combine with other viruses to result in a new strain which may\naffect human beings. I have to reiterate there is no cause for public\nconcern at this stage. This is a precautionary measure. The indication is\nthat there is no evidence that these viruses would affect human beings. Of\ncourse, the public is reminded to observe the usual hygiene standards. The\nmeasures that we have taken and the tests that we have conducted, and the\nresults, show that in Hong Kong we have one of the best and thorough\nsurveillance systems covering not just imported birds but also the\narrangements in our markets, and the public can rest assured that this\nsurveillance system will enable us to detect any problems as soon as they\narise so that we can take the necessary measures.\"\n******\n[2\nDate: Wed 16 May 2001\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times Times, Wed 16 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/16/world/16CND-HONG.html>\n\nHong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu\n-------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in\n1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4700 chickens after public\nhealth officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu. The officials\nsaid that unlike the previous strain, which killed 6 people, there is no\nevidence that this strain affects human beings. But it has killed 797\nchickens in 3 poultry markets over the last several days, prompting the\ngovernment to take what it called precautionary measures. \"We believe we\nneed to adopt a determined effort to stop the spread of this virus,\" said\nLily Yam, the secretary for environment and food. \"Whether this is a strain\nthat could affect humans, we do not know yet. Nobody can ever be sure of\nanything, particularly where viruses are concerned.\"\nIn late 1997, Hong Kong killed every chicken in the territory about 1.2\nmillion birds in an effort to stamp out a strain of [avian influenza\nvirus. The grisly campaign drew unwelcome attention to Hong Kong 6 months\nafter its return to Chinese sovereignty, but succeeded in containing the\nvirus. Hong Kong has inspected poultry markets since then for signs of a\nrecurrence of the virus, known as H5N1. [The designation H5N1 refers to the\nantigenic type of the (H)aemagglutinin and (N)euraminidase proteins of the\nvirus. - Mod.CP. In April, officials found an H5N1 virus similar to the\ncurrent strain. But until this week, they had not found a strain that\nkilled birds, as the 1997 influenza virus did. \"We have birds dying, which\nmakes this different,\" said Leslie D. Sims, an assistant director of the\nagriculture department. Dr. Sims said the influenza was highly virulent,\nkilling virtually all the infected chickens within days. But he added,\n\"Just because it causes death in birds does not mean it causes death in\nhumans.\"\nOfficials said people could continue to buy and eat chickens from Hong\nKong's poultry stalls, except for the 3 infected markets, which were shut\ndown this afternoon. But they acknowledged there was no guarantee that the\nstrain could not be transmitted to humans by other means. \"Up to the\npresent moment, we have had no human cases,\" said Saw Thian-aun, the deputy\ndirector of health. \"But we recognize there is a possibility it could\naffect humans. We learned a bitter lesson in 1997.\" In that outbreak, the\nfirst known case of avian flu was detected in May 1997 in a young boy, who\nsoon died. But health and agriculture officials did not devise a concerted\nresponse to the virus until December, by which time it had spread to farms\nand markets throughout Hong Kong.\nThe bird flu scared away tourists and devastated poultry farmers. Coming on\nthe heels of Asia's economic collapse, it symbolized Hong Kong's painful\npassage from British colony to Chinese possession. Today's action seemed\ndesigned to eradicate the new strain at a much earlier stage. Within an\nhour of the announcement, health officials fanned out to the 3 markets,\nyanking chickens out of cages and slaughtering them. The carcasses were\nstuffed into plastic bags and dumped in a landfill site. Ms. Yam said the\nmarkets, which are in different parts of Hong Kong, would be closed for 3\nweeks. She said the government had not traced the source of the virus. Hong\nKong imports poultry from neighboring Guangdong Province, but also breeds\nchickens on farms in the New Territories. Ms. Yam said Hong Kong had\nalerted health officials in Guangdong to look for signs of the virus in the\nChinese mainland.\n[Byline: Mark Landler\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................cp/mpp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-05-17 00:00:00", "2001-05-17 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "2001-05-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special \n Administrative Region of China", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Poultry", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Hong \n Kong 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "162", "headline": "PRO/AH> Avian influenza, H5N1 - China (Hong Kong) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=162", "date": "2001-05-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1 - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n2000\n----\nAvian influenza, denied - China 20000608.0923\nAvian influenza - China: RFI 20000605.0907\nAvian influenza virus, H5 - China (Hong Kong): NOT 20001122.2025\n1999\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (Hong Kong) 19990329.0490\n1998\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (31) 19980101.0004\nInfluenza, bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong) (38) 19980210.0267\nInfluenza, H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (02) 19980113.0101\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China 19980108.0055\nInfluenza H5N1, avian - China (04) 19980119.0156\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) 19980110.0081\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong) (04) 19980115.0113\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China(Hong Kong):serosurve... 19980224.0364\nInfluenza H5N1, human - China (Hong Kong): serosurvey 19980131.0199\nInfluenza virus A (H5N1): 2 strains - China (Hong Kong) 19980404.0621\n1997\n----\nInfluenza, bird-to-human, China (Hong Kong) (17) 19971216.2484\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, - China (Hong Kong) (12) 19971209.2452\nInfluenza, bird-to-man, first case? 19970820.1747\nInfluenza, bird-to-man transmission - China (Hong ... 19971206.2438\nInfluenza, human, avian strain - China (Hong Kong) 19971204.2426\n[1\nDate: Thu 17 May 2001\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhopp@iri.ldgo.columbia.edu>\nSource: WHO Disease Outbreaks Report, Thu 17 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.who.int/disease-outbreak-news/n2001/may/17may2001.html>\n\nIsolation of Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry in Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region of China\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nInfluenza A (H5N1) virus was recently detected in 3 retail live-bird\nmarkets in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, with increased\nmortality in the bird population noted in the last few days. No H5N1\nviruses were isolated in other retail markets. No human cases of H5N1 virus\nhave been detected. The strains isolated from the birds differ genetically\nfrom the H5N1 virus, which caused human disease in 1997. There is no cause\nfor public health concern, but as a precautionary measure, the birds at all\n3 retail markets have been destroyed and the markets cleansed and disinfected.\nThe following is the transcript of the English portion of the opening\nremarks made by Mrs Lily Yam, the Secretary for the Environment and Food,\nHong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, at a press briefing held\non Wed 16 May 2001: Precautionary measures taken to prevent spread of\nchicken disease\n\"I have called this press briefing to announce that at 3.30 this afternoon\nthe Director of Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation has issued a notice\ndeclaring the poultry stalls in 3 markets as infected places in accordance\nwith the Public Health (Animals and Birds) Regulations. The 3 markets are\nYeung Luk Road Market in Sheung Wan, Fa Yuen Street Market, and the\nSmithfield Road Market. The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department has\nalready started action to close these poultry stalls and the department has\nrequested all poultry stall-holders to destroy the live birds in their\nstalls, and these stall-holders will be given every assistance and advice\nby members of the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department. The department\nhas also made appropriate arrangements for the destroyed birds to be sent\nright away to a landfill for proper treatment. After all the birds have\nbeen destroyed, the poultry stalls in the markets will be thoroughly\ncleansed and disinfected. We have taken this precautionary measure for 2\nreasons. The first is that since yesterday, in Yeung Luk Road Market, 763\nchickens have died. There are also a number of chicken deaths in the other\n2 markets. Tests by the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department\nhave demonstrated that these chickens have died of avian influenza. I have\nto emphasize that there are many strains of H5N1 and according to the\ninformation currently available, only the H5N1 chicken strain that we had\nin Hong Kong in 1997 would affect human beings, and the vast majority of\nH5N1 strains will not affect human beings. From samples we have recently\ncollected from these 3 markets, a few are shown to contain the H5 virus,\nand genes sequencing tests have demonstrated that these viruses are not - I\nrepeat not - the same as the kind of H5N1 chicken virus that we had in Hong\nKong in 1997. Nonetheless, we feel that it is essential for us to take this\nprecautionary measure because there is a need to destroy these viruses\nthoroughly, to prevent their lingering in the market always with the\nprobability, no matter how low the possibility, that they might - they\nmight - combine with other viruses to result in a new strain which may\naffect human beings. I have to reiterate there is no cause for public\nconcern at this stage. This is a precautionary measure. The indication is\nthat there is no evidence that these viruses would affect human beings. Of\ncourse, the public is reminded to observe the usual hygiene standards. The\nmeasures that we have taken and the tests that we have conducted, and the\nresults, show that in Hong Kong we have one of the best and thorough\nsurveillance systems covering not just imported birds but also the\narrangements in our markets, and the public can rest assured that this\nsurveillance system will enable us to detect any problems as soon as they\narise so that we can take the necessary measures.\"\n******\n[2\nDate: Wed 16 May 2001\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times Times, Wed 16 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/16/world/16CND-HONG.html>\n\nHong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu\n-------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in\n1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4700 chickens after public\nhealth officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu. The officials\nsaid that unlike the previous strain, which killed 6 people, there is no\nevidence that this strain affects human beings. But it has killed 797\nchickens in 3 poultry markets over the last several days, prompting the\ngovernment to take what it called precautionary measures. \"We believe we\nneed to adopt a determined effort to stop the spread of this virus,\" said\nLily Yam, the secretary for environment and food. \"Whether this is a strain\nthat could affect humans, we do not know yet. Nobody can ever be sure of\nanything, particularly where viruses are concerned.\"\nIn late 1997, Hong Kong killed every chicken in the territory about 1.2\nmillion birds in an effort to stamp out a strain of [avian influenza\nvirus. The grisly campaign drew unwelcome attention to Hong Kong 6 months\nafter its return to Chinese sovereignty, but succeeded in containing the\nvirus. Hong Kong has inspected poultry markets since then for signs of a\nrecurrence of the virus, known as H5N1. [The designation H5N1 refers to the\nantigenic type of the (H)aemagglutinin and (N)euraminidase proteins of the\nvirus. - Mod.CP. In April, officials found an H5N1 virus similar to the\ncurrent strain. But until this week, they had not found a strain that\nkilled birds, as the 1997 influenza virus did. \"We have birds dying, which\nmakes this different,\" said Leslie D. Sims, an assistant director of the\nagriculture department. Dr. Sims said the influenza was highly virulent,\nkilling virtually all the infected chickens within days. But he added,\n\"Just because it causes death in birds does not mean it causes death in\nhumans.\"\nOfficials said people could continue to buy and eat chickens from Hong\nKong's poultry stalls, except for the 3 infected markets, which were shut\ndown this afternoon. But they acknowledged there was no guarantee that the\nstrain could not be transmitted to humans by other means. \"Up to the\npresent moment, we have had no human cases,\" said Saw Thian-aun, the deputy\ndirector of health. \"But we recognize there is a possibility it could\naffect humans. We learned a bitter lesson in 1997.\" In that outbreak, the\nfirst known case of avian flu was detected in May 1997 in a young boy, who\nsoon died. But health and agriculture officials did not devise a concerted\nresponse to the virus until December, by which time it had spread to farms\nand markets throughout Hong Kong.\nThe bird flu scared away tourists and devastated poultry farmers. Coming on\nthe heels of Asia's economic collapse, it symbolized Hong Kong's painful\npassage from British colony to Chinese possession. Today's action seemed\ndesigned to eradicate the new strain at a much earlier stage. Within an\nhour of the announcement, health officials fanned out to the 3 markets,\nyanking chickens out of cages and slaughtering them. The carcasses were\nstuffed into plastic bags and dumped in a landfill site. Ms. Yam said the\nmarkets, which are in different parts of Hong Kong, would be closed for 3\nweeks. She said the government had not traced the source of the virus. Hong\nKong imports poultry from neighboring Guangdong Province, but also breeds\nchickens on farms in the New Territories. Ms. Yam said Hong Kong had\nalerted health officials in Guangdong to look for signs of the virus in the\nChinese mainland.\n[Byline: Mark Landler\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................cp/mpp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. I have\nto emphasize that there are many strains of H5N1 and according to the\ninformation currently available, only the H5N1 chicken strain that we had\nin Hong Kong in 1997 would affect human beings, and the vast majority of\nH5N1 strains will not affect human beings. I have to reiterate there is no cause for public\nconcern at this stage. This is a precautionary measure. The indication is\nthat there is no evidence that these viruses would affect human beings. Of\ncourse, the public is reminded to observe the usual hygiene standards. The\nmeasures that we have taken and the tests that we have conducted, and the\nresults, show that in Hong Kong we have one of the best and thorough\nsurveillance systems covering not just imported birds but also the\narrangements in our markets, and the public can rest assured that this\nsurveillance system will enable us to detect any problems as soon as they\narise so that we can take the necessary measures.\"\n******\n[2\nDate: Wed 16 May 2001\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times Times, Wed 16 May 2001 [edited\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/16/world/16CND-HONG.html>\n\nHong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu\n-------------------------------------------------------\nHONG KONG: In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in\n1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4700 chickens after public\nhealth officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu. But it has killed 797\nchickens in 3 poultry markets over the last several days, prompting the\ngovernment to take what it called precautionary measures. \"We believe we\nneed to adopt a determined effort to stop the spread of this virus,\" said\nLily Yam, the secretary for environment and food. \"Whether this is a strain\nthat could affect humans, we do not know yet. Nobody can ever be sure of\nanything, particularly where viruses are concerned.\"\nIn late 1997, Hong Kong killed every chicken in the territory about 1.2\nmillion birds in an effort to stamp out a strain of [avian influenza\nvirus. The grisly campaign drew unwelcome attention to Hong Kong 6 months\nafter its return to Chinese sovereignty, but succeeded in containing the\nvirus. Hong Kong has inspected poultry markets since then for signs of a\nrecurrence of the virus, known as H5N1. [The designation H5N1 refers to the\nantigenic type of the (H)aemagglutinin and (N)euraminidase proteins of the\nvirus. - Mod.CP. Coming on\nthe heels of Asia's economic collapse, it symbolized Hong Kong's painful\npassage from British colony to Chinese possession. Today's action seemed\ndesigned to eradicate the new strain at a much earlier stage. She said the government had not traced the source of the virus. Hong\nKong imports poultry from neighboring Guangdong Province, but also breeds\nchickens on farms in the New Territories. Ms. Yam said Hong Kong had\nalerted health officials in Guangdong to look for signs of the virus in the\nChinese mainland.\n[Byline: Mark Landler\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n......................cp/mpp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. China (Hong Kong) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=160", "date": "2001-05-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "AVIAN INFLUENZA, H5N1 - CHINA (HONG KONG) (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nAvian influenza - China (Hong Kong) 20010420.0778\n2000\n----\nAvian influenza, denied - China 20000608.0923\nAvian influenza - China: RFI 20000605.0907\nAvian influenza virus, H5 - China (Hong Kong): NOT 20001122.2025\n1999\n----\nInfluenza H5N1, avian -
